answer: The author concludes the story with this because gardens cannot grow with snow on the ground. So she figures when all the snow is melted she'll try to grow another one. I feel as if she wasn’t happy enough to grow another garden; I think she should be more interested in growing it than disappointed. It seems like she views it as a chore to be done when the weather permits, rather than an activity filled with potential joy and discovery, suggesting a less than enthusiastic approach to the next attempt.

The narrator has that in with Paragraph because it all makes sense and it goes along together. The narrator says that when the geese come out and the hibiscus is budding is because it is once more again springtime. The return of the geese and the hibiscus's budding are clear indicators of the season. It's a time of renewal and rebirth that the narrator associates with the paragraph's coherence. Therefore, the connection between the natural signs of spring and the paragraph's logical flow underscores a sense of harmony and understanding.

The author concludes the story with that passage to show the importance of the inspiration Saeng gets from the hibiscus plant. Saeng, throughout the story was comforted by the hibiscus plant because it reminded her of home and her grandmother's garden. The plant during the winter metaphorically explains Saeng's attitude towards her new country and her driving test; the hibiscus plant in the winter is not as beautiful in the bitter cold, but it adapts and survives, and returns to its beautiful state in the spring. Saeng is bitter about her new country and driving test, but is adapting, and will be inspired by the beautiful state of the hibiscus in the spring to try her test again, hopeful for a different outcome. In conclusion, the author ended the story in that way to stress importance in the relationship between Saeng and the hibiscus plant.

The author ended the story with this paragraph because it shows change. The snow melting represents change from cold to warm, symbolizing the thawing of a previous rigid mindset. The geese returning represents a new life, as in coming back to something semi-new and familiar, yet seen with fresh eyes. Just like the author is going back to drivers ed, ready to approach it with renewed determination. The hibiscus budding represents growth, both literal and figurative. The author will be older and more knowledgeable and more skilled than before, indicating that this return is not a failure but a step in a continued journey of self-improvement and learning, ultimately signifying a positive transformation.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph of, ìWinter Hibiscusî, because it takes us back to things that happened in the story. Saeng failed the test before, a source of disappointment. In the spring the hibiscus will be budding again, a symbol of hope. Saeng realized that many of the things she thought were strange, were almost familiar to her now, a sign of her growing adaptation. The calls of the snow geese were almost familiar to her. The snow melting will tell her that it is now spring, a promise of renewal. Some of the things that might happen as a result of spring coming might be that Saeng will pass the test, finally overcoming this hurdle. Her mother will be proud of her, validating her efforts. Also, Saeng will start to become accustomed to her new country and her new surroundings and stop reminiscing as intensely about her life back in Vietnam, embracing her present and future.

The reason the author concludes the story with this paragraph is because the author wanted to tell about when Saeng will take the test again. The author conveys the passage of time by describing the coming of spring. In spring, the snows have melted, and signs of new life appear with the geese returning and the hibiscus budding. This paragraph provides a vivid image connected to renewal and makes the reader understand the setting of Saeng’s next attempt easier, effectively framing it as a fresh start. This is why the author includes this paragraph in the story, grounding Saeng's future endeavor in the optimistic imagery of spring.

The story ended with the author saying, "when they come back, saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again." The author concludes the story with this paragraph because Saeng is upset about spending @NUM1 on a plant that she had felt was different than the plant at home. She is stating that she is not going to take the test of buying one again until the geese return and the Hibiscus budds, symbolizing a renewed sense of hope and a fresh start after her disappointment. Saeng's vow marks a pause, a period of reflection before she is ready to confront the challenge again, aligning her decision with the natural cycle of rebirth.

I believe that the author concludes the story with this paragraph because the paragraph helps bring the story to a closing. In the paragraph she is basically saying when the geese return and my flower is budding I'll be prepared enough to take the test. She'll be prepared because she'll be adapted enough and she'll have experienced enough just like the plant and the geese. She is comparing her life to the lives of the geese and the life of her flower, suggesting that just as they follow natural cycles of growth and return, she too will be ready when the time is right, signifying a hopeful and natural conclusion to her journey.

The author would conclude the story with that paragraph because she failed the test before, a stinging memory that fuels her current determination, and she desperately wants to pass it this time to prove something to herself. It makes you wonder if she will pass it or not, leaving the reader in suspense about her future success and the potential consequences of either outcome.

In the story, "Winter Hibiscus," by Minfong Ho, it concludes with a good ending. The girl buys a hibiscus that reminds her of home in Thailand. She goes home and tells her mother she failed her test but bought the plant instead. While she was planting it, she saw geese flying overhead, and she was reminded of the rice paddies back home. America was starting to feel more like home, and she was happier. In the text she says, "many of the things that she had thought of as strange before had become, almost familiar to her now." She is willing to give the test another try and is now confident that she will pass it. America is now starting to feel a little more like home, showing that she is adapting and finding comfort in her new environment.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because the story started out by Saeng failing the test, going out and buying a plant to comfort her and confessing to her mom. The plant related to her by the memories of her homeland, and when she failed that test she felt very depressed and sad. She cried to show her pain and bought a plant to cheer her up, connecting it to happier times. As she told her mom she felt the pain again but, her mother, understanding her distress, made her favorite food and helped her plant the plant. She knew that it wasn’t like the old plant but, it represented the thought and memories, and she knew that she couldn’t just give up, so when the time was right, she was going to try the test again. It relates because it helps the readers understand the story a little better and shows that she wasn’t going to just quit, highlighting her resilience. Her mother was very understanding, providing both emotional support and a tangible symbol of hope and perseverance, and when she goes to retake the test, she will be prepared, not just academically, but also emotionally strengthened by her experience.

I think he concluded the story with that paragraph because he described the cyclical nature of things in the story and then reported it. So, when the geese left, the story suggests they will inevitably return and then leave again, mirroring life's rhythms; that's what I think taking the test again means, a recurring cycle.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because when everything starts coming back, the fragmented memories and lost sensations returning to her, she will finally feel whole enough, present enough, to face the daunting test. That is why the author concludes the story with this paragraph, signaling a hopeful, if uncertain, step forward in her journey.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to show a sense of determination that Saeng posesses. When Saeng comes back and shows her mother the hibiscus plant, she is very upset, with tears in her eyes. Her mother at first is disappointed in her for buying the plant, but is then understanding when she realizes that Saeng was distraught over leaving her old home. The mother offers to help Saeng plant the hibiscus, which comforts Saeng a little bit, helping her gain the determination she needs to recover and adjust to her new surroundings. The story says ìAlmost reluctantly, she realized that many of the things that she had thought of as strange before had become, through the quiet repetition of season upon season, almost familiar to her now.î This quote states that Saeng realizes that things at home, while different, can eventually become comfortable and routine, just like things were in her old country. The author uses the term ìfamiliarî to express that Saeng is starting to accept the fact that some things will be different, but she will eventually get used to it, making her view on life more positive and solidifying her resolve to build a new life.

Why the author concludes the story with this paragraph is because in the paragraph there is a lot said that is the main part of this story. For example all the names and talks about the seasons and their comparisons and differences, and it talks about different buddings, like when you get your mids, your nuggets, and headies of the plant. Because hibiscus is a new form of something nice, the paragraph serves as a comprehensive summary, encapsulating the core themes and elements explored throughout the narrative.

He states this as the conclusion because it shows the faith that she has in the flower and how it will bring her luck for her upcoming test. She feels like the familiar flower is out of place, just as she is in her unfamiliar surroundings, and they can relate to somethings, creating a sense of comfort and shared experience which ultimately reinforces her belief in its lucky properties.

I believe the author concludes the story with Saeng because it shows when she is reminded of home. I believe she thought she could pass the test when the flower was blooming and reminded her of home. For example, Saeng mumbled, ìNot like the kind we had before.î This suggests to me that she was probably homesick, missing the familiar blooms of her homeland. Then when spring comes and the flower blooms, its unique fragrance and vibrant color could give her the strength and renewed determination to pass the test. This connection to her roots provides her with a sense of comfort and motivation. This is why I believe the author ended with this paragraph, highlighting the importance of home and memory in Saeng's journey.

The author uses it because Saeng got confidence back from planting the hibiscus and everything that happened that year. So now she’s ready, and that’s what the author wanted the reader to figure out, demonstrating Saeng's growth and newfound self-assurance as a direct result of her experiences.

The author concludes the story this way because Saeng failed the test, the hibiscus comforts her, and she feels she is similar to the geese. For example, Saeng says ìI-I failed the test.î She has admitted to failing the test and is upset about it and wants to ìtake that test again." Furthermore, this shows her determination. Saeng says," And that rich sweet scent- that was familiar, too, ìwhile describing the hibiscus. The familiarity of the plant comforts her and will allow her to build up the courage to ìtake the test again.î Ultimately, it gives her hope. Finally, at one point Saeng thinks to herself, "the quiet repetition of season opon season, almost familiar to her now. Like the geese.î Saeng feels similar to the geese in this way and this allows her to decide to take the test ì when the snow melts and the geese return.î The author concludes the story strongly, describing how Saeng failed the test, how the hibiscus comforts her and she feels similar to the geese; these details all contribute to Saeng's renewed resolve to try again.

I think the author ends the story with this paragraph because she will be reminded of her homeland and going home. The reason I say that is because the geese are returning home and she wants to return as well, signaling a longing for familiar surroundings. Also, the hibiscus will be budding in the wild, just like back home, further reinforcing her connection to her roots and desire to return to a place of natural beauty and comfort. These images of returning geese and blossoming hibiscus collectively evoke a sense of nostalgia and anticipation for her own homecoming.

I think that the author concludes the story with this paragraph by teaching Saeng how to be confident and vow silently, In order to teach her more lessons because of the fact she failed the test in the middle of the passage. Saeng tells her mother that when the snow is gone in the spring time she will retake the test that she failed. Her mother was very upset when she found out that Saeng failed the test the first time, but now seems to realize that perseverance and inner resolve are just as important as passing any single examination, highlighting the lesson learned.

They probably ended it like that to build suspense or leave the reader on a good note because someone might think things are going to get better for them in December, and Saeng might get her license in December. They might get more money in December.

In *Winter Hibiscus*, by Minfong Ho, the main character, Saeng, undergoes many obstacles as she tries to adapt to her new country, which is very different from her home. The author chooses to end the story as, "When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again." The author meant to end the story in this fashion to ensure the reader that Saeng has found new hope, which is symbolized by the hibiscus flower. Now, along with budding new hope, the flower also carries a sentimental value, reminding her about her home. Sometimes, the best way to overcome your obstacles is to embrace them, as she did in the greenhouse, tending to the hibiscus, then that leaves room to start anew, allowing her to envision a brighter future and indicating her resilience in facing challenges ahead.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to show that just because you fail once you shouldn't give up. Saeng's initial disappointment is clear, but the story ends on a note of hope. From what was expressed in the paragraph it was implied to me that Saeng will become stronger by spring and be able to pass the test. She now understands what is required of her and has time to prepare, suggesting a renewed commitment. This underscores the larger theme of perseverance and reinforces the idea that setbacks are simply opportunities for growth and that Saeng's journey is far from over, leading to the strong possibility of her success.

The author concludes this story with this paragraph because all things have routines and things they have to do to survive. The geese fly south for the warm months so they don’t die from the cold. The flower that dies in the winter is brought back to life in the spring. This pertains to Saeng because when the geese and the flower come back, she will face her own cycle, taking the test of trying to fit in, in her new country, just as nature adapts and perseveres; that is why the author chose this to end the story.

In the story, "Winter Hibiscus," the author ends with the last specified paragraph, "When they came back...then I will take that test again," because it leaves many un-answered questions the reader might have, drawing attention and potentially enticing them to read her next piece of work. The reader is left pondering the significance of "I failed the test," and wanting to know more about "her gentle grandmother," "Mrs. Lambert," and what constitutes "home" for the narrator. Another reason the author might end the story this way is to have a dramatic effect on the reader. The reader is left to assume and imagine what is to come. Will she pass the test? Will she go home? What will happen to her? All we know is, "when the snow melts, and the geese return and the hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again," suggesting a cyclical return and a renewed attempt. Ultimately, the author likely ended the story with that paragraph for dramatic effect, leaving the reader with lingering questions and a sense of anticipation.

I think that she ended the story like that because it means that she is getting used to all the seasons and their changes. "In the spring when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again." She will wait to take the test once it’s not cold anymore, so she will wait until the geese come again, which will be spring by then, and she will feel ready. I think that she is also trying to say that when the snow melts and the geese are there again she will have prepared for the test and pass it with renewed confidence. This is I think she ended it like this because the seasons and their associated symbols now hold a personal significance to her, representing her own cycle of growth and learning.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it shows how everything is changing and adapting to the change. Saeng decides that with this change, she can also adapt to her new life by going back and passing the driver's test again. The hibiscus, a vibrant reminder of her homeland, also represents how something from her past has come to America and must now survive in a new environment. When it begins to bud, a symbol of resilience and growth, Saeng will feel empowered to start adapting to America by passing her driver's test. It’s all about trying to become accustomed to changes, both internal and external. When Saeng feels bad for failing, that’s why something familiar and comforting from her past, like the hibiscus, is such a source of strength and hope, reminding her of her own potential for growth.

By ending the story with the idea of retaking a test in the spring, the author sets a feeling of starting fresh and perservering. For example, when the author says "when the snow melts and the geese return and the hibiscus is budding," she shows the idea of starting a fresh new life in the spring by returning to their home and the hibiscus is starting fresh by budding again. This is why spring is when Saeng wants to start fresh and retake the test, signifying a new opportunity. The paragraph also shows that Saeng, like the hibiscus, is perservering. The hibiscus is perservering by making it through the winter and blooming again, while Saeng is perservering by retaking the test, demonstrating resilience and determination. The author ends with this paragraph to show that Saeng is not going to give up, emphasizing the theme of hope and continued effort.

The author concluded the story with that specific paragraph because Saeng feels most comfortable taking the test again when what she explained happens. Saeng misses where she came from a lot. She promised herself that she would take the test again when that happens. With Saeng saying that, it makes you wonder why she won't take the test again until the snow melts, the geese return, and the hibiscus is budding. It makes her feel really comfortable when that does happen, bringing her a sense of peace and connection to her roots that she needs to face the challenge.

The concluding paragraph explains her next goal: obtaining her driver's license. She had to take the written test but failed it, much to her disappointment. She then paid over nineteen dollars for the small potted plant at the local nursery. It reminded her of the vibrant greenery that flourished in her old home's garden. She will have confidence in the spring because the plant, despite being uprooted, grew to its new home, suggesting that she too will grow and thrive in her new environment, finding her own roots and sense of belonging.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph because, although she said ìI-I failed the test,î Saeng said, by failing a test doesn’t mean that it’s the end of everything. She will take the test in the spring and she will do her best, so she will likely have more confidence next time she takes the test.

The author concludes the story, ìWinter Hibiscus,î with this paragraph for several relevant reasons. By concluding the story in this way, it shows Saengís growth and more willingness to strive and do her best. When she says she will take the test again, it shows her gain of confidence and her beginning to gain comfort in the place that is not her home country. She is now striving and working toward doing her best to become successful and making the very best of the given situation, indicating a positive shift in her attitude. The author is trying to give more depth and meaning to the study in this way. Saeng went from being nervous and worried when saying, ìI-I failed the test,î to now setting a goal for herself to take it again the time the bud blooms next year. Basically, the author did a full circle by ending the story in this way, moving from speaking of the test to sharing the flower experience with her mother, to stating that she will re-take the test next year, thus emphasizing her resilience and determination.

The author concludes with that paragraph because it shows that despite her sorrow and discomfort, Saeng is able to remain hopeful. In the story, Saeng sees a hibiscus which makes her very homesick for her native country of Vietnam, reminding her of what she left behind. The reader also learns that she failed a test and feels out of place in her new environment, compounding her sense of isolation. However, the hibiscus symbolizes hope and comfort, offering a connection to her past and a promise for her future. The author chooses to conclude with that paragraph because despite Saeng’s hardships, the hibiscus helps her realize that she can overcome her obstacles and be hopeful of the future, suggesting a resilience that allows her to face the challenges ahead.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because when Saeng and her mother go back to their home, the flowers were more beautiful than the flowers where they are living now. She wants to plant flowers that are going to remind her of her home and bring a piece of that beauty with them. In the story, Saeng's mother said that these flowers aren’t as pretty, but it’s strong enough to make it through the cold months here; this winter hibiscus her mother wanted her to know that the only thing that matters is that the plant can last through winter, symbolizing resilience and the ability to adapt to a new environment, which is what they themselves are trying to do.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because the author wanted to show just cause Saeng failed that test don't mean she giving up. She said when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then she will take it again. What the author means is that right now she has failed, but over time she can study and learn more to get ready to retake it. And by the time she ready to take the test the snow with have went away every should be hot out the birds come back and the flower is growing fine. She will take it. And how author ended it lets us know she going to take it but how he use the words let us know that she will not only take it but pass it too, signaling her determination and future success.

The author concludes the story with that because the hibiscus started budding and she’s happy now. So she’s saying after the geese come back and the snow melt, she’s to do it all over again, facing the cycle of seasons and life's challenges with renewed hope each time the hibiscus blooms.

The reason the author of the story “Winter Hibiscus” ends it the way she does is so that we know we can never give up. She fails her driving test the first time, and me being less than a year from taking the test myself, I understand the anxiety. No matter how many times I fail the test, I will never give up. We need to persevere through every problem we go through in life. If we don’t and we just give up, we will never get anything done in life. She vows in the spring, when the hibiscus is budding, she will take the test again. I hope I pass my driving test the first time, just like I did the learner’s permit test. Also, you can’t give up on anything at all, even something small like working; if you stop working, you will lose your job. Never give up, because perseverance, like the promise of spring, ultimately brings new opportunities.

The author added that sentence to the story to show how much Saeng cared about the snow and the plants. She says that she much rather do gardening than school work, preferring the feel of soil to the sight of textbooks. She loves planting new things, nurturing them from tiny seeds to blossoming life. This highlights her deep connection to the natural world, suggesting a passion that transcends academic pursuits.

The reason why the author concludes the story with that paragraph is because it shows that Saeng is starting to expect the new place she is in. Throughout the story it says how she feels out of place just like the "winter hibiscus." Then later in the story she says how, "many of the things that she thought of as strange before had become, through quite repetition of season upon season, almost familiar to her now." That quote means that most things she thought of as strange she is now getting used to slowly, which means she is adapting. So, the reason why she says the last paragraph is to show that when everything changes back to spring, the geese come back, and the hibiscus is budding, "then she will take that test again." Therefore the author puts the conclusion on the story because it shows how she will adapt as well as the hibiscus, highlighting her growing sense of belonging and anticipation for the future.

The writer leaves the reader with a sense of hope for the future by concluding with this paragraph. Even though the narrator buys the plant in sadness, after she fails her driving test and is missing her home, it is still a symbol of hope. She means that when the flower is blooming, her hope will be also and she will try again, maybe this time with success. Right now she might be sad and scared, but she knows that things will work out, and she will be fine. She is finally settling into her new life and says that “many of the things she had thought of as strange before had become almost familiar to her now.” She means that even though she misses her homeland so much, she is slowly getting used to her new home, and her new life. And maybe by the spring she will be happy and comfortable here, comfortable enough to try her driving test again. The hibiscus represents both the longing for the past and the hope for the future.

I think the author concludes the story with this paragraph because it shows that Saeng is most comfortable when she is surrounded by things from her homeland. She thinks she will be ready to take the test when she sees the ducks again, and when the hibiscus begins to bud. The narrator says, "High hedges, tall and high, had surrounded their garden" is evidence that Saeng had hibiscus in Vietnam, and the story of the well reminds her of it, reinforcing the connection to her past. The narrator also says, "Overhead, a flock of geese, their faint looks clear and -yes-familiar to Saeng now," proves that the geese symbolize home also, providing a sense of belonging and familiarity in a new environment, and thus she can reconcile her future and her past.

I believe the author concludes with that quote for an assortment of reasons. One is to show that the character isn’t just going to give up, that her failing isn’t the end for her. This imparts a moral of never giving up. It feels as if the character is referring to the hibiscus sentimentally. “The hibiscus will be budding” which implies that she herself will branch out and learn more. By springtime, she would have learned and experienced enough to try to pass the test again. The hibiscus also reminds her of her home, and looking at it will give her the courage to pull through and face her challenges, like her test. The ending quote wraps up the story, highlighting the character’s will to persevere and always try again.

The author uses this concluding paragraph to draw the whole story together. She speaks of the driving test, geese, and the hibiscus plant – three subjects found in the story. When she says "when the snow melts and the geese return", she is referring to the geese mentioned when she says "She lifted her head and watched as their distinctive V was etched against the evening sky". She went through a change, much like the geese do every winter as they migrate and adapt. She realizes "that many of the things that she had thought of as strange before had become...familiar to her now". We all have to go through changes; Saeng just had a bigger one, adapting to a new culture and finding comfort in her surroundings.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because the author wrote the same thing that it had in the paragraph and he wrote it in his story but added a little more details to it, weaving in complexities and obstacles along the way. He essentially took the essence of that paragraph and fleshed it out, developing the initial idea with richer descriptions and introducing compelling conflicts that tested the characters and advanced the plot, making the final paragraph a satisfying resolution to the expanded narrative.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to show how Saeng is respectful and how her feelings miss her homeland. The first example, when "Saeng vowed silently to herself," shows her respect and longing for her homeland. It suggests she wants to try again, addressing her past failures. The line stating her desire to overcome her past failures reinforces this idea. The final line of the paragraph, "then I will take that test again," emphasizes her desire for another chance, highlighting her resilience and connection to her roots.

The author had concluded this story with this paragraph to make it as if they were on a clean slate, like they had started over, so the past no longer haunts them. Saeng sounds as if she has a bit of relief after she takes her mom the plate, perhaps feeling a sense of duty fulfilled and a step towards reconciliation. I believe that she feels better because at the end of the paragraph she sounds sure of herself, a stark contrast to her earlier uncertainty. She sounds certain, as if she wants to start over, because she says "when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” To me, she sounds like a brand new person, who has forgotten about the past and is ready to face the future with renewed determination.

The author ends the story with this paragraph because the plant is noticed when she is coming home after failing the driving test. So she says when everything is right, meaning when her plant is flourishing, she will take the test again. The driving test is not all that important to her; she isn’t even sure she will pass it though, so she wants to go take it again when the plant she bought is budding and at its best point, symbolizing a time of personal growth and good fortune.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it shows how much Saeng has grown because of this experience, and how determined she is. This last paragraph offers a sudden happy ending to a rather sad story, but gives the reader hope, knowing the main character is confident enough to try again. The whole story was filled with sadness about Saeng’s family having to move to a new country and start all over. However, the one thing that acts as an escape for them is their gardening. In Vietnam, they seemed to have a nice garden and enjoyed working with it very much. Now that they're in their new location, their garden and the plants in it remind them of that homeland, and how their life used to be. Although saddened by not passing her driving test, Saeng finds a plant that makes her happy and seems to rejuvenate her hope of passing the test. The final paragraph seals the deal, as it shows that she is again confident in herself because of the happy memories that she is thinking about, demonstrating her resilience and positive outlook for the future.

The author used the last paragraph because the hibiscus is a symbol for Saeng. It shows that she will be ready when spring comes. When the plant is ready to bud, she will have faith about taking the test, drawing strength from the hibiscus's own growth. She'll probably want to nurture the plant, ensuring it thrives before she takes the test. When the plant buds, symbolizing her own readiness, Saeng won't have to worry about its initial care anymore, freeing her to focus on the test.

I think the author concludes the story with the paragraph because Saeng is saying when the good time comes back around she will try for the test again because she had failed it. For example on page @NUM1 at the top she says "I-I falled the test," showing her disappointment. This reinforces why the author concludes the story in this way, because it emphasizes that passing the test was important to Saeng, and she intends to persevere and try again when the favorable season of Spring returns.

"Winter Hibiscus" is about a girl, Saeng, who moved from Vietnam to the United States. After she fails her driver’s test, she walks home and finds a hibiscus. “She closed her eyes and breathed in, deeply. The familiar fragrance filled her lungs, and Saeng could almost feel the light strands of her grandmother’s long gray hair…” She goes to a flower shop to see if it can be purchased. She pays a lot of money for the plant because it is rare and valuable. It is special to her because she used to have hibiscus plants in Vietnam, reminders of her old home. She brings the plant home and tells her mom that it reminds her of Vietnam. The mom says that it reminds her of Vietnam too, bringing back memories of their life before. The mom is not happy with how much Saeng paid for it, thinking of their current financial situation. She plants it in her garden. When the hibiscus was lowered in the ground, a flock of geese flew by, as if welcoming it to its new home. When the hibiscus returns in the spring, Saeng will take her driver’s test again. In the spring, all the flowers start to bud and bloom, signaling a time of renewal. Everything is new again. Saeng will have a new chance to pass her test, symbolizing a fresh start in a new country.

I think that is included because she is comparing herself to a flower. When she grows again like a flower, she will go prove to the past that test. She’s saying there's always a second chance, and she wants to tell everyone that it’s not too late to fix a miss or a mistake. For an example, "they said there were many things that she had thought of strangely, season upon season," showing her resilience and determination to overcome past challenges and see things differently, ultimately illustrating the enduring hope for a fresh start.

The author concludes the story like that because she wants everybody to know how she feels about the hibiscus. She felt like the hibiscus was a wonderful plant. She described its leaves as "smooth and cool" toward the end of the first page. When she first saw the plant back in Vietnam she thought that is just grew wildly. Then when she saw it in the United States she was surprised that it grew in a pot. For example she described the smell of the hibiscus as a "sweet scent." This is why she concluded the story like this; because of how she felt about the plant, and she clearly wanted to convey her admiration for its beauty and adaptability.

The author concludes the story with that statement because it shows Saeng's passion for gardening. Her willingness to take the test signifies her commitment to nurturing plant life. She's eager to see if her plants can thrive when spring arrives. The anticipation of the hibiscus budding fuels her resolve, and she will attempt to cultivate it, illustrating how anxious Saeng is for gardening and to try and get the hibiscus to grow during the spring, demonstrating her dedication to bringing life to her garden.

The author concludes the story with this to mean that when everything is back to normal and beautiful, that is when Saeng will take the test. She did this to show that Saeng is a spring person and that she likes working in the garden in the spring. Also, it means that Saeng feels that she does better in school during the spring time, suggesting a connection between her academic performance and the revitalizing energy of the season.

Change and disappointment are enough to over-come. Some people have an arid fear of change. For Saeng, the main character from ìwinter Hibiscus,î change comes in the form of a move to @LOCATION1, a place vastly different from her previous home. Everything around her is different and new, presenting unexpected challenges. Coupled with the disappointment of failing her driver's exam, the feeling of living helpless overwhelms her. After buying a winter hibiscus plant, she vows to take the test again when it blooms in the spring. The resiliance of the winter flower and the memories it represents inspire Saeng to try again, showcasing her determination to adapt and thrive despite initial setbacks.

I think the author wanted to express Saeng's emotions when she took a vow, and also to express the author's own feelings about that moment. The statement, in addition to portraying Saeng's commitment and inner state, was also likely intended to pique readers' interest. Primarily, though, it seems its purpose was to aid comprehension of the significance surrounding Saeng's decision and its impact.

For shadowing, future reference, continuous behavior—all are reasons why that is the last paragraph. They foreshadow because she states her future intentions. She is referencing what she plans to do, maintaining a continuous behavior. She says she will do something again next year, indicating sustained action. She says, "when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again." Thus, foreshadowing, future reference, and continuous behavior are strong reasons why her statement is significant, effectively portraying her planned actions for the coming year.

I believe that the author concludes the story like this to show a sense of continuation in life. In the story, Saeng takes a test and fails. She goes out and buys a hibiscus plant for well over what she should have paid for it. Her test is to try to get over the memories of her real home that Saeng now only cries about when she thinks of it. To Saeng, the plant represents memories and a life that she once had, but no longer does, however does want it back. Her vow to herself is that when the geese come flying back over her, a sign of the changing seasons and the cyclical nature of life, she will go back to the greenhouse that reminds her so much of her home and try once again to say “home” without breaking down, and without having something extremely expensive, revealing her hope for healing and a return to a sense of normalcy.

In 'Winter hibiscus' by @CAPS1 Ho, the narrator never clearly indicates what test Saeng has failed. However, through subject matter and word choice it is clear that the test is not only important to Saeng and her mother, but also to her new life in @LOCATION1, America. Throughout the story Saeng's longing for her homeland is overpowering. The flood of memories that came back to her when she purchases the hibiscus, are obviously painful and part of her everyday life. Saeng is working hard to keep her memories of Vietnam alive, while knowing that she must learn to live the @CAPS2 American customs and lifestyle. There are some things she doesn't need to change, like passing the test. Saeng realizes that she can use these memories to keep her spirits alive; she can use them as motivation. This is why the last sentence of the story is so empowering, because she has learned to use the @NUM1 two things together – memory and change, "when this hibiscus is budding I will take that test again," showing her determination to succeed while honoring her past.

The author chose to conclude the story with that paragraph to show that the girl had adapted to her new country. Saeng missed her home deeply. It was hard for her to say her country was home without crying. "It's not like the wind we had at-at-," she'd often lament. She also spent @MONEY1 on a plant because it reminded her of home and provided a sense of comfort. One could infer she adapted because she was familiar with the season change and the comfort it brings, and it states when the geese return she is going to take the test again, demonstrating her resilience and determination to integrate into her new life.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph because it makes Saeng feel more at home. For example it says, "the snow melt, and the geese return and the hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again." I think the author says this because all the things in that sentence remind her of home and offer her a sense of hope. Therefore, when winter is over and these signs of life reappear, she will feel more connected to her roots and better prepared to face the test.

The reason why the author ended with Saeng vowed is because she is very committed. The author concludes the story with in the spring when the snows melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding then I will take that test again, because she is saying there will be a new year. In this story Saeng shows her mother how passionate she is with planting and her passion for plants. The author concludes that in the paragraph. I think he concluded that in these because it shows a lot of confidence about her. The author concludes the story with this paragraph to show that she has not given up on her dreams. The path may be winding and arduous, but she remains committed to pursuing her aspirations, holding onto the hope that one day, she will reach the summit.

Hope, a new beginning, adjustment—all are reasons why the speaker concludes by saying “when they come back, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” That hibiscus flower gives that girl hope because it reminds her of her grandmother and back home, how wonderful things were back there, and by the flower blooming, she realizes it could work out there too. She’ll also have a new beginning in the spring; by spring she should adjust to her surrounding and have new friends, things to do, and new memories to look back on, so looking back about fall won't be as bad. Ultimately, the flower will bring her hope and comfort along with her adjustment, allowing her to face the test again with renewed optimism.

The author is saying that she’s not doing anything until it is a nice day outside. She wants it to be not too cold but not too hot either, so she can come out and play with her children. The author ends the story with this conclusion to show that Saeng is very passionate about connecting her life in the United States, to how life was in Vietnam and bringing them together somehow. In the story, Saeng talks about how she misses home and how she is still trying to adapt to her new life away from the home she knew; when Saeng says that she has failed the test and wants to take it again, she means that she wants to show that she can survive in the United States without disappointing her mother. When Saeng spent $25 on a plant, her mom was in disbelief because Saeng knows how hard it is to survive. When the conclusion says, “I will take the test again,” it shows that Saeng is willing to try to make it in the United States from Vietnam, proving that she can make a better life for herself and her family by working hard, while still keeping traditions in Vietnam alive. Saeng simply wanted to make her new home feel like Vietnam by buying a plant she knew her mother would like, ultimately demonstrating her unwavering commitment to bridging her two worlds.

The author might have concluded this story because it feels like a downfall. Which means he's at the bottom and has to make it to the top. This last paragraph gives emotion to know she can't garden due to winter. In the winter time all of her plants die for the season. I think that the author concludes with that paragraph as his ending because that is what the girl is going to be doing for the following year that is going to pass, and she will still be with her mother helping her out in the garden. The author ends the story with this paragraph to show how Saeng has found hope from the hibiscus plant. Like the plant, Saeng is going to overcome an obstacle. She will try the driving test again, and the plant will overcome the harsh, brutal winter months. The plant will bloom in the spring and show its resilience during adversity. Saeng, too, will overcome the adversity she faced when failing her driving test and realizing how much she missed her homeland. Saeng too, in a sense, will bloom in the spring. The winter, representing her despair and homesickness, will not prevent her from living happily and taking the test over. The hibiscus reminds her of home. The story ends with the paragraph to show how the “Winter Hibiscus” has taught her something about overcoming obstacles, ultimately revealing her own inner strength and determination.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it shows that Saeng is going to accept her new home and recognize the similarities from her old home and hold memories close to help her overcome obstacles that she is facing in life. "I've seen this kind blooming along the lake. It's flowers aren't as pretty, but it's strong enough to make it through the cold months here, this winter hibiscus. That's what matters." This sets similarities from their old home to their new home, demonstrating a connection despite the change in environment. This shows that things do change but they are also the same at their core. This leads to the conclusion because this is where Saeng realizes that she will always have the memories of her old home and will use them to help her overcome the troubles she's going through, finding strength in resilience and adaptation.

The author ends the story the way she did to show how Saeng and the hibiscus plant are alike and how Saeng will overcome her obstacle when the plant overcomes its obstacle. Saeng’s obstacle is adjusting to her new life, and the first step in that is passing her driver’s test. The reader knows she has to pass because Saeng tells her mother, “I-I failed the [first] one.” The hibiscus must make it through the winter; it also has to adjust to new surroundings to survive, just like Saeng. The mother says to Saeng, “...but it's strong enough to make it through the cold months here, this winter hibiscus. That's what matters [now].” So, if the winter hibiscus’ job, or hurdle that it has to jump, is to make it, to stay alive during the winter months, then its job will be done in the spring. The author ends the story with Saeng telling herself, “...in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again” [and pass it]. If Saeng’s obstacle is completing, and passing the driver’s test, and she passes in the spring, right as the hibiscus passes its “test,” the symbolism between the two, showing determined spirits to adapt, will grow deeper because they will adapt and pass their obstacle at the same time. This parallel resolution underscores the theme of resilience and the ability to thrive in new environments.

I think that the story came back to this because that is what the story starts off with. It all started with Saeng going to take a test, specifically her driver's test, but she did not pass it. So when the weather is better, and perhaps she's had more practice, she would have a better time trying to pass that test. The reason why the author concludes the story this way is because she wanted to leave the reader in suspense, wanting more. You can tell because it never really says what the test is, adding to the mystery. She wanted you to try and guess what the test is, and perhaps even ponder its significance. When Saeng walked up to her mother, she had told her that she failed the test, but the nature of that test remains elusive, leaving the reader to contemplate the possible reasons for her failure and ultimately, the story's unanswered questions.

The author ends the story with that paragraph to give us insight into a potential next story. I think there will be another story because there are clues to support my theory. The author ended with this paragraph because it is an example of how everything gets a fresh start in the spring. The author concludes the story with the paragraph because these geese coming back symbolize Saeng’s determination and hope that she needs to pass the driving test. This is a great way to end the story because it is really deep and makes the reader think about the meaning of the scene and how the geese, hibiscus plant, and spring arriving effect the conclusion of the story, leaving them with a sense of optimism for Saeng’s future.

I think the author concludes the story with that paragraph to say that he will wake up in springtime when the snow melts and geese return. The short story, Winter Hibiscus, is about a girl who moved with her mother to America. The story tells about the girl's transition into the different culture. During the story, the author makes references to the daughter having to pass a test. At the end of the story the author wrote “In the spring…then I will take that test again.” In the text, the girl says “it’s-it’s not a real one,” when referring to the winter hibiscus plant she bought. The reader could infer that this quote means that the girl has memories of home, but they are not the real thing. Also the author wrote “…much preferred it to the Big Mac". This quote shows that she misses her own culture & cannot adapt to the American one that she lives in now. In conclusion, the girl's test may be that she needs to be able to handle change & also be able to recall memories of her homeland with happiness instead of sadness.

The author concludes the story with that ending because he wanted to show the reader “if you just try, you might like it,” and that’s why the girl said she would come back next spring when the snows melt so she can take the test again, demonstrating her newfound willingness to persevere despite initial difficulties.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it brings everything together. One way it ties everything together is by revisiting what happened in the beginning and connecting it with why she had bought the flower in the first place. It also connects Saeng's old memories from Vietnam to her new way of life in the United States. The story states "carefully Saeng picked it up and smiled. She closed her eyes and breathed in, deeply. The familiar fragrance filled her lungs." This shows how the flower she found in the flower shop evoked memories from Vietnam, bridging her past and present. This connection between her past and present life is why the author concludes the story with that paragraph, providing a sense of closure and understanding of Saeng's journey.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph because it's telling/showing us that Saeng is going to try to pass the test in the spring. The author mentions "when snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding" to help indicate that it's going to be spring when she tries to take her test again, suggesting a time of renewal and a fresh start for Saeng.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because, after all that has happened, like she failed the test, he wanted the ending to be remembered as a happy thing. He also wanted the end to show how something bad happened, but next, she was going to do it again. The author wanted to show that she wouldn't give up; she goes after what she wants, and he wanted that resilience to be the lasting impression of the story.

The author concludes the story the way that they did to signify that the girl will not give up trying to pass her test and will adapt to her new found home and make it what her home in Vietnam was to her. The Author chose to conclude the story with this paragraph because it is resolutive to the entire reading before it. In the story Saeng (the girl) had been stressed from failing the @CAPS1 test. After Saeng fails her driverís test, she gives up hope for the future. The sight of the hibiscus plant reminds her to never give up, no matter how tough the situation. The author concludes the story the way he/she did because it shows how much the plant truly means. She concludes the story with this paragraph because she wants him to come again @DATE1. She says "when the snow melts." She wants to look at the events again and take care of them, hoping for another visit and a chance to revisit their shared experiences.

In this short story, Saeng vows to take the test again in the spring because she knows that she will be able to pass it once she has accepted living in this new place. The author concludes the story with that paragraph because in the being of the story her family moved to the United States from Vietnam. Saeng was walking home from failing her driver's test. The author concluded the story with the paragraph because it shows that Saeng can overcome obstacles, & the next time she has these reminders she will succeed. In the story, ìWinter Hibiscus,î the author concludes the story with the paragraph for a few reasons. One reason is that she is trying to overcome change and wants to make the situation better. She tries doing that by taking the test again, demonstrating her resilience. The author also concludes with the paragraph because she feels heartbroken that life is not going her way and that she needs to do something about it, highlighting her sense of agency. I think that the author concluded the story with that paragraph because she is going to see if she can adapt to the new country. The author concludes this with the story because the snow is pretty and geese are animals that make it pretty, so they want you to think that our outdoors is the nicest thing around. This imagery of pleasant natural elements likely serves to reinforce a positive perception of the environment being described, leaving the reader with a favorable impression overall.

The author, Minfong Ho, concludes the story "Winter Hibiscus" with that paragraph to show Saeng starting over. The imagery of "spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding" connects to her life, suggesting she is starting fresh in a way. Although she might miss her old life, her grandmother, the well, and the fine-toothed comb, she is making an effort, shown by her decision to "take that test again." By retaking the test, she demonstrates that she is not ready to give in to the feeling of loss and to her grief, signifying her resilience and willingness to embrace her new life despite the challenges.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because he knows all of this stuff going on will probably definitely come back up again. I think that the author made that the concluding sentence because it means that when Saeng is ready then she will take the test again, implying it's a matter of personal readiness rather than inherent ability. I think that she is comparing herself to the snow, the geese, and the hibiscus. I think so because she says that when the snow melts and the geese return and the hibiscus is budding then she will take the test again, using these natural signs as metaphors for her own internal development. So I think that she is saying that she is not ready for the test and when she does get ready, after a period of growth and preparation symbolized by the changing seasons, then that is when she will take it.

The author's conclusion to the story shows how Saeng interpreted the experience of that day. She uses a spring time setting to show when her confidence in herself is reborn. Seeing her hibiscus bud in the spring will give herself a newfound integrity to go try that driving test again, representing a personal resurgence and the courage to face her challenges anew.

Hope, positiveness, helpfulness—all are reasons the author concludes the story with this paragraph. The last paragraph gives the readers a sense that Saeng has hope because she is willing to take the test again, suggesting a belief in a better future. Since she is going to take the test again, it also indicates she wants to help her mother, understanding her mother's aspirations. The last paragraph also gave me the feeling that Saeng has a positive attitude. She bought a flower to replace the dead ones, symbolizing renewal, and she stated that she will re-take the test in the spring, showing resilience. Furthermore, Saeng is helpful to her mother. Saeng finished digging the hole for the new flower for her mother, so her mom could go make dinner, easing her mother's burdens. Saeng also saw the feeling her mom felt when she found out Saeng did not pass the test, motivating her to re-take the test out of consideration. Saeng was feeling just about what any other new kid probably would have felt. She was scared, but through everything Saeng had hope, a positive attitude, and she was helpful, illustrating her admirable character and the uplifting message of the story.

To her the hibiscus was a test. Saeng felt she failed the test of letting go of the past and embracing "now." The hibiscus reminded her of home, so she spent over @MONEY1 on it, knowing she and her mother needed the money for necessities. Essentially, she felt as though she failed a test of prioritizing the present.

I think the author concludes the story with that paragraph because they want you to understand Saeng's strength. One reason I think they also end the story like that because she knows inside that when her plant is strong and not covered in snow that she will be strong, and that's when she wants to take her driving test. For example, when she said, "When the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again," it shows she connects her personal resilience to the hibiscus's growth. That is why the author concludes the story with that paragraph, emphasizing Saeng’s hope and determination are intertwined with the natural world.

In the story “Winter Hibiscus” by Minfong Ho, the main character, Saeng, and her mother moved from their homeland to a new place where everything felt different. She was having a hard time adapting to this new environment, and Saeng even failed an important test, a setback that deeply discouraged her. She tried to reconnect with her memories of home, seeking solace in familiar thoughts and feelings. It was then that she bought the winter hibiscus, hoping its presence would serve as a constant reminder of her roots. However, as she planted the hibiscus, a shift occurred within her. Instead of just longing for the past, she became determined to embrace her present and future. She resolved to retake the test, setting a personal deadline for herself, coinciding with the hibiscus's budding. The author is concluding by conveying hope and determination for Saeng to adapt to her new home, suggesting that even in unfamiliar soil, she can find the strength to bloom.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it adds the uplifting message that Saeng will be able to overcome the obstacles of living in an unfamiliar country. First; the Canada geese represent a piece of her new home because she reasons ìreluctantlyî that they are familiar to her now, This depicts her ability to adapt to her new environment. In addition, she also equates spring to when the hibiscus is budding and the hibiscus is a symbol of herself because both are trying to live in a country that is not their own. Therefore, the hibiscus budding represents her being able to live comfortably in America. Finally, she vows that she will take her drivers test again. Her intial failure to pass the test showed her inability to become a part of America, but if she passes it. Then she will have successfully adapted. Overall, the author of this story concludes with this paragraph because it contains the theme of the passage through an uplifting message of resilience and hope for a brighter future in her new home.

In the story ìWinter Hibiscusî by Minfong ho, the ending includes the hibiscus budding and retaking the test to make a connection between the two. The geese are also included in the end to show the new country she has adapted to because she recognizes when the geese come and go, marking the changing seasons of her new home. The budding of the hibiscus is to her much more than just a flower. It shows the rejuvenation of new life within her, signaling hope and growth, just as flowers tend to bud in the spring. That is also why she chooses to take the test because her ìbuddingî will occur in the spring, and she will have newly born confidence for the upcoming test, reflecting her newfound resilience. That is why the geese, hibiscus, and the test are all included in the end of the story to show the connection between her past home and adaptation to a new lifestyle, symbolizing her journey of embracing change and finding strength in her new environment.

She will try gardening again after the geese and flowers return, hopeful for a fresh start. She wants to have the best garden around, filled with vibrant colors and fragrant herbs. She wants to keep the tradition going, passing down the knowledge and love for gardening to future generations.

I think the author concludes the story with this paragraph because Saeng didn’t think the winter hibiscus was in the ground anymore, and she feared that when she got back, all of her plants would be gone due to the snow. So, she resolved that she would take that test again, meaning she would start back at the first steps of nurturing her plants and flowers, recommitting to their care with renewed determination.

The author concludes, "When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again because Saeng doesn't want to give up yet." In the story Saeng mumbled, "I mean, not like the kind at-at- " She found that she was still too shaky to say the words 'accident' at home. When Saeng puts the hibiscus in the ground she feels more alive and Saeng wants to feel at home in the United States and start anew. Saeng isn't going to give up driving but to try, harder and harder to pass the test, finding a sense of purpose in her persistence.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it’s related to what she thinks. When her smile of welcome warmed, Saeng-ìcheep skipped over, alive. To “you’re back,” she saw cheerfully. ìWhen they came back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.î The story ìwinter hibiscusî ended with this paragraph because it will be a fresh start for Saeng. It will be spring out and the geese will come back to her home where she lives now, which now has the hibiscus to remind her of her old home and its beauty. The paragraph also compares Saeng to the hibiscus, reinforcing the theme of resilience. In the story her mother says, ìIíve seen this kind blooming along the lake. Its flowers arenít as pretty, but it is strong enough to make it through the cold months here, this winter hibiscus. Thatís what matters.î Saeng is the winter hibiscus thatís strong enough to make it through winter, and failing the test wonít matter until spring when she will take it and pass, symbolizing her adaptation and growth. Thatís represented when the hibiscus is in bloom, suggesting renewed hope and determination. I also think the story ended this way because it ties in Saengís feelings throughout the story of her new home and old home, bridging her past and present. Itís also showing her ability to conquer obstacles, mirroring the hibiscus's survival. She is going to forget about failing the driving test and work to pass it in the spring, demonstrating her optimistic outlook and ability to persevere.

I think the author concludes the story with that paragraph because the hibiscus makes them overcome obstacles. She wanted to take the test again so she can prove to her mum that she can pass it. I also think that because the hibiscus gives them strength, she got more confident in herself to pass the test, showing the hibiscus's positive influence on her determination.

The author chose to end the story this way for several reasons. Some of the reasons is that it creates a feeling of hope in the reader, tells us we always have another chance and the importance of persistence. The ending paragraph creates a feeling of hope since it shows how everything will return and others will be another chance. The author chose to put this in the text since it creates a happy note to end on and give the reader happiness of knowing there is hope. Another reason the author chose to end the story with this paragraph is that it tells the reader that you always get another chance no matter what you do. The author wanted to impart this on the reader since it is an important lesson to know, suggesting resilience is key. The ending also tells the reader that persistance is very important in life and almost essential to live. The author shows this by talking about the snow melting, the geese returning and the flower blooming which are things that happen constantly and almost stop because they refuse to give up and die. The author concludes the story with this paragraph because he is saying that Saeng likes to do things in the spring when she sees flowers growing because she feels like she is at home, so she feels more confident about passing the test, finding comfort and assurance in the familiar beauty of the season.

In the story "Winter Hibiscus", the author concluded the story with the quote "when they come back, Saeng's vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again." The author put this paragraph as the concluding thought to stress that Saeng is determined to make a change. She failed the test but wants to take it again, demonstrating her resilience. Her grandmother's resemblance is in the flower so if the flower buds, then her grandmother will be back in a sense, offering a tangible connection to her past. When her grandmother "comes back" then Saeng will feel as if her grandmother is giving her strength and encouragement to try the test again, fueled by memory and love. This cyclical return of nature mirrors Saeng's own renewed commitment.

The author ends with that paragraph to show how Saeng, like the budding Hibiscus, will get a new start in the spring and overcome obstacles. Just as the Hibiscus, though seemingly dormant in winter, holds the promise of vibrant blooms, Saeng, after facing hardships, possesses the inner strength to flourish again. The imagery of the Hibiscus, known for its resilience and beauty, mirrors Saeng's own potential for growth and renewal, suggesting she will find her own vibrant expression despite the challenges she has encountered, demonstrating her capacity to overcome adversity and blossom anew.

The author concludes the story with, "when they came back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and the hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again." Based on my understanding of the story I think the author concludes the story with the paragraph to emphasize what will happen as well as to get the reader to thinking and build the excitement and with questions as well as thoughts in the head after reading the passage. The author chose to end the story with that paragraph for emotional meanings. The last paragraph is saying she will re-take the test when the hibiscus is blooming in the spring. The author ends the story in this way because the plant and leaving of the geese represent change to Saeng. This paragraph shows that the familiarity of the budding plant gives Saeng courage and the ability to overcome her obstacle, the upcoming driving test. The author includes that because it show that she is not given up. Since she is not given up she can have more trys, increasing her chances of eventual success. This persistence highlights her determination.

There are many reasons why the author chose to conclude the story with Saeng vowing to attempt the driver's test again. At first, the story begins with a tone of sadness, setting the fact "as Saeng walks home after failing her driver's test." This quote sets the tone as sadness because she has failed a very important test, and she is walking alone. "She sees a familiar plant" is when the hope comes back into the story. When she brings the plant she purchased to her mother, her mother also seems delighted. "Where did you get it?" her mother asked, and Saeng replied, "I bought it." She bought it for more money than her mother said for all of the seeds in the garden. As time went on, it was clear to her mother that the plant signifies strength and hope to her daughter, and she ended up delighted with the plant as well. The author chose to conclude the story with Saeng vowing to attempt the driver's test again because her mother felt hope from the plant, which made Saeng happy and gave her courage to try the driver's test again.
The author concludes the story with that paragraph because it makes the story longer and it gives it a good ending, providing closure and a sense of resolution for the reader.

the Author concluded the story with this paragraph because the Author was trying to let us know what happened after the story was done, and tried to make it clear. That's why I think that the Author came up with that idea to conclude with that paragraph, to provide a sense of closure.

The author concludes this paragraph because Saeng is going to wait until winter is over so she can have a fresh beginning in the spring. The author of this essay includes those sentences as the conclusion to make it clear that she will realize that they are coming back. The cyclical nature of trends, once seemingly relegated to the past, inevitably re-emerges, often in altered forms, shaped by new contexts and sensibilities. Though initially dismissed as outdated or irrelevant, these resurrected styles gradually gain traction, fueled by nostalgia, innovation, or a simple desire for something different. Recognizing this pattern allows for a more nuanced understanding of cultural evolution. Ultimately, the anticipation builds, a quiet certainty that the echoes of what was will resonate again, and she will realize that they are coming back.

The author concludes the story with the paragraph, ìWhen they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snowÖî to show that Saeng got stronger. Confidence, persistence, memories ñ all things that Saeng has that helps explain why the author concludes this story with this paragraph. Because with the blooming of the hibiscus plant comes new hope. In the story, she sees the hibiscus as representative of her old life, burdened by past events. I think that the author concludes the story with this paragraph because he's trying to prove his point. I think that Saeng was comparing herself to the flower. The reason why the author concludes the story like that is because he or she wants to show Saeng is determined to not fail that drivers test. I think the author concludes the story as he or she did to teach a lesson. No matter what stands in your way or no matter what slows you down never give up. Memories, hard work – All are reasons why the author concludes the story with this: “When They come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, Then I will take the test again.” First, courage, because she failed her test first, so it takes some guts and willpower to go back and even try it again. Also, because when she remembers her grandmother, it upsets her, so that definitely takes courage and the human willpower to do her test a second time. Next, memories. I think she keeps wanting to do this test because she has had so many good memories with her grandmother and doesn’t want to ever forget them; but again, it goes back to the willpower, or the want to, to go back and do the test a second time. Last, all the hard work, because she knows what her grandmother meant to her, and through all the things, or hard work, that her grandmother put out, she saw and wants to honor or appreciate all of the stuff that her grandmother did for her. These are the reasons that I think the author ended with that paragraph rather than some other paragraph, showing Saeng's determination to honor her grandmother's legacy.

The author includes the last paragraph to show that she still has hope. It is the last sentence because the author, Fong Ho, wants to show that when all seems lost and you're at the end of the line, you can always hope for the better; when spring comes, so will a new beginning, not only for Saeng's plant but also for her life in a different country, highlighting the enduring power of optimism even amidst challenging circumstances.

The author of ìWinter Hibiscusî chose to end the story with that paragraph to reenforce the theme of the story and conclude with a hopeful tone. The theme of the story is adjusting to new circumstances and making the best out of each change. "Saeng vowed silently to herself" tells the audience that Saeng is making an effort to fit in and find the good in her new life. The hopeful tone that is created is a way to show that Saeng is willing to accept changes in life and wants to do her best to overcome obstacles. She says, ìI will take that test againî. The test represents the obstacles she will overcome when efforts applied. The hibiscus in the sentence "when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding..." symbolizes starting over. The budding hibiscus is compared to Saeng with a fresh start and determination to achieve her goals of adjusting to a new lifestyle, suggesting resilience and growth. The author chose this paragraph to conclude the selection to highlight the theme and symbolize a new start, leaving the reader with a sense of optimism about Saeng's future.

I think the author concludes the story with that statement because the audience can then compare Saeng and the hibiscus. After reading that statement, I realized Saeng and the hibiscus are alike because they are both going to make it through and come out on top, (Saeng getting her license and the hibiscus blooming), highlighting their resilience. The author might have ended the story with that statement because it shows that Saeng is committed to working toward her goal and won’t give up, mirroring the hibiscus's persistent beauty. Saeng vowed silently to herself, “I will take that test again,” showing her unwavering determination. Finally, I think the author concluded the story with that statement because it gives the audience the satisfaction of knowing what is going to happen to Saeng but leaving a little mystery for the audience to fill in how they want. For example, I know Saeng is going to take the test again and I believe she will pass it, while another person reading it might believe she failed again and had to retake it again, allowing for a personalized interpretation of Saeng's journey and ultimate success.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to let the reader compare the girl to the geese and the hibiscus. The geese leave for the winter and then come back in the spring, however, the geese also show how the girl is going to come back and take the driver's test again in the spring. The hibiscus dies off over the winter and starts budding again in the spring, this shows that winter is its weakness. Like the hibiscus, the girl overcomes her weakness of not being able to drive by remembering her homeland and drawing strength from it. The author puts this paragraph at the end of the story so you can see that the girl, much like the returning geese and the resilient hibiscus, will also find her way back and bloom again.

I think the author concluded the story with that phrase because it shows she will mature. For example she did not pass her test but instead of crying about it she just said I will take it again next year, displaying resilience. In the story she also longed for her homeland, which she truly missed. She coped with this by buying a winter hibiscus to remind her not only of her homeland but also of her grandmother, who nurtured her love for it. Overall the main character showed depth and maturity throughout the piece, suggesting a hopeful path forward despite the difficulties.

The author concludes the story the way that she does because it shows Saeng’s willingness to adapt to her surroundings, just like the hibiscus. Saeng needs to adapt to her new home in Minnesota, and the hibiscus needs to adapt for the upcoming winter. Initially, Saeng was very reluctant to accept her home. She says of the hibiscus, “it’s not like the kind we had before.” But she realized that the hibiscus could be a reminder of home as well as a reminder to change for her new home. She knew that if the hibiscus could survive the winter, she could survive living somewhere new, and it's this shared struggle that ultimately gives her strength.

The author concludes this story with the promise Saeng made to herself to take the test again, come springtime, because Saeng is having trouble adapting to her new home, and she won’t give up on fitting in after only one failure. The hibiscus and other familiar flowers she found comforted her, because they reminded her of home and provided a small piece of familiarity in an unfamiliar place. At springtime when the geese return and the hibiscus starts blooming, Saeng will feel ready again to take the test, the spring represents the chance for another try, and a new beginning for her in this new land.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to show she has hope.
