I think that the author put that sentence in to get a little personal with the character, fostering a sense of connection so you can relate to that person and understand their motivations more deeply. This brief glimpse into their inner world helps bridge the gap between reader and character.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to show the importance of new beginnings and to accentuate the theme in the story. In the story "Winter Hibiscus" the author Minfong Ho concludes the story with that paragraph because it was a way of saying she's going to forget about what happened in the past with her failing her test, accepting it as part of her adjustment to a new culture, and she's going to do better the next time. It's like the author is saying she will be reborn again like the hibiscus, when the spring comes, full of renewed potential. And the hibiscus, blooming unexpectedly in winter, inspired Saeng to do well where she's at and to persevere despite the challenges. It’s kind of like a theme for the story. The hibiscus inspires her to want to do things. I guess it brings memories of her home country and makes her want to try new things. I think the author chose to end the story this way to show that the girl is remembering her past and being at ease. With the flower, she attains a sense of peace, perhaps recalling simpler times or a connection to nature she had forgotten. Ultimately, the flower serves as a symbol of hope and the enduring human capacity to find joy in unexpected places.

She is determined to pass that test and is not going to give up until she passes it. She knew the road ahead would be challenging, filled with late nights studying and countless practice problems. But the feeling of almost succeeding, of understanding the concepts just enough to taste victory, fueled her resolve. The library became her second home, the textbooks her constant companions. Each failed attempt only strengthened her will, reinforcing her belief that with enough effort, she would conquer this obstacle and ultimately achieve her goal.

The reason why I feel the author ended the story with this paragraph is because she is showing how the character has matured and how the character grew in her circumstance, demonstrating resilience. This shows that because you failed once doesn’t mean you’re going to fail again, highlighting a crucial lesson in perseverance. Also, it’s okay to feel out of place; there is always going to be a time in life where a new beginning is going to start, so it is your choice to take that chance or be stuck in your own ways, but the decision is always up to you, ultimately emphasizing the character's agency in shaping their future.

In Minfong Ho's short story "Winter Hibiscus," she ends the story by saying, "when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again. ìI-I failed the testî". As many kids do, Saeng failed her driving test, and she is crucially upset about it. Nobody wants to fail at something, and it is almost a humiliating experience to have failed at a test, knowing that others have already successfully passed. With the quote in the introduction paragraph, it was written as a sign of symbolism. When the geese return back north, it is to show that they are ready to "start over" again or to "try again." When the hibiscus is budding, it is trying to "start life" again. Saeng seeing objects doing things over and over again empowers her to want to succeed and try again, finding strength in nature's cycles. She realizes it is just a part of life and that in order to succeed you have to fail. Minfong concludes with that quote because she understands that no matter what the obstacle, you must press forward and keep trying in order to succeed. She realizes success can only come from hard work and commitment, and that that is what makes a great, strong individual.

The reason why the author concludes the paragraph with that sentence is because he wants to let the reader know that it's not over. He wants the reader to know @ORGANIZATION1 will not forget, suggesting a lingering sense of injustice or a commitment to future action. And also that all this will happen again, implying a cyclical nature to the events described and a warning of impending repetition.

The author concludes the ending as ìI will take that test againî meaning that the things she going through now is going to happen again but next time she will be prepared. Saeng has a very difficult time moving to another country and getting comfortable in the place; the mother supports her as she goes through winter. The hibiscus that she bought is a symbol that represents more than itself; in this text of Winter Hibiscus by Minfong Ho shows this hibiscus that she bought when she was in the worst time. She went through winter with the hibiscus, and at the last paragraph of the story expresses ìwhen the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is buddingî; she is thinking of the future and how she ìSaeng vowed silently to herself in the spring. She canít wait until winter is over and is just waiting for the spring to come, embodying hope and resilience as she looks forward to a new beginning, suggesting she will face future challenges with renewed strength and determination.

The reason why the author concludes the story with this paragraph is to tell us what she does once she gets back in the spring. That means when she gets back, she will then be taking care of the plants and resuming her gardening. When she gets back she wants the snow to melt and everything to awaken with new life. That is what the author is telling me from the story, showing her anticipation for the return of warmer weather and the chance to nurture her garden once again.

I think the author concludes the story with the paragraph to ensure the reader that she will say again. Also, the author concludes the story this way to show the reader that no matter where you go in life it will always be something and or someone there to assure you of everything. The author also wanted the reader to feel a sense of similarity to the character, meaning no matter how out of place you feel, there's always something you can relate to, offering a comforting sense of connection and shared experience. This reinforces the idea that even in unfamiliar situations, common ground can be found, assuring us that we are not alone in our feelings of displacement.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph so that we buy his coming book, or so that we get more excited. The cliffhanger ending and unresolved questions are clearly designed to pique our interest. By leaving key plot threads dangling, the author hopes to entice us to seek answers in the next installment, thus ensuring a readership eager for the continuation of the narrative.

In this story the author decides to end the story with this paragraph, "when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again," because she wants to take the test when everything is pleasant, for example, she wants everything she likes in her environment such as the flowers, the geese and the weather. Another reason why I say the author ends the story with that paragraph is because she wants to be in an environment like the one that she was in her home country, for example, there was no snow; it was like springtime all year round. This hopeful image of the return of spring and familiar comforts motivates her to try again, making it a fitting and conclusive end. This is why I say that the author ended the story with that paragraph.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to show that she is comforted by the memories of her homeland and really appreciates the beauty of tropical plants. She believes that since it is winter and the hibiscus is not budding, that cannot pass the test until it is. The geese flying south for the winter and the hibiscus budding are normal things to Saeng. Saeng still feels homesick because she wants things to be how they were. The plants in the greenhouse, along with the disappointment of failing her driving test, bring her to the emotional state that she was in. In the second to last paragraph, the author talks about the feeling of repetition Saeng has when seeing the v formation. Saeng feels that in the winter she will not have the same comfort feeling as when she can see the hibiscus and the geese flying overhead. The author concluding by saying Saeng will take her driving test when the winter ends is a good closing because it gives you some insight as to what Saeng is going to do, signifying a hope for a fresh start and renewed comfort in familiar signs of home when spring arrives.

I think the author concludes the sentence then they come back, Saeng vowed to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again" is that because it was winter and the school was likely closed. In the story, “Winter Hibiscus,” the author concludes his story with an odd ending. “’when they come back,’ Saeng vowed silently to herself, ‘in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus budding. then I will take that test again.’” I believe that beyond the literal meaning the author is showing how Saeng is adapting to the new country. By failing her driver’s test she also failed in adapting and accepting the new country. This failure represents her struggle to navigate a new culture and its requirements. By vowing to try again it also shows that she is willing to give the country another chance. It signifies a renewed commitment to integration, a willingness to learn and overcome challenges. “She found she was still too shaky to say the words at home…” I believe that this is showing that she still didn’t consider this country her home. She was still stuck on her past, her roots. The hibiscus, a symbol of hope and resilience, blooming in the winter, mirrors Saeng's own potential to flourish in this new land, suggesting that she will eventually embrace her new home and find her place within it.

The author concludes this story in the paragraph to show that Saeng won't stop, just because she failed the first time. The setback with her initial attempt only fuels her determination. It also shows that she is not going to let certain things keep her down, highlighting her resilience and unwavering spirit in the face of obstacles. This ending emphasizes her persistent nature and implies future successes despite current challenges.

The last sentence of a story is usually the most meaningful. I believe the author ended the story this way for many reasons. For example, I think the author did this to leave the reader with a strong sense of determination. The story quotes, ìI will take that test again.î By use of the word will, the author shows the girl's determination. She didnít say she would try to, she said she will, without a doubt implying a firm resolve. I also think the author ended this way to emphasize the theme of new beginnings. The story quotes, ìwhen they come back... in the spring... I will take that test again.î This shows that in spring, the new beginning of life, she will take the test, linking her renewed effort with the season of rebirth and hope. This is why I believe the author ended the story this way, effectively solidifying the themes of perseverance and fresh starts in the reader's mind.

The author of “Winter Hibiscus” made a good choice to conclude the story with “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” This paragraph hints to the reader that Saeng intends to combine her new and old lives. Her old life is represented by the hibiscus; she used to the constants from back home, like the familiar plant. The geese symbolize her new life; they have become “almost familiar to her now,” a part of her present reality. The obstacle she faces is passing the driving test, a symbol of independence and integration into her new environment. The author implies that in the spring, when the old and new parts of Saeng’s life are combined, Saeng will be able to overcome her “obstacle,” and all will be well. With the geese in the ground, symbolizing her settled new life alongside the blooming hibiscus, Saeng’s life will have come full circle, suggesting a harmonious blend of her past and present, ultimately leading to her success.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it's important when she says when the geese return and the hibiscus is budding; these are markers of time and change. In the story ìWinter Hibiscusî by Minfong Ho, I think the author concludes the story with this paragraph because it emphasizes that Saeng is willing to retake the test when it comes back, showcasing her resilience. The last paragraph states ìin the spring, when the snow melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding then I will take that test again.î I believe the author has ended with that paragraph to state the fact when her new home is like her old home maybe she will feel more confident and more in her place, instead of cold winter total opposite of where she use to live. In the story "Winter Hibiscus" by Minfong Ho, the author expresses how Saeng believes in the power of her memories, and only when she changes and adapts to the culture will she have the courage to retake the test she failed. Saeng misses her home and struggles to see similarities between her new and old lives. "She realized that many of the things that she had thought of as strange before had become, through the quiet repetition of season upon season, almost familiar to her now." Saeng, initially resistant to the move, begins to embrace new experiences while cherishing old memories. At first, everything felt foreign, but now she is starting to find comfort in her new surroundings. "She found that she was still too shaky to say the words at home, lest she burst into tears again." The ending paragraph, reflecting Saeng's changing feelings, offers hope for her new life. She gradually gains confidence, knowing that with it, she can retake her test and succeed. The author illustrates the positive potential of change through adaptation. While life may not always be perfect, courage can create a happy home filled with both new and cherished old memories, as Saeng begins to realize in the final paragraph.

In Minfong Ho's "Winter Hibiscus," the author concludes the story in a unique way that demonstrates a will to survive. For example, the author writes and explains how the plants "dok faeng-noi" have adapted to their cold environment, differently from those back home. This demonstrates the idea of survival because the plant migrated to a place that seemed warm but later faced cold conditions; it found ways to change and adapt, driven by the instinct to survive. Specifically, the text notes how the plant learned to bloom even in the harsh winter, a clear example of adaptation. Another example in the text is Saeng telling herself that in the spring she will try and take the test again. This demonstrates the will to survive because when Saeng failed the test, she felt melancholy and failure. The fact that she has the courage to prepare for the test in spring shows how a human being wants to live, and for her to live in a new country, she must adapt by passing that test, ultimately becoming a survivor, determined to build a new life despite the initial setback. Through both the plant's adaptation and Saeng's determination, Ho underscores the profound human and natural drive to persevere and flourish.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to show the story about snows on the roads. He shows people how to watch where they are going, focusing on the treacherous conditions. In the story “Winter Hibiscus,” Saeng vows to herself in the spring, when the snow melts and geese return and the hibiscus is budding, "then I will take the test again." The author concludes with this paragraph because the hibiscus brings her comfort from home and confidence. “Almost familiar to her now,” this quote from the story shows that things are starting to be right and she is starting to feel comforted by making her realize that where she is living now can be similar to where she used to live. Both the mother and the daughter appreciate the flower they found because it is similar to what they had back home. For example, in the story the mother says, “Its flowers aren’t as pretty, but it’s strong enough to make it through the cold months here.” This shows that they appreciate its similarity to the old hibiscus. In conclusion, the author concludes this story with that paragraph because it helps readers to understand the importance of the girl's memory of where she used to live, suggesting that home can be found and rebuilt even in new and unfamiliar places.

The author chose this end to show that Saeng hasn't given up on how she is living yet. Saeng did not dare look her mother in the eye. Instead, she stared at the hibiscus plant and nervously tore off a leaf, shedding it to bits." Saeng just needed hope, and the author chose this to portray to the reader that there is a chance of hope, a chance for a brighter future despite current difficulties.

In "Winter Hibiscus," Minfong Ho ends the story as she does to highlight the complex emotions and shifting perspectives of Saeng, the young protagonist adjusting to a new life in America. The open-ended conclusion, where Saeng contemplates the winter hibiscus, allows readers to ponder the ongoing negotiation of identity and belonging. It is a symbol of resilience and adaptation in an unfamiliar environment. The author leaves us with a sense of hope. The author's ending choices effectively underscore the nuanced process of cultural assimilation and the enduring power of heritage, leaving the reader to contemplate Saeng's journey.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it lets the reader know that there is still a chance for Saeng; she is not giving up on herself or the test. Minfong Ho concluded the story ìWinter Hibiscusî with a strong paragraph to show the passion and will of Saeng in her new home to complete the test. When the closing sentences states that Saeng ìvowedî to pass the test, it shows her determination to fight, showcasing resilience in the face of a challenging new environment. Saengs courage to face her homesickness is the seed of the story, and by ending it with such a bold statement, Minfong Ho blooms this seemingly sad tale into a story of willpower and drive to pass her test. ìWinter Hibiscusî is a passage of heartache, despair, and yerning for a past life. The author concludes the story with this because the season is ending and also the story is ending, mirroring each other in their respective conclusions. Just as the vibrant colors of autumn fade into the starkness of winter, the narrative arc reaches its natural resolution. The falling leaves symbolize not only the end of the growing season but also the culmination of the events and relationships explored within the story. The characters, like the landscape around them, have undergone a transformation, and the ending provides a sense of closure, fittingly aligning with the seasonal shift.

The author concludes the story with this type of paragraph because the author knows it’s bound to happen again. Saeng wants to take the test again when it is beautiful out and the hibiscus is budding. The plant shows the beautiful achievement of passing the test. The author ends with this paragraph because it symbolizes a new beginning. The author concludes the story with this to show that Saeng will be ready to take the test in time, but not before a period of adjustment. She first has to grow and adapt to the new surroundings, embracing her new life. Just like the hibiscus flower, uprooted from the familiar store and now planted outside, must adapt to its new environment to thrive. The geese are adapting to the surroundings by flying south for the winter, instinctively responding to the changing seasons. By ending the story with this paragraph, it shows that Saeng realizes what she needs to do. She needs to stop dwelling on where she used to live and begin her new life in a new country, embracing the challenges and opportunities it presents.

Minfong Ho ended her story "Winter Hibiscus" with an optimistic sentence. She concluded it this way because the main character of the story was beginning to lose hope. Saeng decided to retake the driving test when her hibiscus flower was blooming. This flower reminds her of her past life in Vietnam with her grandmother. "Saeng could almost feel the light strands of her grandmother's long gray hair, freshly washed, as she combed it out with the fine-toothed buffalo-horn comb". She preferred her life in Vietnam than hers in America. She was going to wait until "this hibiscus is budding," so she can feel more comfortable and happy, drawing strength from the familiar comfort the flower provided. The author wanted to end it so Saeng would be happy, suggesting a hopeful future where she finds her place and rediscovers joy.

The author ended the story with that because she is sad and she wants to give hope to the reader that you should never give up on anything, always keep trying. Also it ends on a good note; if it was like "I stayed up in my room crying" that would not be a good ending. This ending gives hope to the reader and it also tells the reader to practice. This is because when spring comes around, the lady is going to practice driving so when she takes the test she won't fail. Also, the girl is getting happier at the end and that makes the reader happy. So in conclusion, that ending for the story was a good choice for many reasons, like making the reader happy, giving the reader courage to never give up, and to practice something if you fail it the first time; it also encourages readers to help their mother when she is planting or digging up plants, ultimately offering a message of perseverance and familial support.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph in order to develop the theme and to project what the main character will do after she plants the hibiscus, I believe that the theme of this story is adjusting to changes in life and the author builds upon this theme in the final paragraph. In the ending paragraph, the author writes, ìwhen they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and the hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.î The author demonstrates how Saeng learns to adjust when things change in her life. In this instance, Saeng fails her driverís test and to deal with this setback, she buys a hibiscus to remind her of her homeland. The hibiscus symbolizes a new start, and Saeng plans to retake the test once the geese return, highlighting her resilience and adaptation to a new environment.
So she did not forget to take the test again, having carefully marked it on her calendar this time.

Saeng did not give up on herself. She said she would take it over again then she might pass it, showing resilience. That's why the author concluded the story that way, highlighting the importance of self-belief and perseverance in the face of setbacks.

The author ended the story with the paragraph of Saeng vowing to retake the test in the spring, because he wanted to show that the geese and the hibiscus plant represent a sort of rebirth or revival to Saeng. In the last paragraph of "Winter Hibiscus" by Minfong Ho, the author concludes by saying "when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again". In Minfong Ho's "Winter Hibiscus," the concluding paragraph, showcasing Saeng's silent vow, emphasizes her unwavering determination. The hibiscus, reminiscent of the plant from "home," represents her comfort and, more importantly, symbolizes her resolve in navigating her new life. The simile, "like the Geese she lifted her head and watched as their distinctive v was etched," illustrates the enduring presence of hope within her. This final paragraph effectively ties together Saeng's newfound hope and beliefs, solidifying her commitment to persevering in her unfamiliar surroundings.

The author concludes the paragraph with a statement that Saeng said, a very good statement. The author ended with this to show that she is motivated and determined to do this. The author concludes ìWinter Hibiscusî with that paragraph to show the narrator realizes that even though sheís in a new country, some things are still the same, so she becomes determined to pass the test. For example, the narrator said, ìshe realized that many of the things that she had thought of as strange before had become, through the quick repetition of season upon season, familiar to her now.î This quote shows that the narrator has realized that even though aspects of how life has changed, some things remain the same. This also shows that some things, like the test, were strange to her, but now that she is familiar with it, she could pass it. The author shows a willingness to try harder in this story. The author concludes the story with this paragraph to show that Saeng now thinks about images associated with memories in her new home, as well as images she remembers from Vietnam. In the story “Winter Hibiscus,” the author ends the story saying “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” The author concludes the story with this paragraph because the paragraph is saying no matter that Saeng failed the driving test the first time, she is not giving up until she passes and gets her license, demonstrating her resilience. In the story ìWinter Hibiscus" the author concludes in a way to relate back to the beginning conflict of the main character, failing her driverís test. In the short story "Winter Hibiscus," by Minfong Ho, a teenage girl fails a driving test but vows to take it again in the spring. The story is ended like this to show that the girl will have a new beginning. For example, "When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again" (Ho). The hibiscus, a cutting from her grandmother's plant in Laos, is what makes her feel as though she is connected to her homeland and provides her with a sense of continuity. So if the hibiscus is budding, a sign of resilience and growth, it is starting a new beginning; she feels that she will be able to do the same. This symbolic connection between the plant's renewal and her own determination is why the story ends like that, emphasizing hope and the promise of a fresh start.

These are a few reasons why the author concluded the story this way. It would be the same if he just ended with what happened so he just added something that made you think a little more than a normal conclusion. The author ended the story with "when they come back, saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and its hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again." because it was different, a distinct departure from the expected narrative closure, leaving a lingering sense of determination and hope in the face of adversity.

Because she is going to practice driving more, focusing on her weaknesses, and get better. The author concludes with that because she means that she will try to go a whole season without thinking about home since she failed it in winter she will try again in spring. The story "Winter Hibiscus" by Ho concludes with, "When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again." The author does this as a symbol of hope for the reader, and to provide a sense of resolution rather than an abrupt ending. Furthermore, when the geese return, signifying warmer weather and the blooming of the hibiscus, Saeng will likely feel more settled, having adjusted to her new life and formed connections with others. The blossoming hibiscus will also evoke cherished memories of her homeland, offering comfort and perhaps boosting her confidence. This connection to her past, coupled with her growing comfort in the present, will help Saeng achieve her goal of passing the test. The author ended the story with that passage also because it piques the reader’s interest, making them want to revisit the story or share it with others. This avoids the dissatisfaction of an unresolved ending by assuring the reader that Saeng intends to persevere and retake the test, giving the story a hopeful and forward-looking conclusion.

The last paragraph of the ìWinter Hibiscusî reads ìwhen they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.î The author ends with this statement to let the reader know that Saeng has hope and will continue to adjust to her new settling in the United States. Throughout the story, Saeng realizes that she is not as distant from her home in Vietnam as she believes. In the florists shops she sees ìplants that she had not even realized she had known but had forgotten drew her back into her childhood worth. ìThe plants she grew up with exist in the United States as well. She fails ìthe testî by buying a winter hibiscus after breaking down crying, homesick. By the end of the story she recognizes that she is becoming more accustomed to her new life, which is ìalmost familiar to her now,î such as the geese flying overhead. The statement of the last paragraph means that by the spring, she hopes to no longer be homesick, and to think of the United States with its geese and winter hibiscuses as her home, showing her growing acceptance and adaptation.

The author ends the story that way to show Saeng's newfound determination. The whole story is about Saeng's journey one afternoon to come to acceptance with her new home, so it seems fitting to conclude with Saeng's determination to pass her driving test and make life work in her new town. The story deals with several things Saeng finds that make her feel at home, like the sharp bitter melon and the hibiscus. These objects lead Saeng to feel more at home and make it fitting to end with Saeng's acceptance that she will stay in her new town. Saeng is also inspired by the hibiscus, which is ìstrong enough to make it through the cold months thatís what matters.î This mirrors Saeng's determination to make it through her new life. And finally, the geese Saeng recognizes make life in her new home becoming ìfamiliarî. These geese lead Saeng to the realization that this is her new home, and she can't go back. The whole story is filled with events like the three above that lead to Saeng's determination, so itís fitting to conclude the story with her determination of it.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it shows that a new beginning is starting. For example, the fact that they moved to a different country signals a significant life change. Also, the snow represents a blanket over the past, covering up hard times and difficult memories. Last but not least, when the hibiscus starts to bud, that also signifies a new beginning and the promise of growth. So if you put it all together, you get the hard times going away when the snow melts, and then a new beginning when spring starts and the flower buds emerge, representing hope for the future. That is why the author put this paragraph in the story: because they needed a fresh start and a chance to build a better life.

In the story, "Winter Hibiscus," by Minfong Ho, a teenage girl, Saeng, and her family, have moved to the United States from Vietnam. Saeng is walking home after failing her driver's test, and she passes a familiar plant. She then goes into a florist shop to purchase the plant. She arrives home and tells her mother she failed the test; of course, her mother is upset, but she makes dinner and plants the "winter hibiscus." At the end of the story, Saeng thinks to herself, "when they come back, in spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again." I think Saeng says she will retake the test in spring because she feels confident and happy now that she is comfortable with the plant she has, and her mother isn't too mad at her. She feels that everything is going to be ok and she can retake the test in spring, when life is blooming, symbolizing a fresh start and renewed hope for success.

That's why the author decided to conclude the story with that line, because she wanted to show Saeng being inspired, and not giving up on her dreams.

The author most likely concludes this story with the quote because she has renewed hope. The author concludes the story with, ìin the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again,î to show Saeng growing up. Since the hibiscus plant is familiar to Saeng, she is better able to relate to it, and as it buds and starts fresh, so will Saeng. I think the author includes this paragraph in the story because it makes sense the geese come back home after the snow melts, a natural cycle suggesting renewal. In the story ìWinter Hibiscusî by Minfong Ho, the author ends the story with ìWhen they come back, in the spring when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again,î to show that Saeng is ready to adapt, but still needs time. Throughout the story, Saeng struggles with overcoming moving from her home, to an unfamiliar place hundreds of miles away. The author concludes the story with ìwhen they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the show melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again." because Saeng failed the test before and now she wants to pass the test. The reason why the author, Minfong Ho, finished the story "Winter Hibiscus" with the last paragraph was due to the girl going out on a test. On this test, which I do not know what the test is, she failed and returns with a saebba hedge. This is a tamed plant for the family, and they love this plant. They are, as I understand from the story, newcomers to a country, and the country is America. They’ve moved here from Vietnam. She goes for her driving test and comes home having failed. One of the things her mother asks is, "Why do you spend so much money on this beautiful plant when you could have had the famed bee-maags," which is the mother’s attempt to say a Big Mac, their favorite fast food sandwich. But the reason the daughter comes back with the plant is she feels she has failed her parents on the driving test. She wants to go back and try again. “Then the snow will melt and geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will return to take the test again.” She believes the next time she goes, she will pass the test and that she will not be ashamed and that she will make her parents proud by passing, as it is a high honor to the family. In Vietnam, not many people drive, and they want their daughter to earn this; it is something they do not have, and she is determined to achieve this goal for herself and her family.

It is clear that Saeng is in the midst of struggle during a time of homesickness after recently moving from Vietnam. But as time goes on she will learn to balance the affection she feels for both her new country and homeland. As Saeng moves through the story it is apparent that she longs for memories of her homeland, but is beginning to find new things to enjoy about her new home. For example, while she is touched by the memories aroused by the hibiscus flower, she is intrigued by the new experiences, such as eating Big Macs and new friends. While homesickness has caused her to struggle she knows that with time she will be able to overcome the obstacle of leaving the old ways, for the new without completely obliterating either. She is convinced that by spring she will be able to overcome this obstacle and have the confidence to pursue any that will arise in her future. Ultimately, Saeng's journey highlights the common experience of immigrants adjusting to a new life, suggesting that while the pull of the past is strong, the promise of the future can be equally compelling.

ìWinter Hibiscusî, by Minfong Ho is a story about transition to @LOCATION1 and her own ability to be strong. Saeng failed her driver's test and was disappointed as she walked home. Winter Hibiscus by @CAPS1 Ho explores one's quest for acceptance and adaptation to changes in life. Saeng is the young protagonist dealing with her recent move to America from her homeland in Asia. After failing a test, Saeng spends a disproportionate amount of money on a flower, a winter hibiscus. When she consults with her mother about the hibiscus, Saeng silently vows something to herself. Saeng vows "when they come back in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again". @CAPS1 Ho chose to end the story this way because the story represents the quest for adaptation. Single-handedly, Saeng was able to say a vow to herself that showed she had accepted her new foreign home of America, even though she will always remember her homeland, highlighting her resilience and willingness to embrace new challenges.

In Winter Hibiscus by Minfong Ho, the last paragraph is a vow by the main character (Saeng) to retake her driver’s test when spring comes and her hibiscus is budding. The story concludes with Saeng's silent vow to retake the test in the spring, when the snow melts, geese return, and the hibiscus buds. In the story “Winter Hibiscus” by Minfong Ho, the author concludes the story with this paragraph because in the springtime everything is reborn and in the springtime Saeng will be used to her surroundings. The author concluded the story with this paragraph, ìWhen they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.î This concludes the story with the paragraph above because it shows Saeng is a caring person to nature. I think the author concludes the story with that paragraph because it helps to explain the significance of the hibiscus. This shows that she has not given up and is going to try hard to adapt and do well in this new land. It leaves a sad story off with a happy ending. The authors conclude the passage with this paragraph to show that after all of that heartache and confusion she knows it will take time to adjust, acknowledging the emotional toll of the experience. The author concludes the story with this paragraph because she wants to make a goal for herself in the future. She wants to pass the test, and she will try hard to do it next year. The author ends the passage with this sentence to show that in order to succeed, one must keep trying. Saeng will retry her driver's test when the plant buds again, starting its life cycle all over again, signifying her renewed determination and hope for a successful future in this new place.

She is saying that she will take the test again after the snow melts in the spring, hoping the warmer weather will bring better luck. This suggests she believes a more pleasant environment will help her focus and succeed.

The author ended this story with this paragraph because that's how Saeng felt now. She felt connected to the geese and the hibiscus. The author concludes with this paragraph to show how the hibiscus flower profoundly implanted Saeng’s life and gave her new found courage and strength. For example, while on her way home after failing her driver’s test, Saeng sees a flower and says, “[I] felt a shock of recognition so intense, it was almost visceral.” This shows the deep connection between Saeng and the hibiscus, and it is this connection that will guide her through the tough times. Saeng subsequently went into a flower shop and identified all the flowers there from her childhood. She realizes that her old home had all these flowers and Saeng used this connection to her past to further increase her courage in adapting into her new life. Another example is when in the text it states, “She realized that many of the things she thought of was strange before had become…almost familiar to her now.” Saeng comes to this realization by listening to her mother talk of how the hibiscus flower which normally survived at her old home would be able to survive here. She understood that she too would be able to do so and not think things like big supermarkets here would be strange anymore. It is in this way that the hibiscus tree offers Saeng support, courage and even strength, acting as a symbol of resilience and adaptation in her journey.

ìWhen they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and his hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again. ì So, it seems that when they return, she intends to retake a test she previously attempted. During their trip, they witnessed a variety of landscapes. The soil, cold and hard, resisted their efforts. She felt as though she'd entered a completely new, hot, moist world teeming with diverse greenery; plants of all shades and shapes grew seemingly without order. Nearby, another familiar sight appeared: a small shrub featuring waxy leaves and delicate flowers with purplish petals and white centers. It was dusk when Saeng arrived home; a strong wind tore the last remnants of green from the chicory weeds sprouting through cracks in the sidewalk. So, they observed many things on their journey and saw things they had never encountered before, such as the weeds growing through the sidewalk, reminding her of both the beauty and harshness of the world.

I think the author includes this to show the determination to pass this test no matter what. The author might conclude the story with this because it shows that the girl had confidence that when the flower blooms she will be able to pass. The author concludes the story with “When they came back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again” because she wanted another chance at the test. The girl says that she is going to take the test again when the Hibiscus blooms, which shows that she misses her country and still wants to be connected somehow. ìthen I will take that test againî. Saengís whole intention in the story was to take the test and pass it. However, she failed the test, which brought the whole story together. The author ended this story with this sentence because it's a good conclusion. It's a good conclusion because it closes by telling what she will do. The author of "Winter Hibiscus" concluded the story with that paragraph because it shows that Saeng is going to give the test another try. In the story, “Winter Hibiscus,” ends by, “when they come back, saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” The author concludes that story with that quote because the author sees spring as a new beginning. The author ends the story with the paragraph and because it is winter time and she can not do anything in the winter because of the snow. The heavy snow made it impossible to travel, so she would have to postpone taking the important test until the spring thaw.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to show that Saeng has overcome an obstacle in her life and that she is learning to move on. In the story Saeng is often stuck on past memories rather than making new ones. For example, when Saeng goes to the florist shop to purchase the plant, she starts remembering old memories from her homeland. When she sees the plant labeled “jasmine,” she thinks of her grandmother that died and remembers how she used to put jasmine blossoms in her hair. Also, she tells her mother that the hibiscus she bought is “not a real one” and she also says it’s “not like the kind we had before.” Indeed, she keeps comparing her new life to her old life in her homeland and she does not allow her new experiences to be as good as her old ones. Indeed, when the author concludes the story with that paragraph, it shows growth in the girl, Saeng, and that she is willing to move on and make new memories, such as trying to pass her driving test again, demonstrating her newfound resolve to embrace the present and future rather than being solely defined by her past.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because the story is coming to an end. The author concluded the story with the paragraph “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” To show that the character has become a part of her new environment. All throughout the story "Winter Hibiscus," the author gives the feeling of hope and comfort that is obtained by Saeng when she thinks about the past. Minfong Ho concluded ìWinter Hibiscusî with that paragraph to show hope and renewal for the character Saeng. Spring represents birth and renewal, a second chance for Saeng. She ends the story with that because the flower gives her strength. It gives her hope and reminds her of home. At her home they were everywhere, a vibrant, comforting presence. I think the author concludes the story with that paragraph because she feels a connection to the geese, and her memories relate to the times she sees them. The author concludes the story, "Winter Hibiscus", with a very spiritual and confident paragraph to show that hope has an important part in our lives. In the story, "Saeng", a foreign chinese citizen, is touched and flattened by all the majestic plants and nature that was living in the green house. She ventures to find all the plants that remind her of home and to relate them to her past experiences. As she walks through the green house, she whispers and pronounces the names of the nature she sees, "Saebba," Saeng whispered, "Madagascar periwinkle," its tag pronounced. "How strange to see it in a pot," Saeng thought. "Back home it just grew wild!" But as her tour grew with time, she soon relizes she is missing some of her memories, and begins to cry. As she reaches home she is greeted by her mother. "I-I failed the test," Saeng said. Saeng's mother is touched by her comment, and cheers her up with planting the "hibiscus". This act of planting symbolizes a fresh start, a chance to nurture something beautiful even after perceived failure. In the end, the author shows strong expression by writting one last paragraph to bring out hope, and emotion, to represent that everyone deserves a second chance, demonstrating the enduring power of resilience and the possibility of growth even in the face of disappointment.

The author of the story ends it with a very interesting paragraph. This paragraph talks about overcoming obstacles and is telling the reader to try again. She was really upset. She saw a group of geese flying above her and said when they come back in the spring and my new plant starts to grow, I will retake my driver's test, finding inspiration in their journey. Her plant has to overcome being small until it can bud in the spring. People face obstacles all the time, just like Saeng's plant and the geese. You have to keep trying in order to get around them and, eventually, thrive.

The short story “Winter Hibiscus” ends the way it does because the narrator realizes that with spring comes a new chance or opportunity to start over, a rebirth. This passage shows that she realized that a lot of things that seemed strange to her before suddenly had purpose. She realized that there is a new rebirth in the spring, a sense of renewal. The concluding sentence states that she is going to retake the test in the spring. She is now realizing that she has a whole new opportunity and life to start. The author concludes the story with this paragraph to show the motivation and confidence Saeng has after her experience with the plant. There are many reasons and examples that support this. This flower motivates her to pursue her license with renewed determination. Another reason is, it shows how confident this experience has made her. For example, after failing, she comes back saying, "... I will take the test again." This statement demonstrates her newfound resolve and belief in her ability to succeed. In conclusion, the author includes this paragraph to show how confident Saeng has become because of her experience, highlighting her growth and positive outlook.

The author concludes that statement at the end of the story because he wants to show that Saeng won't give up, just like the hibiscus. The author ends the story in this way because it represents the new birth that will take place. In the story "Winter Hibiscus," the author, Minfong Ho, concludes the story that paragraph because she wants to show the determination the girl in the story possesses. In the story "Winter Hibiscus," I think that the author concludes the story in "when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again" because she has made Saeng feel that if that hibiscus can restart and make new flowers, Saeng should do the same; the hibiscus, struggling in a new environment like Saeng herself, serves as a potent symbol of resilience and hope, thus inspiring Saeng to persevere and retake the test. Saeng failed her driverís test at the beginning of the story. She finds a hibiscus plant and buys it because it reminds her of her life in Vietnam. The mother says, ìThis kind blooming along the lake, itís flowers arenít as pretty, but itís strong enough to make through the cold months.î Sheís trying to make her daughter feel better about the setback and adapt to her new environment. It states, ìOverhead, a flock of Canada geese flew by their fault honks clear and yes-familiar to Saeng now. She realized that many of the things that she had thought of as strange before had become almost familiar to her now, showing she is slowly adjusting to her new life.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because at the end she realizes that the things that seemed strange before she had just realized as the seasons were changing and the plants were simply reacting to the new environment. So, the author put that paragraph at the end because in the spring she goes back to school to take the test again, now understanding the natural cycles she previously struggled to grasp.

The author concludes the story the way he or she does because it shows that the time she found the plant is when she will get her license, so it is a reminder for her. I also think she did it that way because when the plant blooms it starts over, and so when she sets off to take a chance at the test, she is starting new, embarking on a fresh opportunity, symbolized by the plant's cyclical renewal.

The author ends the story with that paragraph because she wants to show that the peace that the flower gave will build her confidence and she will not give up. I know this because in the story the main character fails her driving test and when she sees the flower, its familiar presence helps remind her of the home she had in Vietnam, a place of comfort and resilience. Another reason is because the flower blooms in spring and, seemingly tireless, it never stops blooming. Seeing its persistent vitality, she knows it will never give up, and she realizes that she shouldn’t either. Plus the plant, a symbol of her heritage, gives her strength to try again. So the reason the author ends her story with that paragraph is to show the power the flower that was known to her gave her and how she will not give up, suggesting a renewed sense of hope and determination rooted in her past.

The author concludes the story with this ending paragraph because it combines the two imperfect situations. The author is saying that she would take the test again in the spring instead of the winter cause she would be more focused, as the immediate pressures of planting wouldn't be looming. She feels that in the winter, her mind would be divided between test preparation and anxieties about the upcoming planting season. But during the spring, she could dedicate her full attention to the task at hand, allowing her to perform better since her focus could be entirely on the test itself. By choosing spring, she aims to eliminate a significant source of distraction, thus maximizing her chances of success.

I think she ended the story with that because throughout the whole story she tries to work hard. And this last sentence is saying that it's not over, that she will be back to take the test again. She tries to prove herself during the whole book, demonstrating resilience. And she will continue working hard to get what she wants, showing her unwavering determination to achieve her goals.

In the story, the author concludes the story the way she did because it is metaphoric; she is comparing herself to the hibiscus plant. Just as a hibiscus would be tested to overcome conditions such as the cold, the author sees a parallel in her own life. For example, in the text the author states, "its flowers aren't as pretty, but it's strong enough to make it through the cold months here. This winter hibiscus." She, like the hibiscus that will bloom again and have to pass the test of surviving the cold, will be able to have a chance to pass her own test, which is why the author concludes the story as she did, emphasizing the resilience and hope for future blossoming, both for herself and the hardy winter hibiscus.

The concluding paragraph in the story ìWinter Hibiscus ìportrays the powerful massage of change from a cold, distant failure to adapt, to a new life. The author concludes with this because it had the most impact, leaving the reader with a powerful image. The ending also gave the most meaning, resonating with themes explored throughout the piece. In the story “Winter Hibiscus” I believe they end the story the way they did, “when they come back, saeng vowed silently to herself, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again” because with Saeng making a goal, she’s overcoming her disappointment and uncomfort living in a new country. In the story, ìWinter Hibiscus,î by Minfong Ho, the authorís final paragraph shows how much the hibiscus means to her. In the story "Winter Hibiscus" by Minfong Ho, the author concludes the story with this paragraph. The author concludes the story with this paragraph to show if they can adapt then she can too. ìIn the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again. ìI choose this saying because it shows you if they are able to come back after everything that has happen she can to. Authors often end stories with paragraphs that make readers wonder what happens next. In "Winter Hibiscus" by Minfong Ho, there is an ending paragraph just like that. The author concludes the story with this paragraph because the author wanted the reader to understand what was going on. The author concludes the story with the paragraph because the geese and the hibiscus were both things that were familiar to Saeng. They remind her of her homeland. The author included that paragraph because the hibiscus plant makes her think of where she is from and helps her to succeed at certain things. The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it might be important to the author about Saeng. It's something personal about her past or where she had come from. The author concludes this story with ìwhen they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, whe the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is building, then I will take the test again". The author concludes the story this way for a few reasons. One reason is that she will have more experience with her new country. In order to get over her failure, Saeng bought a flower that reminded her of home. Saeng started to cry when she bought the flower. She wanted to be back home. I think the author ended this story with this conclusion because everyone should have fresh starts, or second chances. Eventually, she realized it would be bad giving up and not trying again with a fresh start, understanding that failure is a part of learning and growth and that a new attempt offers the opportunity to apply what she learned from the previous experience. Therefore, the ending emphasizes the importance of resilience and the possibility of redemption through renewed effort.

Minfong Ho included the last paragraph in the story because it alluded to the fact that Saeng felt better and more confident when reminded of home. When Saeng saw the hibiscus she got a feeling "so intense, it was almost visceral.” The flower was creatively used by Ho, symbolizing resilience. She said that the winter hibiscus is strong enough to make it through the cold months, which made the reader think after reading the last paragraph, that this flower must give Saeng hope and confidence. Also, the geese make a V which I infer would mean Vietnam to Saeng, which is what the author is trying to get her reader to think. That is why “and the geese return” is mentioned in the last paragraph, suggesting a cyclical return to roots and strength. Minfong Ho wants her readers to realize that objects that make us more comfortable and happy are what make us strong and confident in the end. The author did a great job placing that last thought into the last paragraph because it perfectly sums up the lesson, and that is that you should do things when you feel confident and it feels like home to you. You may be small and fragile, but if you “plant” yourself you can thrive with confidence, drawing strength from familiar comforts and the memories of home.

The last paragraph at the end of the story was the author's way of showing how Saeng wanted spring to come early because she longs to see her hibiscus bloom. The author concludes the story with the sentence "When they come back, saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again" because that winter hibiscus symbolizes a new beginning for her. I think that the author concludes the story with that paragraph because Saeng is saying that she will try again. The author concludes the story with a statement that makes you think because she wants to emphasize the relationship between Saeng and the hibiscus. The author includes this as the last paragraph because it could give Saeng's mother hope. It could give hope because they could really need Saeng to pass the test, perhaps due to the significant opportunities or better future it promises for him and, by extension, for her as well, making his success deeply intertwined with their shared well-being and future prospects.

It was very important that the author concluded the story with that paragraph. It reestablished the meaning of the hibiscus and why it was important to Saeng. It showed the determination she had in overcoming her problems with living in a new place. Without this paragraph we would have been left assuming what was to come of Saeng. In some stories it would have worked but in this case it was needed. When she first saw the hibiscus she broke down because she could not remember her homeland. This is why the hibiscus is so important to the story. By restating the importance of it in the end helped the reader follow what was to come next even though the story had come to an end. It was important to express this again. In the last paragraph it says, “This hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” The buds represent a new beginning for Saeng and a new chance to overcome her problems. This paragraph was very important and without it these events would be left hanging, unresolved and incomplete. The meaning of the story is much clearer with it as a reader.

Including the bit about taking the test again when the hibiscus is budding provides a sense of closure and lesson to an otherwise open ending. The hibiscus represents perseverance and strength, mirroring Saeng's own journey. After a harsh winter, this hibiscus can bloom again and continue to live. Even after moving from Vietnam and struggling to adapt, Saeng must recover and keep trying, just like the flower, illustrating her resilience. Just like the flower blooming again, so will Saeng. She will take the test a second time and pass. She will adapt to her environment and keep going, just like the hibiscus, demonstrating her ability to overcome challenges.

The author concludes the story with the paragraph “When they come back , Saeng vowed silently to herself in the spring , when the snow melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding , then I will take the test again ,” because the author started out the story after Saeng failed her driving test. The author include it because her mother took the test and passed it, and the daughter wanted to do the same, just like her mom. I think the author is trying to show that Saeng is finally starting to accept and get over the struggles in her life.
