I think the author concludes the story with that paragraph for many reasons. One reason I think is because she’s concluding that the winter is there, and when winter is over, she is going to start flowering and planting again. In the story it said, “the winter hibiscus was in the ground now,…” which suggests a period of dormancy and anticipation. So, now she has to wait for winter to pass by; then the hibiscus will be starting to grow and will hopefully bloom by spring. The ending highlights a cyclical nature, with the promise of renewal and growth, which is why I think she concluded the story the way she did.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because the question of what about her test? Needed to be answered and thatís when she'd be comfortable to take it. In the text, to her, the plant felt smooth and cool just as she had known it, which was comforting. She closed her palm around it and held it tight. That, at least, she could hold on to. Unlike her grandmother, she felt a wave of loss so deep and strong that it stung her eyes, with sadness, and maybe disappointment, which she probably wouldn't want to deal with for a while, hinted at in the conclusion. Her mother even uttered a small cry of surprise and delight to see the flower, even before being shocked when Saeng reveals she paid all of over nineteen dollars for it. With this concluding paragraph, I believe that she will be more comfortable at the time planned because she'll have new and old things to come home to, such as the geese and plant, offering her a sense of continuity and grounding amidst the changes in her life.

In the story ìWinter Hibiscusî the author includes this ending paragraph because she wants to show that next time around she will be prepared and ready for the garden and the challenges it holds, particularly the nuances of a new environment. This first time, she wasnít ready, and she didnít know about the winter hibiscus because she never did anything like it before, highlighting a journey of adaptation and learning that suggests future gardening attempts will be approached with more knowledge and anticipation. This newfound awareness promises a more informed and successful experience.

In the story “Winter Hibiscus,” the story ends with saying “in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” The author ends the story like that because it is showing that even though she failed the test once, she’s not going to give up just because of an adjustment change. The Hibiscus made the reader realize that a plant in the foreign place where she lives can adapt, so can she, suggesting resilience and hope for future success.

The reason she ended the story like that is because when everything is blooming, she will feel more at home and will have healthy. I say this because the girl used to help her grandma with her hair before she moved, which was a comforting routine. So if the flower is blooming, then it would remind her of her grandma, creating a sense of familiarity and comfort, which would be incentive to do good on the test and feel more settled in her new environment.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it is a personification involving snow smelting, geese returning, and the hibiscus budding. It's explaining moments in time, marking a subtle shift. The author describes how isolated the hibiscus is, a single point of vibrant color against the backdrop of a thawing world, emphasizing its unique resilience.

The author ended the story with that paragraph because it’s telling how Saeng feels about winter being near and how she has to wait until spring comes back around to do her tests again. A sense of resignation settles over her as the cold air hints at the dormant months ahead, knowing her experiments must be paused, patiently awaiting the thaw and the return of the vital warmth needed to continue her work. This paints a picture of anticipation mixed with acceptance, concluding her current endeavors and highlighting the cyclical nature of her research, tied as it is to the seasons.

Saeng cares about the flowers. She cares about the flower's delicate petals and vibrant colors. Natural occurrence with them growing unique. She appreciates the imperfections and variations that make each blossom special, recognizing the beauty in their individuality and the natural processes that shape them, showing her deep affection for the floral world.

I don’t know why the author wrote the story; with that I really don’t know. Maybe she was talking about how she took all the tests and now she wouldn’t take them over again, ever. The time has come. She is in school, and when one took the test, it was a kind of trial, one that is now over. It is @DATE1, and school is over, so the pressure is finally off.

The author concludes the paragraph into the story because an ending was needed to provide closure. Furthermore, the author selected a conclusion that would best fit the narrative, ensuring a satisfying resolution for the reader. Thus, the paragraph serves as a deliberate and fitting culmination of the story's events.

I believe that the author chose to conclude the story the way they did because the story was about perseverance. For example, the story was based around the winter hibiscus plant, which bloomed even in the cold. This is a good example because in the end Saeng vows that she will persevere and take her test again, and the hibiscus perseveres and forges through the winter, not allowing itself to die. Another example is that Saeng's mother worked outside while it was cold to get her gardening done. This relates to the story because she stayed out in the cold garden to get her job done; she could have quit and gone inside the nice warm house, just like Saeng could have quit and said she was not going to try to take her test again. But she did not; she said she was going to try again, which demonstrates how the author chose to end the story to truly encompass the theme of perseverance.

I think the author ended this story like that because it means that she hasn't given up yet, and even though she failed the first time, she is going to try again. "In the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding," means that when all is renewed, she will try to do it again because if she passes, it will be worthwhile. The story was pretty bad because I don't even know what she failed, so I didn't like it.

I think the reason why the author ended the story with this "when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding. Then I will take that test again" paragraph because like this the plant didn’t have a fair chance for survival in the winter and was the same with the girl when she took her driving test, unprepared and in unfavorable conditions; but in spring the plant has a chance to bloom, symbolizing renewed hope, so she believes she has a chance to pass the test because there is a time and place for everything, and spring represents the right time for her to try again, suggesting that with preparation and favorable circumstances, she will succeed.

Emotion, commitment, hope, all are reasons why the author ended the story with "when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again." That last paragraph shows that she has emotion, specifically resilience in the face of potential disappointment. Next, it shows that she has commitment, as she states that when the hibiscus blooms again, she will retake the test, demonstrating dedication to her goal. Lastly, it shows that there is hope, implying that she believes in her ability to improve and succeed in the future. Therefore, these emotional elements effectively explain the author's choice to conclude the story with that particular paragraph.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to emphasize her new found determination to overcome her obstacles. For example, in the passage she states, ìshe realized that many of the things she had thought strange before had become, through the quiet repetition of season upon season, almost familiarizes to her.î At this point she has an epiphany, and realizes that life is like seasons. In the end paragraph she intercedes this by saying that in the spring she will take the test again. This shows that just as the winter hibiscus is along winter, and then blooms in the spring, she must be strong during these hard times. One day her time will come for her to ìbloom.î @CAPS1 experiences hard times, but we all must be strong and steadfast as we wait for our time to ìbloom,î and this cyclical imagery offers hope and resilience in the face of adversity.

The author concluded the story with that paragraph because he wanted to show that she wasn't going to give up just because she failed one time. She failed the test one time already, which was disheartening. She was very sad about it. She went and bought a plant to try again. Saeng's mom told her that they were going to do it the right way this time around. Saeng was crying when she told her mom about it, overwhelmed by the setback. Her mom was very understanding, though, offering comfort and support. Her mom could have been very mad with her, especially given the importance of the test. She could have used a plant that they grew, saving money and effort. The plant @MONTH1 might not grow right now due to the season. She should have bought a real plant from someone else to ensure success. Therefore, the ending emphasizes Saeng's resilience and her mother's unwavering support, highlighting their determination to succeed despite the initial failure.

Determined, new beginning, symbolism – each are reasons why I believe the author concluded the story with this paragraph. She finds new hope after buying the plant, and is newly determined to pass the test that she writes about. As she sees the geese flying overhead, she realizes what determination they must have on their long journey and vows to do better on the test next year. With the new flower, she feels like she's starting over so that she’s able to pass this test that seems important to her. When the author writes, "and the geese will return and this hibiscus in budding, then I will take that test again," it shows symbolism. By telling about the flower blooming new buds, it symbolizes that Saeng wanted to turn over a new leaf of some sort, illustrating her fresh perspective and renewed motivation. Determined, new beginning, symbolism – each are reasons why I think the author concluded the story with this paragraph, leaving the reader with a sense of optimism for Saeng's future endeavors.

The author of ì Winter Hibiscusî by Minfong Ho ends the story with the statement, ìwhen they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take test again,î because it showed that Saeng had overcome her problem and vowed to correct it. By ending with this statement the author showed that the beauty of nature can help one to overcome their problems, as did Saeng. Upon seeing the Geese migrate and the ìWinter Hibiscusî Saeng, ìrealized that many of the things that she had thought of as strange before had become, through the quiet repetition of season upon season, almost familiar to her now. Like the geese.î Saeng realized that the test although strange and different to her now became familiar because of her experiences with nature. Seeing the geese and ìWinter Hibiscusî remind her that even the unfamiliar can become familiar with time and perseverance. This plant also made Saeng think of her past in Vietnam and all of one good times back at her home. ìThe familiar fragrance filled her lungs, and Saeng could almost fast the light strures of her grandmothers long gray hair, freshly mashed.î The plant made her think of good experiences. In the end, the plant made her joyous enough not to think about the past, but about the future, about taking the test again and her new life in the United States.

The reason why the author puts that last line into the story of the end is to show us the raids and saeng that even though it's almost over, she doesn’t want it to end. But she knows that it will also start up again next year when things go back to the way they were before everything changed. This cyclical nature, the temporary respite before the inevitable return to the raids and the saeng, emphasizes the enduring impact of these events. This is why I think the author put that line into the story, highlighting the bittersweet reality of endings and beginnings.

The author concluded the story with Saeng vowing to herself “in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again” to express her determination of fitting into new things and to express the change she was getting used to. Describing spring was important in the conclusion because it described what Saeng once thought was odd in @LOCATION1, but got used to the seasons and weather changing. The hibiscus, budding in spring, symbolizes a fresh start and her own growth. Once she realized that she needed to deal with change, she knew that she would need to try the driving test again. It was very important that the author’s conclusion was “in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again” because it expressed how Saeng was accepting change in her life, demonstrating her resilience and newfound adaptability.

In ìwinter Hibiscusî the author uses hibiscus flower to symbolize beauty in unexpected places, adapting to a new life, and Saeng's home country. At the end of the story I think that the author realizes that even though she failed the test, everything is going to be okay. While looking at the hibiscus she remembers her old life, which she loved, and she is reminded of the natural beauty that can be found in a hibiscus flower, even in winter. In life, I think every one should always remember that even though one might be disappointed at sometime, we have to keep in mind, the fact that life goes on. There will always be another chance, as long as you can find peace and beauty in something good, like Saeng finds in the hibiscus, reminding us that resilience and hope can bloom even in challenging circumstances.

The author concludes with this paragraph to show how Saeng and the plant are similar, highlighting their shared potential for growth. The plant represents Saeng’s strength and abilities, currently dormant but full of promise. She knows that only when she is stronger, revitalized in the spring like the plant, will she be ready to retake the test with renewed confidence. Her hopes, currently fragile, will be stronger and more resilient like the plant flourishing in the spring. That is why the author concluded with that paragraph, emphasizing Saeng's anticipated resurgence.

I believe the author ends the story with this paragraph because it refers to previous events in the story. For example it says, "and this hibiscus is budding." This refers back to the beginning of the story when Saeng first saw the hibiscus plant and it reminded her of home, creating a sense of nostalgia and connection. This is a good way to conclude a story, bringing it full circle. I wouldn’t change it at all if I could. Also in the summary before the story it says how she had failed her driver’s test and in the last paragraph it says, "then I will take that test again." I think Saeng didn’t have much confidence before taking the test because of her new surroundings, but now that she is familiar with everything and found a hobby, she will likely think of passing while taking the test again, suggesting a newfound hope. I think she is looking to start over and forget about failing, indicating a resolution to her initial struggles.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because she overcame adversity and she wants to retake the quiz for herself and to prove it to herself, not for anyone else's validation. She states, "When they come back, Saeng vowed to herself, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and the hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again," emphasizing her personal resolve. So, because she says that she wants to retake the test, it's clear she is not being pressured into taking it. She is taking it to prove something to herself, demonstrating her resilience and determination to conquer the challenge she previously faced.

In the short story “Winter Hibiscus” by Minfong Ho, a young girl named Saeng recalls her life before she moved to America. She misses her homeland and all of the things she loved before she came here. Towards the end of the story, the author includes a paragraph saying that Saeng vowed to take her driver's test again when winter ends, when the geese return, and the hibiscus is budding. The author concludes the story with this paragraph for one reason: He/She wants to show that Saeng is strong enough to survive the winter, just like the hibiscus, and will be ready when the weary days of winter are over, and the beautiful days of spring come. Saeng’s mother states, “It’s strong enough to make it through the cold months…That’s what matters”. The winter hibiscus is a direct parallel to Saeng in that just like it, she is strong enough to survive the winter months, and ultimately, she too, will blossom again.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph to make the reader want more. When an author ends the chapter of a story or an episode of a show it is always a good idea to use a cliffhanger to drag the audience along. In many stories I have read this is used. In my favorite series, the CAPSTONE Chronicles, the Peterson book always ends with a cliff-hanger. Like in the end of the third book one of the soldiers is killed but you don’t find out by who until the next book, effectively hooking the reader and ensuring they return for the continuation of the narrative.

The author concludes this story the way she does to say that the girl is not going to give up on trying to fit in this new country. The author concludes this way because it refers that it's not over, and even though the test was a failure, it won't be next time. The author lets us know that the little girl cares about the test and wants to prove to people that she can pass it. She is reminded of her home by these flowers, and with this reminder she can retake it and do it right, showing her resilience and determination to succeed in her new environment.

I think the author included that in the paragraph because Saeng didn't like the cold, so she would wait until the snow melts and the geese return to test the plants again, preferring the warmer weather for her work. I also think she added it to show that she would come back to visit her mother, ensuring their connection remained strong despite her travels.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph because Saeng failed the test and in the spring she will take the test over, armed with a renewed determination to succeed after understanding her weaknesses.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it provides closure to both Saeng and the story. Saeng was upset about the fact that she failed her test, but towards the end of the story she realizes that things happen, and sometimes we have no control over what happens, but you’ve also got to pick yourself up again if what happens, knocks you down. When seeing the geese and the hibiscus, she realizes that everyone and everything has to adapt to something new all the time. Saeng might have failed her driving test because they drive differently in Vietnam, so she will have to adapt to the way we drive here, along with all our rule and laws, indicating her willingness to learn and persevere despite the setback. This is why the author concludes the paragraph in that way, leaving the reader with a sense of hope and Saeng’s resilience.

Saeng was taking a test, and she didn’t quite pass it. She was afraid to tell her mother, but she had to tell her anyway. Her mother got upset because she didn’t pass it, expressing her disappointment. Saeng knows that right after winter's over, she’ll be taking that same test again, and she hoped she would pass it this time so she could make her mother proud.

In the story, ìWinter Hibiscusî by Minfong Ho, the author includes the phrase, -When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again- because she wanted to make the story end with Saeng finding positive views on her new home and positive views in the future and have her look forward to it. Throughout the short story, Saeng happens to have a sad disposition about her new home and how the plants remind her recent home. - ìI mean its not the kind we at-at-ì she found that she was still too shaky to say the words at home, last she burst into tears again.- This phrase shows that Saeng really missed her home and was truly sad about it. Seeing the hibiscus bloom in winter, a time of hardship and cold, likely inspires her. The concluding phrase shown before shows that she found the strength to look positively at the future of her new home, suggesting a newfound resilience and hope for her life in America.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because at the beginning of the story Saeng went to take a driving test but didn’t pass, and so she goes and buys a hibiscus that reminds her of home and gives her strength and comfort. So her mother says this at the end because she knows Saeng is going through a hard time adapting to her new country, with the driving test being a symbol of her struggle, and she doesn’t want to put more pressure on her just because she knows Saeng is very upset and is trying to make it up to her by buying a flower for her. So she says by next spring she should be adapted and ready for the test because the flower should give her hope. She wants her to know she is there for her, offering unspoken support and understanding as Saeng navigates her new life.

I think the author of ìWinter Hibiscusî said ìwhen they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, the I will take the test again.î to conclude the story for many reasons. First, it shows that she isn’t giving up despite facing a challenge in a new country and struggling with the language, demonstrating her resilience. The second reason is it gives a feeling of hope for what's to come, suggesting a brighter future where she overcomes obstacles. The last reason is it leaves us wondering if she makes it next time, creating suspense and keeping the reader engaged. That is probably why the author ended it that way, leaving a lasting impression of perseverance and anticipation.

The author of the Winter Hibiscus concludes the story with the paragraph to show the connection between the hibiscus and @CAPS1, a young immigrant adjusting to a new country. The hibiscus has to survive the winter until spring when it can bloom and become big and beautiful. @CAPS1 is connecting to the flower and saying she can make it through her obstacles that come with the change in environment if the flower can deal with being confined in a plastic container and surviving the weather. She feels that right now she's like the Hibiscus, uprooted and waiting. She’s trapped because the area is alien to her and she has to adjust. Just as the container is alien to the flower because it’s used to being free in nature. But once it’s planted, it will become a part of its surroundings and grow. And once she accepts the change and becomes willing to start over, she will begin to grow, gaining confidence and perhaps finding everyday tasks, like her driving test, easier. In conclusion, this is the reason the author concluded the paragraph with this sentence, to highlight the parallel journey of resilience and adaptation between the flower and the protagonist.

In the short story ìWinter Hibiscusî, the author ends with the main character Saeng saying that she will take the test ìwhen the snow melts and the geese return.î I believe that the Hibiscus and the driverís test are relevant like the blooming of a flower. If it wilts at the first, it can blossom later on, thus the author included this to show that Saeng wilted at first, but will blossom at spring. It also a symbol of her constant blossoming. The authorís intention of the last line was demonstrated early when Saeng was disappointed of failing the test. She is upset that she failed her driverís test, but when she sees a flower from her homeland, she starts to get boosted and start to weep a little. It shows her blossoming because she changes from a negative mood to a positive one, after seeing the flower from her childhood memory. It shows her wilt and blossom again when she tells her mother the news about the test. At first she gets nervous and scared, so scared she tears the leaf off and shreds it to pieces. Her mother then wipes the green matter of and asks her to plant it. Saeng then gets a morale boost and start to feel better. This once again shows her blossoming because she thought her mother would yell at her for failing the test, but instead accepts the plant, showing her rise again. Saeng falters throughout the story, but manages to rise above it all and give herself determination to meet her goal. She is determined to pass the test when spring arrives, and blossom again, illustrating her resilience. The Hibiscus shows it with its budding stage, symbolizing hope and growth. It will blossom like Saeng, reflecting her journey of perseverance and eventual success.

The author probably includes part of the story with the paragraph to put more details into the paragraph, trying to talk about the life that Saeng had vowed silently to herself in the spring when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding then I will take that test again, illustrating that with the return of nature's beauty and the promise of new beginnings, specifically when flowers start blooming again and spring comes around again, that's when she will take that test and pass this time, showcasing her renewed determination and aligning her personal goals with the cyclical renewal of the natural world.

I think the author concludes the story with this because she's proving she has the strength to do something that she failed the first time again. She took this plant and looked at it as a memory and a passage of time. Saeng planted it as a reminder of home and her promise. Saeng said, "It's not a real one," "Not like the kind we had before." Saeng loved home and wished she was back there, but her new promise was what had mattered, and now she could nurture this new plant and fulfill that promise.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph because it signals a new beginning, a fresh start with the arrival of day time. This symbolizes the opportunity she has to take the test on a budding new day. The return of the geese indicates spring, mirroring the hibiscus bud, suggesting her test is also timed with this season of renewal, and concluding the story with this imagery emphasizes the hope and potential inherent in this fresh start.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because she wants to take the driving test in springtime. Springtime is a symbol of positive feelings; she gets positive feelings from the blooming of the winter hibiscus, a resilient flower that blooms even when things are difficult, reminding her of her own perseverance. Thus, the hibiscus blooming in spring inspires her confidence for the test.

They had to come back, so they did, and they were walking into a then world over there in the corner, a world of faded photographs and whispered memories, and the childhood world too, complete with the familiar scent of pine and damp earth, just as she had known it would feel. The worn porch swing creaked a welcome, solidifying the comfort she sought.

This last paragraph is written for several reasons. First, she will try again when she feels the time is right. Just like the geese coming back, Saeng will come back to take the test, and so the Hibiscus plant will also bloom again. She feels that it is the right thing to do and it will be the right time to come back and take the test. This paragraph describes Saeng well, capturing her patience and resilience; it reflects how she lives and how she will approach the test again, trusting her own internal sense of readiness. Ultimately, she believes in returning when the moment aligns with her own preparedness and conviction.

I believe that the author ends because the author is showing that Saeng is determined to pass the test. "She paused as she noticed the tearstains on her daughter's cheeks and her puffy eyes." (Ho) This quote shows that passing the test meant a lot to Saeng. She was crying because she couldn't help but buy the plant and fail the test. She didn't want to fail and showed her sadness by crying. This highlights how deeply she cared about the outcome and the principles behind it. "Then I will take the test again." (Ho) This quote shows that even though she failed, she is determined to pass the test and succeed. Failing hurt her greatly, so she can't wait to do it again and pass because she is determined to succeed. This willingness to immediately try again underscores her resolve. This is all important because Saeng shows that determination is the key to success and she is determined, making her willingness to try again a testament to her character and the importance of perseverance.

The author uses this paragraph to conclude the story to show Saeng's determination and her adaptation to her new home. This shows her determination because it says, "I will take that test again," revealing her resolve to not give up despite facing challenges. This also shows that she has adapted to her new home, as she is now willing to persevere and integrate herself into the system, indicating a growing sense of belonging and a proactive approach to her future.

I think the author concludes the story with this paragraph because she was upset that she moved away from her friends and familiar surroundings. She is also upset that she failed her drivers test, hindering her independence in this new place. So she planted the plant, a tangible act of hope for the future, and says that when spring comes, symbolizing renewal and new beginnings, she will retry her drivers test, demonstrating her resolve to adapt and overcome her setbacks.

In the story, ìWinter Hibiscus", by Minfong Ho, the author concludes the story with a paragraph with Saeng vowing she will take the test again in the spring. Minfong used this paragraph because it means never give up, even if you fail the first time. For example, Saeng just failed her driver's test, feeling dejected after misinterpreting the yield sign, but after buying the Hibiscus and delving deeper into things, recognizing its resilience to bloom even in winter, she realized she shouldn't give up. This newfound determination, fueled by the hibiscus's symbolic persistence, underscores the story's message about perseverance.

The author concludes with this sentence for emphasis. It takes Saengís mind off of the flower and she focuses on her test. By waiting until next spring to take the test it gives her something to look forward to, a renewed goal. This statement also shows that you should never give up on anything that you do, even when faced with setbacks. The author ends on a good note explaining this, offering a message of hope and perseverance. The last paragraph is also a break from the rest of the story and from what Saengës was just doing, shifting the focus to her future aspirations. It is Saengís last and final thoughts, providing closure and a sense of optimism.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph, I think, to say that when the hibiscus starts to grow back, she will be back at what she started. I think that is why, because she says, “In the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is building, then I will take that test again.” This suggests a cyclical return, mirroring nature's renewal, implying she'll revisit her challenge with renewed hope and a fresh perspective, signifying a return to her initial state of striving.

The author concludes the story with a paragraph so the people reading the story would actually read it and not guess how the story is going to go. This final passage serves as a safeguard against premature assumptions, compelling readers to follow the narrative's intended path and experience its unfolding events directly, rather than jumping to conclusions based on limited information. The intention is to maintain suspense and encourage a deeper engagement with the text, ensuring the story's impact is felt fully and completely.

The authors conclusion in the story explains that after all that team work and handwork you should keep that flow going each year. Even though something might have changed, like team members or project specifics, the collaborative spirit and dedication to quality should remain constant. This ensures continued success and improvement year after year, fostering a culture of sustained excellence.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to create a feeling of hope. Saeng had a bad day, from failing the test to her deep feeling of loss, but after finding the hibiscus and planting it she seemed to be enlightened, while she still missed her homeland but had comforting memories. She shows determination, because she declares she will take that test again, and seems to have more confidence in herself. The author adds that Saeng will take the test again in the spring. When looking at archetypes, spring is a time of new beginnings and life, mirroring Saeng's renewed resolve. When the hibiscus is budding (being reborn), she will take the test, symbolizing a fresh start. It will be a new, better start for Saeng too, leaving the reader with a sense of optimism for her future.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to show determination. It shows that Saeng wants to take her time to adjust to her new life and her new surroundings, observing the nuances of her environment. Then she thinks it might feel more like this place is becoming a home, a comfortable and familiar space. She feels that maybe, if she's been used to this new place for awhile, absorbing its rhythms and atmosphere, she will have a better chance at passing the test. She is determined to pass the test, showing her resilience and commitment to succeeding in this new chapter.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because when Saeng was saying this to herself, she made a promise to not give up getting her license, and the hibiscus makes her feel like she is at home again. The hibiscus reminds her of warmth and familiarity. In the text when the mother says, "@CAPS1 seen this kind blooming along the lake. Its flowers arent as pretty, but its strong enough to make it through the cold months here, this winter hibiscus. Thats what matters," when she says this, it makes Saeng not so sad because she knows that the hibiscus will remind her of the hibiscus at home and that gives her the power to want to try again in the spring, renewing her determination to succeed despite the setbacks.

The author concludes the story with “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” I think that the author includes this paragraph to show how persistent Saeng is. Saeng is persistent because she tries over and over again at this “test,” showing resilience in the face of a challenge, and also she tries to get used to her new country. It demonstrates this in the story when it says the quote above. This quote shows that Saeng can try something and fail, then be determined to try and succeed again, revealing her strong will. Also in the story, Saeng has moved from one country to another. This is a huge jump, a significant life change, and for her to be confident with herself is very persistent. The way the author concludes the story, with “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again” definitely portrays Saeng, the main character, as a persistent person, and that is the purpose of the quote, solidifying her character as someone who doesn't give up easily.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because he wants the audience to think about what he said and to want to read more. For example, I was reading a book that ended in a question, and I wanted to read more to discover the answer to the question. Another example is that I was reading another book that ended in a statement, and I wanted to read another book by the same author, but they didn't have one, so I don't know how the story ultimately ended. That's why authors end stories like that, so they can make you read another book with the resolution, or at least ponder the possibilities beyond the page.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph for many reasons. The author wanted to convey a sense of hope to show the growth of her character, and to show how things are going to change. In the last paragraph when she vows that she will take that test again it gives you a sense that everything will be okay. Earlier in the story she had been crying and missing her homeland; the tone was troubled and sad. This last paragraph suggests that the tone is now hopeful, demonstrating resilience. Even though she failed the test, she is still going to try again, showing her unwavering spirit. The author also put the paragraph to show how much her character has grown. Saying that she will try again shows how much stronger and more determined she is. Lastly, she had the story end with that paragraph to foreshadow what is to come. The geese coming back and the snow melting, and the hibiscus budding all show a change in the seasons, mirroring the cyclical nature of life. This represents the change that has occurred in her and it foreshadows that things will be different from now on, indicating a brighter future.

The author concluded the story with that message is because, if you think about it, if not, that seems to negate the whole story and leaves an opening for a sequel. It's obvious that the whole point of the story is to make you think, prompting reflection long after the final page.

I think the author added this paragraph because it signals a new start for her. Because she has had a hard time, it doesn't mean she will always have hard times, suggesting a shift towards a more positive future and the hope that things will improve. This paragraph, therefore, acts as an optimistic turning point in her narrative.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph because it meant a lot to Saeng. Saeng failed her driving test and was scared to tell her mother that she also spent nineteen dollars for "Dok Faeng-noi," which was a flower/plant they had back at home. For example, "As Saeng walks home after failing her driver's test, she sees a familiar plant." The plant Saeng saw meant a lot to her mother. "@PERSON1 uttered a small cry of surprise and delight. 'Dok faeng-noi' she said. 'Where did you get it?'" That was a quote stating that her mother was excited to hear that. The story is concluded by that paragraph because after all Saeng went through, her mother was glad she bought it. "'It's a beautiful plant, this dok faeng-noi,' she finally said. 'I'm glad you got it.'" It shows a moment of connection and shared joy between mother and daughter despite the day's setbacks, making it a fitting and heartwarming conclusion.

Authors sometimes use interesting sentences as their concluding sentence that you often have a hard time understanding. In the story "Winter Hibiscus," the author concludes her story by saying "when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again." The author says this to show that Saeng is not ready to garden yet and needs to learn more. The mother is very disappointed in the daughter for buying a plant that is very expensive and shows her inexperience in buying things because of your feelings is wrong. This is showed when they say "I paid over Nineteen dollars for it." "You what?" She also says "facing. Now where did you get that" showing her surprise at the expensive, beautiful plant. Authors use those paragraphs and sentences to show or recap the story. The Author of "Winter Hibiscus" ends her story with the paragraph because Saeng should not have bought the plant based on having emotions, and that she shall try again next year to not mess up. Therefore, the ending encapsulates Saeng's realization of her impulsive decision and her determination to learn and improve, suggesting a hopeful outlook for the future despite her current setback.

The author of the passage ends the story with this statement to create curiosity. This creates curiosity through writing for the spring and the geese to return. Saeng waits for the spring because she knows that is when everything else creates new life, so Saeng must wait till then to get her new beginning, implying that her renewal is intrinsically linked to the natural cycle of rebirth and hope that spring embodies.

I think the reason why the author ended the story with that paragraph was because that will be the time she thinks she will be ready to retake the driver’s test. The author includes this sentence, "When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again," to show her determination. The girl had just moved from Vietnam to the United States. It would be hard for her to understand anything, and anything could bring her memory back about Vietnam. The author concludes this paragraph because he wants to make it clearer for the readers, ensuring they fully grasp the intended meaning. The author finished off the story with that paragraph because it suggests that with time and adaptation, she will be ready for the test. In the story, "Winter Hibiscus," by Minfong Ho, Ho concludes the story with that paragraph due to the fact the flower represents Saeng's happiness, reminding her of her home. I think the author concludes the story with this paragraph ìWhen they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, iN the spring, wheN the @CAPS1 melt and the geese RetuRN and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test againî means to the author kinda like the meaning to life. The author concludes this story this way to go over again the important things in the story. “I will take that test again,” This is the test that she had failed that day, a test that assessed her memory of her home. The author of ìWinter Hibiscusî concludes the story with the excerpt "when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test againî because it emphasizes Saeng’s pain to come to an unknown place and fail her first test but also emphasizes Saeng’s resolve to work hard after seeing a flower that resembled one from home. The author concludes the story with the afore mentioned paragraph to represent the connection between the return of the hibiscus’ bids, and the return of Saeng’s resolve. In the passage “Winter Hibiscus,” the author uses this phrase in the last paragraph: “when they came back, Saeng vows silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and the hibiscus is budding, I will take that test again.” I believe she concluded this story with these words because she is conveying that even when the birds flew away, the seasons, like the birds, would inevitably return. The author concludes this story with the paragraph showing that when it becomes spring and the geese are budding, she said silently to herself that she is going to take the permit again, revealing her persistent determination despite previous setbacks, indicating a cyclical return to her goal with the changing seasons.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because she wants to show Saeng's determination to survive and be happy in her new home. The author concluded this paragraph in the story because it was showing that there are geese that hang around the garden around the spring time, a common sight as the weather warms and they seek out fresh vegetation.

The author in this story explains how hard some changes can be. The author also explains how family and objects from home, such as the flower, can be comforting during these times. I think the author concludes this part of the story because he wanted to let the reader know that this wasn’t it for the little girl, and she wasn’t going to give up on planting flowers. In the story “Winter Hibiscus,” the author concludes the story with, “When they come back take that test again.” She does this to show that she still has hope, and won’t just give up. I think the author ends the story with this paragraph for many reasons. Where Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again. The author concludes the story with this paragraph to show Saeng's outlook on the future. It is a fitting conclusion, drawing from numerous elements in the story, and it shows how Saeng has grown. In this phrase she shows a growing acceptance and even an affection for her new homeland, a place that once felt alien. The geese are "familiar to Saeng now" despite her thinking of them as "strange before," highlighting her gradual adaptation. The hibiscus is a piece of her past, a symbol of home, adapted to fit her current situation and blooming in a new environment. Saeng's vow that she will "take that test again" in the spring, "When the snows melt…" etc., shows that despite losing so much - her home, her grandmother, her way of life - Saeng is still determined to make the best of her situation, embracing resilience. She plans on passing her driving test come spring, no matter what obstacles she faces. The concluding paragraph is a fitting way to wrap up the story, showing how the threads of Saeng's past and her present are entwined, and displaying her determined attitude towards the future. With its optimistic words, the final paragraph neatly ties up the mood of optimism amidst regret, showcasing the character's strength. The author's wording was very well done, leaving the reader with a sense of hope for Saeng's future.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because the story says "I will take that test again," suggesting she's trying to see how much she has adjusted to changes in life. In the story, it also states "when they come back," concluding that when the flowers come back next season, she will see how much she remembers about her homeland, her grandma, and the good things, essentially using the recurring bloom as a personal benchmark for memory and adaptation.

The reason why the author concludes the story with this paragraph is because they wanted the reader to know there will be another story that will be made up. Also to show that Saeng was not happy that the snow melted and the geese return and the hibiscus was budding, suggesting her longing for the winter landscape and perhaps hinting at future adventures or a continuation of her emotional journey in a different season, thus leaving the audience anticipating what comes next.

Now that she knows a lot about plants the narrator makes it seem like the girl is interested in nature. The author concludes the story with that paragraph because it shows that Saeng can overcome her weaknesses and succeed in her new home. The author concludes the story with this paragraph for many reasons. The first reason is to show that Saeng is a determined young girl. Minfong Ho concluded the story with this because it shows Saeng’s determination to pass the driver's test. But in this final paragraph, observing the flower's resilience, she vows that she will overcome all her challenges of being in an unfamiliar place and pull herself together to accomplish her goal, just as the winter hibiscus blooms even in harsh conditions, symbolizing her own potential for growth and adaptation.

The author included this sentence in the paragraph because Saeng was a very determined girl. She would keep trying till she got it right, pushing through any obstacle. In the concluding statement Saeng states that ìwhen they come back In the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again.î The author concludes the story with this passage because she is using the hibiscus as an example of survival. I believe the author uses this as the last paragraph because it tells of how Saeng wants to overcome and be strong even though she misses her home. The author concludes the story with this specific paragraph to sum up the realization and determination Saeng obtains. Initially, Saeng is upset after failing her test. In the story “Winter Hibiscus,” Saeng had failed her driver's test. As she walked home, disheartened, she spied a vibrant hibiscus flower at a roadside stand. Its bright color reminded her of her faraway home. She bought the flower and returned to her new home where her mother was already working in the garden, tending to the unfamiliar plants. Together, they decided to plant the winter hibiscus in their garden, hoping it would thrive. As they finished planting, a flock of geese flew overhead, honking as they headed south for the winter. Saeng then realized that everything was becoming familiar; the initial strangeness was fading. She concludes the story saying that when the geese come back in the spring, a sign of renewal and return, she will take the test again. She says that by then, the flower will be buckling, meaning blooming and growing, and she, too, will have grown and become familiar with everything, so she will be ready for the test when the geese are ready to come home and the hibiscus is ready to bloom, symbolizing her own readiness and belonging.

The author does this because they are comparing to the plant. The author does this because when the plant starts to bloom then the character’s confidence will come back. The author concludes the story with this paragraph to show that Saeng is finally comfortable with her new “home.” After the passage is mostly a reflection of Saeng’s old life, it ends this way to signify that she has become accustomed to her new way of life. This last paragraph reveals something special to the reader. Saeng was given new hope winter mothers understanding and the hibiscus plant. The actual flower represents a new life for Saeng in a new country. The author concludes the story with this paragraph in order to show Saeng’s determination. In "Winter Hibiscus," Saeng finds comfort in the plant after failing her test. The author concludes the story saying, "when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again." The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it describes the cyclical nature of the seasons, how they change, come, and go, starting with a new season that then transforms into something different. The author chose to end the story with the final paragraph for several reasons. Saeng states that she will retake her driving test in the spring. The author concludes the sentence on the end to state when the plants start over growing and the geese come back, she will try again.
