The author concludes the story with this because she is saying that she is going to grow with the season's change. She is in a new country and just failed her driver's test, leaving her feeling dejected, but the hibiscus reminds her of being back home. In the story, Saeng's mother says, "I've seen this kind blooming along the lake; it's strong enough to make it through the winter." Saeng can relate to that sentiment, understanding that if the flower can make it through the winter, then she, too, can persevere and thrive in a new country.

In the story “Winter Hibiscus”, the author finishes the story with this last paragraph, “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is building, then I will take that test again.” The author finishes the story with that paragraph because in the beginning, Saeng had purchased a hibiscus plant because it had reminded her of her hometown. (“Plants that she had not realized that she had known but had forgotten drew her back into her childhood world”) So she purchased it, but since there was bad weather at the time, Saeng had to get the plant back in time and plant it in the garden. But she failed, missing the deadline for the test. That is why it says “I will take that test again,” showing her resolve. And she will take it again during the spring when the hibiscus blooms once again, symbolizing a fresh start and renewed hope. That is why the author finished the story with that paragraph, linking Saeng's personal growth to the natural cycle of the hibiscus.

The author concludes the paragraph like this because it shows that she is not going to give up. I like this because she vowed silently to herself that she was going to take the test again during the spring; this resilience, coupled with the mentioned challenges, underscores why the author concludes the paragraph with such determination, highlighting her unwavering spirit.

The story "Winter Hibiscus" is written by Minfong Ho. The author ended the story with this excerpt, "When they come back," Saeng vowed silently to herself, "in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again." The reason for this is so she will have time to adjust to her new environment. Saeng just needs a little comforting because all of this is new to her, a new school, a new language, a new country. These words use figurative language because the geese reminded her of herself, "Almost familiar to her now. Like geese." They, like her, were newcomers, adapting to a foreign land, hinting at her own journey of assimilation and her hope for a fresh start.

It is almost spring, like he said, showing melting and geese returning, and hibiscus is budding. Grass is growing, trees are budding, @CAPS1 birds are singing, heralding the warmer days ahead. With these signs, the promise of spring feels truly palpable.

In the story ìWinter Hibiscusî by Minfong Ho, the author concludes the story with an interesting paragraph. The paragraph saysî When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding  then I will take that test again. "The author ended the story with that paragraph because she was not in her comfort zone, she had move to a new country and missed everything, like the familiar warmth and the hibiscus flower, elements that represented home. So she would wait until she felt more settled and comfortable again to retake the test, giving herself time to adjust to her new surroundings. In the text it states ìthrough the quiet repetition of season upon season, almost familiar to her now.î She was realizing that it wasnít so bad & she was getting used to it, slowly building a new sense of normalcy and adapting to the rhythm of her new life in America. This suggests a growing acceptance and a preparedness to face challenges again, once she feels more grounded.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph, ìWhen they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself in the spring, when the snows melt & the geese return & this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again,î so that the audience has something to think about, it gives the story a little more of a dramatic effect. This cyclical promise, tied to the changing seasons and the return of life, leaves the reader pondering Saeng's resilience and determination, amplifying the emotional impact of her journey.

The author concludes the story this way to show she will be alright, and remain determined despite the hardships she faces. The way she speaks of future times shows confidence that she will make it till spring, enduring the winter's challenges. The way she speaks of the test shows her determination to overcome obstacles and prove her strength. The use of the word “vowed” shows she will follow through with her statement, demonstrating her resolve and commitment to persevere.

The author concluded the story with this sentence because she's letting people know that she enjoys nature more than school. The descriptions of the vibrant forest, the sounds of the birds, and the feeling of freedom she experiences while exploring contrast sharply with any mention of her academic life. This contrast ultimately highlights her preference, solidifying the idea that she finds greater fulfillment and joy in the natural world, leading her to value it above the structured environment of school.

The author concludes this story with this paragraph because the flower is talked about all through the story, and the author emphasizes its significance by stating that when the hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again, making the hibiscus a symbol of hope and a fresh start.

The author concludes this story with this paragraph because she is telling us what will happen beyond the story we are reading. It means when the snow melts, she’ll start all over again and rebuild the greenhouse, ready to face the next season with renewed hope and determination.

I think the author concludes the story the way she did to show determination. Saeng's resolve is highlighted. I also believe that it symbolizes adaption, when the season changes, as will Saeng; she will take the test again. The changing season mirrors her own transition. Everything will soon go back to normal and will adjust just like she will. The familiar surroundings offer comfort as "everything is almost familiar to her now" (@NUM1), signifying a return to equilibrium and suggesting her resilience in the face of challenges.

The author concludes with this ending because it gives hope to the reader. It is like a happy ending to a sad story, offering a sense of resolution and optimism after the challenges presented. It is also her final thought for the story, carefully chosen to leave a lasting impression, and a good end point that provides closure and a feeling of satisfaction.

The author concludes this paragraph in the story because that's when she starts growing plants again, and she wants to start over again, signifying a renewed sense of hope and purpose after a period of stagnation or loss. The act of nurturing new life reflects her own desire for personal growth and a fresh beginning, allowing the paragraph to end on a positive, forward-looking note.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph because it explains that Saeng will try again once spring comes around. For example, "I failed the test," (Ho) shows that Saeng did fail the test, but she also thoughtfully got her mother a hibiscus to plant in her garden. Her mom feels bad about Saeng failing, so she cooks her favorite foods, like japchae, to comfort her and help her forget about failing, even if just for a little while. This is important because it makes Saeng feel a sense of comfort and relief, knowing she is supported and loved, and can therefore take the test again in confidence, strengthened by her mother's love and ready to face the challenge anew.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because of some causes. Saeng vowed silently to herself, showing she has calmed down. She feels better in her new country. The imagery of the snows meeting and the geese returning suggests a sense of hope and renewal. Her determination to take the test again indicates she no longer feels defeated by it. She recognizes the opportunity for improvement and approaches it with a renewed perspective. This shift in feeling towards the test reflects a broader change in her perspective on her challenges. She now views her new country with different eyes, suggesting acceptance and optimism. All things, therefore, seem to be improving for her, providing a hopeful and resolved ending to the story.

The author concludes the story with “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again,” to show that she will try again with a new start. When she sees the flower the clerk identifies it as a hibiscus. The hibiscus brings back fond memories of her childhood home. She then takes it home and excitedly shows the plant to her mother. Her mother replies with a surprised “You what?” hearing her daughter tell her how much it cost. With the hibiscus representing something of emotional importance, she acquires more hope. By saying she will start again once the flower has bloomed and the geese have returned, she means she will approach the test with renewed determination and a fresh start, symbolizing a hopeful future.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to show Saeng's determination despite her sadness. She misses Vietnam, but she will take the test again next year, demonstrating her resolve. The author’s choice of words in the concluding paragraph convey a sense of hope and something to look forward to. In the story, Saeng is disappointed in herself for failing the test, but buying the plant helps her because it reminds her of home and provides comfort. The idea that Saeng is persistent and the hopeful tone of the story are expressed in this final paragraph, illustrating her resilience and suggesting a positive future despite current setbacks.

The author concluded the story with that particular paragraph because it appeared to be an important thought to "Saeng" and it was basically the main cause of everything, rather the main subject of the story. She also may have concluded the story with that particular paragraph because that was her last and final thought, or memory of her previous life / lifestyle before their present place of living, thus providing a poignant reflection.

The author concludes the story with “In the spring when the snow melts and the geese return and the hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again” because Saeng fails the test by spending her money on a Big Mac and not having enough for the type of flower her mother sent for. So since Saeng failed the test, she wants to take the test again and make her mother happy. This shows Saeng's resolve to try again, hoping for a better outcome and to honor her mother's wishes when the season of renewal arrives.

I believe that author ended the story with that sentence because it gives a lifting feeling after the story was so sad. Saeng missed her homeland and the familiar comforts of her culture, and this homesickness made her sad. She used the flowers as a small piece of home, offering a bit of relief from her feelings of displacement. The disappointment surrounding her driving test added to her woes, but she genuinely liked the plant and found solace in nurturing it. So the last sentence seemed to fit in as a comfort zone, a small victory and a symbol of hope, to make the reader feel a bit more relieved after witnessing Saeng's struggles.

The author concludes the story with these final lines to create a tone of hope that creates a theme. Final lines have a great impact for the reader because it is the last thing they read. In this story, Saeng refers to the time “when the snow melts”. Here the snow is symbolic to the sorrow she has been facing because she left home. At one point in the story, “Saeng broke down and wept!” The spring is a time for archetypal rebirth. Therefore, as the “snow will melt” her sorrow will go away. This creates a tone of hope for happy times in the future. Next, Saeng refers to the time of the hibiscus budding. The hibiscus represents a comforting connection to her old country. She referred to the plant as “yet another old friend”. If the hibiscus blooms, then her new life will also bloom because she will be comforted to the point where she feels security. This creates a tone of hope for future comfort. The times ahead she speaks of are followed by a promise to take the test again despite her failure the first time. The author is using the symbolism of hope to illustrate how home that we can overcome. She is showing optimism toward the spring and is willing to face a challenge. Therefore, he uses all of that to make a hopeful home, revealing a life lesson of courage.

The author of ìWinter Hibiscusî ends the story with this paragraph because it reveals the importance of the Winter Hibiscus. In the story Saeng moves from Vietnam and feels very homesick. She fails her drivers test and is very upset. When she sees the familiar plant she is reminded of her home in Vietnam. The Winter Hibiscus reminds Saeng of fond memories with her grandmother and simple things such as her fine. Toothed buffalo-horn comb and the hibiscus hedge that would leave soft red petals in her well water, little details she treasures. When seeing the familiar plant, ìSaeng felt a shock recognition so intense, it was almost visceral. îThis shows how important the hibiscus was to her and the deep connection she still has with her homeland. The author ended the story with that paragraph to show how the winter hibiscus is a comfort to Saeng and will encourage her to do better on her next driverís test, offering her a renewed sense of hope and connection to her past as she navigates her new life.

After reading "Winter Hibiscus," I can tell that Saeng is a determined person and likes nature. I can also tell that she is determined to pass the test. The author concludes the story with this paragraph because, in the beginning of the story, Saeng fails her driving test. Disappointed, she walks home, and as she is walking, she comes across a familiar plant, the winter hibiscus. This discovery takes her back to her childhood world, offering a moment of comfort and reflection. Had she not failed the test, she would have never walked home and come across the plant. The author didn’t want us to forget the reason she walked home and experienced that poignant reconnection with her past. It would have never happened, highlighting the unexpected beauty that can arise from setbacks.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to show that next spring she will have another chance. The author shows that Saeng will relate to the blooms of the hibiscus plant and take the test again. The author does this to leave a cliffhanger, suggesting there is more to Saeng's life yet to come. In the story, Saeng is trying to get used to change and is having a hard time. Her mother's hope cheers her up, but just like winter comes, Saeng will have next spring to take the driver's test again, offering a sense of hope and anticipation for her future.

When they come back, then I will take the test again because Saeng needs time just as the hibiscus to grow. Saeng didn't do well on a test but says she will try again after snow melts and the spring comes, bringing with it renewed hope. After moving, Saeng feels alone and wants to go back home, missing the familiar faces and places. However, she feels in her heart that she can try, given time to adjust and learn. The hibiscus reminds Saeng of the flower back in her home country, a vibrant symbol of resilience, and this helps her see that she has to let go of her past, embrace her new surroundings, and live in the now.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it shows Saeng being mature about it and being confident knowing she can take it again. The final paragraph emphasizes her resolve. When it says Saeng vowed silently to herself, reflecting on everything that had happened, the phrase suggests she is going to start over, but with a renewed sense of purpose forged by her recent experience. This quiet vow underlines her growth and resilience, leaving the reader with a sense of optimism for her future.

The author concludes the story with a sentence about retaking her test when the geese are back and the hibiscus is budding because they each represent something else. The geese represent change because they change their environment in the winter just like Saeng changes her environment by going to the plant place, finding a new job, and adapting to a different culture. The hibiscus reminds her of home because at her home there are similar plants, and seeing them brings back memories of her family and familiar surroundings. The hibiscus budding represents a new life just like the one Saeng has to live in a new home, full of new opportunities and challenges. Overall, the sentence that the author ends with is used to show Saeng's life as compared to the geese and hibiscus, connecting her personal journey of adaptation and growth with the natural cycles of migration and renewal.

Saeng was happy when the snow was disappearing because she couldn't wait for spring to come back to see the animals running around by her garden and seeing the beautiful geese flying in after their long & hard hibernation. So Saeng was excited to see everything grown back, including the rare herbs she needed, so she is guaranteed to pass the botany test this time.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because Saeng was waiting for the winter time to be over. She knew the harsh cold would be too much for her precious hibiscus. After the winter time, Saeng was going to take the flower-growing test again, feeling more prepared this time, and she could finally plant the hibiscus. Saeng really liked this hibiscus, finding its vibrant color a source of joy, and she didn't want it to die in the winter time. Her patience showed her dedication to nurturing the delicate bloom.

The author concluded this story with this paragraph because she wanted to show how the flower gave the little girl strength. The girl was in a new place, and back at home where she is from, there are a lot of beautiful flowers that she loved to look at, and being in a new place that doesn't have these flowers really gets her down and has her upset. She misses her home so she is hurting, and the only thing that sort of comforts her a little bit are the flowers. For example, the girl says, ìItís-it's not a real one...I mean, not like the kind we had at...", here she stops because she is so upset that she canít say home. The flower she has right now isn't real, but when the real one blossoms in the spring, seeing the flower will comfort her and give her confidence to retake the test, representing a renewed sense of hope and resilience in her new environment.

The authorís conclusion explains her feels. The author's conclusion says to me "when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again", what it means is that she is a new woman. For example, taking the test means that she will change. Also what it means is that she is ready to take on new things. For instance, the test to her is getting ready to take on a new thing. That's what I got from the conclusion, suggesting a readiness for transformation and new challenges in her life.

The author ends with this paragraph to show that Saeng had hope. It shows that there is still hope for her future. The ending paragraph makes you kind of create your own ending for Saeng, imagining what becomes of her after all she's endured. I like to imagine Saeng with a big garden next to her, filled with the vegetables she learned about, and that she passes the test, finally achieving her dream.

I believe that the author concluded the story with this paragraph for several reasons. This final paragraph draws together and unites all the concluding ideas. It tells us that in the spring when everything is coming to life Saeng will find the strength to take the test again. These central ideas expressed in the last paragraph show how Saeng and her mother have adapted and that new things are started in the spring, as well as new possibilities. In the text it says, ìI know", her mother said quietly. ìIíve seen this kind blooming along the lake. Itís flower arenít as pretty, but itís strong enough to make it through the cold months here, this winter hibiscus.î This means and represents that even though life is different here away from Saeng's home they will adapt and survive in their own way, demonstrating their resilience and hope for the future.

The author concludes the story the way she does because it shows that Saeng needs to heal from the failing of the test before she can take it again. Saeng already knows that she can heal. She realizes that she has gotten used to where she now lives, that things in her new land, like the sound of geese, are now "familiar to her". The narrator of the story says, "...she realized that many of the things that she had thought of as strange before had become… almost familiar to her now." Things in Saeng's new home had been strange to her at first, but she had healed and gotten used to them. Saeng has also healed from leaving her original home of Vietnam. She was sad to leave her home, "A work so deep and strong that it stung Saeng's eyes now swept over her.", but she had healed. Saeng remembers the flowers that she had known in Vietnam as "old friends", showing that it did not hurt her to remember them. This demonstrates her resilience and ability to adapt to new circumstances. When Saeng heals from failing her driving test, like she had healed when moving from Vietnam to the United States, she can re-visit the test, without pain and with a renewed sense of hope.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph because it shows the character, Saeng, was going to adapt to their new home and stay strong. I believe, when Saeng’s mother says, “Its flowers aren’t as pretty, but its strong enough to make it through the cold months here, this winter hibiscus,” I think Saeng’s mother is also sort of thinking about Saeng. It's almost as if she’s saying that the move here scarred Saeng but she will be strong and survive the change like anyone who has failed a test, she will study more and try harder to pass it next time. Just like the winter hibiscus, Saeng isn’t going to give up and she’ll keep holding on to make it through. Saeng knows it’s hard to adjust to changes to life’s circumstances, but with a little courage and hard work, it will be a breeze. If she believes in herself, she’ll be able to get situated in this new place, showing her resilience.

When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again. That is in there for many reasons. One is because when winter comes and brings all the snow it kills her garden, a space she clearly cherishes. So that's why she wants it to be spring again so she can start growing things again in her garden. She got to take a test on the things that she is growing to make sure it is safe for someone to eat it. That's why I think the paragraph “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again” is significant, because it highlights her determination to resume her gardening and ensure her produce is safe after the harsh winter.

In the story "Winter Hibiscus" by Minfong Ho, the author concluded the story with an interesting paragraph. It was, "When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again" (@NUM1). This shows that the girl is adapting to her new country and hopes to do better in the spring. The reason the author ended the story with this paragraph is because it shows that the girl has successfully adapted to her new country and is determined to get stronger as time goes. She is saying when the hibiscus returns, she will be ready to take the test again and not fail it, illustrating her resilience and growing sense of belonging in her new environment.

The Hibiscus is budding means that the flower was growing. That is a flower with lots of bright colors and nothing else can beat it, especially when it is in full bloom. The reason another flower can't beat it is because that flower represents so many things and it is one of the most naturally born flowers around, making it truly unique.

The author concluded the story with that paragraph because that was how he wanted the story to end. He wanted to end the story with her talking to herself, a final, solitary reflection that encapsulated her journey and perhaps hinted at the uncertain path ahead. It was a deliberate choice to leave the reader with her internal monologue, underscoring the intensely personal nature of her experience, and ultimately providing a fitting closure to the narrative.

People have to adapt to different cultures if they move. They could do this in a variety of ways, including making new friends and adjusting to the area. However, when adjusting to a new area, you should still remember your past home as well. This is what Minfong Ho is trying to display in the ending paragraph of the story, "Winter Hibiscus". In the story, a teenage girl named Saeng moved from Vietnam to the United States. She has various rememberances of her past home while visiting a plant store. She buys a plant that was common in Vietnam and plants it in her garden. The last paragraph of the story says "In the spring, when the snow melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that driving test again". This shows Saeng’s desire to fit in with this culture, by taking the driving test, as well as remember her past, by keeping the flower. This last paragraph summarizes Saeng’s emotion for her old country as well as her determination to succeed here, showing the importance of balancing the old and the new.
Because she was promising herself that when spring comes back, with its milder weather and clearer roads, then she will take the driver's test again, hoping for a better outcome this time around.

The author concludes with this paragraph to show her determination. When she says, "when the snows melt and the geese return and his hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again," Saeng is explaining how the geese have the determination to fly back and that the hibiscus has the determination to bud again, so why shouldn’t she have the determination and confidence to take the test again? The return of the geese and the blooming of the hibiscus represent resilience and the cyclical nature of hope. Saeng said, "I-I failed the test." It seems as if failing the driving test made her feel like she was going to fail in the new country. But after she saw the geese’s and hibiscus’s determination through harsh conditions, she was determined to try the test again, drawing strength from the natural world to overcome her own perceived limitations.

The author concludes this story with that paragraph to explain how she already took the test and it is now winter, she will retake the test again when all the flowers and plants come back to life and start again in spring. Saeng wants to take the test again to show her mother that she can pass it, hoping to prove her capabilities. She bought a plant called dorl Faeng-noi for nineteen dollars, a purchase she made to help her mother not be disappointed in her. However, her mother was disappointed that she spent that much money on a plant, revealing a clash in their perspectives on value and priorities.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it shows that when she sees the things from her home and living space, it will comfort her in what she does. The author seems like she needs things from her homeland that help her make the best of things and bring back good memories of earlier life. I think that whenever I want to do a good job it helps to think of the good things that mean a lot to me so I will be happy and want to do good. The author is smart to want to see those things before retaking her test because if she sees her plant doing well and sees the memory of the geese again it will be good luck for her, enabling her to perform her best.

The author chooses to end the story with such a paragraph as this in order to show that Saeng has received a new burst of hope from her memories and the newly familiar things in her new home. The combination of the failed driverís test and being away from her original home caused Saeng to feel much loss. While Saeng is in the flower shop, ìaware of loss so deep and strong that it stung Saengís eyes now swept over her. ìThrough the rest of the story Saeng is shown to still be down, and the reader is left unsure if she will be alright. Then her recovery begins with the presence of familiar things. ìThe pungent small of bitter melon wafted out, and Saengís mouth watered,î, ìThe winter hibiscusí was in the ground nowî, and, ìoverhead a flock of Canada geese flew by, their faints honks clear and ñ yes ñ Familiar to Saeng now.î This realization that the geese are familiar to her gives way to new realization and a new wave of hope, signifying a turning point in her emotional journey. She recognizes the fact that she is now coming to be familiar with many of the things about her new hone that she had initially thought to be strange. This is what the final paragraph explains to the reader. It summarizes Saengís newfound hope that she will learn to not just live in her new home, but to thrive in it, suggesting a positive outlook for her future and adaptation.

The auther concludes the story with this statement because it shows that to her the hibiscus symbolizes overcoming obstacles. It symbolizes this because she says"…and the geese return and this is budding, I will take that test again" (Ho @NUM1). This shows that even though she failed it this time when the hibiscus gets bigger she will retake the test, it shows **hope** or overcoming obstacles. Also I believe that this symbolizes overcoming obstacles because it "gives her strength from her old country". This shows that it symbolizes overcoming obstacles because it will help her overcome this test. It will do this by giving her strength or comforting her. From this you can tell that the author ends the story with this statement **to show the hibiscus will help her get through anything**.

I believe that the author concludes the story with this paragraph because it says that Saeng is confident and is willing to go back and take the test. Saeng feels good about herself and wants to do this. This newfound self-assurance, stemming from her experience and realization of her own capabilities, empowers her to face the challenge again, highlighting a journey of growth and resilience. The ending, therefore, emphasizes Saeng's positive transformation and her proactive approach to overcoming obstacles, leaving the reader with a sense of optimism.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because Saeng was taking a test. In the story there are some quotes to support my response, like, “I-I failed the test,” Saeng said. This suggests she was taking a test. Another reason why the author concludes the story with this paragraph is because the story was about spring, gardening, and the life connected to them. The paragraph likely revisits themes of spring and flowers, echoing the story’s central focus on growth and renewal. The daughter and mother depend on plants, growing vegetables and fruits, making the test's outcome particularly relevant to their livelihood and future.

The last paragraph of the story "Winter Hibiscus" by Minfong Ho is important. The last paragraph leaves a definite ending, so the reader knows exactly what is going to happen in the future. This paragraph is a very significant ending to the story because it represents symbols in the story. The author concludes the hibiscus is important to her, signifying a connection to home. Along with the hibiscus, it also shows that the geese and the melting of the snow represent a fresh start and a new beginning. These symbols are important to her in that they give her a chance to start over, and she sees that hope reflected in the winter hibiscus.

Saeng was very distraught knowing that she didn't pass the test, and to her, it felt like a letdown, a significant disappointment. This feeling highlights the ambition and determination Saeng possesses, revealing her strong desire to succeed and pass this particular test, demonstrating her commitment to achieving her goals.

The author concludes the story with their return to show how Saeng has changed throughout the plot. In the beginning, she refers to her new home as, "walking into another world." As a teenager, she had to move from Vietnam, where traditions are so different than in the United States. However, the winter Hibiscus is one plant that provides a connection, resembling those of her previous life. The plant connects her previous life and home to the life and home she lives now. It was hard to adapt to the situation of moving, but the plant created familiar scents and the "familiar fragrance" which "filled her lungs." It was even difficult for Saeng to say the words "at home" without bursting into tears. Once the winter Hibiscus was in the ground, it changed Saeng, and she realized that she needed to appreciate what she had. In conclusion, the author ended the story with that paragraph because it showed how much the plant resembled Saeng and how her mindset on life was altered, demonstrating her growth and acceptance of her new reality.

I feel that the author concludes the story with this phrase as a way of showing how Saeng is adopting to her new home, yet still valueing her old one. The gist of the sentence is that Saeng will take her test again in the spring, showing her perseverance. However, the sentence also shows how Saeng is coming to know her new land. She says, "when the snows melt and the geese return," this is important because the geese and the snow are of her now home, and she now accepts them. Furthermore, she is looking forward to spring, a new beginning in a new place. However, Saeng also says, "when this hibiscus is budding," and this shows how Saeng is still thinking of her old home, because the plant is her connection to the memories of Vietnam, a tangible piece of her past. Therefore, I feel that the author is showing how Saeng is growing up and living with changes in her life by ending the story with this statement, illustrating her ability to embrace the present while cherishing her roots.

I think that the author is saying to day is that when it is winter the hibiscus is trying to piece the cold. While must plants just die the hibiscus must face it head on, enduring the harsh conditions rather than succumbing as other flora do, and this resilience is what the author seems to highlight.

I think the author includes this because she doesn’t want to leave her audience guessing about what would happen next. Then “I will take the test again.” This quote is saying she might have failed the test with the plant but she is never going to give up and that when spring comes she is going to try again. I feel as though the author added this to give a better understanding of how it feels to leave your homeland to come to a place you don’t know or understand such as the flower situation in the story. When she thought about the plants and how they smelt it gave her the old feelings that she had about her homeland and how close she was with her grandmother. She was so use to plants being free and growing rather than seeing them in pots and not having the room to grow. By seeing all this got Saeng to break down and cry. In conclusion I feel as though the author added the paragraph in the end for understanding and to also let you know that Saeng may be in a new place with a new culture but she will never give up on that test until she feels that she has passed it.

The author of “Winter Hibiscus” purposely had that last paragraph in there. Honestly the story is better with it too. In the last paragraph when it says “In the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” @CAPS1 @NUM1. When the author writes all those things in nature that will happen it symbolized re-birth and a fresh start, a new chance and that is what Saeng needs with her driver’s license. The author put powerfully those symbols in there to show hope for the girl to make it through her tough time. Finally, the story has a sense of roundness and ends with that last paragraph, the story is complete. The cyclical nature of the seasons mirrors Saeng's own journey, suggesting that even after setbacks, renewal is possible. This carefully crafted ending provides closure and reinforces the theme of resilience, leaving the reader with a sense of optimism about Saeng's future.

The reason I think the author concludes the story with that paragraph was because it was a good learning story you can learn something from it. The author did that so you can get a better understanding of the story. It said "ìsaeng, a teenage girl, and her family have moved to the united states of Vietnam." I believe the author of ìwinter Hibiscus ìends the story like she did because Saeng agrees to take the test again. Saeng states in the story ìitís the flowers arenít as pretty, but itís strong enough to make it through the cold months here, thes winte hibiscus. The author used "when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again" because it's resembling that her mother is refreshing, waking, and restoring its self. And Saeng said she would retake the driving test when that happens. She was really sad she failed. "I—I failed the test" She seemed to be embarrassed + sad. I, the narrator, value hibiscus because it's a valuable plant, and the garden is your own decision, reflecting your preferences, just like her mother's choice to grow hot peppers. A garden is a way to express different tastes, like the different types of foods you can plant, showcasing the diversity of the plant world, for example, hibiscus, lilies, and other plants.

The author ends the story with that paragraph because she is trying to overcome an obstacle. Failing the driver's test was a setback for Saeng, so she plans to take it again. She plans to use the hibiscus as motivation, because the winter for the hibiscus is like overcoming an obstacle, a period of dormancy before renewed growth and blooming. This connection to the hibiscus allows Saeng to view her failure not as a full stop, but as a temporary pause, encouraging her to persevere and try again.

Why I think the author concludes the story with this paragraph is because I think it’s showing how much it actually means to her and shows that she does actually care, despite any previous reluctance or indifference. And by showing that she care's, and acknowledging the importance of the outcome, she will likely take the test again, driven by a newfound sense of purpose.

She ends the story with that paragraph because she wants to let everyone know she feels most comfortable in the spring, when the world feels fresh and new. It also states that she can not wait for the geese to return and the hibiscus to start budding because it is her favorite time of the year, a time filled with hope and the promise of beautiful days ahead.

Saeng is not comfortable in her surroundings and has not adapted to the changes from where she moved. She finds the hibiscus and chooses to buy it because it reminds her of her home in Laos. When she brings it home, her mother seems shocked at first by the price Saeng had paid but is then more sympathetic when she realizes she misses Laos. Saeng says she is going to retake her test in the spring, also implying that she is going to change her attitude about living in America. The hibiscus serves as a catalyst for her to accept her new life while still holding onto her memories of home.

I think the author concludes that in the story because he is saying when the geese are coming back. This cyclical return suggests a sense of hope and renewal, implying a conclusion where life continues despite challenges. The return of the geese provides a tangible marker of time passing and a return to normalcy. This emphasizes the author's conclusive point about enduring cycles.

The author concludes that because she wants to show that Saeng was not giving up. I say this because she moved to a place where she didn't like and knew no one. The author is trying to tell us no matter what don't give up, have faith. At the end, Saeng has faith in herself that she can pass the test next time. She must have realized that just because you're at a place you don't want to, it doesn't mean you can't go on. This reinforces the idea that even in undesirable circumstances, perseverance and self-belief are crucial for overcoming challenges and achieving future success.

The author concludes the story like that to give the reader the idea that you can't just quit if you fail. Despite the setback of not passing, when Saeng said that when spring comes around I will return and take the test again, that shows that she will not quit and life will go on. This resilience in the face of disappointment emphasizes the importance of perseverance. That’s why I think the author chose to conclude the story like that, highlighting Saeng's determination and the cyclical nature of challenges and renewed efforts.

I think that the author concludes the story with this paragraph to show that she does not want to give up on fighting her homesickness. The first time she bought that plant, it brought back memories of her old home and it showed how much she missed it there. Now, even though the plant has died, symbolizing a setback, by saying she'll do the test again shows that she doesn't want to let this defeat her in her new home and her new life, demonstrating a continued commitment to adapting and building a future where she is.

The author concludes Saeng's vow in the story to show that Saeng can and does have the ability to overcome obstacles. Saeng feels like she is a failure, especially after failing her driving test. Her hibiscus represents courage to overcome her obstacle, which is her driving test that she failed, and serves as a reminder of her potential. The geese represent survival and the importance of never giving up; they symbolize the need to keep trying your hardest to achieve success, reinforcing Saeng’s resolve to persevere. Through these symbols and her vow, the author emphasizes that Saeng possesses the inner strength to confront her challenges and ultimately triumph.

The author concludes the story with this because the girl in the story is almost like the flower itself. Just as the hibiscus will blossom, Saeng will take the test again, both receiving a fresh start on things and symbolizing hope for the future. Finishing the story this way left the reader feeling positive; it was a short ending but one with a lot of meaning. “...and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” I think the last sentence is almost inspirational and it makes you want to start out fresh as well as Saeng, understanding that new beginnings are always possible.

The author ends the story with ìWhen they come back, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test againî for many good reasons. Some reasons are that she will keep moving on and adapting to her new life in Canada, embracing the cyclical nature of life and her own growth. She is going to change her way of life and try to fit in with her new culture, showing a willingness to integrate and learn. She is also going to have to relive the memory of her grandmother again and wants to handle it better, seeking closure and acceptance with the passage of time. ìA wave of loss so deep and strong that it stung Saengís eye now swept over her.î She wants to be able to handle the loss better, suggesting a future attempt to reconcile her grief. The author wants to emphasize that the story is not yet over, and her journey of assimilation and healing will continue into the next season.

There are many reasons the narrator could have ended with this paragraph. One reason is the start of the winter, so hibiscus won't return until spring. Also, it's the end of the story, so it's a good way to end it because it's the ending of the hibiscus and the ending of the story. The last paragraph also kind of summarizes the story and it's short and sweet, which makes it a great ending. It's not like most endings to a story, so it's unique, because most stories aren't about nature. It's a fitting conclusion because it leaves the reader with a sense of closure and reflection on the cyclical nature of life, mirroring the hibiscus's seasonal disappearance and return. In conclusion, there are many reasons the narrator could have chosen to end the story with this paragraph.

The author concludes the story with his paragraph to show how people can regain their determination. In the beginning of the story, Saeng is disheartened after failing her driving test. When she sees the Hibiscus in her mother's garden, she is filled with memories of the past and weeps. Her mother's kindness and gentle words cause Saeng to draw strength from the flower, which, as her mother says, is "strong enough to make it through the cold months here." Knowing that the Hibiscus will bud in the spring, Saeng renews her determination to pass the test, understanding that perseverance, like the flower's resilience, can lead to future success.

The author concludes with this response because he suggests Saeng will likely repeat her patterns, but with a shift in focus. She will likely continue her dedicated approach, directing it towards being more helpful not only in the garden but also to her mother’s needs. The implication is that she will also apply herself more diligently to her schoolwork, perhaps finding a better balance with her passion for gardening; thus, she will channel her energy into areas where she can contribute more broadly, leading to a more well-rounded and supportive role within her family and academics.

The author ended the story with that paragraph in order to show that Saeng is looking forward into her life and with a positive outlook. The author concludes the story with this paragraph ìSaeng vowed silently to herselfî because she wants to do things in proper time and season. At the end of the short story “Winter Hibiscus,” Saeng says “when they come back, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and the hibiscus is budding then I will take that test again." The author is trying to convey a sense of hope for Saeng in her new country. The author concludes the story with this paragraph to tell us that she will try and find that flower to bring back memories of her old home, and to show us that it will survive even though it's not from where she wanted it to be from. In the story it says, "I failed the test," meaning Saeng had bought the hibiscus that wasn't real or what she thought wasn't what she wanted it to be. The Author was trying to end the story quick thats why he ended it with this one. He likely felt pressured by deadlines or perhaps lost inspiration for the complex narrative he initially envisioned, leading him to resolve the plot with uncharacteristic haste. The abrupt conclusion, though unsatisfying, suggests a desire to simply finish the project and move on, sacrificing depth for the sake of completion. Ultimately, this rushed ending leaves the reader with a sense of incompleteness, highlighting the author's need to finalize the story quickly, even if it meant compromising its overall quality.

When spring comes and all the snow melts then she is going to plant new seeds. The author concludes that because she didn’t do good on the test the first time. In the story "Winter Hibiscus" is about this girl named Saeng and her mother and grandmother. Flowers are beautiful to them; they plant them all day. The author concludes the story with the saying because it shows that she has confidence in herself. Because she did not pass the test, she could take it again and know she can pass the test. When winter ends and the geese return from the south, signaling the arrival of spring, and when her favorite plant, reminiscent of her homeland, blooms once more, she will attempt again what she had previously tried. This time, however, she will approach the task with a newfound sense of confidence, bolstered perhaps by the passing of time and the lessons learned from her previous experience, allowing her to feel more secure and ready to achieve her goal.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it sums everything up and addresses the conflict of her failing her driver's test. And like the geese who persevere, she will return and face the challenge again, demonstrating resilience.

In the story ì Winter Hibiscusî by Minfong Ho the author ends the story in a well mannered carhoined. The author ended with that paragraph to show that Saeng was not going to persuade even though for away from home. She is in a down was spiral at the beginning of the story, she had failed a test and the hibiscus triggered her feeling nostalgic. Well in the story, Saeng fails her driving test. Disheartened, as she is walking home she sees a familiar plant growing near a fence. Intrigued, she then goes to a florist and finds out the plant is called a hibiscus. She then buys the plant with the little money she has because its vibrant color and shape reminds her of her homeland and childhood. It also reminds her of her grandmother who she left behind, a comforting reminder of her, so now she feels connected to the plant. Also, she sees geese fly overhead heading south for the winter, a sign of the changing season, so she says “When they come back,” so she means when the geese fly north for spring. And when “the snow melts," so when it becomes warmer and starts spring. When “this hibiscus is budding,” so when spring comes and the plant starts to bloom, a symbol of new beginnings, she will “take that test again," so she says she will take the driving test that she failed when spring comes. She gives herself the winter to practice and get ready for the test, using the time to improve her skills and confidence. She vows to herself that come spring, a time of renewal and growth, she will be ready to take the test and this time she will pass, symbolizing her own personal growth and resilience.

She said this to show the determination it takes to make it; no matter how many times you fail, you need to get back up and try again. She displays her courage in this way also, as it takes a lot for someone to fail at something and to get back up and try again on it. Her resolve is evident in her willingness to persevere. She isn't willing to accept failure, and she's trying to redeem her failure, so she says she'll try again. That is why she ended the story that way, demonstrating a commitment to overcoming obstacles and ultimately achieving success.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph. I think the author did this so that people who read the story will know what she is gonna do next spring and they might make out another story in so that you will know that she will take the test in the spring, leaving the reader with a sense of anticipation about her future endeavors. This ending provides closure while simultaneously hinting at a potential continuation of her narrative, centered around the test she will face in the spring.

In the story "Winter Hibiscus," the author concludes with that paragraph because when winter hits, the plant she likes will disappear. The flower gave her good luck, so she said, "When the snow melts in the spring and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again." The flower was very important to her. She said, "that rich, sweet scent that was familiar too." She was talking about the flower's smell compared to her grandmother's shell; it was the same, evoking a sense of comfort and connection that strengthened her resolve to try again in the spring.

The author concludes the story like this because she is going to come back and do the same thing next year, already anticipating the familiar joy and challenge. She knows the rhythms of the place, the subtle shifts in light and color, and the comforting predictability of the task ahead. The ending, therefore, isn't a farewell, but a promise of return, fueled by a deep appreciation for the experience and a quiet determination to repeat it all again.

The author concludes the story with that because she wants to retake the test. She knows she needs to study harder this time. The author concludes the story with this paragraph because everything in the story will repeat, such as the season changes, and you will not be able to plant nor grow in the winter. The author concludes the response by saying that when spring comes and the hibiscus is budding she will take the test again, because I think she feels hope and faith. when they come back Saeng vowed silently to herself. The memory of her previous attempt stung, but resolve hardened within her. In the spring when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus budding, then I will take that test again, better prepared and more determined than before.

In "Hibiscus" by Pham Thi Hoai, the author chose the last paragraph because it matched the tone, the hope, and the representation of the essay. The tone of the story is one of a depressful mood because Saeng failed her driver's test, so she is very upset. Her memories of her old country start to affect her when she sees the winter hibiscus. "And in the warm moist shelter of the greenhouse, Saeng broke down and wept." She misses Vietnam very much, and seeing this plant in this store gives her flashbacks. The winter starts to give her the feels; all hope feels lost. "almost reluctantly, she realized that many of the things that she had thought of as strange before had become through the quiet repetition of season upon season, almost familiar to her now." To her, the strange things are starting to feel the same year by year; no new hope, no new anything, just the same old thing day by day. This plant really starts to tear her apart purely from the representation. "She found that she was still too shaky to say the word at home, lest she burst into tears again." She can't say home because home isn't here in the United States but in Vietnam. This winter hibiscus gives Saeng an explosion of immense emotions, all having to deal with her past, so the last paragraph is more giving to how when her hope returns in spring she will just try again. Tone, hope, and representation all support the last paragraph, so that's why it fits when it does, providing a sense of closure and suggesting a potential for renewal despite her current struggles.

This was a very interesting story and it snowed all the hardships this young girl has gone through, the author ended it in a very interesting way. When they ended the story I thought to myself how nice it ended. If think the author did a very nice job. Then as the author said, “as the snow melts away,” I think this shows how even though Saeng's problems seem never ending and harsh, that one day they will be gone and things will become beautiful again, like the flower budding in the spring time. Also she did a nice job because throughout the story I could feel her pain. I felt as if I was there with her because of her use of descriptive words like, “exploding, shock, intense” and others to describe how much of a sudden everything was. Then when she ended it, it was like she was showing us Saeng’s hope for a better future, even though things aren’t the way they were back home, offering a sense of closure and optimism for Saeng's journey ahead.

The author concludes the story with the paragraph -ì when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again.î because she feels that when the hibiscus blooms she can too bloom by passing the test. Also Saeng is relating herself to the hibiscus. ìItsí flower arnít as pretty, but itís strong enough to make it throu in here, this winter hibiscus.î Her mother is trying to tell her she can be strong also, drawing a parallel between Saeng's resilience and the hibiscus's ability to endure. The author concludes this paragraph in this story because it sounds good and to show the people he is writing it to that no matter what happens to you in life you should just keep on doing what you think is best for you, just like the flower; she keeps coming back for more after going through all that's tough, demonstrating resilience and the importance of pursuing one's path despite adversity.

I think the author concludes the story with that paragraph because at the end it's talking of a new beginning. By the end of the story, she has more confidence that she will succeed next time, demonstrating a renewed sense of hope and determination after connecting with something familiar and receiving her mother’s empathy.

Minfong Ho ended the story with a phrase of dialogue because it was about the main topic of the story. Saeng was to buy a plant and bring it home, but when she did so, her mother did not approve. The narrative states "You what?" Her mother stared at her incredulously"(Ho). When her mother said this, it showed that she was displeased, highlighting the central conflict. The narrative states, "I-I failed the test"(Ho), further emphasizing Saeng's disappointment. Saeng was not proud to displease her parents in any way. By saying, "When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again"(Ho), the author is just showing Saeng's love and want to grow for her parents; it shows maturity and determination to reconcile her actions with her parents' expectations, thus concluding the story with a sense of hope and resolve.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to tell the reader that Saeng is going to take the test again. The author wants to tell the reader because she failed the test and now she knows what she did wrong, and she's going to correct it. For example when Saeng said, “then I will take that test again,” Saeng felt sorry she failed a simple test, so she wants to retake the test when the snow melts, showcasing her determination to improve and succeed next time.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because the plant wasn't budding and the geese were going away, and then she failed the test because all that made her sad. The gray skies and bare branches mirrored her inner state, making concentration impossible. But when the snow melts, the geese return, their honking filling the air with life, and the plant starts budding, showing tiny signs of green, she will be happy again. The returning vitality of nature will lift her spirits, and she will take the test again, her mind clear and focused, and she will pass because she is happy and hopeful.

The author concludes the story this way for many reasons. One reason is to show Saeng is not going to give up and will keep trying to pass her test, demonstrating her resilience. Another way is to show that even though your life has changed, that doesn't mean that you have to give up on your goals or dreams. These are some of the ways that the author concludes the story, highlighting themes of perseverance and adapting to change.

I think the author concluded the story with this paragraph because they wanted to show that she is committed to her nature, especially to the hibiscus. She thought that the hibiscus was special because of what she did with it. Like when they said “she reached out and touched a petal gently. It felt smooth and cool, with a hint of velvet toward the centre”. This detail emphasizes her connection to the flower, solidifying the idea that it represents something significant to her. And that’s why I think the author concluded the story with this paragraph, using the hibiscus as a final symbol of her enduring spirit.

I think that the author concludes the story with this paragraph is because Saeng feels like that will be the right time to take over her driving test, when the hibiscus is budding and signaling a time of renewal and potential. And another reason would be because the author wants to showcase her unwavering determination, highlighting Saeng's resolve to succeed despite previous setbacks and connect her personal growth to the natural cycle of blossoming.

She vowed this paragraph because she wanted to make her mother proud by passing the test after she had failed it, but she waits for the plant to go through and start budding. The hibiscus bud is like a new start, so if it makes it through winter, she will pass the test. Then Saeng will be able to pass as well, because she knows if a tropical plant was able to survive a harsh winter, then she can survive and pass the test the next spring, proving her resilience and determination.

I think the author concludes the last paragraph in the story because it's kind of like a moral to the story. She's trying to say that when the time is right, she will try it again until she gets it right, showing resilience and determination. Without this last paragraph, you wouldn't be able to fully understand the message of the story, which is about perseverance and the willingness to learn from past experiences. This final thought encapsulates the protagonist's hope and resolve, reinforcing the story's central theme of continuous self-improvement.

Saeng is a very helpful young lady to her mom; she makes things easier. The author made that the ending sentence to make the story more interesting for the reader and to keep them hooked to the end, hinting at Saeng's deeper motivations and the impact of her helpfulness, leaving the audience eager to discover more about her character and the unfolding narrative.

The author concludes the story with that sentence because she wanted to explain to you that she will do this again when the hibiscus is back in season, suggesting a cyclical nature to her actions tied to the blooming of the flower.

I guess she says this because she only wants to take the test when she is comfortable around the flowers, plants, and greens, suggesting her performance might be affected by her environment and she needs a calming, natural setting to feel at ease and perform optimally. Therefore, she believes a familiar and pleasant atmosphere is crucial for her to showcase her best abilities.

I think that the author concludes the story with this paragraph because it says when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding then I will take the test again, showing a cyclical return and a promise of future readiness. This means that when she gets older and gains more experience, and thus more confidence, then she will blossom and get to take the test when she is ready, just like the hibiscus will be ready to start budding again after the winter, signifying a time of renewed growth and potential. This evokes a sense of hope and anticipation for the future.

The Author ends the story off with that paragraph because when dealing with flowers and nature, there are seasons when the flowers don’t come up, like winter for example. The paragraph is saying that in the spring, when the winter is over, she tells herself that she will look forward to seeing all the plants that nature has to give, implying a cycle of hope and renewal after a period of dormancy. This reflects a broader theme of resilience and anticipation for future growth.

I believe he used this as the ending to ensure that she was strong and she would do whatever it took to persevere. He likely wanted to forge her resilience, knowing the road ahead would be fraught with challenges. This difficult conclusion, therefore, wasn't about punishment, but about instilling an unyielding spirit, a vital ingredient for survival and ultimate triumph. He aimed to equip her with the mental fortitude necessary to overcome any obstacle, thus ensuring her future success and demonstrating his faith in her capacity to endure.

The author includes this sentence in the paragraph because it’s the start of a new beginning, signaling a shift in focus and potentially introducing a fresh perspective on the topic at hand. This new beginning could represent a change in the narrative, a different approach to the argument, or even the introduction of new characters or settings, thus setting the stage for further developments. Therefore, this sentence serves as a pivotal point, guiding the reader towards a new direction in the text.

In the story the author concludes with “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” I think she did that to say that you shouldn’t give up. In the story Saeng goes to the store and “touched a petal.” She buys the plant in an attempt to get a reminder of her old home. It seems Saeng is not willing to give up her memories of her past, as she seeks to hold onto them through the hibiscus. When she brings home the plant and her mom helps her plant it in the garden, I think Saeng is trying to make her new home like her old. In this way, Saeng is working to create a sense of continuity and connection to her past, rather than forgetting it.

The author, Minfong Ho, concludes the story with Saeng vowing to take the test in the spring when the geese return, the snow melts, and the hibiscus is budding. This is done to symbolize the many things that Saeng learnt. For example, she learnt she has to adjust to changes in her life and becoming familiar to the new things. The geese and snow she admits are the things that were “strange before [and] had become familiar to her now.” The hibiscus also represents something and has a reason for being included in the last paragraph. It represents the ability to overcome obstacles, connection to the past, and comfort when needed, reminding her perhaps of her grandmother's strength. The last paragraph symbolizes many things, and if you look into it deeply, you will learn what Saeng learnt, which is the embrace of both the new and the old.

The author ends the story with Saeng vowing to herself about the relationship between passing and driving test and the significance of the hibiscus flower. The flower is linked to the way things used to be for her in Vietnam; for example, hibiscus in @LOCATION3 was ìMadagascar periwinkleî in Vietnam. It also symbolizes how the flower adapts to its surrounding when taken from a different country in accordance to Saeng adjusting to life in @LOCATION3. The reason she said when spring comes she will take the test again symbolizes that connection of the flower to the way she lives now, reflecting her resilience. For instance, her ability and determination that when that flower buds she will overcome obstacles, like passing the driving test. Another is a connection of her past experiences, a comforting reminder of home. And it was a sense of comforting to her after she failed her driving test, offering solace and renewed motivation. The author linked the flowerís significance to the ending of the story showing the hope and dedication within Saeng, highlighting her determination to overcome the obstacles she faces to get where she is today.

The reason why I believe the author concluded the story like that, is because she is always going to start over. For instance, in the story she said "I failed the test." From that moment, she thought she was going to give up. So, the ending emphasizes her resilience; even with setbacks, she embraces new beginnings, showing that failure doesn't define her journey, but rather fuels her continuous efforts to improve and move forward. That is why I believe she ended the story with that line.

The author concluded the story with that paragraph because the author is trying to say that Saeng is going to start all over again just like the hibiscus would, blooming anew. Even though you go through bad times in your life, just step up and do it over again until it becomes better, finding renewed strength. The author also concluded the story with that paragraph because the paragraph pretty much starts the story all over again, suggesting that like Saeng was going to do, life offers cycles of renewal and opportunity.

She means that when she returns, she's planning to repeat the same task or process. She wants to give it another shot, essentially, and see if she can achieve a better outcome this time around. This implies a desire for improvement and a belief that with another attempt, she might perform better.

Saeng vowed silently to herself, "In the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again," because her mind went off track from thinking about a flower. She noticed, "One of the blossoms had fallen off," then carefully Saeng picked it up and smelled it. It happily distracted her mind. Her promise regarding the test was silenced for a long moment, and she didn't say anything. Her mother never got mad. All she did was brush the fragments of green off Saeng's hands. Her mother was mainly thinking about the plants as the day went on. Saeng dug out a hole and carefully lowered the 'winter hibiscus' into it. Seeing her mother caused a reaction of ideas, so she tried to etch an image of geese. She felt she could even send a goat to retake the driving test, as she was getting used to her new surroundings. The intro states, "Saeng, a teenage girl, has moved to the United States from Vietnam," and this move, along with the hibiscus, was clearly weighing on her mind.

The author included this paragraph to show how much the girl missed Vietnam. When the girl saw the hibiscus it brought back memories of Vietnam. Seeing the hibiscus allows her to find comfort. So the paragraph is there to show, in part, how the United States is different from Vietnam. Since the United States has changing seasons it allows the girl to get use to the United States. The plant will always be there, a reminder of her past, but she has to look for the good that United States provides. The author states, ìAlmost reluctantly, she realized that many of the things she had thought of as strange before had become, through the quiet repetition of season upon season, almost familiar to her now.î This quote shows how the girl was getting use to the United States. How she will always remember Vietnam, and finds things in the United States that remind her of Vietnam, helping her bridge the gap between her past and present. In conclusion, the paragraph is used to show how much the girl missed Vietnam, but how she finds comfort within the United States, suggesting a gradual process of adaptation and acceptance.

These basically say that he will be around again just like the geese always come back, returning with the seasons in their familiar V-formation, a constant presence in the cyclical rhythm of nature. This imagery suggests a predictable and inevitable return, much like the unchanging patterns of the natural world. Thus, the assurance of his eventual reappearance echoes the reliability of the migrating geese.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph for several reasons. One being that she is still uncomfortable about talking about her old home; she was still yet to say the words "at home." The snow melting, the geese returning, and the hibiscus budding all remind her of her home. We know this because Saeng says, "Just as she known it would feel..." Back home, it would "grow wild just at from the cracks in the brick walls or between tiled roofs." So, with reminders of her home, she is given both comfort and confidence. The author therefore concluded with this paragraph because since the geese, hibiscus, and the snow melting remind her of her home, that is when she will take the test again, when she is confident and strong enough to face the challenges ahead.

By adding this paragraph to the end of the story, it shows that a resolution was made and that the theme of overcoming obstacles is present in the story. When Saeng failed the test, she was miserable and heartbroken however, after buying the hibiscus, she had found hope and motivation and decides, in the end, that she will take the test again, ìin the spring, when the snow melt, and the geese return and this hibiscus is buddingî. This hope at the end of the story helps put the reader at ease when they wonder what might happen next, and it helps move the story to a conclusion. This is why most endings are meaningful like this; readers are able to obtain the message as the story ends through paragraphs like this. In this case, the authorís message was to never give up and that people find motivation in simple things, showing that even in defeat, renewal is possible. It is important to know what an author is trying to tell the reader through paragraphs as not only a reader trying to understand the purpose of a story, but also as a writer trying to express their ideas clearly to an audience, making the narrative resonate more deeply.

I think that the author uses this quote, ìwhen they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and the hibiscus is buding, then I will take the test  again.î It symbolizes that spring brings new life and hope. ìBut where was the home thought come? The hibiscus hedge? The way her gentle grandmother?î ìBOAT RIDE into the night and it was gone.î from Vietnam to a foreign land. One night she had so much hope, like, abundance, then the next she is in foreign land that is nothing like her old home. The flowers bloom in the spring bringing new life, and she associates that with taking the test again. There is a chance to move on; there is hope. There is hope that spring will come, flowers will come, birds will come. It is a chance to let go of the old and embrace the new. The ending quote was said to bring hope and like to her and she sort of promises to herself that it will get better. Hope is what makes every obstacle easier to get over and everything bearable, suggesting that Saeng's internal promise is a critical tool for navigating her new, unfamiliar world.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to show that the hibiscus is a symbol for Saeng. In the springtime the hibiscus grows just like Saeng. When Saeng got to the new place she was small and puny just like the plant. "Its leaves quavering in the wind" (@NUM1). This quote tells us that the plant was weak and puny. If the plant was strong it would not be quivering. The fact that Saeng broke down and bought the plant tells us she was not strong. And at the end the author uses that paragraph to tell the reader that the hibiscus is strong and so is Saeng and they can overcome anything, demonstrating their shared resilience and ability to flourish despite initial hardships.

The author concludes the story this way to show Saeng does not give up and is determined to pass the test. The narration says ìNot like the kind we had @NUM1]. Saeng feels very strongly about her old home and wants hibiscus just like she and her grandmother used to have. Because Saeng would not bring back the same kind of hibiscus, she is sad and determined to get another one. The text also states, ìÖ and the hibiscus is budding then I will take the test @NUM2]. This also shows she is determined because even though she failed the test once she is going it to try again, demonstrating her resilience. She misses her home and wants hibiscus just like she had at her old home, revealing her deep connection to her past and fueling her resolve to succeed. Therefore, Saeng's actions highlight her unwavering spirit and commitment to achieving her goals despite setbacks.

In this story the reason that the author concludes things this way is to pick a tone that feels comfortable to test again.
