This comfortable tone ultimately helps her approach the test with a renewed sense of confidence.

The author concluded this because she thinks this is the right time to retake the test. She adds this because the snow is melted, the hibiscus is budding, and the geese's return is a perfect time because everything is back and warm. She believes this signifies a period of renewal and growth, mirroring her own readiness. She says "when they come back...then I will take the test again" means she will have all the confidence to take the test, drawing strength from the positive changes around her. Saeng vowed to take it again, and she will; she thinks this time she will pass, fueled by the optimism of the season. That's what the author concludes this to the story, suggesting a hopeful outlook and a belief in the power of timing and perseverance.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to show the hope and the meaning of the hibiscus to Saeng. The author also ends the story like that because spring is a time for new beginnings and where everything comes back to life and starts to regrow, so to say that when the snow melts and geese return, it's saying it's the right time for a second chance. "It failed the test," Saeng said. She tore off a leaf, shredding it to pieces; that shows the dying of the hope she had, or the hibiscus symbolized it. So that’s why the author ended it like that because it shows new beginnings, suggesting that even in failure, there is the potential for growth and renewal, offering a sense of optimism despite the immediate disappointment.

The author concludes the story, “Winter Hibiscus,” with the strong, one-sentence paragraph stating that Saeng will take the test when the geese return and the hibiscus is budding. This sentence leaves the reader in suspense while incorporating the main point of the story and combining them to express an idea about what might happen in a continuation of the future of Saeng and this story. After all, the reason Saeng had bought the hibiscus was to comfort her mother and herself during a difficult time. While she stood watching the geese, the author chose this moment to express Saeng’s feelings of determination to stay strong and take the test. In the end, the author concluded the story with a striking sentence which not only summarized the story's key themes but also left a cliffhanger, suggesting hope and renewal for Saeng's future endeavors.

ìWhen they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself ,in the spring ,when snows melt and geese return and  this hibiscus is budding ,then I will take the test againî. The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it makes you think about the story after you're done reading it. Saeng's determination, tied to the natural cycle of renewal, leaves us contemplating her future and the cyclical nature of hope, challenge, and perseverance. This cyclical structure highlights the enduring human spirit, suggesting that setbacks are not final but rather opportunities for renewed effort, symbolized by the return of spring and the blooming hibiscus.

In many stories the narrator uses a dramatic yet conclusive statement to end the story. An example of one such occurrence is in the short story ìWinter Hibiscusî. In the story the young girl finishes off by telling us when she will be taking her test again, although not directly to us as it says ìSaeng vowed silently to herselfî but it still informs the reader. The reason the author includes this last ìvowî is to inform not only the reader of the future but to show the girl's determination and spiritual connection with the plant, particularly its resilience mirroring her own. For example, when it says ìand this hibiscus is buddingî it’s showing the girl's connection with the plant because of the comfort and confidence it has given her, especially since she needs to take the test and succeed. In conclusion, the narrator concluded the story with the paragraph to show future events and to illustrate the spiritual connection the girl had with the flower and the homeland, solidifying the themes of perseverance and hope.

In the story, at the end of the last paragraph the author wrote that “why they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again” (last paragraph). Even though Saeng is so interested in flowers, particularly the hibiscus, she also cares about her school too. When the snows melt Saeng will take the test, connecting her academic life with the natural world she so admires, just like the hibiscus is budding and starting to blossom. This shows her commitment to both her passions and her responsibilities.

After they come Saeng was silently to herself, "In the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and the hibiscus is Saeng, then I am take that test again." Due to failing her driving test things herself was thing for her to United State was so different from Vietnam and she expresses her feelings will she talk a about this something flower, a flower that perhaps reminds her of home, a vibrant splash of color in a landscape that feels so foreign, connecting her past vows to her present struggles.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because she wants to remind the reader and summarize the story. The way she summarizes is by mirroring the beginning, where Saeng failed the test, with the ending, where Saeng plants the hibiscus in winter. The author wants to remind the reader about the journey of the whole story, highlighting the transformation and perhaps the cyclical nature of hope and perseverance.

He concludes this story like that so you dont feel as if she was defeated. She is now more aware or believes she can complete the task. Also she has more selfconcious in herself because of the flower and now it reminds her of her home, giving her a renewed sense of purpose and determination as she faces future challenges.

The author concluded the story with this because just like the flower it will come back anew, and so will she. The flower represents determination, using the flower to show her own determination. Even though she failed her driver's test, she still has determination to take it and try to pass again, viewing the flower as a symbol of resilience. Even with failure, she is determined to get over it. Just like the flower losing its buds in the winter and growing them back, Saeng is forgetting her failure and coming back anew, ready to face the challenge again with renewed hope.

The author uses this paragraph as a symbol of realization and a new beginning for Saeng. She spent so much time missing the past that she didn’t know how to enjoy the present, which theme-wise the author is saying “live in the moment.” The hibiscus represents strength, as her mother said, "It's strong enough to make it through the winter months,... that’s what matters." Symbolically, the hibiscus flowering even after hardship shows the potential for joy after sorrow. Ultimately, the author is saying that tough times are inevitable, so hold on to the moments that make you smile, for they will help you persevere through the times that are tough. In essence, the flower embodies resilience and the importance of cherishing present joys to weather future storms.

In the story ìWinter Hibiscusî by Minfong Ho the character Saeng had many obstacles to overcome. In the end of the story Saeng vows to herself when winter is over she will take the test again. I think that the author ends the story like that to foreshadow the future for Saeng. It seems like the author is trying to say Saeng will be taking time to adjust to her new lifestyle and focus on other things before she takes the test again, now that she better understands the culture and expectations. It also shows that Saeng has a lot of courage to complete what she has once failed, revealing her resilient spirit. The perserverance in Saeng shows and will help her overcome many things in her new country. In the text when Saeng's mother starts to dig a hole she says ìlet me help mother.î This shows her love towards her mother and her care for the plant that represents her pastime, further emphasizing their bond and shared hope. So in the end of the story adding the vow was a good way to show Saengís commitment to her future success, suggesting a promising path ahead despite initial setbacks.

The author puts that excerpt into the text to show the reader that she had made a mistake and will fix it in the future. I believe the author put it in for that reason because in the text Saeng began to cry when she admitted to her mother that she failed the test, highlighting her disappointment. This shows that she was really upset by the fact she failed and hopes to improve in the near future, suggesting a determination to overcome this setback. Another reason why I believe the author concludes the story like this is to lead the reader on to believe Saeng is going to get over being homesick, implying a future where she adapts and thrives despite her initial struggles.

The author ends the story “Winter Hibiscus” with the passage “When they come back Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” She is saying how she is going to try to take the test again because of the fact that she failed the first time. I think the hibiscus she bought comforted her and made her think of her homeland, with its vibrant life and promise of renewal, so she thought when the hibiscus is budding she will take the test again. The plant made her think positively. And instead of thinking she will fail she is thinking she will pass the next time. I also think Saeng felt comfort in nurturing the plant when she was upset, and I think that helped her feel a lot better; tending to the hibiscus provided a sense of purpose and a tangible reminder of home, allowing her to approach her future studies with renewed hope.

The author concludes the story, “Winter Hibiscus,” with that paragraph as a sign of reassurance. Saeng had had a tough few years adapting to the United States from Vietnam, and this paragraph leaves the reader with hope that she will overcome this challenge just like a bump in the road. Saeng had just had a rough day after failing her driver’s test and wanted to buy the plant she saw on her walk home. While in the greenhouse she says, “That, at least, she could hold on to. But where was the fine-toothed comb? The hibiscus hedge? The well? Her gentle grandmother?” Saeng missed all these things from Vietnam, especially during this rough time of transition. The final paragraph gives hope that she will take the test again and it will all be okay, suggesting resilience. The winter is a symbol of the hardships she has and will continue to go through. It says, “in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and the hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” The winter is a hardship for the geese in that they must move away, the hibiscus must survive the cold winter, and the winter is a time Saeng will be away from Vietnam in spirit. As the geese and the hibiscus overcome it, so will she. This last paragraph is a good, positive, and hopeful ending to this touching story, so the reader knows to have hope in life, even amidst difficulties.

There is why the author ended the story with this paragraph. It means that when she comes back after winter she will repeat her tasks all over. For example, she will dig, sow flowers, and serve their customers. Then when winter comes again, she will do it all over. So essentially the author is using different words to say when winter ends she will repeat her actions. That is why the author ended the story with that paragraph, emphasizing the cyclical nature of her work and life.

The author brought out the paragraph "when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again", to portray the theme of hope and perseverance in the story. Saeng used the hibiscus, a symbol of resilience and beauty, for hope in her life, connecting her personal aspirations to the natural cycle of renewal. The author also uses the choice of words or diction, such as "spring," "snows melt," and "budding," to explain the way Saeng lived her life depending on a flower and the changing seasons, highlighting her patient anticipation. The paragraph also subtly explains the way her culture, with its deep connection to nature and the rhythm of the seasons, is depending on the theme of the story, where personal milestones are intertwined with natural events, emphasizing the cyclical nature of life and the enduring power of hope.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because the plant brings back memories to Saeng, and she is sort of like the plant. Saeng can be compared to the plant by how she is starting out in a new area that she is unfamiliar with, as is the plant. The plant is now being planted in the soil outside her house and has to grow. Saeng has to learn to grow as well and get better and prepare to take the test again, embracing her new life. So, when the plant is grown and adapted, Saeng believes she will be grown and adapted too. In conclusion, this paragraph is a perfect ending for the story "Winter Hibiscus" by Minfong Ho because it symbolizes Saeng's hope for the future and her ability to adapt and thrive in a new environment.

I think that the author ends this story with that paragraph to sum up what the story was all about and to also suggest that Saeng would try the test again. In the story it says she realised that many of the things that she had thought of as strange before had become, through the quiet repetition of season upon season, almost familiar to her now, and this last paragraph helps bring all this together, showing her growing comfort and perhaps hinting at a future attempt, fueled by her increased understanding.

A vow is a good ending; she vowed to take the test again because she failed it. It expresses how she feels, and she made a commitment to pass. The author wanted to show a lot of feeling and how desperate she was, showcasing her determination. So she saw tons of beauty to keep her going, fueling her resolve and reinforcing her pledge. This act of finding beauty highlights her strength and dedication.

The author concludes the story with the paragraph, "When they come back," Saeng vowed silently to herself, "in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again." She buys the flower because she failed the driver's test, a disappointment she feels deeply. She has seen the familiar plant on her way home as she went to a florist shop to try and buy one, its vibrant color catching her eye and stirring a sense of comfort within her. The flower makes her happy and reminds her of home, a connection to her roots in this new place. The author ends the story the way he does because it leaves hope, so that the story doesn't end sad, emphasizing the cyclical nature of life and second chances. She still has hope of passing the driver's test, symbolized by the recurring seasons and the promise of the hibiscus's bloom, suggesting a renewed determination and a brighter future.

She failed the test the same day she got the plant and saw the geese fly over. The plant and the geese represent symbols to her: the plant represents her home, where she used to live, and the geese represent how they are moving on in life, overcoming the obstacles of cold weather and snow to move on to something better, most likely a warmer climate. All of this is a symbol of a new beginning for her, signaling a fresh start. So, she wanted to take it again around the time of a new beginning – when the geese fly over again and the plant grows, as these coinciding events will provide her with a sense of reassurance. She feels that since she failed, she should start over, aligning her efforts with nature's cycle of renewal to enhance her chance of success.

The author added the story in with this paragraph for a lot reasons, including to make the story longer, and also to show that even if you screw up the first time you can still try again. The inclusion serves to build suspense and provide a richer, more detailed narrative for the reader. By showcasing a character's initial failure, the author emphasizes the importance of perseverance and highlights the possibility of redemption through renewed effort. In the short story "Winter Hibiscus" by Minfong Ho, the author concludes with a paragraph explaining when the character, Saeng will take her driving test again. Saeng says that when “this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” Just as the hibiscus bravely blooms, even in harsh conditions, Saeng will bloom forth and strive through the winter to try and succeed in passing her test. Saeng concludes by saying this as a realization that she can’t be sad forever about failing. She must be determined, like the persistent hibiscus, in order to pass the test. The next season will be a sort of renewal, starting fresh and coming out beautiful as does a hibiscus in bloom, demonstrating her resilience.

The Author of ìWinter Hibiscusî, Minfong Ho, concluded her story with the paragraph about how when the geese are there, and the hibiscus is blooming, Saeng will take her drivers test again, because she wanted to end on a happy note. In the beginning of the story, Saeng, who had just moved from Vietnam to the United States, failed her drivers test. She had found a plant they had back in Vietnam, but it made her sad. ìI mean itís not like the kind we had at ñ at-" she found that she was still too shaky to say the words 'at home', lest she burst into tears again.î (Ho, 124). So by ending by describing positive things for the future, Saeng could think about that, and get her mind off of everything else, providing a sense of hope and renewal after a period of adjustment and sadness.

The author concludes the story with these paragraphs for a very good reason. In a way, she's just letting it go and will wait to take it again, understanding the timing wasn't right before. I think it's good that she found the flower, the hibiscus. That is because it let her and her mother, and in a way, made her better by offering a sense of hope and renewal. For example, when it says "the geese return and the hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again," it shows she's aligning her efforts with the natural cycle, suggesting patience and a belief in a more opportune moment, and ultimately accepting the test is only one part of her journey.

The author concludes the story this way to show how the main character, Saeng has changed from the beginning of the story to the end. It shows a small amount of newfound confidence Saeng now has, as she decides to face a challenge she previously avoided. This ending also shows how much of an effect the “winter hibiscus” had on her, with bringing back memories of her old country and a sense of connection to her roots. If Saeng wouldn’t have found the hibiscus, she would have never started to reminisce about her old home and the life she left behind. This reminiscing not only reminded her of her past, but it also helped her compare her new home to her old home, highlighting both the differences and unexpected similarities. Through this she realized that life in America is not so bad, and that she still has a little bit of her old home with her everyday, represented by the hibiscus. This realization gave her just enough hope and confidence to want to try the driving test again, symbolizing her willingness to integrate and build a life in her new environment. This ending effectively showcases the change of heart Saeng feels for America and her small gain of hope and confidence, suggesting a more positive outlook on her future.

The author decides to conclude the story with that because she wants the moral of the story to be burnt in your head. In the story “Winter Hibiscus” by Minfong Ho, the author decided to end it with the sentence, “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring. In the last paragraph of the story, Saeng vows to herself that she will take the driving test again in the spring. The author has a good reason in which she concludes the story with this. The main character of the story, Saeng, moves to the United States from Vietnam and fails her driver's test. Saeng has not adapted to life in the United States, missing the familiar sights and sounds of home. When she sees a familiar hibiscus plant, she buys it for her memories of Vietnam, a tangible connection to her past. The author is trying to show that since Saeng planted the hibiscus during winter, a time of dormancy and waiting, when it blooms in spring, she will be ready to try to pass her driver's test because she will have adapted to life in the United States, just as the plant adapts to its new environment. The theme of the story would be if you are moving away from somewhere you grew up in, bring things that remind you of that place so you still have a little of that culture with you, easing the transition and fostering a sense of belonging in a new land. Therefore, the author begins and ends with the same subject, the hibiscus, symbolizing both Saeng's past and her potential future in America.

The author concludes the story “Winter Hibiscus” with a sentence about retaking the driver's test in the spring, to express the themes of adapting to circumstances and determination to succeed. For instance when she sees the flower “Madagascar periwinkle” she thinks “how strange to see it in a pot” because “Back home it just grows wild.” The last sentence of the story is symbolic when it says “and the geese return,” because the geese adapt to circumstances by flying south for the winter, just like Saeng is trying to do, and Saeng realizes their patterns are becoming familiar. The very last line says “I will take that test again.” This summarizes the determination Saeng has throughout the entire story. Not only is she determined to succeed in her driver’s test, but in other things as well. For example, when trying to plant the hibiscus Saeng observes that “the soil was cold and hard, and she had trouble thrusting her shovel into it.” Despite the difficulty, though, she “Dug out a hole” and knows it’s strong enough to move it through the cold months just like Saeng will be strong enough to overcome obstacles if she tries. The last sentence in the story is significant. It expresses important themes and lends valuable insight into Saeng’s character, showing her resilience and hope for the future.

The young girl Saeng from Minfong Ho's "Winter Hibiscus" has moved from her homeland of Vietnam to the United States. She was hoping to get her driver's license but failed the test, leaving her disheartened. The sight of the hibiscus at the local nursery comforts her, its vibrant color a reminder of Vietnam's warmth and beauty. When she purchases it, her mother is initially concerned about the price, a significant amount for their family. However, she sees how homesick her daughter is, recognizing the deep longing in Saeng's eyes, and becomes understanding. After carefully planting the hibiscus, Saeng watches the geese fly overhead, noting their seasonal migration, and understands that every year they change their habitat. The geese inspire Saeng, their journey mirroring her own, along with the resilient hibiscus, and she promises herself that in the spring, when the snow melts away, the geese return, and the hibiscus is budding, then she will take the test again, ready to embrace her new life while cherishing her roots.

In stories, authors employ various techniques to achieve different effects. In "Winter Hibiscus," the author concludes the story with a paragraph that evokes a "touching" response in the reader and effectively summarizes key elements of the narrative. The opening line, "Saeng vowed silently to herself," uses imagery, creating a mental image of a solitary girl kneeling in the cold garden, whispering. This image contributes to the emotional impact of the conclusion. Furthermore, the concluding paragraph encapsulates themes explored throughout the story. The quote, "When the geese return hibiscus is budding I will take that test again," directly references the hibiscus flower, a recurring symbol, the geese which appear at the story's end, and Saeng's initial failure on the test. In conclusion, the author's choice of this particular paragraph as the conclusion serves to reinforce the story's emotional resonance and tie together its central motifs, leaving a lasting impression on the reader.

I think that this shows hope because she had really missed her homeland and kind of found peace and serenity by being around them; she says, “That at least she could hold on to,” meaning the bud. I think that she was very upset because of missing home; she missed having her grandmother wash her hair and put a dok mallk into it. I think that since she really had nothing else but the flowers that reminded her of her homeland, the text said, “where was the fine-toothed comb, the hibiscus hedge, the well, her gentle grandmother?” She was missing all these things, so I think that by putting her in this position, it has brought her to a place of where she not only misses the people from her homeland but the beautiful things as well, and how she always has kind of a part of home with her because of the flower, offering a small comfort and connection to her past amidst her longing.

In the last paragraph, the author uses "when they come back, in the spring when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, I will take that test" because Saeng finally found comfort. After moving from her homeland to the United States, she felt homesick. For example, she comes across this flower that reminds her of the time she spent in her homeland. She remembers her grandmother's smell because of the plant. So when she finally got home to her mother, she showed the flower to her. They both planted the flower, and Saeng got a sense of relief. That's why she vowed that when winter was over and spring came she would take that test, because she had a sense of home in her, that gave her encouragement and strength, showing that even when you are in a different area and you feel lost, there's always something that can make you remember the memories and time spent where you came from. Ultimately, the hibiscus flower and her mother's presence fostered a sense of belonging, providing Saeng with the resolve to face her challenges.

The author concludes the story like this because it shows that she is determined to pass the test, despite her anxieties. It is also like if the birds can instinctively fly south, facing their own challenges, then she, with effort and resolve, can certainly pass that test. This parallel underscores her belief in her own capabilities and reinforces her commitment to overcoming the academic hurdle.

The author concludes the story with the paragraph, “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” The author does this for several reasons. The author wants to show you that Saeng still has hope and that she believes she can make it right, demonstrating her resilience after facing a setback. Also, to show Saeng will still try and adapt to her surrounding and make friends, suggesting a willingness to integrate despite the initial difficulties. Saeng is also determined that she will pass the test next time she takes it, highlighting her ambition and perseverance. Last, it is emphasizing the conflict and how Saeng overcame it by resolving to face the challenge again, showing her spirit.

I believe the author ended this story with this paragraph because life lives on. "When the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again," proves that she's moving on with life and so will all the creatures in the world, embracing the cyclical nature of seasons and personal growth. Also even though she moved to a new country doesn't mean she can't still enjoy the things from her homeland, "but she had grown up eating it and, she admitted to herself, much preferred it to the Big Mac," highlighting the enduring connection to her roots amidst change. That's why the author put that last paragraph to show that life lives on, demonstrating resilience and the ability to find comfort in familiar aspects of her identity, even in a new environment.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because she really isn't worried about when they take the test again; she's only concerned with the plants she picked out, showing a shift in focus. Also, she knows that it will be a really long time before she takes the test again, which gives her more time to study and get more prepared and focused, suggesting a sense of optimism. The author also ends this article with this paragraph because she wants to let the readers know that since she failed the first time, she will be back again to take it over, and nothing will stop the author from trying again, highlighting her resilience.

It shows not to give up; it ends almost the same way it began; it shows that people should not stay too attached to the past—each are reasons why I believe the author concludes the story with that paragraph. It shows that people should not give up because even though she failed her test then, she will try again later to pass it, demonstrating resilience. Also, the story ends the same way it begins, by her taking the test or getting ready to, which provides a circular structure and a sense of closure. One last thing is that it shows that people shouldn’t become too attached to the past because if they look at one thing that reminds them of it, they @MONTH1 fall apart; that is why she takes the test, to see if she can look at the familiar flowers without falling apart. This ultimately underscores the importance of moving forward and not being defined solely by past experiences.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph to end on a happy yet motivating note. In the story Saeng says that she failed the test and was very dissapointed with herself, a feeling heightened by her mother's expectations. The test must have been very important to her for her to be so dissapointed. The author also probably ended with this paragraph to show that Saeng is devoted in passing this test, indicating her resolve despite the setback. Saeng seems like a sentimental yet reliable person, someone who values both personal connections and fulfilling responsibilities. I believe that the test is to spend a minimal amount of money and she wants to earn respect from her mom, proving her ability to manage resources wisely. That is why taking and passing the test seems so important to Saeng, representing more than just a challenge, but a chance to gain her mother's approval. That is why the author ended with that paragraph, highlighting Saeng's determination to try again and ultimately succeed.

In the story "Winter Hibiscus," the author concludes the story with the lines "when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again." The reason that the author concludes the test with these lines is because she is re-establishing the symbolism of the plant. In the text it said that the plant buds in the spring, once it has time to grow and adapt to the new environment. Just as the plant needed that time so did the main character Saeng. She just moved from Vietnam and failed her driver's test. Saeng is very unsure of her new culture. For example she likes bitter melon it says. "But she had grown up eating it and, she admitted to herself much preferred it to a Big Mac." She appears to think she is misunderstood and no one likes her, but just as the plant will adapt to this new life so will she, and she will be ready to face the driving test again, symbolizing her own budding confidence and adaptation.

The author concludes the story by saying she will take the test again in the spring and until then, vows silently, because the spring reminded Saeng of home. In Vietnam, there were many beautiful wild flowers. After failing her driving test, Saeng goes to the flower shop to get a piece of home and find solace. It said the flower's "leaves quivering in the wind." This shows that the plant was not the same as those in Vietnam because there were also no buds. Needing hope after her failure, she is awaiting spring, when the hibiscus will bloom again, that will give Saeng a sense of home, which in turn, will give her the hope to do well on the driving test.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because for Saeng, her whole world is the plants. Since they are gone, there is no motivation left; the vibrant life she cultivated and nurtured has vanished, leaving her adrift and without purpose, effectively concluding her story as well.

In the story ìWinter Hibiscus,î the author concludes the story with, ìwhen they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.î The authorís reasoning for saying this is because the presence of memories from Saengís homeland comforts her, so much so that she believes she will pass her test with ease because she will not be nervous. ìit was like walking into another world,î said Saeng, when she entered the florist shop after failing her drivers test. It was almost as if she completely forgot about failing and was only thinking about the plants and flowers. The flowers take her to a happy peace and make her feel at home, like everything is going to be alright. This is why the author concludes with such a sentence because we as readers should understand that these memories of her farmland and the promise of spring will give her the strength and peace of mind needed to pass her driver's test.

The author likely concluded the story like that because of the title and the beginning of the story. Or he might have concluded the story like that because he wanted to. He could have concluded the story like that to show what might happen. But whether it is a good conclusion is debatable.

I really do not know why the author concludes the story with this paragraph. Possibly because she started to talk, finally breaking the long silence that had defined their interactions and perhaps offering a glimmer of hope for future understanding, leaving the reader to ponder the significance of that single utterance.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to show Saeng’s determination. Saeng has been through a lot and misses what its like at home, the familiar sights and sounds that comforted her. She feels different and out of place but she is still strong. Life goes on, and this paragraph shows that Saeng will move with it. The paragraph says, “in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” Spring will come, as nothing can stop time. The snow will melt because the weather changes. The geese will fly home and the hibiscus will bloom in spring, a symbol of hope and resilience. Saeng takes a positive look at things and decides to join them. Sure she failed once but she is strong and willing to try again. If at first you don’t succeed, try, try again. Saeng will always have her memories of home but she is willing to change to her new surroundings and adapt. The concluding paragraph shows Saeng’s determination to succeed and survive in the new world, embracing the future with renewed resolve.

The author concludes the story saying that because she wants to show us that Saeng is confident in herself and will not hesitate to take the test again. She went over to the corner of the vegetable patch, picked up her small shovel, and started to dig a hole in the ground. This action, deliberate and focused, speaks volumes about her resolve; burying her anxieties, she prepares to face the challenge anew.

The author concludes with this paragraph to give a sense of hope and growth. The flower represents Saeng's homeland, and it makes her feel comforted amidst her new surroundings. It connects her with her emotions and reminds her of the way things are back home. The growth and flourishing of the hibiscus corresponds to the flourish of Saeng's own potential. When it blooms, she will have a true piece of home with her, and will be able to take the test again with renewed confidence. The story is ultimately about overcoming obstacles and adjusting to change, finding strength in unexpected places. The visual, and nearly lyrical expression of the blooming hibiscus makes the reward and result of her struggles seem so much more beautiful and attainable.

The author concludes this story with hope in this sentence. The beginning was very negative with Saeng failing her drive's test and her mother yelling at her. But when this sentence comes, the reader is filled with hope for the young girl Saeng. The author does this to show that Saeng will adjust and will persevere, whereas before she was so upset when she said, "I-I failed the test." Then, for Saeng to rebound from this event, gave the reader hope, and that's why the author did this; it highlights her resilience and suggests a positive outlook despite the initial setback.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because the author is talking about how there will be a new start. Since Saeng failed the test, signifying a setback, and in the winter the plant will die, representing the end of a cycle, in the spring the plant will bud again, symbolizing rebirth, and she will retake the test. It's a new chance to start things over, offering hope and the potential for future success.

Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, Saeng vowed don't really like to talk. Saeng liked to be by herself sometimes. When spring came it was a different story. Saeng loved the spring and being outside. She would play outside all day every day. The author concludes the story with that paragraph because it shows that the character will retry what she failed. In the story the character loves gardening, finding solace and purpose in nurturing life. So, when her favourite plant, which she thought was dead, unexpectedly comes back to life, it symbolizes a renewed hope and determination. This resurgence inspires her to retry and successfully pass her test, mirroring the plant's resilience and offering a fitting and optimistic conclusion.

The author concludes the story with that because, as winter comes, everything goes away. Like the trees lose their leaves, the geese fly south, and the flowers die off. So, this passage is saying that in the springtime when everything comes back to life, she will start the test again. It is like starting a new life back over, suggesting a cycle of ending and beginning, mirroring nature's rhythm of dormancy and renewal.

In the story called "Winter Hibiscus" the author concludes the story with this paragraph "when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, than I will take that test again." The reason why the author had put that at the end of the story was because when things go under ground everyone wants to wait and wait until it comes back up again because when you fail everything goes down but if you wait awhile than everything will start to raise Just like flowers and everything else that you can think of. Saeng's failed test represents a winter, a period of dormancy. So that is why the author put that at the end of the story cause to tell people that it is ok for people to fail Just as long as you get up and try again until you reach your goal. So that is what the author was talking about and thats why Minfong Ho put that at the end of the story so that people can read and learn for what it says. Ultimately, Ho uses the cyclical imagery of nature and the winter hibiscus to convey a message of hope and resilience, encouraging readers to persevere through setbacks and embrace the opportunity for renewal.

The author concludes the story with that last paragraph to set the final mood. The author wanted to show that Saeng will not give up and she will continue to adapt to her new surroundings, even when facing challenges. It made the end of the story feel warm and it also inspired hope for the future. The end of the story encourages the reader to not give up as well, regardless of their own circumstances. The last paragraph sets an example of how the reader can vow to improve as well, taking proactive steps toward positive change. The author knew that the last paragraph would stand as an inspiration and maybe help a reader going through something similar to the story, offering a sense of resilience and determination.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph because to her the plant seems to remind her of her homeland which calms her, and when it is budding she feels stronger and more hopeful. In the story Saeng is kind of an outsider, struggling to adjust, and when she sees the plant she sees a tangible piece of her past back home. In the story it says she gets shaky when she tries to say “at home.” When she says “and this hibiscus is budding,” I think it is really saying when she is ready to accept this country as her home, she will blossom as well, because the flower is a reminder of her homeland and her roots. At the end of the story it says how she is getting used to the geese flying in a “V,” so she is gradually becoming more accustomed to this country, suggesting that when she feels truly ready, she will take her test again with renewed confidence.

The author includes the paragraph, "when they come back...then I will take that test again," to show that hibiscus is a symbol of time. Saeng uses the hibiscus to measure the amount of time there will be until she takes her test again, observing its growth as a marker. The hibiscus also symbolizes the power to get through struggling (stay strong). Saeng had trouble with her test, but the hibiscus is there to help push her through it to prepare for the next test, offering a visual representation of growth and perseverance. The hibiscus also helps Saeng's mother push through her hard time of seeing her daughter sad from not succeeding on the test, reminding her of hope and resilience. The plant helps the mother try and stay positive and it also helps the mother by trying to do the right thing for her daughter. In the story, the mother decides to plant the hibiscus in the garden to make her daughter happy, showing her support and belief in Saeng's ability to overcome challenges. The hibiscus shows strong symbolism and it helps Saeng and her mother stay strong throughout their struggles, representing hope, time, and the power to persevere.

This final paragraph goes along with one of the main premises of the story: to not quit and keep going in order to understand and be happy in this world. Saeng is taking this 'test' of sorts to see if she's ready to change and adapt to her new environment, leaving behind the familiar comforts of her past. She failed this time, the overwhelming feelings of displacement still too strong. But when all is right, when she feels more grounded, and the hibiscus is ready to bloom again, signaling a time of renewed hope, she will try again to see if she's ready to truly let go of the old and embrace the new, finally finding happiness in her present reality.

She said it because she didn't do what she was suppose to, so she said she failed. Her mother was mad for a second, her brow furrowed with disappointment, but then stopped, her expression softening. She said, "I love it," perhaps finding a silver lining in the effort, and asked if she wanted something to eat. So they went inside, the aroma of dinner wafting out. But she took the task as a test, a challenge to overcome, so she said, "Next time I will do it right," determined to succeed and meet her mother's expectations in the future.

I believe the author ended the story with the "test" because it is a big part of Saeng's life, a significant custom that shapes her future. It's not merely an event; it's a tradition deeply woven into the fabric of her community and personal identity, representing a rite of passage, which concludes her journey in the narrative. Therefore, ending with the test provides closure and emphasizes the importance of cultural heritage.

There are many reasons why the author concludes the story with that paragraph. First, that ending evokes a lot of emotion, ensuring readers don't find the story uninteresting. Another reason is that it shows strength—not physical, but mental. Saeng is stating that even though she failed the test the first time, she will take it again. Another reason the author may have used this paragraph to conclude the story is to encourage people to never quit. It shows how she failed, and her mom was disappointed, but she is not going to quit and will retake the driver's test. Overall, the author concludes the story with the paragraph because it leaves the reader with a strong message to keep trying and never give up.

The author most likely concludes the story with this sentence because it shows how dedicated the author and her child are to gardening. I am guessing that the young child’s favorite plant is the hibiscus. I think that the mother and her child’s favorite thing to do together would be gardening. This is a nice way to end a story. It gives the reader kind of a look of question on their faces. It leaves them perhaps curious of why the author did that. But in my opinion I think it adds some curiosity to the story, leaving a pleasant and lingering feeling.

The final lines of the story, "Winter Hibiscus," are meant to provide a glimpse into the near future, to show a change in Saeng's attitude. Up until this point Saeng had been lamenting her old country and not adjusting well to her new one. The hibiscus, a symbol of resilience, inspires her and lets her know that the new country has many of the same beautiful things as her old country, offering a sense of connection. "When the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding," is a way of saying she's going to let a little time pass, allowing the seasons to change and bring renewal. By taking her driver's test again, she will actively begin her new life, embracing the opportunities her new home offers and moving forward with a renewed sense of hope. Ultimately, this shows her coming to terms with her present situation and actively shaping her future.

The author concluded the story with saying that Saeng will retake the driving test in the spring to prove a point. When walking home, dejected, from her failed test, Saeng saw a familiar flower growing stubbornly by the sidewalk and impulsively decided to treat herself with a visit to a flower shop. There, surrounded by vibrant colors and scents, she saw many flowers that reminded her of home and the warmth of her native land. She bought a hibiscus, its bright bloom a stark contrast to the muted tones of the late autumn day, and went home. Her and her mother carefully planted it in a pot, after Saeng realized with relief that the flower could be brought inside and make it through the winter. She looked up to see many birds flying overhead, migrating south, and she realized with a start that she, unlike them, has chosen to stay and adapt to her life in @LOCATION1. The hibiscus, a small piece of home transplanted to a new land, has given her the will to survive and she knows she can adapt to life in @LOCATION1. The point the author wanted to get across was that the hibiscus, a symbol of resilience and beauty, gave courage and hope to retake her drivers test and continue surviving, and ultimately thriving, in @LOCATION1.

The reason I think the author concludes this story with this last paragraph is because this is Saeng's passion. And that Saeng is very patient and will do this every year. She really loves plants and she will wait to do it again next spring. The last paragraph really showed a lot of dedication to her Hibiscus. And she really values the spring and the Hibiscus, highlighting its importance to her.

The author concludes the story with this line to show that just like the hibiscus, adapting and struggling to survive and fit in in its non-native land, Saeng will too. She will not give up her fight to pass the test to become a part of her new country. This is supported throughout the story when her mother comments on the hibiscus by the lake. She says, "It's strong enough to make it through the cold months here, this winter hibiscus. That's what matters" (Ho @NUM1). Here the author shows the comparison between the hibiscus' struggle through hard times in a foreign land similarly felt in Saeng's life. Both must be strong and fight through hard times where no one, "not even her classmates or friends, or Mrs. Lambert" (Ho @NUM1), understood how alone and out of place she felt. So just as she vows to take the test again, she's promising herself she will fight through the hard times and grow strong, just as her winter hibiscus does, demonstrating her resilience and determination to thrive.

The importance as to why the author ended this story like this was to show readers the importance of the plant. The author concludes the story with this because the hibiscus and Saeng are very similar in their resilience. The reason why the author concludes the story like this is possibly for him/her to have a spin off. The author concludes the story with, ìwhen they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again,î for several reasons. Another reason is like the hibiscus budding, Saeng has began to grow older and much wiser of things allowing her to go back in the spring and hopefully pass the driving test, demonstrating her determination. The author @CAPS1 ends the story with this paragraph because Saeng is saying that when she @CAPS2 comes @CAPS2 back she will take the test over again, which means that, in the form of the test, is that while she was there it was a test of survival, and when the story begins it is the beginning of the test, and at the end of the story is the test and their leaving, and she wants to come back to see what grew. The author of the story, Winter Hibiscus, concluded the story with that paragraph because the author wanted to show that Saeng is finally going to start getting used to her new home. The author ends with this because of what the hibiscus means to Saeng. To her it is a symbol of strength and comfort, representing resilience.
