I believe the author concluded the story with “When they come back, saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the gesse return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again,” because it shows the entire theme of the story. The theme of this story is adjusting to things in life. The conclusion demonstrates this when she says she will take the test again, showing resilience. The hibiscus allowed her to get over the changes in life. For example, “The familiar fragrance filled her lungs, and saeng could almost feel the light strands of her grandmother's long grey hair." The hibiscus was something familiar from home that gave her good memories, helping her cope with the new environment. The hibiscus encouraged her to accept her new life and keep trying to make it better, providing her with a sense of hope and determination to face future challenges.

The author most likely concludes the story that way because that is the time that Saeng feels most comfortable. Saeng and her mom moved from Vietnam, where the winter Hibiscus are popular and familiar to Saeng. She ends the text in this manner because it reminds Saeng about Vietnam and how she feels better during that time of year, providing a sense of solace. When she says, “And beside it was yet another old friend,” she feels as if this plant is a friend to her, offering a connection to her past and making her feel more comfortable in her new environment. This emphasis on comfort and familiarity is why the author ended the story in the manner that she did.

The author concludes the story with this saying because it will be a fresh start, and it will be spring and beautiful. "Plant it right now" is telling me that she wants another try. She wants a fresh start, and come spring, when all of her pretty flowers are blooming and getting their chance, she wants her own chance to pass. The phrase suggests urgency and hope, emphasizing the importance of seizing the present moment to cultivate a better future for herself. Ultimately, the saying encapsulates the story's theme of renewal and the character's desire for a second chance at happiness.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because of her sadness for what she did. The test she was telling about was how she was supposed to use the twenty dollars they had and buying one item. Big mistake that she spent most of the money buying a plant, which reminded her of home, besides what was needed for the item; and this last paragraph is saying that when she has the chance to do the "test" again, she will do what she is supposed to do, indicating a resolve to act more responsibly in the future.

After reading “Winter Hibiscus” by Minfong Ho, I believe Ho ended the story with that paragraph to support her idea of overcoming obstacles. First, after failing her driving test, Saeng was very upset and didn’t know if she would ever pass it. But after seeing a hibiscus plant at the greenhouse, its vibrant color and resilience reminded her of her home in Vietnam and the strength she possessed, which inspired her. Second, when she bought the plant, her mother was a little angry because it was expensive and seemed frivolous given their limited resources. But, after seeing how the plant brought joy to Saeng and connected her to her roots, her mother understood its importance and forgave her. Last, when Saeng was digging a hole in the frozen ground to let the hibiscus grow, facing the physical challenge and cold weather, it inspired Saeng to take the test again because she overcame the obstacles of bringing the plant home and ensuring its survival, realizing she too could persevere. Therefore, I believe Ho ended “Winter Hibiscus” in this way to emphasize her idea of overcoming obstacles through resilience and connection to one’s heritage.

The last paragraph of the story displays the theme of determination. The Hibiscus reminded her that her "home" was her old life, but misses @CAPS1 in her new life. She gains determination through the reminder of this. She soon realizes that she is home, for things have come familiar to her, such as the V formation of the geese overhead, a sight that now brings comfort instead of longing. She loved her old home, but she realized it was time to move on and build a fulfilling existence where she is. The last paragraph does not only mean retaking a driving test; it symbolizes the determination to embrace her new home and life, suggesting a renewed commitment to establishing roots and finding happiness in her present circumstances.

I will take that test again. She has unwavering confidence from the hibiscus and snow. When the snow melts and hibiscus buds bloom, then she will go again, kind of growing with the hibiscus, so and in all she is determined to have enough confidence for the test.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because they want people to know what happened in the story, summarizing the events for clarity. Also because they want people to know what it might mean or say in relation to the story, offering a layer of interpretation. The sentence means that when spring comes and when the snow might melt the plants will be out and budding, symbolizing renewal and hope, but by next class or next school year he will come out and be brave and take the test all over again, demonstrating resilience. That is what the sentence means of the story and how it might be compared to both things in different ways, highlighting the cyclical nature of challenges and the potential for future growth.

The final paragraph in “Winter Hibiscus” by Minfong Ho reads, “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently, to herself, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” This paragraph compares her to the flowers, which shows that she is resilient like the flower; as the hibiscus is strong enough to bud again after winter, so too is Saeng determined to take the test again next year and pass it. She would also take the test because it is comforting to her and reminds her of home, connecting her to a sense of familiarity and hope in a new and challenging environment, reinforcing her resolve.

He ended the paragraph like that because he may want you to read on, or it could be that he is showing you the comparison between the flower and Saeng. "When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again." The quote is showing the flower can fight through the winter and come back. Saeng failed the test once and is now going back to retake the test, which shows that they both have motivation and the integrity to come back, further emphasizing the author’s potential intent to draw a parallel between Saeng's resilience and the flower's perseverance.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph, ìWhen they com back, Saeng vowed silently to hersef, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, Then I will take that test againî. I believe the author concluded the story like this because it shows that the hibiscus represented to Saeng a new beginning and a chance to restart after her failure. The return of spring, signaled by the melting snows, the returning geese, and the budding hibiscus, mirrors Saeng's own potential for renewal. When Saeng saw the hibiscus after failing her driving test, it gave her comfort in a time of disappointment, connection to her past experiences, and the belief that she could overcome her obstacles. Therefore, when the narrator says, ìwhen the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again", this imagery implies a fresh start, suggesting the hibiscus is not just a plant, but a symbol representing Saeng's resilience and determination to try again. This symbolic connection solidifies why the author concludes the story with this hopeful and forward-looking paragraph, emphasizing Saeng's renewed resolve.

The last line is included in the story “Winter Hibiscus” because it showed the connection between Saeng and the flower. Even though Saeng failed the driving test the first time, she decides to take it again in the spring. The hibiscus flower, like Saeng, is out of place and will have to make it through the winter into the spring so it can bud again. This shows how, like the flower, Saeng will bud again in the spring by retaking the driving test. Another reason is that Saeng and the flower are not used to the conditions in @LOCATION1. So they both have to weather the winter months they are not used to, as Saeng adjusts to a new country and the flower to an unfamiliar climate. This shows again how the last line connects the girl and the flower together, emphasizing their shared resilience. In conclusion, the last line is used in the text to wrap up the story with a connection between the flower and Saeng, highlighting their parallel journeys of adaptation and eventual flourishing.

I think the author concludes the story with this statement because the author is determined to get used to the new country and surroundings. In the story, the author is showing homesickness. The author sees a plant that is known where she comes from and buys it for over @NUM1; her mother couldn't believe it. She didn't want to tell her mother exactly why she got it because she was too shaky to say "home" or start crying again. The last sentence is showing that the author is trying to adapt and find a piece of familiarity in this unfamiliar place, signaling a willingness to embrace her new life despite the pangs of nostalgia.

The author concludes with this paragraph because she/he wanted to close the story with a conclusion that portrays the story. The author talked about the hibiscus in the story as a ìcomfort in time of distressî a hobby or thing she likes doing with her spare time. In conclusion the author concludes with that paragraph for the reasons stated in the preceding text, emphasizing the hibiscus as a symbol of solace and personal enjoyment, effectively encapsulating the narrative's core themes.

The author ends the story with the given paragraph to get across that Saeng will recover and try again. It highlights the things important and familiar to Saeng that gave her comfort, and uses them to essentially say that she’ll take the test over again once she feels better. The winter hibiscus was a plant that Saeng remembered of life back home up to the story, so when she saw the plant, “a wave of loss so deep and strong that it stung Saeng’s eyes now swept over her.” Saeng was unable to comfort her emotions when she first saw the plant because she realized how much she missed her old life. The plant is mentioned in the final paragraph because when it blooms in the spring, the winter hibiscus will help fill the emotional void, and help Saeng to try to take the test again. She also mentions the geese for the same reason, but in a different way. Unlike the winter hibiscus, it took a while for the geese to become, “through the quiet repetition of season upon season, almost familiar to her now.” Saeng mentions this so that she can get used to the strange and unfamiliar parts of her life, and to come to grips with her failed test. Therefore by mentioning the things she does in the last paragraph, Saeng uses familiar objects, foreign and domestic, to illustrate her coming to grips with her failure, suggesting a resilience and determination to face future challenges.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph, because it expresses the meaning of the story. Life continues no matter what, the hibiscus will return again in the spring. The hibiscus is like a symbol to Saeng's life. The plant normally doesn't survive in winter months, but this one did. The mother says, "It's flowers aren't as pretty, but it's strong enough to make it through the winter months here..." Saeng and her mother are just like the plant, resilient and determined. They are strong and their lives will continue even though they are in a new environment, facing unfamiliar challenges and adapting to a different world. The author chose to end the story with that paragraph because even though she says the hibiscus will come back every spring the deeper meaning is that Saeng and her mother, like the hibiscus, will continue to live their lives, demonstrating a quiet strength and an enduring hope for the future.

The author chooses to end the story in a very deep, connected way. It is ended on a note of rebirth and second chances. When Saeng vows, "When they come back, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return, when the Hibiscus is blooming, I will take the test again," the author is connecting a sense of a new country and second chances and rebirth. Spring and snow melting could be connected to rebirth, while the geese returning could symbolize a second chance, as geese often migrate back to where they started. This is connected to Saeng's second chance at not only the test but also life in a new place. The author also shows that Saeng is getting used to the new country, which shows a sense of hope; seeing the familiar signs of spring allows her to feel more at home, and this shows that there is some hope for her test and her future.

I think the author concludes the story with this paragraph because he wants us to get the moral of the story. I said this idea because in the story he talks about orchids, lanno bushes, oleanders, elephant ear begonias, and bougainvillea vines surrounded her. It talks about how these flowers surrounded her, seemingly to test her resolve or perhaps symbolize the beautiful but potentially challenging aspects of life she was navigating. The author uses the imagery of the garden to highlight the central theme, suggesting the conclusion serves to solidify this message and leave the reader contemplating the deeper meaning behind her experiences.

I think the Author concludes this in the story because it is key information for this story. Because it is dealing with her mom, she loves to work on the garden and become a gardener, and have a real job like her mom, showing how deeply connected she feels to her mother's passions and aspirations.

Saeng thinks that she has failed because she misses her grandmother. The hibiscus plant that she buys reminds her of grandmother’s scent. Saeng spent over @MONEY1 on the hibiscus plant. She needed it to feel a little bit more at home in this new place. Saeng feels she had very little time to leave her country, in “a blink.” Her grandmother would want her to be strong and not cry at the thought of being away from her. Saeng needs to think of the good and smile when she is reminded of her past. Saeng wants to pass the test; she will remind herself of her grandmother's strength. Next time the hibiscus are budding she must not cry, and she will honor her memory by facing the future with courage.

The reason I think that the author did it is because they wanted you to know what time it took place and what the weather was like. It also tells you how long she is going to wait, like until the snow melts, and that is going to be a while. Furthermore, the description includes when the geese live and when they will return home, providing context to her timeframe and intentions, so this is why I think she tells you what it is like, to ground the narrative and set the stage for the events to follow.

I think that this is about winter hibiscus and hedpe tall and lush bad surrounded their garden. Its lush green leaves dotted with vermilion flowers, She said when she got to the hibiscus she reached out and touched a petal gently. The winter hibiscus, despite its name, thrived, and the hedpe, a tall and lush bed, offered a vibrant backdrop to their garden. Its lush green leaves were dotted with vermilion flowers. She said when she got to the hibiscus she reached out and touched a petal gently, marveling at its delicate texture, concluding her appreciation of its simple beauty.

The reason that the author had ended the story the way she did was to leave the reader on the last thought. Also it symbolizes rebirth. When Saeng says, ì... this hibiscus is budding ...î (Ho @NUM1). She is also describing that they will start over when spring comes. And that leaves the reader with the last thought about Saeng, and how she has overcome living in the new place. Lastly, it ties up Saeng's feelings and experiences the whole time she had moved, ì... I will take the test againî (Ho @NUM1), which tells the reader she will continue to give her new home a shot. In conclusion, the reason for this quote being the last paragraph is to show that Saeng will continue to try to overcome adversity.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph because she wants there to be hope for the future, seeing that the hibiscus budding in the spring is what Saeng is waiting for. It gives her hope that she will be able to pass that test again. This is shown when she says "...and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again." All through the winter, Saeng hopes she will improve, and when the hibiscus buds, she will know that it is time to try again. Saeng sees the spring as a new beginning, so that means it is a time to overcome her obstacle. I think that obstacle or test might be to not cry when she thinks about her old life in Vietnam. When she accomplishes this, she is growing just like the hibiscus, signifying her personal growth and ability to face the future with renewed strength.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph for one main reason: to leave the reader with a lingering sense of ambiguity. This uncertainty mirrors the protagonist's own unresolved feelings and questions about the events that transpired. The final paragraph, therefore, doesn't offer neat resolutions or definitive answers, but rather reinforces the complexities of human experience. This concluding choice allows the reader to continue pondering the themes of the story long after finishing it, solidifying the narrative's impact.

The author is showing that Saeng wants to keep on with her mother's gardening, continuing to cultivate the familiar rows of vegetables and fragrant herbs. To take over an elder's traditions and what her mother started means more than just tending plants; it represents a desire to honor her memory. In essence, Saeng's commitment ensures the garden's continuation, symbolizing the enduring connection between mother and daughter.

I believe that the author ended the story with this paragraph to show the persistence of the main character. I believe this because in the beginning of the story when she is walking home, she states that she failed the driver's test. This initial setback highlights her disappointment. In the last paragraph, she states that after winter is over she will take the test again when her hibiscus blooms, symbolizing a renewed hope and determination. Her persistence allows her to push through life as if she was a plant trying to survive the winter, waiting for the right season to flourish, and ultimately demonstrating her resilience.

The author concludes the story with the paragraph because she wants to do it right next time, suggesting a sense of hope and determination. What it's saying is that she can try every year to get it right to impress her mother and perhaps achieve a deeper understanding or connection. In conclusion, this cyclical pursuit reveals a continuous effort to improve and strengthen their relationship.

In the story “Winter Hibiscus” the author most likely ends the story with this quote because he wants to show that she thinks of the Hibiscus as more than just a flower; to Saeng it is also a memory. For Saeng, the Winter Hibiscus is like story books, waiting to be read; simply by smelling the flower it unlocks wonderful memories of precious time spent with her “gentle grandmother” from her first home. The author is trying to use the flower to show the reader how much a simple object can trigger a memory, thought and so on. The last sentence clearly states, with evidence from the story, Saeng cares deeply about her past and so she can fit in with life today she must not forget who she was. By keeping the hibiscus in her garden she can have a beautiful reminder of whose she came from. Therefore one is to believe this reasoning is the assumption as to why the author ended the story “Winter Hibiscus” with the paragraph selected, emphasizing the importance of remembering one’s roots while navigating a new life.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph for many reasons. For example, it shows a sense of hope, when she says “this hibiscus is budding". That indicates a new beginning or starting over. I think that is the idea the author is trying to get across. Obviously it was difficult for the author to adjust to her new country. For example, she was disappointed that the hibiscus wasn’t the same as the one in her homeland. Even though she's feeling nostalgic, this paragraph reassures the reader that the author is willing to give her new country another chance, suggesting an acceptance of change and a willingness to embrace the future.

The author concludes the story with that particular paragraph for a number of reasons. The last paragraph states that “when they come back ... I will take the test again,” (Ho @NUM1). Already upset about failing her driving test, the main character is upset missing her homeland. The buds of the flowers give her hope and, essentially, the strength to take the test over again. Also when she was originally in the flower shop, after smelling and seeing the flowers, “A wave of loss so deep and strong that it stung Saeng’s eyes now swept over her ... And in the warm moist shelter of the greenhouse, Saeng broke down and wept ”(Ho @NUM2). It is obvious that to the main character these flowers mean so much to her; they take her back to her home country, which she was abruptly torn from and misses, they give her hope and they remind her of the things she loves, like her grandmother. The flowers represent a connection to her past and a source of resilience for her future, allowing her to envision a renewed attempt at the driving test. In conclusion, the author chose to end the story with this paragraph because that is what means the most to the main character.

The author concludes this story with this paragraph to show she loved them flowers. That they meant a whole lot to her. When she failed her driving test she was sad, and the flowers made her feel better. Now that the snow is falling, she waits until spring; that's when they come up, and she will have faith and take the test again, knowing they will bloom anew.

The author concluded this sentence because he was letting everyone know that Saeng would return to the hibiscus and take care of it still, showing her continued dedication, and that she has not forgotten about it despite any intervening circumstances.

In the story "Winter Hibiscus", by Minfong Ho, a teenager, Saeng, moves from Vietnam to the United states. She later takes a drivers test, but does not succeed in passing, but does succeed in finding comfort from her memories of her homeland. The last paragraph states "When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again." The author concludes the story with this paragraph for many reasons. These being that Saeng was very upset about failing her test and was reminded of her homeland and the changes she's had to adapt to during this move. The hibiscus plant gives Saeng a hope to continue her journey even when things get very hard. Saeng sees the plant as a symbol of her own resilience, its ability to survive the harsh winter mirroring her own struggle to adapt. The winter is this plant's time of trouble and sadness, as Saeng's time of trouble and sadness is failing this test and not being at her real home. The end of winter gives both the plant and Saeng a chance to start over and a renewed hope to start over; Saeng will find it easy to get through hardships if she continues to find comfort from her past. Ultimately, the hibiscus becomes a symbol of hope and perseverance, suggesting that Saeng, like the plant, will bloom again in a new environment.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph to get the readers wondering about the future and what might happen next. To show that she's not going to give up on what she wants to do, despite the obstacles she has faced and the uncertainties that lie ahead, leaving a lasting impression.

The author Minfong Ho ends the story talking about the test Saeng failed and vowing to take it again because, like in the story, the test was symbolizing slightly moving on, just kind of starting her new life and not living in the old. But Saeng couldn't do that immediately. She bought the flower with all her money because it held memories for her, memories of her homeland and the life she left behind. But I think as the story goes on, especially after her interaction with the flower seller, she kind of realizes she can have both, her old and new life, preserving her past while embracing the future. I think she ends the story that way because she really does want to try again; the determination in her vow is palpable. She wants to be able to please her mom, and herself; she wants to be able to move on and start her new life, accepting the challenge this new beginning presents. Ultimately, Saeng's decision to retake the test suggests a willingness to integrate her past with her future, indicating a hopeful path forward.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph because Saeng relates that she needs more time. If she takes a break and does what she needs to, then she will be able to pass the test, demonstrating her potential with focused effort.

The author chose to conclude the story this way because he can now expand on this story, creating a sequel about Saengís success. Also, by ending the story this way, the author is showing there is no limit to what Saeng is willing to do and that she will stop at nothing until her test is complete. Saeng is having difficulties adapting to her new lifestyle because the plants and the previous luxuries that she had are no longer present in her life. In the story, Saengís determination is strongly shown when her mother finds out that she spent @NUM1 dollars to have a similar plant. The mother responds by saying their whole garden is worth less than @NUM1 dollars, highlighting the vast difference in their current circumstances and reinforcing Saeng’s unwavering commitment to recreating her past comforts, suggesting a promising narrative arc for future installments.

This sentence concludes the passage, to show how when the hibiscus is budding and a new season starts, Saeng will be a new person and will be able to take the test. In this sentence the cold snow, fleeing geese and planted hibiscus can all represent Saeng and what she is going through. They are either cold, ready to leave or restricted just like Saeng feels, symbolizing her current state. But, when a new season starts, the geese come back, and the hibiscus is no longer restricted in a pot, Saeng will also grow up and be able to take the test, signifying her anticipated transformation. This sentence is put at the end to show how much Saeng can now grow because she has the hibiscus, which is growing with her, suggesting a parallel journey of growth and liberation for both.

The author ends the story with the sentence provided because, as she was saying that when you and winter are over, there will be time again to get the gardening back to the test with the plant she had planted, signifying a hopeful outlook for renewal and the return of life after a period of dormancy.

The author has concluded the story with a paragraph about Saeng taking the test again another time. The author concluded the story with this paragraph because Saeng wanted to take the test again when the snow melts, the geese return and the hibiscus is budding, marking the arrival of spring. She feels ready when that time comes around, feeling more prepared with the change of seasons. Saeng is trying to say to herself that she needs more time to be ready for this test and the pressure it brings. When she gets more time to be ready for the test, she will take the test again. I think that is why the author wrote the paragraph as a conclusion, leaving the reader with a sense of hope for Saeng's future attempt.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph. Because when the hibiscus started budding it will give her inspiration to try and past the test again. In order to past the test she wanted to feel like she was home, and to have memories of her home to encourage her to try again. Therefore, this is the reason the author concludes the story with the last paragraph, emphasizing the hibiscus as a symbol of hope and a connection to her past, providing the necessary motivation for her future attempts.

The author concludes the story with a paragraph taking the test again to show that the narrator might be upset about being in a new place but she will keep trying. The narrator gets upset when she knows the hibiscus is not like the one's from her old home. This upsets her because she probably misses things that she was used to before. The author uses that paragraph to show the narrator is strong and wonít give up on making things the way they were but also showing that she'll try to adapt to her new home. The author does this to show that you should keep trying at something that you love. The narrator will keep trying when the geese fly back and the hibiscus is budding, illustrating her dedication to her passions. So the author is saying try if you fail and set goals to never give up, ultimately showing the importance of resilience.

I think the author concludes the story with this paragraph for many reasons. It serves as a final reflection on the events that have transpired, offering a sense of closure. The paragraph encapsulates the central themes explored throughout the narrative, providing a concise restatement of the story's core message and leaving the reader with a lasting impression of its significance. Ultimately, it solidifies the story's overall impact and reinforces its intended meaning, thus bringing a satisfying resolution to the narrative journey.

I think the author concludes the story with this paragraph because he knows that he messed up on the test, and he's saying when spring comes back around, he will be ready to take the test. I know it is spring because he said when the snow melts, implying the end of winter and the hope for a fresh start with improved preparation.

When she moved to America she saw all the beautiful flowers that were out in the spring. She saw a blossom that caught her attention; it was called hibiscus. She felt connected with it that she went to the florist to see if they had it. Back where she came from, they grew wild, jittering out from the cracks in ceizors walls. The blossom reminded her of her grandmother, its long, delicate petals like her long gray hair, freshly washed.

In the passage “Winter Hibiscus” by Minfong Ho, the quote “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and the hibiscus is budding, I will take the test again,” symbolizes a new journey in the new country she lives in. In the test Saeng is having a personal discrepancy, missing her homeland as she states “I failed the test.” This test meant more to her than just failing; it was a test to her ability to function in her new country, and she felt she failed. The “when they came back…” quote started above can be analyzed deeply, as the snow being her obstacles and the hibiscus being herself. When the obstacles melt away and she buds into a new, stronger person, she will take the test again. This demonstrates Saeng's resilience and determination to adapt and succeed in her new environment, viewing the test as a personal challenge to overcome rather than a definitive failure.
She will go back to where she started, her journey complete. It's a circle, a seasonal return, and she will be back the next year where she began, ready to start anew.

Original Text:  The study of media effects is a complex field. Researchers use various methods to explore how media influences individuals and society. These methods range from surveys to experiments. Each approach has its strengths and weaknesses. Understanding these methodologies is crucial for interpreting research findings.  Expanded Text:  The study of media effects represents a complex and multifaceted field of inquiry. Researchers employ a diverse array of methodologies to explore the intricate ways in which media influences both individuals and broader societal structures. These methods span a considerable range, encompassing approaches as varied as large-scale surveys designed to capture broad trends and controlled laboratory experiments aimed at isolating specific causal relationships. Each methodological approach possesses its own inherent strengths and weaknesses, impacting the type of data collected and the conclusions that can be drawn. Therefore, a comprehensive understanding of these methodologies is absolutely crucial for accurately interpreting research findings and evaluating the validity of claims made about media influence, ultimately enhancing our understanding of the media's role in shaping our world.

I believe that the author concludes the story with this paragraph, ìWhen they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again,î because that flower budding would make her feel confident about everything. The reason I think this is because that flower reminds her of past time memories of her homeland. Itís basically like she has a little peice of home in her new home. An example that represents this is, ìNot like the kind we had before,î this is explaining the new hibiscus is similar, but not the same as the one from home, so this reminds her of home. The hibiscus blooming serves as a symbol of hope and resilience, connecting her to her roots and providing the emotional strength needed to face the challenge again, which is why I believe the author ends the story the way they do.

The reason the author concludes the story with this paragraph is to show that Saeng is not just going to give up; she is going to overcome the problem. This is a great way to end this story because the entire story is about overcoming problems, and if Saeng just gave up it would ruin the story’s message of resilience. Just like she was able to move away from her homeland, she will eventually pass the test. The mother was also able to overcome obstacles, such as moving away from her homeland and having to plant all new plants, showing her own adaptability. She obviously misses the old plants, which you can tell by the way she knew what her gift was. But she is able to deal with that, demonstrating her strength, just like Saeng will do on her test the next time, proving that she too possesses that same strength.

Everything in the story is about to change. The winter will change to spring, the snow will melt and vanish, the geese will return, the hibiscus will bud, Saeng will also change and mature as well. Saeng is just like the hibiscus plant, as the plant is out of place on the road, Saeng is out of place in the new country and she must adapt like the hibiscus plant. The plant looks different in the United States than in Vietnam because it matured and grew, acclimating to its new environment. That is what Saeng must do; she must mature and grow in this new country, embracing the opportunities for change. For example, Saeng observed how different the plant looked in the shop window then it did in her home country, its leaves a deeper green, its blooms more vibrant. She was observing herself and how different she appeared as well, a reflection of her own adaptation. The reason for putting the paragraph at the very end was to show that she had matured already, placing it at the end to show that she had grown and learned. Putting it at the beginning would not give the same effect, the transformation needs to be revealed gradually. The hibiscus plant was able to sustain the harsh winters change. Saeng is able to do that as well, drawing strength from the plant's resilience, and she made the silent vow to take that test again when she has matured, just as the things around her have, demonstrating her commitment to growth and her new life.

The author concludes the story with the paragraph shown for several reasons. First, the author needs to conclude the story without leaving any questions in the readers mind as to what happens. This is achieved by incorporating the geese, hibiscus, and her driver's test into the last paragraph, providing a sense of closure. Next, this last paragraph adds a theme of perseverance to the story, highlighting her determination. The main character is driven to take the driver's test again through memories of Vietnam, showing her resilience. Lastly, it adds to the character by saying that she will "take that test again"; she is shown as being realistic and not overconfident, suggesting a grounded approach to future challenges. These are some of the ways that the last paragraph enhances the story, providing a satisfying resolution while reinforcing key themes and character traits.

The author chose to end the story with this paragraph because it shows that Saeng is starting to adjust to her new home and that she will not give up. You can tell that she still misses her homeland by her reaction to seeing the hibiscus plant, a vibrant reminder of her past, but also that she is growing accustomed to her new home because of how she recognizes the geese overhead. This connection to the natural world around her, specifically how she will make the decision of when to retake the driving test based on their migration patterns, suggests a growing sense of belonging and determination to build a life in this new place, indicating she is finding her footing.

The author concluded the story with the paragraph because it shows that Saeng was not prepared for this test, likely due to being unaccustomed to the unfamiliar environment of the testing location. However, after seeing the familiar plants that reminded her of home, and knowing that springtime is a season of renewal when more will blossom, she will likely feel more confident and ready to take the test over, suggesting a hopeful outlook for her future success.

The reasoning for concluding this story this way is to state that the season of the flowers is over and is to be held off until the spring, offering a natural point to pause the narrative. This allows the author to end the story gracefully, creating anticipation for the flowers' return in the spring, when a new story, perhaps building upon the themes or characters introduced, can begin. In conclusion, this cyclical ending provides closure while simultaneously hinting at future possibilities, making it a fitting choice for the author's final paragraph.

The author concludes the story with "when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again". To show that Saeng is going to take the test again and is not going to give up. This is shown by saying, "then I will take that test again". This shows that she has not given up and wants to try again, her determination fueled by the cyclical promise of renewal that spring embodies. The return of the geese and the blooming hibiscus serve as personal symbols of hope and perseverance, reinforcing her commitment to future success.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph because of how it related to when Saeng failed her driving test. But she was determined to take it over when she feels she's ready, and the paragraph said "in the spring when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take this test again." This cyclical imagery emphasizes Saeng’s renewed hope and resolve, linking her personal journey to the natural world's rhythms of renewal. The hibiscus budding specifically symbolizes her own potential and growth, suggesting a future attempt rooted in patience and self-belief.

In the story “Winter Hibiscus” which was written by Minfong Ho, I believe she put it there because it keeps you asking questions. The story leaves you wondering about the unspoken tensions. I think because her mom was so disappointed with her, as suggested by the mother's critical remarks about her English, that maybe she can change things and make things better. The hibiscus becomes a symbol of hope and a reminder of their heritage. Ultimately, the ambiguity encourages readers to reflect on the complexities of mother-daughter relationships and the challenges of cultural adaptation.

The author ends the story by saying ìwhen they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again.î she chooses to end like this to show the change of the mood throughout the story. When she gets home her mother ìnoticed the tear staie on her daughterís cheeks and her puffy eyes.î Saeng felt sad and out of place in the beginning of the story, clearly disappointed by her performance. But by the end she felt happy and optimistic, already looking forward to the spring and another chance to prove herself.

I think the author concludes the story "Winter Hibiscus" with this paragraph for these reasons. The first reason is to show that the girl won't give up. She was crying in the store and just very depressed, missing her home. But, she knows that she has to keep going and adapt to her new life. It shows a sense of determination to make the best of the situation. Another reason why I think the author made this the last paragraph is this: it showed her getting used to her environment. I think the author used what she remembers about her country and what she now knows of the new country and puts them together. That way she gets hope from both the familiar and the new. For example, in the article it says, “many of the things she had thought of as strange before, had become… almost familiar to her now.” This shows that she is realizing that she is used to the arrangement right now, finding a sense of normalcy. So she then gets hope from it, blending her past and present. Also, I think the author did that so that it would add a positive effect on the story, leaving the reader with a feeling of optimism for the girl's future. That is why I think the author wrote that as the last paragraph, creating a hopeful ending.

The author concludes this story with this paragraph to show people that the story or people in the story have a thing for nature, or like writing about nature, like what's in nature, the changes, or maybe this story is about nature at its best, highlighting its beauty and power as it shapes the characters' experiences and reflections.

The author wrote that last paragraph to give hope to Saeng and the reader. After seeing the hibiscus flower, Saeng is reminded of her old country and feels sad; the author writes, “A wave of loss so deep and strong that it stung Saeng’s eyes now swept over her.” Saeng buys the flower and talks with her mum about it at home. The flower reminds her of home but it also gives her inspiration. That is why she says she will pass the test when the hibiscus buds bloom, demonstrating her renewed optimism and determination to succeed in her new life.

The author concludes with this paragraph because it fits along with a lot of the story and sums it up well. In the story the hibiscus means a lot to Saeng. During the story she relates a lot of memories to the hibiscus. It reminds her of her home and her past so it plays an important role; it's a symbol of hope and perseverance for her. When she is planting it, it's winter and the hibiscus hasn't bloomed yet. So by saying that she will take the test again when it is budding is like saying she will take the test again when it's budding again, symbolizing a new beginning. She is pretty much acting the same as the flower, waiting for her own time to bloom once again, showing its importance. And that's why I think the author ended with that paragraph, connecting Saeng's personal growth to the natural cycle of the hibiscus.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph because it’s saying that she can’t work in the garden in winter, but “when the snow melts and the geese return and the hibiscus is budding,” are all signs of spring. The author concludes the story like this: the Author (Minfong Ho) is telling you what will happen in spring time. because she thinks she will do better in the spring for some reason I dont know if I should agree because she will be in a better mood then and it will look more like her home place.

The author chose to conclude the story with that paragraph because it symbolizes Saeng's decision to try again. Just like Saeng, the winter hibiscus was out of its normal environment but was learning to adapt, drawing strength from an unlikely place. That inspired Saeng to keep trying even if she failed, because the hibiscus was trying to survive the winter even though it was out of place, demonstrating a resilience that mirrored her own journey and ultimately, her choice to not give up.

I think that the author concludes the story with that paragraph because no matter what she said or did, she had to get the flower because it reminds her of where she used to live and how it was there, so she started to cry. The test, it seems, was not to buy the flower and not to cry, showing her emotional connection to her past. The ending suggests hope, indicating that in the spring she is going to grow her own flower, symbolizing a fresh start and the ability to create her own memories, which completes what I think the test is about.

She will see if her plant will survive through the winter, just like the ones back at home, in her familiar garden. And she thinks things will be the same here as they were there, hoping for a seamless transition for her beloved plant.

It's the start of a new life. She has a new school and a new plant, a hibiscus. It is like she has a connection to the plant; when it grows, she grows stronger and more confident. The author ends it with that because it shows that she won’t give up and that she will give her new country a chance, despite any hardships she may face. She ends it with that to say that she will be strong like the flower, resilient and capable of thriving even in difficult conditions, and that she will stay no matter what! That she will be there, in that spot to see it grow back, symbolizing her hope for a brighter future in this new land. That's why I think she concluded with that powerful image.

Throughout this story we are given background information on a girl who deferentially misses her true home; when we are first introduced to young Saeng she is in a florist’s shop simply looking at flowers. We soon learn that she is not only looking at flowers but looking at pieces of her home and past; she then purchases a hibiscus, which is a flower native to her Vietnam. After discovering that she has just failed a test, it becomes more apparent that buying the flower is a way to cope with her new situation in America and feel comforted by her past. The author is able to conclude the story with that statement because it speaks of moving forward without clinging to the past; in the spring, Saeng will have a new home and find strength in her past, that is what I feel the final paragraph suggests.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because Saeng is determined to pass the test. She knows when it's spring and the hibiscus is budding, she will retake the test. I think she wants to retake the test because the hibiscus makes her think about her homeland. It makes her feel more confident. She thinks she can pass it next time. The hibiscus makes her happy and overwhelmed, reminding her of familiar beauty and strength. She wants to retake the test, fueled by this renewed connection to her roots. She's sure she will do better next time, carrying the spirit of her homeland with her.

I think that the author concludes the story with this paragraph because it shows that if that type of flower could bloom in different places and go through natural changes, adapting to new environments, then so can she. To me, the flower is a symbol to the author that encourages her to keep trying and persevering through challenges. No matter if you have to start all over and doing it again, it’s just this time you will know and would have learned from the past mistakes, making you stronger. Just as a flower blooms one spring, it dies in the winter, and then comes again in the spring, representing resilience and renewal. That’s the same as Saeng failing that test that year; she can go back next time and take it again, armed with experience and determination to succeed.

Guess that she is saying that when winter is gone she will be prepared for that winter's test again. I guess this because they were not prepared for the winter to come, evidenced by their late-season planting. This late harvesting suggests a lack of preparedness for the approaching cold. The author concluded the story in this manner so that the audience would feel sympathy and understanding for the things that Saeng and her family were going through in this hard time. It makes the reader feel sympathy for Saeng because all she can think of to make herself feel better is her home town and how she got taken away from it, highlighting the deep sense of loss and displacement she experiences. This evokes a powerful emotional connection with the reader, fostering empathy for her situation.

He concludes the story because he was offered another chance to enact the test. This second opportunity presented itself after a period of reflection, allowing him to approach the challenge with a clearer understanding of the potential outcomes and his own motivations, thus bringing the narrative to its natural resolution.

The author concluded "Winter Hibiscus" with this paragraph to emphasize a new life and new chances for the main character. The future setting of the paragraph, spring, symbolizes rebirth and another start from the cold, hard winter. The author takes this to heart including more events which enhance this symbolized meaning. The author uses structured choice to carry her thoughts. To convey the theme of rebirth, the author uses words like "the geese return" and "take the test again" which add to the importance at the home. Also, the literal action of the "hibiscus is budding" symbolizes rebirth. In winter the plant is dormant and less colorful, but in the spring the plant shows rebirth through its colorful buds. The author finally conveys the theme of rebirth by ending with this paragraph, solidifying the idea of new beginnings for the character and reinforcing the hope that spring brings.

In the story "Winter Hibiscus" by Minfong Ho, it tells of a girl who just moved to a new country & is having a hard time adapting to the new land & its people. But I think the author put that quote at the end to lead you to believe to never give up, there is a new beginning & you will make it. I believe this because Saeng thinks to herself, "almost reluctantly, she realized that many of the things that she thought of strange before had become, through the quiet repetition of season upon season, almost familiar to her." This shows that Saeng finally has found comfort & is confident, like the geese, who instinctively know where they are going and going to adapt in a new area, & then will come back, & that the winter hibiscus never gives up & will keep living in the new weather conditions every season. This resilience, mirrored in both the geese and the hibiscus, signifies a hopeful message about the potential for adaptation and growth, ultimately suggesting that even in the face of unfamiliarity, one can find a sense of belonging and thrive.

She concludes the things at the end of her paragraph, saying she will review everything when winter is done. She will then be able to retake the test again in the spring, showing that she is already planning ahead for improvement. That is what she was writing about.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it shows that she is trying to adapt to her new surrounds. The hibiscus reminds her of her old life and it comforts her. The author chose this paragraph because it fit right like a good conclusion, showing for example, the word "again." This highlights a cyclical process, not necessarily of regret, but of repeated examination and experimentation within the natural world, concluding the exploration.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it still shows how determined Saeng is to take the test again and pass it this time. In the short story "Winter Hibiscus," a young girl from Vietnam moves to America and fails the driver's test. After she decides to spend money on a winter hibiscus to remind her of her homeland, the ending paragraph, "When Troy come back, in the spring when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again," shows deep feeling towards nature. She feels as when the geese are ready to return home and when the hibiscus is ready to bud, so will she be ready and she will take the driver's test again. This reflects her connection to the natural cycles as a source of hope and renewal, suggesting her readiness will coincide with the return of spring.

She is talking about the flowers, and when she says "test," I think she means how she looks, examining the flowers and seeing the snow fall all over again. It sounds like the author is someone who admires flowers a lot, or maybe just this one hibiscus, and how it buds. Maybe she is just someone who likes to see changes, observing the subtle transformations and cycles of nature with a keen eye.

I believe the author adds this passage to the story to represent determination and America. While Saeng is not originally from Laos, she is determined and willing to try and adapt to American customs. While the winter was cold and harsh in many ways for her, the Spring will bring forgiveness and relief from her hardships. She will try to pass the driving test again to further herself into American culture, while the blooming of the Hibiscus will bring her memories of home.

The author probably concludes the story with that paragraph to show that Saeng has realized she needs to be confident, and to also end the story on a good note. Also, the author wraps things familiar with Saeng, and things native to her new home into the last paragraph. At the beginning of the story, the girl seemed very upset and lost in this country, and missed her home greatly. "A wave of loss so deep and strong that it stung Saeng's eyes now swept over her." But once she gets home, and tells her mother she failed her driving test, she seems to feel better, indicating a shift in her emotional state. Towards the end, after she planted the hibiscus, she sees geese and she feels as if they're "almost familiar". The paragraph that ends the selection does a good job of tying her past (the hibiscus), her present (the geese & the snow) and the drama of the story (failing the test) into one, suggesting a sense of integration and hope for the future.

She wanted to learn, and do more things. She loved the way the plants looked at the store, their vibrant colors and interesting shapes captivating her. And she said that next year I’ll grow a plant as wonderful as the one her mom was growing, full of beautiful blooms.

I think the author concludes this paragraph in this story to describe how grown up Saeng is now since it doesn't look like she leaves with her mom anymore. "d-d failed the test that Saeng paid.î This tells the reader that she attempted to adapt to her new home but failed. The author concludes the story with this paragraph to show that Saeng isn't going to give up. With the hibiscus around Saeng, she will have more courage and also have had more time to adapt in their new home. The story concludes that paragraph because it tells you that there are changes in the weather and seasons just as there are in your life, implying you have to sometimes deal with changes. In the story “Winter Hibiscus” by Minfong Ho, the writer ends with a paragraph that concludes the story. One of the reasons she concluded with the last paragraph the way she did is because it tells the reader that Saeng has not given up on her driver's test. “Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and the hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” This explains in more detail when she will take the test again, another year on, and also because it leaves the reader to think about how the rest of the story will go, implying that her determination remains strong despite the initial setback, suggesting a hopeful future.

I believe that the author's conclusion, "When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again," was a great way to end it because she sees how much the hibiscus can take, and believes she can endure just about anything, mainly the test. Also, when her mother said, "You what?" and "Her mother stared at her incredulously," she might have understood that if her mum could get over being mad, then she would overcome being upset about the test; much like the hibiscus, she too can recover and bloom again. Therefore, the ending signifies Saeng's renewed hope and determination, drawing strength from the resilience of nature and her mother's eventual acceptance.

The writer writes this conclusion to the end of the story because he wants people to know that the seasons are changing and the flowers are going to be dying. The hibiscus flower is viewed as a symbol of hope and a reminder of their homeland. the author concludes the story with this paragraph, because it tells that if you fail the first time, there is always a second time, just like the seed I dies in the winter and it comes back alive in the spring. The author chose to conclude the story like that because she’s saying that it isn’t over and she’s going to take the test again. I think what the author is trying to say is that she will take her driving test again in the spring when the flowers are out because it will make her feel more relaxed and less anxious. In the story "Winter Hibiscus" by Minfong Ho, the author concludes the story with that final sentence likely because it signifies the end of the growing season for the plants, but it also implies a promise of return when the time is right. She will be back to nurture them, as caring for these plants has become a central part of her life. The author might have also ended the story in this way to pique the reader's interest, leaving them in a state of anticipation, wondering if she will indeed return to the plants and her studies. Another reason for this ending could be that, despite the current snowfall, she remains committed to the plants but understands that their care must wait until the appropriate season arrives. Her statement, "when they come back then I will take the test again," demonstrates her unwavering dedication and her intention to persevere in pursuing her passions, showing that she is not giving up on the things she loves and will continue to strive until she succeeds.

In the story "The Winter Hibiscus", I think the author uses the last paragraph to show that although the memories of her old country would always be with her, she soon will adapt to her new one. The author concludes the story with this paragraph to show that Saeng is going to retake the test when these seasonal changes occur. The author concludes the story with the last paragraph of the story. When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, their I will take that test again, ready to prove her understanding and determination.

In “Winter Hibiscus,” the author concludes with Saeng saying “I will take that test, again,” it means that Saeng will be ready as soon as the spring arrives and her hibiscus is all in bloom. When Saeng bought the hibiscus, she was sure that as soon as the winter passes with the coming of spring, she is sure that taking the driver's test again will be easier; the blooming hibiscus mirrors her own anticipated growth and resilience, helping to overcome the fear and grieving times in a new place. This means that Saeng is able to overcome her fear of a new place. Saeng is also sure that the memories of her homeland will help her, too, providing her with a sense of grounding and strength. The author includes this last paragraph in the story, ìWinter Hibiscusî to show that the main character still has hopes and has not given up on her new lifestyle. During the story, the main character Saeng reminisces on her not so distant past memories of her native home in Vietnam when she recognizes a certain plant from her country. This is important in the story because Saeng is still unhappy about moving to America and she begins to cry as she walks home, having bought the plant, to her mother. ìA wave of loss so deep and strong that it stung Saengís eyes now swept over her.î Saengís mother understood how she was feeling, and she was not dissapointed in her for failing her driving test either. Her mother made Saeng feel better by planting the familiar Hibiscus into the garden right away. The last paragraph of the story gives hope to the reader that Saeng will not give up her strength to live a different life in America that she is not used to. ìWhen the snows melt, and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.î It is as if Saeng is vowing that in time, she will be happy with her new life, not just passing a driving test, suggesting a willingness to adapt. The Winter Hibiscus stands as a symbol for Saeng to be strong in the new country while still remembering her old life in Vietnam, showing her resilience.

The author of "Winter Hibiscus" uses this paragraph to conclude her story because it is a symbol of Saeng’s future. Winter Hibiscus is a symbol of Saeng for many reasons. The author of "Winter Hibiscus" concludes the story with the paragraph, "When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again." The author concluded the story with this paragraph for one reason. That reason is because Saeng thinks she failed because she got a fake plant instead of a real one. "When they comeback, Saeng vowed to herself, in the spring when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again." This statement aligns with the story because Saeng finds solace and determination in her garden, a place inaccessible during the snowy winter months. Her love for plants is evident, making the budding hibiscus a symbol of renewed hope and a promise to revisit the test when spring arrives. The connection to plants runs deeper; perhaps she recalls a similar plant, maybe even visiting a florist later, only to be disappointed if something were to go wrong with them, further emphasizing the emotional importance she places on the natural world, thus solidifying her resolve to retake the test alongside nature's rebirth.

This suggests they are inherently pretty and strong, capable of blooming fully in the spring. Itís also reflected to the flower, how theyíre pretty and strong in spring, further reinforcing the idea of inner strength leading to eventual flourishing.

In the short story, ìWinter Hibiscus,î by Minfong Ho, the author includes a paragraph at the end, stating that the main character, Saeng, will take her driving test again. Ho includes this paragraph to show that Saeng is determined to adapt. Saeng is new to the United States; she and her mother had moved there from Vietnam. Throughout the story she is reminiscing about her home life in Vietnam, about her grandmother, and the flowers there. ìWhere was me...hibiscus hedge?.. Her gentle grandmother?î When at the flower shop, Saeng finds a hibiscus, a flower they also had in Vietnam. She sees how it has adapted to survive in the winter here, despite the unfamiliar climate. As she is planting the flower in her backyard, she makes a promise to herself to pass the driving test next spring. She, too, wants to become adapted to the United States and be able to live there without missing home too much. This vow she made is included in the last paragraph; the author included it to show Saeng, too, wants to adapt to her surroundings and pass the driving test, demonstrating her resilience and willingness to embrace her new life.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to illustrate the true meaning of the hibiscus. The hibiscus is symbolic to Saeng in several ways, but the most important is that it represents change and growth and the ability to overcome obstacles. Upon seeing it, she is overcome with childhood memories and sentimentality, longing for her familiar life. However, she must adjust to her new home if she wants to grow as a person and adapt to her surroundings. She will survive here, just as the hibiscus will survive through the winter and bloom again. Also, Saeng vows that “in the spring” when “this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” She is determined to succeed and persevere, and the hibiscus itself represents triumph over obstacles. It stands for survival and endurance through life’s disappointments and challenges, from failing a driver’s test to starting a new life in a strange and foreign country. The author’s choice to end the story with this paragraph exhibits Saeng’s ultimate understanding of her strength through the symbol of the hibiscus, highlighting her resilient spirit.

I believe that the author concludes the paragraph like that because he/she wanted to show an important message to the audience. The message that the author was trying to get across was that even though she didn't pass the test she was going to try again next year. An example of this is an exact quote ìin the spring when the snow melts and the geese return and the hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test againî. This shows resilience and determination, highlighting that failure is not final, but rather an opportunity for future success, which is why I think the author concludes the story like that.

The author includes the story with this paragraph because since Saeng failed her driver's test the first time when the hibiscus starts to bud, it will represent a change in her life, potentially signifying a fresh start. The author finished the story with, ìwhen they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melts and the geese return and this hibiscus budding, then I will take that test again.î The reason for conclusion is that it is important for Saeng to feel at home.
