Which then relates it to the theme of adjusting and keep trying till you adjust, demonstrating resilience in the face of setbacks. That last paragraph was quite vital to the theme and meaning of the story, solidifying the central message of continuous effort and adaptation.

I believe the author concludes the story ìWinter Hibiscusî, written by Minfong Ho, with ìWhen they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test againî, because she is trying to show how past memories can be transformed into hope and determination. After failing her driving test Saeng finds the Hibiscus, a familiar plant that reminds her of her native Laos. The memories of her homeland and her grandmother consume her. She buys the plant and puts it in the vegetable garden, a tangible link to her past. After she is done planting, feeling a renewed connection to her roots, Saeng sees a flock of Canada geese fly overhead. Using her memory of her old home and her family, now applied to her new surroundings, Saeng vows to re-take the test, to try again, demonstrating resilience. The author ends the story ìWinter Hibiscusî with that paragraph to show that Saeng will not give up, suggesting that her past provides strength for her future endeavors.

The author concludes with this story to show how Saeng is ready to accept her new life. Once the geese and the hibiscus are back she feels like she's at home. When she feels more at home is when she will be ready to take the test again. The text states “if the hibiscus is budding, and the geese return" then I will take that test again”. Clearly the geese and hibiscus remind her of home, providing a sense of comfort and familiarity in her new surroundings. Once she feels at home, she will feel at ease, less anxious and more confident in her abilities. That's why the author concluded with this passage: to emphasize Saeng's reliance on these symbols of home as indicators of her readiness to face future challenges.

The author concluded with that paragraph because it restated the story's main idea, ensuring the readers understood the central theme. By summarizing the key elements, the author reinforced the narrative's purpose, leaving the audience with a clear understanding of what the story was ultimately about, thus providing a sense of closure.

The author explains that she has failed the test. While it is still winter and the hibiscus is still trying to grow it's lovely peddles back. As she tells her mother that she will not take the test again, until the hibiscus starts budding and spring is back, signaling a time of renewal and, perhaps, a fresh start for her as well.

Yes, I do think that this concludes the story because after all of that in the story and all that learning about gardening from her mother, she remembers what her mother had said about the hibiscus and its budding. And what she means by this ending sentence is that when the springtime comes, then she is going to take that test again. The test will determine whether or not she has learned enough about gardening from her mother over the past time, showing that the cycle of learning and growth will continue.

The author concludes the Story with this paragraph because I guess her grandma died while the geese were flying, a detail echoed in the somber tone. Or that’s when the flowers start to bloom, signaling a new beginning alongside the grief. The passage likely connects the grandmother's passing to the changing seasons, perhaps symbolizing a cycle of life and death reflected in nature. This juxtaposition of loss and renewal adds a layer of emotional complexity, suggesting the grandma's memory will forever be intertwined with the beauty and transience of the natural world, bringing a bittersweet closure to the narrative.

The author of ìWinter Hibiscusî included the last paragraph to convey to readers that she will be moving on, but still remembering her old country. Before finding the flower, the author terribly missed her old country. "Itís-itís not a real one, ëSaeng mumbled. 'I mean not like the kind we had at-atí she found that she was still too shaky to say the words at home, last she burst into tears again." She missed her home in the other country and was having trouble getting past it. The author could not accept her new country as home yet. Saeng, the hibiscus flower brought back memories of her old country, making it even more difficult to move on. One of the blossoms had fallen off, and carefully Saeng picked it up and smelled it. Saeng could almost feel the light strands of her grandmotherís long gray hair, freshly washed, as she combed it out with the fine-toothed buffalo-horn comb." The flower was too much of a memory. She finally had something from home that she could hold. ìGently, she closed her palm around it and held it tight. That, at least, she could hold onto.î The author now had a solid thing to remind her of home, a tangible link to her past. This was the first step to finally moving on. Now Saeng needed some time to get use to her new country. ìAlmost reluctantly, she realized that many things that she had thought of as strange before had become almost familiar to her now.î Saeng needed just a little more time, almost like a hibernation. She decided once the hibiscus came out of hibernation, and was ready to bloom, she would be ready to accept her new country and move on. Saeng decide the time between fall and spring would be long enough to adjust to her new life, to witness the changing seasons and find her place within them. By taking the test, Saeng will be moving on. The author included this last paragraph so that readers can infer that Saeng will take the last steps towards acceptance of her new country and move on by taking the test, although she will look back on her old country through the winter hibiscus, a symbol of her enduring connection to her roots even as she embraces her new life.

The story includes this paragraph because at the very beginning of the story the girl failed the test. And so when she told her mother, she saw that she was upset with it. So after they planted the plant, she decided to take the test over, knowing that her mother would think the best of it. It's also there because the story started out with her telling her mother that she failed the test, and if you kept it out, people who read it would be like, ok, so her mother just let her fail the test and didn't do anything about it. Plus, when the reader reads that the girl failed the test, they are going to be wanting to know if she took it again, and why she took it again if she did, making the resolution more satisfying and complete.

The author ended the story with an unconcluded ending. What I mean is the author wrote so that he could keep readers interested so that they would want to read his other books. Also, with an ending of that sort it kind of leaves room for improving and room for a sequel, thus creating a lasting connection with the audience and potential for future engagement.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to show that Saeng is not going to give up until she successfully passes the task her mother gives her. Saeng fails the test because, though she buys a beautiful plant, it is much too expensive. "But how could you? All the seeds for this vegetable garden didn't cost that much!" Saeng becomes very upset and realizes that she has failed her mother's implicit challenge to be both resourceful and appreciative of beauty. Saeng still plants the winter hibiscus in the ground. "Left alone in the garden, Saeng dug out a hole and carefully lowered the 'winter hibiscus' into it." This shows that even though she had failed the economic aspect of the task, she wasn’t going to give up on the hibiscus because it represented her home and the beauty she sought to bring into it. It was very special to her, and her dedication to planting it underscores her resilience and determination to keep trying, highlighting her unwavering spirit.

The Author concludes with that paragraph because she wants to reiterate her central argument. This final section serves to reinforce the key themes explored throughout the piece, ensuring the reader leaves with a clear understanding of the author's perspective. By summarizing the main points, the author effectively drives home the significance of her analysis and leaves a lasting impression. Ultimately, the concluding paragraph aims to solidify the author's message and provide a sense of closure to the discussion.

I think the author concluded the story with this paragraph because it shows that the character in the story is starting to adapt to her new country. In the beginning of the story the character Saeng is feeling homesick and has not adapted to her new country. She is on her way home from her driver’s test, which she just failed, and on the way she spots a hibiscus in a flower shop. The hibiscus is special to her because it reminds her of her home country of Vietnam. For Saeng the hibiscus represents comfort in time of disappointment, connection to her past experiences and ability to overcome obstacles. Saeng has not adjusted to this change in her life and it has affected her badly. The author concluded the story with this paragraph because he wanted to show the reader that there will always be changes and obstacles in your life, but there will always be something or someone that will help you overcome it; the hibiscus serves as a potent reminder of home and resilience. The author shows this by concluding the story with this paragraph, demonstrating that Saeng embodies the hibiscus, symbolizing her way of overcoming challenges, and implying that when she is ready and has adjusted, she will take her driving test again, facing the future with renewed hope and strength.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because he’s saying that once winter and spring’s over and the hibiscus is budding, then I’ll start over again and try again. The author is saying Saeng can’t wait till spring so she can plant her own little garden. This is why I think the author concludes the story with this paragraph, highlighting Saeng's resilient spirit and her hopeful anticipation for a new beginning.

Saeng planned a year-long transformation, a rebirth in preparation for the test retake. She envisioned becoming a new person by then, shedding old habits and anxieties. Her mother, however, seemed to disapprove of every choice, every step Saeng took towards this goal. Then, a sudden understanding washed over her regarding the hibiscus and its inevitable death, "... thought the quiet repetition of season upon season." The flower, like the geese migrating and returning, mirrored her own journey. Through phases of dormancy and renewal, the hibiscus bloomed again, more vibrant than before; Saeng hoped to achieve a similar growth, emerging stronger and better after her own period of change.

The reason why the author concludes the story with this paragraph is because when she came back from taking her driver's test, she saw a winter hibiscus that was so beautiful. Then, she went to the store and bought those flowers, which cost a lot of money. When she got home, her mom was planting vegetables, and her mom asked her what that was. So she told the truth, and when her mom found out the flower's cost, she got mad at the frivolousness of it all; how could she do that? Saeng makes a big decision that she is going to that event, even though her mom is mad; she loves those flowers, perhaps because they remind her of Vietnam. The author includes this paragraph, I think, because as the geese return and the flowers bloom, she will take the test again. Because when she bought them, no flowers had come out yet, so when they bloom, she will go again, as if to let her know that you see something the first time, and wait for it to grow, then you can try again. In my opinion, that is a good ending and a good question too, as it suggests a cycle of perseverance and hope, tying her personal growth to the natural world.

The author concludes the story with "when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself...," because it offers the reader a conclusion. That passage means that Saeng will try talking her drivers test again once she has adjusted to her new life in a new country. Once she can find familiarity in her surroundings she will feel more at home. Throughout the story, her detachment from Vietnam makes her feel alone. The hibiscus plant is what first offers her a sense of comfort, "It felt smooth and cool... just as she had known it would feel." This connection to nature helps ease her transition. The ending paragraph shows that Saeng will find more comfort in her new home than just a plant and a couple of geese, suggesting she will embrace her new life and find her place there.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because when the “snow does melt and the Geese return” it will be time to plant and work in the garden even more. With snow on the ground, planting is impossible, but the return of the geese signifies the right time of year to plant the seed and hopefully have a better flock/harvest and grander garden. The test is to see if she can achieve a better grade than in previous years, signifying successful growth and improvement in her gardening endeavors.

The author concluded his story with that paragraph is because that's how it should end, and that’s why he ended it like that. It provides a sense of closure and finality suitable for the narrative he crafted, leaving the reader with the intended lasting impression.

The author concludes the story with ìin the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again. She does this to show how Saeng is adapting and making decisions in her new country just like she did in her homeland. In Vietnam Saeng used to brush her grandmothers hair and help put it into a bun and put a hibiscus in it. That was one of her traditions with it. Also when she used to get water from the well a hibiscus would sometimes come up with the bucket. Both these thus the hibiscus was seen as a comfort object, now as she is in the states, she is trying to put it to good use, while also taking into account what repeats in the states. She notices that the geese come back in the spring and leave in the winter, and plants start to grow in the spring. By her taking the test again in the spring it is symbolizing that she is ready to start afresh, just like the hibiscus that is going to bloom and mirror her own growth. The plant being potted in her garden and Saeng moving there both signify change, but a remembrance of old traditions, and a space for new.

The author put that sentence in the story because she feels that will give her enough time to get the test right, since the sentence creates a distraction for the teacher, and because she likes geese.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to show the final determination and strength Saeng has been given. It's almost as though it's taken this plant to show her to get back up and pass the test, symbolizing her resilience. The plant becomes a comforting item that reminds her of her homeland and the life she left behind. She returned with the plant to show her mother but found herself too shaky to even say the words "at home," highlighting her continued struggle with displacement. This shows how much she misses home and the familiar comforts it provided. But she is able to realize that this is her new home, a place where she can cultivate new roots, and everything is becoming more familiar to her, suggesting a gradual acceptance and hope for the future.

She ends it with this sentence because it's a sign of new life. Just as the winter that killed the plants ending life, the spring will come and start anew. This is how Saeng feels because she left her country and all the memories left behind; she feels out of place like the winter hibiscus, but as the spring comes, she’ll feel as a new person, ready and able to take challenges, as she said here, “through the quiet repetition of season upon season, almost familiar to her now.” She describes that with a new season comes new changes, and upon those changes she will go on to take the driver's test again, indicating her willingness to embrace the future and integrate into her new environment, finding a sense of belonging through the cyclical nature of life.

The author ends with that paragraph for several reasons. One is to show that she has failed this time, implying that more opportunities will come later. Also, it shows that even though bad times befall her now, the possibility of good times is still present, offering a sense of hope. For several reasons, it was a powerful and efficient way to end the story, leaving the reader with a feeling of anticipation and the understanding that her journey, though currently stalled, is far from over.

The author uses symbolism to convey a different message. Saeng said in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, and then I will take that test again. The author uses the hibiscus to symbolize Saeng gets older like the hibiscus, and as it blooms, that then she will be ready to take that test again. The author uses symbolize to convey more of the story's meaning and depth.

She wrote that response to tell everyone that she will be ready, but by the time when spring comes around next year. Then she will take what she learned and pass the exam, demonstrating her preparedness.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because Saeng wants to start planting again. I know this because Saeng life revolves around planting and FAMILY. Saeng and her mother get there food from what they plant. So all DAY they spend most there time in the garden, growing crops to sell and save. They save for winter and sell to get there equiement to continue whot they do. The part she talking about in the paragraph that say ìwhen they come backî talking about the geese. She loves the geese flying over her head and landing in the yard when she outside on a beauttiful day FAMILY. When The snow melts she wants to get back at in the soil on her hands and knee to start planting again. Once the hibiscus start budding everything else starts growing. Saeng live revolves around DAY planting. The author put this paragraph in the story because this is what Saeng wants to do more than anything, and this reinforces the central theme of renewal and connection to the land that defines her existence.

In the conclusion of ìWinter Hibiscusî Saeng notes how she will retake her driving test in the spring when the snow melts and the geese return. The spring is when these events occur along with the annual budding of the winter hibiscus. Her family had moved from Minnesota from Vietnam, and she had bought a winter hibiscus plant to remind her of her childhood. When it blooms, she will retake her driving test because the bloom will bring her the hope of a new beginning in her life, and as a citizen in Minnesota.

In ìWinter Hibiscusî a young girl named Saeng moves away from home. This transition brings many changes as the young girl tries to adapt to the new lifestyle. She misses the familiar comfort of her old surroundings. The new environment presents challenges, and Saeng grapples with feelings of displacement. Despite these difficulties, she shows resilience as she navigates her new reality, holding onto memories while embracing the possibilities ahead. Ultimately, Saeng's journey reveals the universal experience of adjusting to change and finding strength in unfamiliar circumstances, learning and growing with each step.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because she wants the reader to see that Saeng will not stop until she passes her driver's test, just like the geese won’t stop until they are in the south for winter, driven by an inner need. The author is trying to show the beauty of trying again and going through your obstacles to your goal, highlighting Saeng's resilience and determination. This parallel emphasizes the natural and inevitable nature of pursuing one's aspirations despite setbacks.

In the story "Winter Hibiscus" by @CAPS1 Ho, the author leaves the story off with a powerful ending. The ending was "When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will try the test again". Basically the author concluded the story with that because it shows she's powerful, that she's willing to try and make herself stronger, that she's willing to try again, and that she wants to help herself. Text examples to prove this would be, "then I will take the hibiscus test again," "Almost reluctantly, she realized that many of the things that she had thought of as strange before had become...", and "There was a frail, wiry beauty to her that touched Saeng deeply." These statements showcase Saeng's resolve to face challenges, her growing understanding of a new culture, and the inner strength she discovers, all backing up why the author might leave such a powerful paragraph for last, emphasizing Saeng's journey of self-improvement and adaptation.

The author, in the story "Winter Hibiscus," concludes the story with the paragraph to show how often Saeng gets tested by her memories. Saeng was "tested" earlier in the story when she was in a florist. Memories come rushing back to her like a flood, and she tried to feel the same as she did long ago when her grandmother was there, and she realized that things in her memories were long gone, so she wept. Saeng reported to her mother that she had failed the test, and bought the plant to try and comfort herself. Her mother was very understanding and accepted it. Saeng planted the hibiscus and at the end says that "In the spring when the snow melts, this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again." Saeng knew seeing the flower again would make her cry, would make her memories come back, she will be re-tested, suggesting the cyclical nature of grief and remembrance and her ongoing effort to reconcile her past with her present.

In the story "Winter Hibiscus" by @CAPS1 Ho, Saeng failed her driver's test that day, then vowed that she would retake it in the spring. She ends with this statement to say that it is a new season and a new beginning for her into her new life. This archetype, the changing from harsh cold winter to nice warm spring time, shows that the troubles her mother and Saeng faced would get better. As the hard trouble of winter left, there is a calm, warm new beginning in spring. Saeng knows this and knows that she is going to pass, embracing the hope and renewal that the season promises.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph for various reasons. For example, the whole passage is talking about how the hibiscus flower provides Saeng with the ability to overcome obstacles, and comfort her in a time of disappointment. This ending paragraph shows that ìin the spring, when the hibiscus is budding,î and the world around her is renewed, then Saeng will take her test again. She knows that with the help of the hibiscus plant, and the resilience it represents, that she will pass the test. It shows that her hope and trust to pass the test comes from the hibiscus flower. The plant with ìwaxy leaves and dainty flowers with purplish petals and white centersî will provide her the strength, determination, courage, and will power to pass the test in the spring, proving that even after setbacks, growth and success are possible.

In the story “Winter Hibiscus,” the author ends with the statement, “...then I’ll take the test again.” This shows that Saeng is willing to try to adapt to this new place she lives in, which is what she refers to when she says “test.” For example, in the story she said, “I-I failed the test,” when her mother asked her what was wrong, indicating her struggle to adjust. She spent so much money on that plant, hoping to stay home in her mind, clinging to a piece of her past. She just couldn’t handle that feeling of displacement. She ends with the positive statement because it sends the message that she looks forward to a bright future in her new home, suggesting a newfound resolve to face the challenges ahead and integrate into her new environment.

In the story ìWinter Hibiscusî by Minfong Ho, the author concludes the story with that paragraph for many reasons, using examples from the story to illustrate them. One reason is to show the protagonist's resilience. Her statement, ìThen I will take the test again,î reveals her determination and refusal to give up easily. Another reason is to symbolize the hibiscus's potential for adaptation. The phrase ìÖand this hibiscus is budding,î suggests the hibiscus has a chance to adjust to its new environment, mirroring the girl's own journey of adaptation. A final reason is to emphasize her effort and progress. When she says ìshe realized that many of the things that she had thought were strangeÖ, almost familiar to her now,î it highlights her attempts to adapt and her growing comfort. These reasons suggest why the author chose to end the story with that paragraph, as it provides insights into the character's growth and foreshadows a hopeful future.

The author of "Winter Hibiscus" concludes the story determined to pass the test after the winter is over and the flower is budding. This shows the connection between the plant and the narrator and the hardships of each. The winter represents an obstacle for the flower, but it will live through it to thrive in the spring. This gives the author confidence that she too can make it through her hardships to thrive. Another hardship that she and the hibiscus both face is being "root bound." The author misses her home of Vietnam very much, feeling restricted and out of place in her new surroundings. However, both of them must and will adapt to their new environments, finding the strength to bloom where they are planted, ultimately proving their resilience.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph because it shows that she misses her home and that affected her driving test. At her home country it was warm, filled with sunshine, and she had all her family memories embedded in the landscape. In the new country it is cold and snowy, something she isn't used to, a stark contrast to the familiar warmth she longs for. It states she will take the test again when all them things happen – when the weather warms and reminds her of home – because it will feel like her home country and she will be more focused on the test and not what she misses, increasing her chances of success.

The author Minfong Ho concluded the story “Winter Hibiscus” with that certain paragraph to show that Saeng would not give up, that she was determined to pass the driving test and also in a way get used to her new home and adapt to the new culture. It is kind of like a motivation, “when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” The hibiscus flower serves as the motivation, bringing back good memories of people back home that made her happy and believed in her abilities. Minfong also concluded the story the way he/she did to say, by next year Saeng will start fresh, leaving the past behind. To become happy with her new life and not dwell on her past sorrows. Saeng says, “…in the spring…” it’s the beginning of a new year, a chance to start over, and rejoice in the possibilities. This was a really good way to end the story, because it sets a positive vibe, suggesting hope and resilience. It’s letting the readers know that Saeng is a strong person, who can remember the past but move on to a new day and life. And I think the author is trying to point out that everyone should have the strength to do the same, embracing change and finding hope in new beginnings.

She ended it with that paragraph because she wanted to prove even though she misses the "old century," with its familiar comforts and traditions, she will adapt and survive. The changing world, while unsettling, doesn't frighten her into inaction. Instead, she acknowledges the necessity of evolving alongside it, demonstrating a resilience that ensures her continued existence and perhaps even a measure of success in the face of progress. This closing statement underscores her determination to not be a relic of the past, but a participant in the future.

I think the author concludes the story with this paragraph because it sounds hopeful. She wasn't adapting to her new home very well, and that made her feel hopeless. Saeng failed her driving test, which only made things worse. To make things better, she bought a hibiscus that reminded her of her old home. She found the plant to be very comforting, and it helped her get past the tough times. In the last paragraph, Saeng is looking forward to the spring so she can retake the test and hopefully pass it this time, suggesting a brighter future. I think the paragraph provides a feeling of hopefulness, which is why the author concluded the story the way they did, leaving the reader with a sense of optimism.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to show that Saeng will not give up and there is still hope. It is also to teach the reader to have hope and patience and the knowledge that things take time. Saeng failed the test of not giving into her sorrows and misery of missing her country. She says, ìAlmost reluctantly, she realized that many of the things she had thought of as strange before had become, through the quiet repetition of season upon season, almost familiar to her now.î This shows that she is adjusting to her new surroundings and way of life, a crucial step in overcoming her initial despair. So by ending it with this and comparing to the geese, who undertake arduous journeys with unwavering determination, it's showing that she is getting stronger, both internally and in her resolve. She will take the test again because she wont give up, indicating a resilience that suggests future success is possible.

Clearly, from reading the story Winter @CAPS1, the author @CAPS2 uses the phrase “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test Again” in the story because the passage relates to the title of the story Winter @CAPS1, highlighting the contrast between the present hardship and a future hope tied to the changing seasons, offering a sense of perseverance that transcends the current cold and difficulty.

The reason the author concludes the story with that paragraph is because, even though Saeng didn’t do well on her last test, Saeng will go back and take it again so she can pass it. The author is showing Saeng’s determination to pass the test and do better next time, highlighting her resilient spirit and commitment to achieving her goals despite facing setbacks. This ending emphasizes Saeng's proactive approach and unwavering resolve, leaving the reader with a sense of hope and admiration for her persistence.

I think the author ends the story with that paragraph because it is linking the plant, which stands for many positive things, to the character that failed the test that they really wanted to pass. Both the character and the plant show perseverance, and I think the author is trying to send a message to the reader to never give up on something you want to accomplish. The plant gives an emblem of perseverance because it survives through the harsh winter. The main character isn’t giving up on the test they want to pass, even with this setback. The author is giving a message not to give up, suggesting that like the resilient plant, the character too can endure and ultimately succeed.

At the end of the story the author says ìwhen they come back in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that again.î The author concludes this at the end because she felt like she didnít do her best, she felt that she failed. So when the spring comes again, a time of renewal and second chances symbolized by the returning geese and blossoming hibiscus, she is going to retry to do it, to take on the challenge again. Hopefully this time, with a fresh start and renewed determination mirroring the rebirth of spring, she will pass.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph. Because she wants to come back and do a smell test again when the snow melts and the geese return, hopeful that the thawing earth and returning wildlife might offer a different, perhaps more optimistic, olfactory narrative of the landscape.

@ORGANIZATION1 is about a girl named Saeng. She is a teenager whose family just moved to the United States from Vietnam. Saeng failed her driving test, and on the walk home, she discovers a beautiful Hibiscus plant and falls in love with it. Saeng's mother has a garden where she is always planting things, using plants and veggies from her garden for dinner. The author concludes a paragraph stating that where the Hibiscus plants are budding in the spring, Saeng will take the test again. Saeng likely says this because she wants to see the beautiful plants when she passes the test, and she thinks seeing the Hibiscus will help her pass the driving test, providing her with a sense of hope and good luck.

I think the author concludes the story with that paragraph because she is giving herself hope on passing her test. The hibiscus, a symbol of her home, will have started sprouting, reminding her of resilience and growth. This connection to home and the promise of new beginnings will give her the strength to take the test again and hopefully pass it, all because the winter hibiscus reminded her of the familiar comforts and unwavering support she associates with her roots. This provides a sense of optimism and determination as she faces future challenges.

The author concludes the story with the paragraph of "when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again" because this paragraph can show that the hibiscus, with its resilience, inspires Saeng to try the test again. If the hibiscus is budding after the snow melts and the geese return, signaling renewal and perseverance, then she can emulate the hibiscus, drawing strength from its blossoming to not give up on her test.

The author concludes the story with this to show that Saeng won’t give up. It is possible to adapt and try to love what's around you. Saeng struggled to get out "I-I failed the test" and couldn’t say "at home"; this shows her insecurity and loneliness in the new world around her, and by saying she will try again in the spring gives the reader hope that she will adapt and love her surroundings. She goes through an experience today, contrasting her old life and comparing it to the one she is living in now, revealing some similarities; because she will try again in the spring, it means she has decided to give a new place a chance, ultimately suggesting her resilient spirit and willingness to embrace change.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because she says "Then I will take that test again"; she believes in the Flowers. She and the Flowers both adapt to their circumstances, being determined to **thrive** in **unlikely** places. They both overcome obstacles. Maybe she wants to see what lays ahead, and she hopes she is right about the Flowers; maybe she likes the spring, suggesting an optimistic outlook and a willingness to face future challenges with renewed hope.

I actually like the way the author concludes the story with this paragraph. It basically summarizes the story and sums it up into few words that would want you to wonder what happened next, and if there is a sequel. The concise ending leaves you pondering the protagonist's future, hinting at unresolved conflicts or new beginnings. This is a very good story that I personally can relate to in many ways. The themes explored resonate deeply, making the narrative all the more compelling and leaving a lasting impression.

The reason why the author concludes this type of scenario is simply because the author has a pain to cross and or a situation. In the story “Winter Hibiscus,” the author Minfong Ho ends with “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring when the snows melt and geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again." She ended with this to show her determination to do good in her new country and show that memories of her grandmother help her to strive for the best in her new home. In the beginning of the story Saeng is at a flower shop and she sees all the flowers of her home country growing in pots. At the sight of all these flowers, memories flood back to her, memories that bring her both joy and sadness. Then when she returns home she tells her mother that she failed the test; you can tell from her actions that she is disappointed, “I-I failed the test,” Saeng did not dare look her mother in the eye, nervously tore off a leaf, shredding it to bits.” After a while she planted the hibiscus flower in the vegetable garden. The buying and planting of the flower shows that Saeng wants to remember her grandmother and her home country. Thinking about her grandmother helps her strive for better, helps her want to succeed in her new home. Memories of her grandmother make her sad but in a way also make her happy, fueling her resolve to try again and succeed.

The author concludes the story this way with a quote that says she will get another try at something, a choice that leaves the future open. Using this technique can be effective because the reader understands the events that have transpired, and it makes them wonder whether the character will fail or succeed in their next attempt, leaving a lasting impression.

In the story, "Winter Hibiscus," by @CAPS1 Ho, the author concludes the story with, "when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt. and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again'' because the hibiscus represents hope and adapting to circumstances. Saeng is trying to adapt to the new changes in her life but nothing is working out for her. "She found that she was still too shaky to say the words at home, lest she burst in to tears again." @CAPS2 the Hibiscus makes her life easier because it reminds her of her homeland and her family, @CAPS3 it gives her hope, "look how root-bound it is, poor thing," the root-bound represents Saeng in her new country. Unwilling to try anything, and getting scared but as soon as Saeng and her mother plant the hibiscus, Saeng realizes that by planting it, she is going to try to love her new life in @LOCATION1 America, and in spring when the hibiscus and Saeng is ready to blossom, she will start trying to accept life. It signifies that just like the hibiscus, she too can adapt and thrive.

Mingfong Ho closes the story with that paragraph because it shows how far Saeng has come and her determination to persevere. The narrator says, ìShe lifted her head and watched as their distinctive V was etched against the evening sky, slowly facing into the distance ì(Ho @NUM1). This is when Saeng is recovering from crying and even though she misses her homeland, she wants to adapt and succeed where she is now. The narrator also said, ìshe found that she was still too shaky to say the words at home, lest she burst into tears againî (Ho @NUM1). Being away from her homeland makes Saeng very homesick, but her resolve to move forward is evident. The final image of the geese flying away symbolizes her own journey and her commitment to building a new life, despite the lingering pain of leaving her past behind, ultimately demonstrating her strength and resilience.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because they feel that the plant will bring them luck or something. Saeng feels that the plant gives her some type of comfort. After all the hardships she's faced, nurturing this small life provides a sense of hope and a tangible connection to growth and resilience, and this connection offers a quiet solace.

I believe the author concluded the story with this paragraph because in the story, the author says “through the quiet repetition of season upon season” which means that seasons will come and seasons will go, but she’ll always be there, ready to “take the test,” suggesting an enduring commitment and acceptance of her role within the cyclical nature of life.

The author is probably trying to say in the spring when the seasons change, the snow melts, and the geese return, filling the air with their honking calls, and the hibiscus is budding, promising vibrant color, he will take the test again. Therefore, he will attempt the test again when the time is right.

The author concludes that failing the test is not the worst thing. She realizes that times change and you can always get another chance, which is explained in the last paragraph that once the hibiscus buds bloom, signaling warmer weather and new beginnings, she will take the test again. This signifies her acceptance of the setback and her renewed hope for future success. Therefore, she understands that life offers multiple opportunities for growth and achievement.

...The author conclude the story with her saying in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, a symbol of resilience against the harsh winter, then I will take that test again, better prepared and with a stronger resolve, determined to show myself that I will not gust out like that.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph. It means so many things about her in just one little sentence. For example "take that test again" she willing to do it all over again; she loves it and wants to do it. Also when she said "in spring; when the snows melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding" from that, it suggests that when you come back, don't forget about all the things she just listed. That's why the author concludes the story with this paragraph, encapsulating her resilient spirit and her connection to the cyclical beauty of nature, emphasizing a return and remembrance.

This story about believing in yourself and never giving up is a story about perseverance. Saeng really believed she could pass her driver's test, and although she was disappointed with the result, she found a way to cope with her loss. The hibiscus flower means a lot to her because she can connect it to her homeland, and it is a thing of beauty, something she needed at such an ugly time for her. It's always hard to adapt to a new country in a short period of time, especially with the added pressure of everyday tasks. I know what it's like when one small thing goes wrong; it can feel like the end of the world. You can snap and it will feel a lot worse than it actually is, making you feel helpless and alone, just like the hibiscus growing next to the highway in the photo, seemingly out of place. Saeng vowed to take her driverís test again when her hibiscus would bloom in the spring; I think the hibiscus really symbolizes Saeng as a person, resilient and beautiful, even in a harsh environment, offering hope for a brighter future.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph for many reasons. Saeng was disappointed for failing her driving test, but this feeling is temporary. She found comfort with nature after she went and bought a plant, nurturing it as a way to cope. Saeng must feel that when the geese leave and the hibiscus has not started to bud, it is not her time, and she should not take the drivers test then. She feels comforted by the return of the geese and budding of the hibiscus, associating these natural events with good fortune. This implies nature comforts her and gives her hope. The author ended it like this because it shows Saeng is not as disappointed about failing anymore. She knows she will have another chance next year when the geese return and the hibiscus starts to bud again. With the comfort of nature, she feels she can pass the test next year, finding solace and renewed determination in the cyclical rhythm of the natural world.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph or quote to get the readers something to think about at the end of the reading. For example, it lets the reader know that the person will continue to grow plants when the winter is done, suggesting a cycle of hope and renewal even after a period of hardship. This lingering thought encourages reflection on the enduring nature of perseverance.

In the story "Winter Hibiscus" by Minfong Ho, I think the author concludes the story with this paragraph because it shows Saeng's growing determination. Saeng is having problems with both adjusting and adapting to the changes in her new life, especially her struggle with English. We see an example of this when Saeng comes home with her flower, "she found that she was still too shaky to say the words at home, lest she burst into tears again," highlighting her vulnerability. We see that Saeng bought the flower because it made her feel secure, reminding her of Laos. It was something from home that felt familiar to her, a small piece of her past in a foreign land, and I believe that's why Ho concluded the story with this paragraph: next year, Saeng will likely approach the test with a greater sense of security and familiarity because she will have gained experience, making her more resilient.

The author concludes with this paragraph to show that Saeng is not going to give up, demonstrating her resilience. She also concludes with this to tell people that they should never give up and that they should keep on trying, even when facing obstacles. Even if they have to take a break to study or rethink the plan, perseverance is key, and Saeng's example serves as an encouragement to persist through challenges and ultimately pursue their goals with renewed determination.

When they came back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, "In the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return, and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again." The author included this paragraph to show her determination to improve her grades, marking the passing seasons as a period of renewed effort and focused study before her next attempt.
He ends the paragraph with this because he is implying he would prefer the experience of retaking the test on a nicer day. Therefore, in conclusion, this is why the author ends it with that sentence.

At the end of the short story, ìWinter Hibiscusî, the writer Minfong Ho includes a somewhat inspirational concluding sentence: ìwhen they come back in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding then I will take that test again.î I think this sentence was added in order to create a sense of hope for the future, which contrasts so greatly with the depressing nature of the story, creating a happy ending. Throughout the essay, Saeng is depressed she had to leave her homeland so hurriedly, losing her childhood and beloved grandmother, ìA blink, a channed switch, a boat ride into the night, and it was all gone.î as Saeng narrates in deeper detail. Also contributing to the feelings of sorrow in the story is how much Saeng cries remembering her tragic past in both the greenhouse, recalling the events of her grandmother such as when she says, ìSaeng could almost feel the light strands of her grandmotherís grey hair Saeng would help knot the hair the hair into a bun, then slip a dok Malik bud into it," and in the garden, when she talks to her mother and plants the flower. The hibiscus, a symbol of her former life, offers a tangible link to her memories. After all this sorrow, by putting in a hopeful ending, the writer has successfully allowed a sense of hope for the future.

She says, "Ignoring the spring, I will take the test again," because she knows if she fails the test again, her mother will be disappointed in her for not trying hard enough, or maybe they, too, will never be closer again. The mother thinks she keeps failing the test because of her connection to her past experiences or affection for her new country and ability to overcome obstacles. Finally, I think she is comforted by memories of her homeland. Therefore, she chooses to focus on the task at hand, suppressing the comfort of the past in order to succeed in the present and mend her relationship with her mother.

The author concludes the story with that quote for one main reason: it shows that the girl has hope. In a story, one of the best qualities a character can have is hope because it makes the reader interested and helps provide a good morale for the story, suggesting a possibility of a better future despite current hardships. That is why the author concludes the story with that quote, leaving the reader with a sense of optimism.

The author of this story created the last paragraph so that it finishes the story with a great ending, emphasizing the fact of never giving up and trying again. The author said, “I will take the test again.” In the story, Saeng said, “I failed the test,” but now she isn't giving up. This last paragraph makes a lot of sense and is needed to make this story complete, showcasing her resilience. So, just as others don't give up in @LOCATION1, Saeng is doing the same and is retaking the test, showing her determination to succeed.

The author concludes the story with ìwhen they come back, Saeng wowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test againî, because he wants to express to the readers that she is willingly determined for what she has to do to accomplish what she has failed. Since she has failed the test the first time, experiencing the sting of disappointment, she wants to overcome her failure and succeed. The imagery of the returning geese, melting snow, and budding hibiscus symbolizes a time of renewal and new beginnings, mirroring Saeng's own resolve to try again. Therefore, the author wants her to look determined in the end, embracing the challenge with a renewed spirit.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph because it makes the story longer and it gives it a good ending, providing a sense of closure that the reader might find satisfying. This final paragraph might extend the narrative slightly, adding detail or resolution. The author should elaborate on how specifically the ending is "good," perhaps by pointing to elements of thematic resonance or character development that are finalized in that concluding section, not leaving the interpretation entirely to the reader.

The plant was important to Saeng because it was from her homeland. Saeng said that she would take her driver's test again when her plant bloomed. The plant was a reminder of her homeland and what she came from, a tangible link to her past. The plant to Saeng was a form of confidence, a symbol of hope and resilience. Saeng went through hard times and the plant was close to her because it was from her homeland, offering her comfort and strength during challenging periods, serving as a potent symbol of connection and perseverance.

I believe the author ended the story with that paragraph to create a sense of wonder. I think this because if you put into context the word "test," it could mean many things. For example, it could mean the test to overcome the sadness of her situation after leaving her old life behind. Also, it could mean the test to adjust to her new home and surroundings when the spring comes, bringing unfamiliar changes. That is why I think the author tried to create a sense of wonder with the final paragraph, leaving the reader to ponder the possibilities and uncertainties of the future.

The story “Winter Hibiscus” by Minfong Ho, is about overcoming adversity. She concludes the story by writing “when they come back [the geese] then I will take that test.” The main character, Saeng, had been having trouble at school and on her way home had seen an assortment of flowers that were indigenous to her homeland. “Saeng felt a shock of recognition so intense it was almost painful.” The sight of those flowers namely the hibiscus reminded her of what she lost and offered comfort in the face of the memory. The winter hibiscus could still survive even though it was not in the land where it belonged. Her mother states “It’s flowers aren’t as pretty but it’s strong enough. That’s what counts.” Saeng , after hearing this, decides that she could be strong, too, and would try to do her best in school. She would adapt just like the winter hibiscus, drawing strength from her heritage to face her challenges. This realization gave her the resolve to persevere and demonstrates the story's theme of resilience.

She said that because she was more interested in flowers than a test, specifically the way the sunlight illuminated the delicate petals of the newly bloomed roses in the garden outside the window. This distraction, she confessed with a sigh, made concentrating on quadratic equations nearly impossible, thus explaining her lack of preparedness. Ultimately, her passion lay in observing nature's beauty, overshadowing her academic obligations.

I believe that the author concludes with this paragraph because it shows the ending of one thing and the beginning of another. After she is upset and thinks about home, recalling familiar comforts perhaps, she realizes that something new is happening and she needs to accept it. So therefore in the spring, a time traditionally associated with rebirth, she is going to start new like the flower blossom, embracing the changes and opportunities that lie ahead. This symbolic connection to spring suggests a hopeful outlook, signifying her willingness to move forward and flourish in her new circumstances.

The author ends the story with this paragraph because he wants to get the point out that the character doesn't want to rush into things; she wants to do right and not take the quick way out. It highlights her commitment to a deliberate and thoughtful approach, suggesting a preference for integrity over expediency, thus solidifying her character as someone who values the process as much as the outcome.

It shows the importance of the Hibiscus to Saeng and her dedication to the flower, as she carefully tends to it each day. It is also stating that she will wait for next spring to admire the flower again, patiently anticipating its vibrant bloom after the long winter months.

The author ends this story with this paragraph because she is explaining her thoughts and why she is taking that test, a placement exam that will determine her academic path. She is explaining that next year, after experiencing the classes and the environment, she will find out if this school, this new beginning, feels like home to her. Ultimately, the test is a step towards finding her place.

When the author concluded the narrative by when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and the hibiscus is budding, then I will take test again demonstrates the ability to overcome obstacles, finding comfort in a time of disappointment, and her connection to her past experiences. First, it demonstrates the ability to overcome obstacles because there are obstacles in everyone's lives, and you don't have a choice but to conquer them because they are unlimited. So the hibiscus flower represents the obstacles, and the weather represents time because weather is stopping the flower from blooming. Secondly, it also represents finding comfort in a time of disappointment because when you have gone through an obstacle, you would find disappointment lingering there. However, she knows that the hibiscus will be coming back, and she has the awareness of the obstacles coming back, which give her hope. Finally, it asserts her connection to her past experience because she is trapped in a world that she is not familiar with, which would make her feel like an alien. She captures the sense of being out of place, because you can relate that the hibiscus flower could be her because she feels eccentric and different from the rest of the people in her environment; she is trying to adapt her way of living and trying to survive in the world, like when she was in her own country, highlighting her resilience and determination.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph because it represents Saeng's determination and her present situation. Having just arrived in a new country, she hasn't adjusted yet. She was disappointed, like "shaft of the war afternoon starlight." "War" shows Saeng was very upset. After she saw the flower, she thought of her old country, her homeland, and missed it. Yet, she felt that life was full of hope again. She knew she should adjust to the new situation, though she was still too shaky to say the words "at home." Ultimately, she burst into tears again, missing her homeland very much; "snows" symbolize the difficult situation she faces now. But she believed she could overcome it, and life was full of hope. "Spring" symbolizes the hope for a new life, as Saeng thought things would get better in the spring and that she would succeed then. She had the determination to succeed, so the author uses that paragraph at the conclusion, symbolizing hope and her resolve to build a new life.

The author included this because she felt that since Saeng failed the test that maybe she should be given a second chance because she tried so hard before. When Saeng says “Nothing else. I paid over nineteen dollars for it,” it made her mom upset because she used a lot of money for one plant just so she could feel at home again since she had one when she was at her old home. The mom's reaction stemmed from worrying about finances and wanting Saeng to adjust without spending so much. Eventually her mom says, “It’s a beautiful plant” to make her feel better because she feels bad for how she acted towards her daughter, understanding Saeng's longing for familiarity. After all the things Saeng had to go through with the move and the pressure to adjust, the author added the last passage into the story to show a moment of understanding and reconciliation between mother and daughter, highlighting the importance of empathy during times of change.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph, saying that Saeng will not quit until she passes that test. She will try and try, even to the point of death. The author is referring to the story again, emphasizing Saeng's unwavering determination and relentless pursuit of her goal, suggesting a level of commitment that transcends even her own well-being, highlighting the profound dedication she has towards achieving success in her endeavors.

The author's purpose of this conclusion is that every year when the snow melts and the geese return, she will again have to take care of the plant. That's clear because taking a test is a big responsibility; therefore, taking care of that plant is also a significant task, referring to the cyclical nature of responsibility, much like having to take the test again and again. This is what the purpose of the concluding sentence meant, highlighting the recurring commitment.

Because planting flowers and working on the garden is @CAPS1's hobby, a source of joy and relaxation. And without it, she can't think clearly or focus on creating new things, as gardening helps clear her mind. Therefore, waiting until they are back will not only make her happier, but also ensure she is able to fully dedicate herself to her work with renewed focus and inspiration.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph for many reasons. One is because she is saying when everything gets back to normal, that's when she is going to take the test again. Second, because there would be nothing else to say if it is not back to the way she wanted it to be, implying a sense of hope for a return to normalcy. For instance, if you were building a house and a blizzard came, you would stop; you said that you would not continue until there was nice weather again. In conclusion, the author concludes the story with this paragraph for many reasons, primarily to emphasize the protagonist's resilience and deferred hope for a brighter, more stable future.

The author of Winter Hibiscus, Minfong Ho, ended the story in this way to show the theme of starting over. Her mother adds to the theme of starting over by saying, “Its flowers aren’t as pretty but it’s strong enough to make it through the winter. That’s what matters.” Her words are a metaphor for the family starting their lives again in America, that America might not be as pretty, but it will survive, which is what matters. Her words soothe her daughter’s worries about starting over. Also, the budding hibiscus could be considered a symbol of rebirth, since it is dying and growing with the seasons. The family is dying out as a Thai family and being American was a Thai family. However, even though they “died” as a Thai family, that does not mean that they have lost their heritage, which is why the author ends talking about a flower that is both Thai and American, just like Saeng, highlighting the enduring strength and adaptability inherent in embracing a new beginning while retaining one's roots.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to show that Saeng will persevere through the winter and try to adapt to her new lifestyle. Moving to a new country/culture is extremely tough, and Saeng is sad, but she doesn’t give up on creating a new life in @LOCATION1. The concluding sentence, “in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and the hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test,” is one of determination and hope. The entire story Saeng was struggling with adapting to her new life, and memory of her homeland gives her a sense of security. The sentence wraps up her emotion and shows how strong she is. She could easily give up on her driving test, but she won’t. It is a happy ending for somewhat of a sad story. Furthering the sentence shows Saeng’s devotion to her plant. This hibiscus will survive and so will Saeng when the hibiscus blooms in the spring, so will Saeng. She will try as hard as she can to fit in and enjoy her new life. That plant will help her through it by reminding her of Vietnam as well as giving her a companion throughout the winter. The author would not have chosen a better conclusion for this story. The conclusion brings us to a new hope to persevere and succeed. As a result, the reader is left with a sense of pleasure and a good feeling toward the story. This conclusion shows how Saeng is adapting to changes and has hope to enjoy her new life in @LOCATION1.

The story was about a girl walking home after failing her driving test and breaking down about the "home" where she no longer lived. After she had broken down, bought the plant as a symbol of new growth, and learned to actually accept the fact that she no longer lived in Vietnam, embracing her new life, and accepting that she had failed her driving test, a temporary setback, she realized that she just has to learn to like it here, her new home. She also learned that her time will come and she will one day be driving. The reason why the author concluded the story with this paragraph is because this is the conclusion of the story; this is where one realizes the important things, accepting the present and looking forward to the future with newfound optimism.

In the story ìWinter Hibiscusî the author, Minfong Ho, concludes the story with a statement that Saeng vowed silently to herself. Saeng says she will take the test again referring to the drivers test. Seeing the geese flying in a ìVî formation and seeing the winter hibiscus gave Saeng a sense of remembrance to her homeland, reminding her of the familiar sights of Vietnam and easing her loneliness. Saeng misses her homeland. The author wanted it to seem to the READER as if Saeng is starting to feel at home again, finding comfort in these small connections to her past while embracing her present. The hibiscus is just a symbol to Saeng telling her that it will be O.K., and that itís okay for her to miss Vietnam but also that itís okay to have a new life, finding a balance between honoring her roots and building a future in a new place. So Saeng, in the spring, will go take her drivers test again with a new attitude, carrying with her the hope and resilience symbolized by the winter hibiscus, and will pass the test.

The author used that paragraph in order to create imagery, painting a vivid picture in the reader's mind. The author concludes the story with the paragraph to tell you when Saeng was going to take the test again and to reunite with the plant. This conclusion gives insight into the future, revealing Saeng's renewed determination and hope for success, which is precisely why the author chose to include it, leaving the reader with a sense of optimistic anticipation.

The author ends the story with “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently, in the spring, when the snow melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again” to show a comparison. Since the plant reminds her of home, when it buds she will be more confident to take the test. When she was looking at the petals of the flower it said, “Gently she closed her palm around it and held it tight. That, at least she could hold on to.” This shows that she really missed her home, and she had nothing to give her confidence. The flower is the piece of confidence she needs to feel at home and even pass her drivers test. Saeng felt out of place in her new environment. The hibiscus flower, with its vibrant color, gave her motivation. It gave her a chance to connect with a part from her old home, in her new home. Saeng thinks, “And that rich sweet scent- that was familiar too”. This shows that this flower was of sentimental importance, something she needed to ground her. Therefore, the author ended with that paragraph to show a comparison and highlight the importance of the flower to her adapting and finding the strength to try again.

In ìWinter Hibiscus,î Minfong Ho ends the story as she does to show a sign of hope. Saeng is going to start over when the world starts over. Spring, with its blossoming trees and melting snow, is a time of renewal, when animals emerge. Saeng ìVowed silently to herself to try again in the spring time.î Saeng purchases the hibiscus in remembrance of her homeland, but also to know when it is ready to come back out of the base to try again. The hibiscus demonstrates this by coming out of its buds and blooming, signifying resilience. Ho ends her story in hope of a new beginning. Saeng vows, ìThen I will take that test again,î showing her determination. The word choice of ìThat test againî depicts her new attitude. She wants to try again, approaching her test with newfound resolve and optimism, illustrating a belief in her ability to overcome challenges.

to show how absent she feels without them by her. You see this when the @ORGANIZATION1 says “when they come back.” also when she says “the geese return & this hibiscus is budding.” Shows how she feel without them and how she will feel when they return and how she will carry on where they left off last time as shown when she says “, Then I will take that test again.” These instances highlight the void in her life during their absence, the anticipation of their return, and her resolve to resume her endeavors. This emphasizes the cyclical nature of their relationship and her life, where their presence and absence mark distinct phases.

"I think it was good enough" by Minfong Ho evokes a sense of bittersweet tranquility. While you empathize with the girl's situation, a calm mood persists, reflecting the girl's quiet determination and willingness to persevere, ultimately creating a peaceful and heartwarming story about acceptance and understanding.

I feel that the author concludes the story with the paragraph saying that she’s going to take the test again, to show us that this time she’s going to pass the test and she’s not going to feel the same way she felt when she didn’t pass. It tells us it’s in “spring when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding” because that’s when she is going to take the test, signifying a time of renewal and a fresh start, reinforcing the idea that her second attempt will be different.

Saeng vowed silently to herself and to her mother too. Saeng decided to tell her mother what she had done, “she failed the test,” probably her mom get upset with her but then she talk to her again. The author concludes the story with this paragraph because the author wants to show the readers that Saeng will want to pass her driver's license test. The reason is to show the reader how determined Saeng is after the winter. The example is that in the story, Saeng failed her driver's license and was sad about it. The next example is that when she finds the flower, she knows she'll try again. This shows that the flower helps her feel better, indicating that she will do it again. The first example shows that she was sad that she failed the test. At the conclusion, the author includes this statement in the story to show readers that Saeng will pass the driver's license test later on, highlighting her resilience and future success.

In the story Winter Hibiscus by Minfong Ho, the author concludes the story with Saeng saying “when they come back in the spring. When the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again." The author chose to end the story this way to give it a positive ending. The rest of the story is sad because Saeng misses her home in Vietnam and feels displaced in her new environment. "Its – it’s not a real one. I mean, it’s not like the kind we had at – at – she found that she was still too shaky to say the words at home, lest she burst into tears again. Not like the ones we had before." The end sends the message that even though things are different than before, she won’t give up trying to make a good life in the United States and not let this change affect her. Saeng's resilience is highlighted as she looks forward to spring, symbolizing a new beginning and a renewed chance to succeed, showing her determination to adapt and thrive despite her feelings of loss.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because he wants us to know that she will regain her confidence when the "hibiscus is budding" and take another slot at the driving test. He doesn't want to just leave us hanging with the girl watching the geese fly away into the distance after her disappointing experience. The girl felt very bad about failing the test, which makes the reader feel sad for her situation. To cheer up the reader and offer a sense of hope, he ended the story in this way. Saeng is reminded of home and the cyclical nature of life when "the geese return and this hibiscus is budding." So, the author ends the story having Saeng have a sense of renewed confidence and the reader feeling happy, suggesting that setbacks are temporary and new beginnings are always possible.

The author concludes the story with that because she is determined to succeed in @LOCATION1. She misses her homeland and everything there: gardens, grandparents etc. For example , she walked into the flowershop; she smells the flowers like she used to back home. She then smelled a flower that reminded her of her grandmothers ìlong gray hair, freshly washed Öî. This sensory experience further emphasizes her longing for home and her connection to her roots. But by saying that last sentence, she demonstrates resilience: when the hibiscus budded next winter, she will take the test that she failed again, showing her resolve to build a future in @LOCATION1 despite her homesickness.

The author concludes the story with "When they came back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding then I will take that test again," because the girl is willing to try again and to not give up no matter what, showcasing her resilient spirit. The girl is upset because she doesn't have the real flower her mom had. "It's-it's not a real one," Saeng mumbled "I mean, not like the kind we had at- at." She was upset and afraid that her mother was going to be angry with her that she started to shake. "I know," her mother said quietly. "I've seen this kind blooming along the lake." The author concludes the story ìWinter Hibiscusî with that paragraph because he wants to get across to the reader that Saeng will not give up. Saeng and her family moved from Vietnam, and it has been hard for her to adjust to changes. Saeng really misses her homeland and the flowers that she sees as a symbol of life. She explains how the winter hibiscus is not the same as the one in Vietnam, so she plants this different type of flower and decides to wait till the spring to take the driving test. This shows that Saeng wants to plant her difficulties in America and think of them again in the spring when the weather and atmosphere is nice. She is not giving up, but she does not want to take on the difficulties until a later time. That is why the author concluded with this paragraph, highlighting her resilience and hopeful outlook despite the challenges she faces.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph for a couple of different reasons. The author wants to show with meaning that the budding of the hibiscus plant will be symbolic. Ho states, "Instead, she stared at the hibiscus plant and nervously tore off a leaf, shredding it to bits." This shows meaning because it is currently a point in time where Saeng has to overcome negative circumstances, and with the struggling plant it shows symbolically the challenges she faces. At another point in the story, Saeng realizes that there is much more meaning to the seasons, Ho states, "Through the quiet repetition of season upon season, almost familiar to her now," she is realizing that come spring time, like the plant, she will have the opportunity to succeed and become somehow like a new person, suggesting hope for renewal and a brighter future.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because he or she feels like the audience should know what Saeng is feeling as the season turns again. This story is all about overcoming hardships and disappointments as well as accepting and adapting to the things life throws at people, so it is appropriate that the story is ended with a goal and a determined attitude. Throughout the entire reading, Saeng sought comfort in the things most familiar to her, such as flowers and the taste of bitter melon. She was hurting and disappointed after failing her driver's test, and those familiar comforts were the only things that gave her peace. It was those things that gave her the courage she needed to retake her driver’s test in the spring, so it seems fitting that she end the story with the mention of the hibiscus. The end paragraph also shows that Saeng is adapting well to her new country and finding beauty in it. She says, “when they come back... in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return...” At first the sounds of geese were alien to her, but now she has accepted their honking as a normal sound, even something to look forward to. This implies that she is learning to accept her new country and integrate into her surroundings, which is the perfect way to end the story and highlight her resilience.

In the story “Winter Hibiscus” by Minfong Ho, a girl named Saeng is trying to adjust to America coming from Vietnam. She is sad and misses her home, especially after failing her driver's test. She walks by a store and recognizes a plant from her home. She buys it and takes it home in a pot, thinking of home and all the great memories she shared with the plant. Her mother then comes and shares the moment with her. Saeng feels better now. In the end sentence the author includes “Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring when the snows melt… and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” (Ho, ??) The flower has given her the confidence to succeed, and she wants to take the test again. This shows the connection she has with her home and the flowers, providing a tangible link to her past. She wants to overcome her sadness and plan onward, not leaving her memories behind but her pain, using the hibiscus as a symbol of hope and resilience in her new environment.

In the story ìWinter Hibiscus,î the author chose to conclude the story the way she did to show the comfort the hibiscus provided that allowed Saeng to move on. The greenhouse, with its familiar warmth and life, provided a place for her to get her feelings out about her home sickness, ìand in the warm moist shelter of the greenhouse, Saeng broke down and wept.î Then when she went home she was faced with the reality again of how she failed the test, a symbol of her academic struggles. I think when she failed the test it brought out feelings of how she thinks she is failing to adjust her new home. But when the geese fly by, heading north for the summer, the author brought the story to a conclusion to show how the experience has made Saeng grow. ìWhen they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, I will take the test again.î I think the author wanted to show that through the events in the story, particularly her connection with the hibiscus and the natural cycle of the seasons, she was able to overcome her feelings about a new home.

In ìWinter Hibiscus,î by Minfong Ho, the author concludes the story with this paragraph: ìWhen they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again.î The author concludes the story in this way because it is somewhat of a cliffhanger. In the story, Saeng is upset about failing her driving test, and she has just moved from Vietnam to the United States, so she is a little homesick. She sees a familiar plant, and so she purchases it for nineteen dollars because it cheers her up, reminding her of plants in Vietnam. By ending the story like this, you know that Saeng hasnít given up and that she is going to try and pass the drivers license test again. But what you donít know is the end result of whether she passes or not, and so it is a cliffhanger, leaving the reader to imagine Saeng's future success. That is why the author ended the story in this way.

Saeng has been the victim of a tragic loss in family and also a move to a totally different world. The paragraph is symbolic of turning over a new leaf and starting over. In the story, ìwinter hibiscusî, by @ORGANIZATION1, the author is very sentimental over the Hibiscus plant because it reminds her so much of her home. The author ends the story this way for a few reasons. First it shows that she is starting to like this new life. Also it is an ending that is open. I think that the author concludes the story she fails the driving test, so they added she was going to take it over.
