The author concludes the paragraph with this paragraph because she wants to try again. She going to take the test agan, and she feels like she needs to. She will decide when the snow melts and geese come back; that means she wants to take it in the Spring. It seems like waiting until Spring will give her ample time to prepare, so she can approach the test with confidence.

In ìWinter Hibiscusî the author @CAPS1 sentence is ìWhen they come back Saeng vowed silently to herself, in spring, when the snow melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again". In the same way the hibiscus flower prevails in the winter, Saeng wants to be the same way. Saeng failed a test, which makes her feel unsuccessful. Saeng wants to prevail; she wants to stick it out, and the rough times she’s going through make it very difficult for her. When Saeng says, “I—I failed the test,” this shows that Saeng feels disappointed; she didn’t expect that because she is a fighter. So, the author ends the passage with Saeng saying, “When they come back, in the spring, when snows melt, and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again,” to show how much of a fighter Saeng is because she’s determined to strive under difficult conditions, demonstrating her resilience and unwavering commitment to overcoming obstacles.

The author puts this paragraph last because it shows that Saeng is looking to a new lease almost on life. In the story ìWinter Hibiscusî by Minfong Ho, she concludes the story in this way to show that even though Saeng failed the test, she will try again someday, someday being symbolized by when the geese come back. Saeng is sad because she misses her homeland and the familiarity it offered, a feeling amplified by the unfamiliar surroundings. She sees plants that bring back memories, specifically of the vibrant life she left behind, so she buys a winter hibiscus to ease and comfort her, serving as a tangible reminder of home and a symbol of hope for a future return. Ultimately, the image of the returning geese mirrors Saeng's own anticipated return to her studies and, perhaps someday, to her homeland, demonstrating her resilience.

The author concludes this story with that paragraph because she loves her garden. At this time she vowed to retake a test because of how the flowers will always come and go, a fleeting beauty, but her grades will be there only one time for her school work, a permanent record. This realization, however, pushed her to prioritize her studies, understanding that academic success was a more lasting achievement.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because the winter hibiscus, blooming unexpectedly, gave her some hope amidst her disappointment. The author concludes the story with optimism and hope for the future. She finishes her story with “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again." By concluding the story in that way it helps demonstrate the hope the hibiscus plant brought to her after she failed her drivers test. The hibiscus helped give Saeng one step closer to adapting to her new home. In the story, @ORGANIZATION1, by Minfong Ho, a girl named Saeng tries to adjust to a new country, but it is nearly impossible. She is stressed about failing the driverís test, and she realizes that nothing is the same. Except for one thing that she quickly recognized: a plant called the ìWinter Hibiscus.î It made her think of her old life in Vietnam. This is exactly why Minfong Ho ends the last paragraph by stating that Saeng will retry the driving test when the hibiscus is budding. The flower gives her a thought of home in Vietnam, making her try and try again. Also, the author ends the story like this to state a theme. This particular theme is, ìNo matter how hard something might be, you can get through it. You just have to find a way that benefits you most.î The hibiscus, therefore, is more than just a flower; it is a symbol of hope and resilience, reminding Saeng of her strength and determination to succeed in her new life.

The author comes back to that paragraph because in the story Saeng is so sorry she did not ACE the test. Now Saeng wants to make up for it, She vowed to herself she will ACE that test. The reason why this author includes this story with this paragraph is because it is still talking about Saeng, and that is more like her, reflecting that she has a mind like a butterfly that was trapped but burst out. In the story ìWinter Hibiscusî by Minfong Ho, I think the ending paragraph is there to show that Saeng has not given up. The reason why the author concludes the story like that is because he is telling the reader that after the snow leaves the author will begin to plant more plants. In the story “Winter Hibiscus” by Ho, the author is stating that Saeng is happy when she is around the plant and she finds peace with the plant because it brings back childhood memories. Everytime that I touch or smell a sweater, it brings back memories of my grandmother. The author concludes the story with this paragraph because she wants to show how some people vowed silently because they don't want to express themselves, also maybe because they are not very trustful of people, even themselves. The author concludes the story with that paragraph to show determination and hope. The geese and the hibiscus symbolize Saeng’s determination, because they always come back no matter what. ìWhen they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring. when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.î The author concludes the story with that paragraph to show that Saeng will take the test again. In the story "Winter Hibiscus" at the end of the story the author writes "when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, In the spring, when the snow melt and geese return and this hibiscus Is budding, then I will take the test again." When they come back, Saeng vowed to silently herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again. The "Winter Hibiscus" is a relatively sad, but hopeful story that uses lots of symbols. The author concluded the story with a confident ending that makes the reader feel satisfied. The two reasons he wrote this conclusion paragraph is to give the ending a hopeful tone and relate the objects she sees to the spring. "Winter Hibiscus" ends with a hopeful tone thanks to the confident vow Saeng silently makes. She had a rough day, and the author wanted to make sure she had something to look to as a goal. It also reveals how strong of a person Saeng is, highlighting her resilience in the face of adversity. The author uses this conclusion paragraph to leave the reader with a hopeful and confident tone. The second reason the author concluded with that conclusion paragraph was to relate some of the objects she sees to the spring. The geese represent the new place she is living in, and the hibiscus represents her old home. This paragraph links these two symbols together, so the reader can relate them to the spring season and the idea of renewal. The way the author concluded the story was brilliantly done, as the ending represents a hopeful tone, and symbols that relate to spring, ultimately leaving the reader satisfied with its confident and optimistic close.

I think the author concludes with this paragraph because she wants to not give up. For example, she wants to show us to never give up at anything even if you fail. The author concluded the story with the sentence, because the author wanted to show that since Saeng found the flower she has new hope and reason for passing the test. The author concludes the story with this paragraph because she is saying that when the flowers come back in the spring, and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding after winter, she will garden them again, finding solace and renewal in the familiar rhythms of nature and the promise of new growth.

The author of ìwinter Hibiscusî concludes the story with ìwhen they come back, in the spring, when the snow melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again.î Saeng, because it creates the mood that Saeng is accepting the changes in her life. Just like nature adapts to climate and location change, Saeng seems to appreciate her situation and is deciding to make it a positive instead of a negative. The author is showing that if you're having trouble, try again; through the main character, Saeng, who finds hope in the cyclical nature of the seasons, mirroring her own resilience and determination.

I believe that the author concludes the story with this paragraph for a lot of different reasons. One reason why the author could have concluded the story with this paragraph is because, after reflection, she might try it again, perhaps approaching the challenge with a different strategy. A second reason why the author could have concluded the story with this paragraph is because she probably wanted to try to make her mother proud, seeking her approval and understanding through renewed effort. A third reason why the author could have concluded the story with this paragraph is because she probably really felt that she really disappointed herself, and is determined to overcome that feeling. In conclusion, if you mess up on something, try again; maybe you will do a lot better, and ultimately find success and satisfaction.

Minfong Ho concluded ìWinter Hibiscusî with the lines ìwhen they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test againî to show that there is always hope for better things to come. Saeng had become sad because she remembered her home in Vietnam. She longed for her natural home and familiarity. Her missed memories agonizingly hurt Saeng because she was now far away and in a different world. However, the author started to reveal hints that America would accept Saeng and find some childhood memories there too. ìOverhead, a flock of Canada geese flew by, their faint honks clear and ñyes- familiar to Saeng now.î Already, Saeng was growing familiar with her surrounding area in America. Her hibiscus would keep her VIETNAMESE culture, tradition, and memories alive, as the geese would help her feel happy and accustomed in America. As one kept her VIETNAMESE culture alive through memories, she would continue a successful life and pass her test, showcasing her resilience. That is why Minfong Ho ended ìWinter Hibiscusî with the particular paragraph.

The author concludes the story in *Winter Hibiscus* in a way that is kind of funny and weird. The concluding sentence is: "When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again." The author concludes the story with that paragraph because it shows that the narrator is ready. The narrator tried the test once and failed, feeling dejected after the setback. The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it symbolizes the change in Saeng as well as other things. The snow always melts when the seasons change. The author concludes the story with this paragraph ìwhen they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.î The author shows that Saeng will take the test again, demonstrating her resilience. I think the author concludes the story with this paragraph because in the spring it's warmer and more fun, plus she will have time to study her stuff in winter for the springtime activities. The author concludes the story with that paragraph because it's what she solemly promised herself, a reflection of the personal commitment she undertook to honestly portray the characters and their experiences. In ìWinter Hibiscusî by Minfong Ho, the authorís purpose in concluding the story with ìWhen they come back, Saeng  vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then l will take that test again,î was to show how the hibiscus and the other plants in the store symbolized Saeng. When Saeng enters the store, she becomes overwhelmed by how many things she had forgotten about living in Vietnam. ìPlants that she had not even realized she had known but forgotten grew her back into her childhood world.î This is when Saeng associates herself and her childhood with these plants. When she sees another plant she knows in a pot, she thinks to herself, ìHow strange to seat in a pot back home it just grew wild, jutting out from the cracks in the brick walls or between filed roofs. ìThis symbolizes her, because out of her home, she seems to feel strange and caged, too, while at home in Vietnam she was much more free-spirited. She feels confined by the unfamiliar environment. The hibiscus plant, when Saeng takes it home, is described by her mother as ìstrong enough to make it through the cold monthsî. Saeng identifies herself with this description, and so decided that when the hibiscus is done dealing with the bad stuff, she will have, also, and will have budded and grown just like her plant. Then, she will be ready to achieve her goal, showing that she believes she, like the hibiscus, can overcome her current challenges and bloom again.

The author concluded the story with "when they come back," Saeng vowed silently to herself, "in the spring when the snow melts and the geese return and the hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again." Saeng believes that if the hibiscus can survive through hard times and adapt to changes, and survive, she can also. Saeng knows that even though she has moved to the United States and it is different, she is strong enough to survive. Failing her driver's test doesn't mean that she is incapable of anything, but that she needs to try again with a fresh start, just like the hibiscus, demonstrating resilience and a renewed sense of hope.

The author concludes the story with this, showing the author wants to show Saeng hasn’t given up. Early in the story, Saeng goes to the greenhouse and starts to cry after a setback. That is why the author ended with that paragraph, emphasizing her enduring determination.

The last paragraph was added in order to represent the determinedness and adapting to new things in Saeng and her family. In the beginning, Saeng held bitterness at failing the test. But after she remembers her homeland through the flower she accepts it. Just as the flower will bud, she will be a new person and thus pass the test. The moment of breakdown was as she got the flower, the tangible reminder of her past and the challenge ahead. After she got home it was over with and again she accepts the change, demonstrating a resilient spirit that suggests future success and happiness in her new environment.

The author include the last paragraph because Saeng is not going to give up and she will try again. I think that the author concludes the story with this paragraph because he thinks when the flowers come back they would be better. I think that he thinks that it would be a better test next time, suggesting a renewed hope for Charlie's potential and the experiment's success in the future.

The author concludes ìWinter Hibiscusî with the paragraph because it continues the theme of adjusting to changes in life. In the story, Saeng has come to the United States from Vietnam and it is quite a change, a cultural shift that requires adaptation. Also changed are the plants in this new environment. The hibiscus reminds Saeng of Vietnam, providing a familiar link to her past, but it is different, reflecting her own evolving identity. The mother in the story says, ìIts flowers arenít as pretty, but itís strong enough to make it through the cold winter months here, this winter hibiscus. ìThe hibiscus also relates to the theme because it is able to adjust to changes, mirroring Saeng's resilience. The final paragraph talks about snow melting, geese returning and the hibiscus budding, all symbolic of renewal. These are all changes the author uses to connect to the theme of embracing new beginnings. This adds more understanding to the storyís message about finding strength in adaptation. Additionally, the tone of the last paragraph is hopeful, suggesting a bright future, which gives the reader a positive feeling. The tone adds to the theme of the story, reinforcing the idea that change can bring growth and promise.

He failed the test. She said she would try next year, when the geese come back, their honking a promise of warmer days and another chance. It was a small comfort, but a comfort nonetheless, offering hope for a brighter future.

I think he means that seasons change and that winter will come again, implying a cyclical nature to events. I think that is the test, a test of patience and understanding of inevitable change. Therefore, accepting the return of winter becomes the key to passing this test.

I thinks that the author concludes the story with the given paragraph to show that she is similar to the hibiscus and geese. First, the geese and hibiscus both have a goal, which is to survive the winters. Geese fly south for the winter to stay warm and find food. This is similar to Saeng, whose thing both moved to a different environment where they must adapt. Also, Saeng must experience winter along with the hibiscus, facing a literal change in season and a figurative change in her life. The hibiscus needs to be strong, to overcome winter; from this, it shows Saeng is like her hibiscus because she needs to be strong to overcome the test. If her hibiscus can overcome its test, winter, then she can survive to conquer her own challenges, just as the hibiscus perseveres and blooms again.

The author of “Winter Hibiscus” includes “when they come back in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again because it shows that she can adapt to change and still can think about her old country too. An example of how she can keep her old country alive in her life is” “But she had grown up eating it and, she admitted to herself, much preferred it to a Big Mac.” This shows that she can still eat the foods she ate back at her old home and try new things at her new home. This blending of preferences highlights her ability to embrace her heritage while engaging with her present reality. In conclusion the excerpt shows that the author can put both cultures together and be happy.

There could be many reasons why the author concludes the story with this paragraph. There could be many different meanings of this paragraph that could have importance to the story. I think that the author includes this to say that when the spring comes, she will have many more reasons to take the driving test. You can break this paragraph down to mean many different things. I interpreted it to mean that when the spring comes back, she will have a new beginning. The snow melting away represents all the hardship she faced in the previous year. The geese returning and the hibiscus budding means that they are also coming back to start the new year. They are too coming back, getting ready to start their new life, perhaps stronger than before. It is included at the end to show how Saeng is trying to forget about how she failed the test. She is using this time now to prepare for the next time she is going to take the driving test. She thinks that once she forgets all of the bad things she went through the previous year, and embraces the new opportunities, she'll be ready. She had to move on and be able to pass the driving test the next time around. The author concluded the story with the paragraph to show how Saeng plans to solve her problems, with a fresh perspective and renewed hope. The way you interpret the paragraph gives you different ideas about what it is trying to say. I think that it is showing a new beginning that she will have to go through the next year, one filled with potential and the chance to overcome past failures.

...when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again. She would not be caught unprepared. The knowledge she had gained, the lessons learned from this experience, would serve her well. She would use the winter months to study, to practice, to hone her skills, so that she would be ready, truly ready, to face the challenge again and prove her worth.

The author ended the story ìWinter Hibiscusî with Saeng vowing to retake the test. He ended it this way to show the themes of this story. One theme of the story is to never give up. Just like the winter Hibiscus has to last through the long winter but it does survive, and it inspires Saeng to keep trying, even after facing initial disappointment. Another theme is to overcome your obstacles. The flower faces many dangers, such as the cold and the snow, but still manages to blossom, symbolizing resilience. Saeng wants to overcome her obstacles and pass the test, which is a significant challenge in her new environment. Therefore the ending of the story displays the themes of perseverance and the ability to flourish even when facing adversity, solidifying the message.

The author concludes this part, because it made the story stand out a little. For example when Saeng said that she ment when the plants came back. It also gave the ending a little something to hang on two, rather than staping on talking about the v or geese to get the reader off topic. Last she also ment when the geese came back, offering a sense of cyclical return and hope that resonates beyond the immediate narrative.

I think the author finishes the story with that, signaling the girls see this plant as a symbol of strength and faith, so she will take the test next year when it comes back; she truly likes the plant and hopes it will bring her luck. Thus, the plant's symbolism becomes a source of motivation and optimism for her future endeavors.

I think the author ended the story with that phrase to show that she won't give up; no matter how hard it is, she keeps trying. The girl says in the story "I failed the test," and then at the end of the story says she will take that test again, so she is not willing to fail forever. The author's choice highlights resilience. I also think the author ended the story with that paragraph to make you wonder if she will ever pass the test, leaving the reader with a sense of anticipation about the girl's future endeavors.

I think the author writes this because whatever test she has to take she wasn't ready for before, but now whenever the geese and the hibiscus return, she will be ready to take the test. Maybe she wasn't mentally prepared, lacking the confidence or focus needed to succeed. So, in conclusion, I think when she says the geese and the hibiscus return, she will take the test, suggesting she wasn't physically and mentally prepared for it previously, but now she is ready to tackle it.

Authors chose their closing paragraphs carefully. The author chose to end their story with this paragraph because all of the stuff the actor has in the last paragraph represents something special in the character’s eyes. There are reasons the author chose to conclude the story with that paragraph. The author's choice of the ending paragraph is very important. The character says “this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again”. The hibiscus that she mentions represents the ability to overcome obstacles. In the story it is talking about the girl overcoming the failed test and retaking it, and thus the hibiscus symbolizes her resilience. That is why the author concludes with that. The author also writes, “when the snow melts and the geese return”. This to the character represents new beginnings and chances, suggesting the cyclical nature of life and opportunity. That gives the character the sense that next time around she will pass the test. The author adds that paragraph in the end to symbolize new beginnings and chances and the ability to overcome obstacles, offering a message of hope. Authors choose their last paragraph for specific reasons, and this author did as well. The author did it to symbolize things, ultimately leaving the reader with a feeling of optimism and the potential for future success.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph because of a saying that when it's cold and silent she's reserved to herself, enjoying the quiet introspection of winter. But when the snow melts and spring is here, she's outgoing and does lots of fun things, embracing the vibrancy and social opportunities that warmer weather brings. This contrast highlights her adaptability and the different facets of her personality that emerge with the changing seasons, ultimately showing her as a well-rounded individual.

I believe the author concluded the story with that paragraph because the geese that flew down south in a beautiful V formation, fly down every season. So she tells herself, like the consistent return of the geese, she will take the test again when the geese return and the hibiscus plant is budding. For example, she thinks to herself, ìAlmost reluctantly, she realized that many of the things that she had thought of as strange before had become, through the quiet repitition of season upon season, almost familiar to her now.î Like the familiar return of the geese each year, looking up at the geese she is almost reminded of an experience she went through somewhat similar, a challenge she will face again with the cyclical nature of life offering another opportunity. This reinforces the theme of resilience and the acceptance of repeated cycles in life.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph: "When they came back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again to emphasize that you can overcome a defeat or failure by waiting until the "season" comes again for you to re-endure." Basically, the hibiscus meant much to the narrator and her mother, who was dying, and they dug up a hole to help it grow, so when it grows again, that proves that it will be living better. So when Saeng relates the test, that will be her having the opportunity to pass the test, just as the hibiscus will have another chance to flourish. The story with this paragraph symbolizes a new beginning about to take place, a situation that will come again that will help you to get what is needed out of it that you missed. The story and the paragraph emphasize life's cyclical nature, the promise of renewal after hardship.

She can't wait till the flowers start to come back when the snow melts, meaning it isn't very cold out anymore, so they grow. She is going to take her test that she has failed when the geese and flowers come back, a hopeful sign of a fresh start and a chance for success.

The author concludes with this paragraph to show that Saeng, like the geese and the hibiscus, will return again and have hope. Saeng is a little depressed in the story because she is in a new country and just failed her driving test. The hibiscus plant in the florist shop brings back painful emotional memories for her, but at the same time, is very comforting, reminding her of home. Later in the story, she plants the hibiscus outside in the garden with her mother, grounding herself in her new environment. As her mother goes inside, Saeng watches the geese fly overhead, a symbol of migration and cyclical return. ìAlmost reluctantly, (Saeng) realized that many of the things that she had thought of as strange before had become, through quiet repetition of season upon season, almost familiar to her. Like the geese.î Saeng knew the geese would return in the spring, just like she would to her driving test. The hibiscus would be in bloom again too to provide her with hope, representing resilience and the promise of renewal. This is what the final paragraph in the story ìwinter hibiscusî means, suggesting that Saeng, too, will find her place and bloom again in this new land.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to show Saeng's everlasting determination. This idea of her determination to succeed can be connected to the plant she brings home. The plant she knew grew wild where she used to live, but she found it potted in the United States, which is limiting its growth, just like Saeng's new country seems unordinary, and she feels out of place. However, just as she intends to nurture the plant and help it thrive, she demonstrates her resolve to adapt and flourish in her new environment, showcasing her enduring spirit.

The author concludes the story with Saeng telling herself she’ll take the test again because it draws together the overall theme and major actions of the story. The theme of the story is that you can get used to a new environment by finding beauty in it and similarities to your old home. Saeng says that “many of the things that she had thought of as strange before had become, through the quiet repetition of season upon season, almost familiar to her now like the geese.” And when she’s in the greenhouse the plants draw her back into memories of Vietnam and her grandmother. Saeng was having a hard time adjusting to new things after moving to Minnesota, but she was determined to overcome the difficulties just like she had overcome the differences between the Iowa and Vietnam. I think the author concluded the story by talking about the geese and the hibiscus and re-taking the test because it demonstrates all the ways that Saeng is adjusting to her new life and shows her and the reader that she can overcome new things. She vows to herself that she can do it, and foreshadows her future success and adaptation to an American lifestyle.

The author concludes the story with the paragraph that she did because it was the end and the start of a new beginning. The author uses the senses in her story. The winter is the current season and spring is on its way. Although Saeng failed her test in the winter when most things die, she is looking forward to spring to start again on her test. The geese will return and the hibiscus will bud to show spring is here with new life. Saeng will also have new life in her test to pass it this time and drive. The spring season will come and new life will be provided to all, signifying hope and the cyclical nature of opportunity.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because the paragraph is like saying most of the story but in a small and shorter way, encapsulating the central themes and plot points with brevity. It serves as a microcosm of the larger narrative, echoing earlier conflicts and resolutions. In effect, it provides a final, concentrated dose of the story's essence, allowing the reader to reflect on the journey and appreciate the narrative's overall impact.

This paragraph is a good way to end the story because it relates to the test. The narrator says she will try again in the spring, armed with a better understanding of the material and a renewed sense of determination to pass the challenging exam, showing her resilience.

I believe that the author concludes the story with this paragraph because it's what the story is all about; it just explains what happened in the end as if what happened through the story was the growth and living of a flower. It signifies the completion of a cycle, from seed to bloom and perhaps eventual withering, mirroring the character's journey and ultimate fate. It provides a sense of closure and understanding, reflecting the natural progression that has been subtly present throughout the narrative.

In Minfong Ho's "Winter Hibiscus," the author concludes the story in what seems like an incomplete paragraph. The girl, Saeng, vows to take her driver's test over when spring comes. Holding the plant, she felt cold and helpless, mirroring the plant's condition. "Then she noticed the potted plant that Saeng was holding, its leaves quivering in the wind." Saeng's mother reassuring her that she was okay with her choice fostered Saeng's personal growth. "I'm glad you got it," her mother says, adding, "look how root-bound it is, poor thing." This subtly reflects Saeng's clinging to her connection with her country. Her mother's assurance that the plant will surely survive foreshadows Saeng's resilience. When spring arrives, the plant will be strong once more, and so too will Saeng, which is why the author ends the story where she does, leaving the reader with the hopeful image of renewed strength and a future where Saeng, like the hibiscus, will flourish.

The author concludes the story by showing the girlís connection to the plant and the symbolism of the geese; the ìWinter hibiscusî is her connection to her homeland and represents her resilience. She said sheíll retake her driving test when her plant buds and is brave, so she will do the same, drawing strength from its blooming. The geese flying south show her journey as a person because she will take the test when the geese come back from their journey, symbolizing a return and a new beginning, as she comes back from hers, transformed and ready.

The author wrote the ending paragraph the way she did for many reasons. The main reason for this is because she wanted to end the story on a lighter note. All throughout the story there was depresing nogistalistic tone that made the reader yearn for the past. The author wanted to put on emphisis on being strong even though you @MONTH1 not enjoy where you are at. Also the author wanted to show the strength of the main character Saeng. Even though she has just failed a test in a new, strange world she still wishes to continue pushing foward. This adds more demension the the character and makes her less static and more dynamic. This makes the ending much more impactful. This is a very good story to read if you are homesick and need something to push you forward.

The author concludes with that statement because it shows she needs time. She needs time to adjust to her new home, much like the transplanted hibiscus needs time to get some roots in the new soil it is on. When she is at the orchard, she sees the hibiscus and has memories of her old home, making her cry but yet feel good at the same time, signaling a complex emotional process of adapting to change. This period of adjustment, with its bittersweet memories, is essential for her to truly settle and thrive in her new environment.

I believe the author concludes that passage to show patience. Saeng was to wait for spring; maybe it will feel like her hometown again. She likes the spring better than the winter because she likes the birds and the geese that return in spring, whereas they go away in winter. That way, I believe the author concludes that passage by offering a sense of hope tied to the cyclical return of spring.

ìwhen they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.î The author has left her home and moved to another country. She is now in an unfamilar place. Everything that now surrounds her is new and mostly un-known. By ending the story with this quote, it suggest that the author still has hope of adapting to her new home. When she left her home, she did not just leave a building behind. She left her home, people she loved, and an endless list of memories. At times she might have felt out of place because she was no longer in her comfort zone. She is now ìout of the box,î and in a whole new world. When she saw the hibiscus, the exotic plant took her back to her memories and to the love of her old home. Then she came back to reality and broke apart with sadness and ìfailed her test.î The ending sentence shows that the author is willing to try to survive in this new place and that she is still determined to pass her own test of adapting, indicating a resilient spirit and a refusal to be defeated by the challenges of a new beginning.

The author concludes the story with the paragraph "when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself., in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again," meaning that she will retake the test and hopes to pass, aiming to make her mother happy and provide support. She chose spring, symbolizing the rebirth of nature, as she desires to retake the test with a clear and renewed mind. The author likely placed this paragraph at the end to leave the reader with a sense of hope and Saeng's determination for the future.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph for several significant reasons. Throughout the story Saeng struggles with her past and overcoming it, specifically the trauma of leaving her grandmother and homeland. The paragraph helps bring a sense of closure to the story. When Saeng returns home with the hibiscus she tells her mother she couldnít help it and was unable to overcome her past. Saeng said, ìI-I failed the test.î When she says ìthe testî she means the ability to cope with the loss of her grandmother and homeland, and overcome it, showing her perceived inability to move forward. In the concluding paragraph Saeng says she will retake the test. She said, ìWhen the snows melt and the geese return and the hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.î This promise of renewal and future attempts offers a hopeful resolution. In conclusion, the author uses the concluding paragraph to bring closure to the story and the emotional obstacles Saeng faces, suggesting a path towards healing and acceptance.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because she wants to end the story with hope. For example, since she has moved to the United States, she feels homesick. To make it worse, she failed the driver’s test. ìShe found she was still too shaky to say the words at home, lest she burst into tears again. ì This quote helps add to the homesick girl. She concludes with this paragraph to show that when spring comes, she’ll start out fresh and re-live her life in America, suggesting a brighter future despite her current struggles.

The author concluded this story with the paragraph because Saeng is explaining to the reader that she will take the test again when the time is right. When things seem to be getting better, and she feels more prepared and less burdened by external pressures, she will retake the test. That is why the author used that paragraph to conclude her story, leaving the reader with a sense of hope and Saeng's resilient determination.

In the story "Winter Hibiscus" written by @CAPS1 Ho, the narrator goes to a greenhouse filled with many flowers, but a "winter" hibiscus plant particularly catches her eye. This plant reminds her of her homeland and everything that used to take place there; specifically, the hibiscus reminds her of her grandmother's long, silky gray hair and how she used to watch her dry it in the sun. Afterwards, she would help her knot it up into a bun with a bud of this plant tucked within it. The author ends the story with this memory because it counters her earlier statement, "I-I failed the test," and suggests resilience and hope, as the final line states, "...then I will take the test again," showing that she is not defeated by this setback.

In the story "Winter Hibiscus" the girl Saeng failed the drivers test. "I-I failed the test" said Saeng. She had bought a hibiscus because the flower reminded her of some of the memories from home, particularly the hibiscus she had at her house. At the end, she says that she will retake the test when the geese come back, the snow has melted and the hibiscus is budding. She does this, I think, because she needs time to just think things through, to just remember back home, and to make a hibiscus garden. The hibiscus in this story is just like Saeng. They both experienced something difficult; Saeng failed the test and the hibiscus was constricted to a pot, away from its natural environment. But they both are going to change the bad thing, as Saeng will retake the test and the hibiscus will hopefully flourish. Thus, both Saeng and the hibiscus represent resilience and the hope for a brighter future.

In the story ìWinter Hibiscusî by Minfong Ho, the author concludes the paragraph in that way to convey the determination and new found motivation Saeng found by buying the familiar plant. Although she failed her test, finding a plant that reminded her of her home and her grandmother instilled motivation in her to try the test again, she wanted to make her new home in a new country workout for the better, no matter what. ìShe lifted her head and watched as their distinctive u was etched against the evening sky ...î the author included details about the geese to represent moving on. The geese will go, and come back, just like Saeng. She failed the test the first time, but getting the plant and seeing the birds motivated her to try again. ìAlmost reluctantly she realized that many of the things that she thought of as strange before had become ...familiar to her.î The geese were one of the things mentioned that has become very familiar to her, in her new home. Concluding the story with a bit about the geese conveys to the reader that she is slowly but surely learning how to adapt to her strange new home, embracing aspects she once considered foreign. Finding the plant helped her, because it was already familiar to her. ìSaeng felt a shock of recognition so intense, it was almost visceral. ë@CAPS1, Saeng said.í ìAfter failing her driverís test, walking into the floristís shop and finding that plant comforted her. It made this new place feel closer to home than it did at first. The geese had become familiar over time, and finding the plant was simply comforting, serving as a bridge between her past and present. Concluding the story that way showed the reader that she was adapting and learning to deal with a tough situation in a comforting way, highlighting her resilience and growing sense of belonging.

In the story "Winter Hibiscus" by Minfong Ho, the author concludes the story with "when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again". The author concluded the story with that because she is saying that when the year starts off and starts over, that she will too. She's saying that when the geese come back, the snow melts, and the Hibiscus starts to bud that they all start over and start a new beginning. So when she goes to take the test it will be a new year, a fresh start, filled with renewed hope and determination after the long winter.

The author of Winter Hibiscus ended her story with words regarding to the story CAPS1 failed her driving test. Saeng cried when noticing her past through flower. As well as bought dok malik seeds show that the story ended the way it did, because next season she anticipates cultivating a future different from her past.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to show that Saeng is determined. She says that she is going to take the test again, which shows that she is determined to eventually pass. Even though Saeng failed her driver's test, she is not going to give up on getting her license.

The author used that sentence because the snow is melting and the geese are coming back, signs of the changing season. The flowers were budding up, further emphasizing the arrival of spring, and that is why I think the author used that sentence to evoke a sense of renewal and hope.

I believe that this was a good ending to the story. When Saeng says ìWhen they come backî she is talking about the flowers, when they come back alive. ìIn the springî shows when the flower will come back. ìWhen the snows melt and the geese returnî she is saying that after winter (when the snows melts) and when the geese return(in spring). ìAnd this Hibiscus is buddingî She is saying when the flowers blume again in the spring. ì Then I will take the test again," she is saying after all this happens she will retake the test (in the spring). This shows that Saeng will be watching at all these things happening and count down till spring again, so she can retake the test. She is ready for spring to be here, so that she can study and pass the test, and work at the flower shop. This anticipation demonstrates her renewed determination and hope, solidifying her resolve to achieve her aspirations after the winter months have passed. This will be her goal for the winter, till spring comes!

The author concluded the story with that ending because in the spring when everything blossoms, reflecting a time of renewal and hope. And she wouldn't be focused while there is snow, a symbol of the cold, harsh realities she's trying to overcome. So when the hibiscus is budding, representing new beginnings, that's when she will be able to take her test again. I think he wrote that because it means something to her, a personal goal intertwined with the natural cycle of growth and a chance to finally achieve what she desires.

This conclusion of the story provides a sense of hope for the future. The girl is upset that she failed the test but still has hope for what will happen next. In the story the narrator says, ìShe lifted her head.î This quote is showing that she is not going to quit and give up, but that she will try until she succeeds. The conclusion of the story leaves readers to wonder if she will try harder and pass the test for the second time. When she says, ìwhen the snow melts and the geese return,î this shows us that she is like the geese because their both going back for a hard fought journey. Also, when she says, ìand this hibiscus buddingî she is saying when everything comes to life and is at itís highest peak she will take the test because she will have the most confidence. The author concludes the story to show that there is hope for the future and that she is not going to give up, revealing her resilient spirit. Although she is upset about failing the test she will certainly be ready to pass it in the spring.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph for a couple of reasons. It offers a sense of closure, resolving the central conflict and leaving the reader with a definitive outcome regarding the protagonist's journey. This finality ensures that the narrative arc is complete, providing satisfaction and preventing lingering questions about the character's fate. Furthermore, it reinforces the overarching theme of the story, highlighting the key message or moral that the author intended to convey, thus solidifying the story's impact.

Saeng is @CAPS1 that it will be a longtime before she will worry about school work again. That's why the author concludes the story with that paragraph, suggesting a period of carefree relaxation ahead.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph, because he wants to emphasize that the girl is not completely dissatisfied with leaving her home. He ended with that because he wanted to show that there is hope for her to learn to love her new home, suggesting a possibility of future contentment despite her initial reluctance.

The author ends the story with this sentence because Saeng needs a break before she takes the test again. Saeng is comparing herself to indifferent things, like flowers, and the experience of taking a test. That comparison highlights her exhaustion and need for respite, and that is significant. That's why the author ends the story with this sentence, emphasizing the simple, restorative power of pausing and reflecting before facing the challenge again.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph to show that the girl is going to be like the hibiscus. Just as the hibiscus will bloom again, the next time it blooms the girl will be ready for the test and will take it again and will pass. The author wants to show that the girl will not give up and will try again to make sure she passes. The author involves the hibiscus to show that the girl and the flower will bloom the same time the hibiscus will, suggesting a parallel growth and readiness, and will pass the test, symbolizing her eventual success.

Well, I think the author concludes the story with that sentence because maybe Saeng likes the spring and can concentrate better with her favorite flower that she thinks relates to her life, offering a sense of hope and renewal as she faces future challenges.

The author ends the story like that to show the theme working hard. Some other examples of working hard are the "winter hibiscus." Another example is her vow to pass the test, so that is why the author ends the story that way, reinforcing the idea that perseverance leads to success.

The author concludes the story with the paragraph that they did because it's about the same thing that they opened the story with. To introduce the story, the author tells about Saeng failing her driver's test, and then seeing a familiar plant that she wants to buy. The middle of the story is about how she is having a hard time adapting to her new home. So to conclude the story, the author writes that Saeng will take her driver's test again, once the flowers start budding, and the geese come out. The flower and the geese remind her of home, so this tells you that thinking of her home, and the objects that make her feel at home, comfort her, and help her overcome obstacles. The familiar sights give her the courage and motivation she needs.

Authors use many techniques to improve their stories. Without these techniques a story would seem bland, average, or unattractive. Author Minfong Ho conveys the fact that Saeng will try to take the test again. Instead of simply stating the fact that she will retake the test, she has her make a promise on the geese that she will. The author ended the story like this, showing how strongly she felt about the test and emphasizing her determination.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it connects the hibiscus back to the trials and triumphs of Saeng. Just how Saeng can’t give up and must go back to retake the test, the winter hibiscus must make it through the hard, rough winter and come back strong. The hibiscus are a symbol of hope and Saeng thinks of them as her hope, especially when she feels discouraged. Throughout the story, the hibiscus are comforting to Saeng because they remind her of home and the resilience she learned there. The author includes this because many people can relate to this and find hope in things, whether it’s a flower or a familiar song. For Saeng, knowing that each year the hibiscus will come back even in those harsh conditions, reassures her that she’ll be okay there as well, and gives her the strength to persevere through her own challenges.

I think the author concludes the story with that paragraph to show a new beginning. The geese are coming back, signaling a return and restart to their life there, the hibiscus will be blooming, representing resilience and beauty, and she will re-take the test. At the beginning Saeng was depressed about having to leave her old country and grandmother. Saeng began to feel “A wave of loss so deep and strong that it stung Saeng’s eyes now swept over her.” She remembered how some of these plants grew wild in bushes or between cracks in the sidewalk. Saeng saying what she did in the last paragraph is her showing that she found comfort and confidence in the hibiscus. Memories of the past showed her the way, providing strength, and now she is going to retake her driver's test, embodying a renewed sense of hope and determination.

I think the author concludes this story with this ending paragraph because the story is all about how she feels comforted in the plants, finding solace in their growth and stability amidst her own anxieties. She wants to wait until the weather breaks and the geese come back, suggesting a desire for a fresh start and a sense of natural order to align with her own internal state before facing the test. I think she wants to wait that way so she will be more comfortable with her surroundings, drawing strength from the renewed environment, and she can clear her mind, feeling more at peace and therefore able to do her best on the test.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it shows Saeng wants to take the test again, but she wants to take the test again when everything else good and happy returns like the plant and the geese. This is true because Saeng says "When they (geese) come back… and this hibiscus is budding I will take the test." This shows her maturity and desire for happiness. She wants to do something hard and maybe even not fun when everything else returns and is happy. Just as when she came, she was sad, but when the geese and plant come back she wants to share in that joy and perhaps subtly help them through this renewal. This way they all can be happy at the same time, representing a hopeful cycle of return and resilience.

The short story “Winter Hibiscus” as written by author Minfong Ho, ends with main character Saeng, promising herself that in the spring when the geese return and the winter hibiscus begins to bud, that she would re-take her failed drivers test. Minfong Ho writes this story with heavy imagery and symbolism; the hibiscus found in the floral shop represents a connection for Saeng to her homeland, and the bittermelon, which is loved by Saeng, but unbearable to people in @LOCATION1, represents Saeng’s hard time connecting to people in @LOCATION1. And for Saeng, the budding hibiscus and returning geese are representative of a new opportunity to pass her drivers test and better adapt to life in @LOCATION1, suggesting a hopeful outlook for her future integration.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph because she wanted to show that Saeng doesn’t give up and that nature gives Saeng strength. The conclusion shows that Saeng doesn’t give up by saying that she is going to take the test again, even though she failed it earlier that day, demonstrating her resilience. Also, it shows that nature gives Saeng strength by saying that Saeng will take the test again when the geese return, when hibiscus buds bloom, and when the snow melts in spring. Nature gives her strength because these natural events remind her of where they used to live and her grandmother's stories connected to these seasonal changes. In conclusion, the author concluded the story with that paragraph to show that Saeng is not a quitter, and that nature gives her strength and confidence to persevere.

The character, Saeng, experiences both internal and external conflicts. Saeng had failed her driver’s test and still missed Vietnam. The ending of the story was an excellent choice of conclusion for the story. The flock of Canada geese represented her changes. She used to feel awkward and out of place. Many things were new to her. Saeng realized that life isn't so bad for her, and that she could adapt. The planting of the “winter hibiscus” represented her change as well. It showed how she will start anew and continue happily. Saeng will “plant a new seed.” The ending was well chosen for the story because it foreshadows Saeng’s future, hinting at growth and new beginnings. The story is inspiring and the ending greatly contributes to the effect, leaving the reader with a sense of hope for Saeng's journey.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to show how Saeng relates the hibiscus overcoming of problems to her own overcoming of problems. Saeng is comparing the hibiscus to herself. If the hibiscus can adapt to its surroundings, then so can she, finding strength in resilience. And if the hibiscus makes it through the winter, then she too can make it; and she will re-take the test that she failed before, demonstrating her own persistence. Also, before this she says that things that were once strange to her now seemed familiar, like the geese. She then sees them overhead flying in a V, a symbol of unity and purpose. They are also adapting to their surroundings by flying to a warmer place, and Saeng too can adapt, drawing inspiration from their journey to face her challenges head-on.

The author concludes the story with that sentence because she is excited for spring to come back so she can plant more things and watch them bloom, and come alive, filling the garden with color and fragrance once again.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph, because it shows Saeng will not give up. Saeng failed her driver's test, and as she was walking home, dejected, she found a hibiscus. It reminded her of her old home, a place filled with warmth and familiarity. Seeking to recapture that feeling, Saeng goes to the greenhouse or flower shop and buys one. When she returns home, she carefully plants the hibiscus in her garden. The hibiscus, a symbol of her past and a promise of future blooms, is keeping her from giving up on her dreams. When it starts budding, a sign of new life and growth, Saeng will take the test again, renewed with hope and determination.

The author chose that paragraph to put at the end because that is when everything will be perfect to redo her mistake. Saeng said crying "I-I failed the test!" @CAPS1 means she failed at what she thought she was good at. ìHere let me help mother" getting up and taking the shovel away from her mother. Saeng is trying to get better at gardening so when she does redo her mistake she will do better, showcasing her determination to improve. As the reader can see Saeng wants to pass the test, so she can believe she is a great gardener like her mother, demonstrating her desire for validation and mirroring her mother's skill.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph because it makes people want to read the next story to see how she performs on the test. In the story, she initially failed the test; now that she has changed, she wants to retake it because she believes she can do better now than before, leaving the reader curious about her future success.

Cause everything that is in this paragraph is in the story somewhere, so it really intertwines together. She learns to adapt to her new homeland, finding ways to navigate the customs and environment, as does the plant, adjusting to the soil and climate.

I would say that the author concluded this story entirely paragraph because they wanted to be very consistent. In brief words, the ending served as a deliberate and concise reinforcement of the story's core elements.

The reason why they include the story with the paragraph is because they talk about the same thing. This shared experience strengthens their bond. Then in the story they talk about going to Canada together, further illustrating their close connection and shared adventures. Ultimately, the story enriches the paragraph by providing a concrete example of their relationship.

The author decides to conclude the story with this paragraph to show the strength and confidence Saeng has. By saying she would try to pass the test again in the spring is showing she is confident and is looking for a new beginning to come then, suggesting a renewed sense of hope. Also he concludes it this way because after she failed the test she didn’t have much self-confidence, feeling discouraged by the setback. And once she spoke to her mother and knew she was understanding, offering support rather than judgment, Saeng knew she had to try again and persevere until she passed the test, demonstrating her resilience and determination to achieve her goal.

I think when she takes the test over, it is going to be in the spring, and she is going to try and pass it. But she did not want to cry in front of her mother. I think she is going to make it up to her and pass the test, showing her resilience and determination to succeed.

The author concludes this story with that paragraph to show the readers she was knocked down by the test but she is going to get back up again and take the test again. The reason the author concludes the story with that paragraph is because he is showing that she will not give up and she will do it when she is ready to. The reason I say this is because she is doing the test when she wants to, when she feels comfortable. It highlights her agency and determination to face her challenges on her own terms. Those are the reasons I believe that the author ended the story with that paragraph, emphasizing her resilient spirit.

I believe the author concludes the story like this to show an example of perseverance. Saeng states, "through the quiet repetition of season upon season, almost familiar to her now." This statement represents adjusting to change. The seasons' cyclical nature mirrors her own journey of adaptation. Soon she will adjust fully to her new home, it just takes time. If she keeps persevering, she will make it. In the last paragraph Saeng says, "when the snows melt, and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again." Just as the seasons bring things back, she will come back. This cyclical return highlights her resilience. I believe this last paragraph was put in to show everyone should persevere because things just take time, and with continued effort, goals can be achieved.

This statement shows what the author concludes about the story. It shows the theme of the story really. If you fail, then try again. This is what the statement is saying; she failed her tasks, so in the spring, once the hibiscus blooms again, she will attempt to complete her task. The statement also concludes how you should never give up. Saeng had failed the test. She said, "I-I failed the test." This shows how sad and depressed she was because the tone the statement was said in was a sadder, more depressed tone. Even though sad and depressed, Saeng knows that next year she will attempt to complete the test, showing her resilience. Overall, the sentence shows what the author concludes and thinks about the story "Winter Hibiscus."

The author concludes the story with the paragraph ìWhen they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and the hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again,î for several reasons. Saeng decides that she is determined to pass her driving test just like the hibiscus, which her mother says is ìstrong enough to make it through,î and Saeng decides to be strong like the hibiscus and make it through and pass the test. Next, the reason the geese are mentioned in the final paragraph is to tie in the fact that she is getting used to her new surroundings because the geese ìsound familiar.î As much as she misses her old home, she is adapting to her new environment. Finally, one can conclude that because she mentions the plant, which symbolizes her homeland, and the geese, which symbolizes her new home, that as much as she misses her old home, sheís starting to get used to her new country and she recognizes that she is part of it, indicating a sense of belonging and integration. She knows that letting her past get in the way of her will not help her pass the test and, like the plant and the geese, she will return again, demonstrating resilience and a commitment to overcoming challenges in her new life.

The author concluded this paragraph in this story because I think that he is trying to tell the reader a message. The author is trying to say that if a plant can make it through the cold winter, then she can pass her driver's test. That is why I think the author included that paragraph, using the plant as a symbol of resilience and perseverance in the face of challenges.

I think the author ended the story like that because she enjoys seeing the geese return each spring, a symbol of the season she loves. She also wants to take the upcoming test and, hopefully, pass it. In the meantime, she is diligently studying, hopeful for a positive outcome.

The reason why the author concludes the story with this paragraph is because the author feels that Saeng will pass the test if she has the hibiscus with her, she thinks that because the hibiscus has something unique about it and also gives her memory of where she used to live before she had moved to the @ORGANIZATION1, the orphanage. Saeng had seemed out of place; she did not know what to do, but the hibiscus flower now gives her a sense of belonging and perhaps even confidence, leading the author to believe it will be her lucky charm for the test.

The author is very creative. He concludes the story saying how the hibiscus is budding and that she will take the test again. She believes that she will do better when the snow is gone. The author ended the story with that because Saeng was very upset failing a test, but with the comfort of the hibiscus, she’ll be able to do better. He also concludes the story with that paragraph because the climax was when she failed her test, and somehow the author had to conclude what was going to happen to Saeng with the test; it offers a sense of hope and resilience, suggesting that failure is not final and that improvement is possible with time and perseverance.

He concludes the story like that because the test was the main thing that he was talking about. It had been the central focus of his narration, influencing his actions and anxieties. Therefore, ending with a reflection on the test provides a sense of closure, albeit perhaps abrupt, aligning the conclusion directly with the narrative's core concern.

In the end of "Winter Hibiscus" by Minfong Ho, the narrator describes her desire to take and this time pass the driver's test she failed earlier in the day, she "vowed silently to herself" that she would succeed at something she had failed at in the past. This is an important concluding message, because it shows that the author will overcome obstacles in her future. Most of the story is about the sadness that the narrator experiences because of longing for her homeland, Saeng misses her grandmother and the plants of Vietnam, and she even buys a hibiscus plant to remind her of her homeland. She is also not enjoying America, because she has already experienced failure at her new home. However, the end of the story provides contrast to this, for Saeng vows to succeed in the future, demonstrating her resilience and determination to adapt and thrive despite the challenges of adjusting to a new culture.

The author concludes the story with the paragraph they did because it shows how much the main character has grown. She has learned that if a delicate flower like the hibiscus can make it through rough times she can too, mirroring her own resilience. Nature’s fight for survival is like Saeng’s struggle in a new place. She discovers that you will adapt to your surroundings over time, finding strength and familiarity. Then after that time it will feel just like home. The adaption principle is shown throughout this story, demonstrated by nature or a child’s life—it’s there. Therefore the author would agree that the conclusion of the story illustrates the biological and physical growth of Saeng, highlighting her newfound sense of belonging and the comfort she derives from observing the natural world around her.

In the story, “Winter Hibiscus,” Saeng is new to America. She is missing home when she sees a hibiscus in a flower shop. After she takes the flower home and plants it in her backyard, she decides the next time she’ll take the drivers test is when the Hibiscus is budding in the spring. The author concludes the story this way because it relates Saeng to the flower. Saeng feels out of place in America because the hibiscus is a connection to her old home in Vietnam, the ending symbolizes that if the flower can make it through the cold winter, she can too. She will take her drivers test as a sign of surviving and overcoming obstacles. In this story it has a overall theme that everything will get better with time. Saeng will adapt to the differences of America, the hibiscus will bloom; and Saeng will pass her drivers test, signifying a new chapter in her life.

They ended it because the girl is not going to give up. She is going to keep trying at this test and won't stop at it either, dedicating herself fully to studying. And this way she won't disappoint her mother, who has high expectations. And she will be able to get this test off of her shoulders, relieving the immense pressure she has been under, finally free from this burden.

The author concludes the story with the paragraph inorder to help the reader visualize a new beginning for the girl. A time to re-take the test and have the fresh new flowers to look upon, offering a sense of hope. To watch the geese return, a familiar sight bringing comfort. The geese are symbolic to her and the quest she had taken to her new home, representing her journey and resilience. The combination of the melting snow and the budding flowers lets the reader know of the bright fresh unclaimed future that is to come for the girl, full of potential. The author uses the paragraph at the end inorder to explain more of what is to come, to enhance illustrations and capture the attentive audience, leaving a lasting impression. It is used to show a spirit in the girl that allows us to see that she is like the flower; she is having trouble rooting/grasping on to the new lifestyle, but there is always going to be a fresh/new time to continue on, highlighting her potential for growth and adaptation.

I think the author puts that paragraph in the story because maybe it's a good luck thing or it's a tradition, so it's very important that it's in the story. Also, it could be trying to tell us something, like she only takes tests in the spring when the hibiscus starts budding, suggesting a connection between her academic performance and the blooming of the flower, perhaps indicating a sense of hope or renewal associated with springtime. Therefore, the inclusion of the paragraph is likely significant, either due to cultural beliefs or as a symbolic element tied to the character's experiences.

In the short story ìWinter Hibiscusî by Minfong Ho, the author concludes the story with that special paragraph in order to mutually assuage Saengís yearning for home but also to show that she is learning to overcome obstacles. Saeng wishes that she were in her homeland and keeps referring to it because she wants it back. ìI mean, itís not like the one we had at-at-,î Saeng continues to stumble because she doesnít wish to mention home, as it brings her to tears. In addition, when she mentions the ìtestî, it alludes to her buying a fake test. ìItís - itís not a real oneî. She refuses to buy a real one because it reminds her of the driving test and how sad she already is, as she tries to avoid anything that reminds her of her loss. The test refers to both the plant and the driverís test, representing challenges in her new life. Saeng also ends with this vow because the flower represents hope to her: "... and this hibiscus is budding, I will take that testî. The emotional tests of both of the situations she is in will allow her to be stronger. This vow at the end of the story shows her willingness to be strong and come through in the end, demonstrating her resilience in the face of adversity.

...In the story the author concludes that after she's done her test and there's nothing left to see in the results, no immediate answers jumping out from the data, she'll grow more. This period of reflection, following the active pursuit of understanding, will ultimately be the most fertile ground for her development.

The author concludes this story with this paragraph because the girl did not pass the driving test. And she adds all of those details of nature in there because she takes time to care about nature. That is what it is mainly about in the story, revealing her perspective and connection to the world around her.

I am guessing the author adds this paragraph to tell the reader that when all of the beauty returns, she will try to get used to new things again, embracing the inevitable changes that come with the shifting seasons and a renewed appreciation for the world around her. Ultimately, she will strive to find peace and contentment amidst the ever-changing tapestry of life.

The author of Winter Hibiscus concludes the story with that paragraph because it gives a sense of starting over and a new beginning for Saeng. The author most likely ends the story with Saeng vowing to take the test again, because he wants to show Saeng’s determination. The author concludes the story with this paragraph because she has new hope and determination. The author concludes this story with this paragraph to show that Saeng is going to adapt to the conditions of her new life. When she sees the geese come back for another spring and summer, a sign of warmer weather and new beginnings, she will take the driving test because they are giving her area another chance of being their home for the season. The author concludes the story with this paragraph because the paragraph is about how the snow melts and the greenery returns, like a rebirth. The author concludes with that because she kind of relates herself to the flowers. She has grown to her environment, putting down roots as it were, just like a flower adapts and thrives. I think the author concludes the story with that paragraph because she failed the taste test, so over the winter they don’t get hibiscus. The author concludes this as the last paragraph for two main reasons. One is that the flower is almost like her in its being; the flower hasn't bloomed yet. Minfong Ho, the author of “Winter Hibiscus” concluded the story with Saeng vowing to herself that she will retake and pass her drivers test in the spring when the geese fly back and plant rebuds. The author concluded the story with this paragraph to signify Saeng’s willingness to start over. After failing a test, Saeng visits a green house and misses her old home, Vietnam. She buys a hibiscus and plants it when she comes home after noting the geese flying south for the Winter. The plant signifies her memories. When she first sees it, it’s blossomed. In the spring it will rebud and form another blossom while growing bigger. This parallels Saeng getting over her sadness and homesickness and rebuilding better memories while growing stronger. When she gets the chance, she intends to take it. The birds flying overhead are headed south for the winter for shelter from the cold. In spring they will return to start over, raise goslings, rebuild their home, and begin anew. Saeng is planning to start over, and pass it so she can drive and feel more accepted in @LOCATION2. Minfong Ho chose to end the story with a paragraph to signify the character’s starting over and rebuilding good memories, highlighting her resilience and hope for a brighter future.

The last paragraph in "Winter Hibiscus" was added because the author wants to show that she feels bad because she did not pass the test. The author concludes the story with this paragraph. He concludes with this paragraph because that's how the girl feels. The author concluded "when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again" to tell the reader never give up and to keep trying. I think the author concludes the story with this paragraph because the author is trying to show the reader that she realized she cares about the nature and loves it so because she is waiting for the spring and as soon as the spring comes she will take the test again. The author concludes the story with the sentence saying “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring when the snow melts and the geese return and the hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again” because the hibiscus is not just a good luck charm; when it’s not there, things aren’t right, but its return signals better times. The author concludes the story that way because one theme is to overcome obstacles. The last paragraph reinforces that symbolism with closure because she says she'll wait until spring to take the test again, mirroring the hibiscus's dormancy and eventual rebirth, ultimately highlighting her enduring hope.

Saeng is trying to say that when the time comes again that she will take the test. Also, she cherished the plant because she wants to see it budding, as her and her mother spent quality time due to this plant she had, solidifying her resolve to persevere.

Saeng is talking about her school work and the garden. She always connects the two of them in the same way. The author ended the story that way to show that Saeng won’t give up and is determined to complete her task, passing her upcoming test. Saeng is very much like the hibiscus plant, she’s frail and beautiful, yet resilient. Saeng says she will do her test again when the hibiscus is budding, almost like she’s growing along with the plant, symbolizing her own personal growth and adaptation to her new environment. This connection to the hibiscus underscores her hope and perseverance.

The author concluded the story with the paragraph because it shows that everything and everyone can make it through a tough time. This paragraph acts as a final positive message to readers. The text say, ìwhen they come back... I will take that test againî. This quote shows that Saeng can see herself as one of the geese or the budding hibiscus plants, drawing parallels to their resilience. She knows that her ìwinterî is her test and that when she is ready, sheíll be able to take the test again and be successful. The budding of the hibiscus represents the time when sheíll be prepared to take the test, symbolizing hope and future success. Though she is having a tough time now, she'll be able to get through it and make another attempt. This paragraph is at the end because it brings together the purpose of the hibiscus, solidifying its symbolic meaning. Without saying this, the readers would have never gotten this message; instead, they would believe that the role of the hibiscus was to serve as a connection to Saengís past. In conclusion, this positive paragraph was included to show readers that everyone can bounce back from a bad situation, offering a message of hope and perseverance.
