I also think that the author is trying to say is that when she wrote this letter it was cold outside and she wouldn’t take the test until it was warm again because of the cold. "In the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this is when the hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test over again." This suggests a strong aversion to the cold and a preference for taking the test under more favorable, warmer conditions, ultimately influencing the story's conclusion.

The author says, "when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again," because the girl left everything to come to this country and feels the immense pressure not to fail. The girl said, "That at last, she could hold on to. But where was the fine-toothed comb? the hibiscus hedge?" She said this also because the hedge was all she had from her old home besides her mother, and when the "hibiscus is budding" it signifies starting a new life and growing leaves, mirroring the girl's own journey of growth and moving on with her life in a new place. Therefore, the hibiscus serves as a tangible link to her past and a symbol of hope for her future success.

The reason the author concludes the story with this paragraph is because if the author tries it again, it might work out a lot better now they know what they are doing and have learned from their mistakes. Also, if they try it again and it makes enough, they can sell it and make money, so they will keep doing it for years to come, refining their technique and hopefully achieving greater success in the future.

The author of ìWinter Hibiscusî concludes the story with a resolution of Saeng in order to show how Saeng will not give up and how she is determined. The reference to the spring blossoms shows how Saeng will fight to survive through the hardships, which are represented by winter. Just like the hibiscus that struggles to adapt to a new home, Saeng is struggling to adapt to a new country, facing challenges with language and cultural differences. The final paragraph provides a resolution to the internal conflict of Saeng throughout the story by suggesting that Saeng will succeed in taking the test and embracing her new life. In conclusion, the final paragraph in the story ìWinter Hibiscusî provides a resolution to the conflict in the story, and shows the reader Saengís determination.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it shows what Saeng will be doing and if she will go to school. Saeng didn't want to go to school because she would rather wait for the snow to melt and the geese to return, and this hibiscus is budding, and prefers gardening to school, and the garden reminds her of her homeland. For Saeng dug out a hole and carefully lowered the winter hibiscus into it. The things that made her think about her homeland were the beating of eggs against a bowl, the sizzle of hot oil in the pan, the pungent smell of bitter melon wafting out. Another thing she did was go over to the corner of the vegetable patch and start to dig a hole in the ground; that shows she cares about the garden, solidifying her choice to connect with nature and her roots instead of attending school.

The author concludes her story with the quote, “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again,” because the author is showing that nature and the plant are valuable to her. Saeng (who says the quote) believes that the hibiscus, tied to the cyclical return of spring, will bring her luck and renewed strength to pass the test. Earlier on in the story it shows that when she gets in trouble, she rubs the plant leaves in her hands to help her overcome the problem, finding solace and courage in its presence. The author is making the idea clear and portraying the idea that the plant helps Saeng with obstacles, acting as a tangible source of comfort and resilience for her.

In the end of the story the girl Saeng vowes to herself that she will take the drivers test next year. One reason she might have vowed to herself to do that is to prove that she can pass the test, overcoming her fear and self-doubt. Also, the flower after she bought it and planted it, and after she remembered all the good times she had in Vietnam, gave her the confidence to go out and get what she wanted. This newfound determination, spurred by both a desire for personal validation and a reconnection with her roots, solidifies her resolve to take the test and move forward.

The author includes this in the paragraph to simply be sarcastic for you to know that it is almost impossible for Saeng to take the test afresh. I say this because she was being very sarcastic, meaning she’s not going to take the test. For example, if someone were to tell me to take a test and I said "whenever @LOCATION1 is president again, then I’ll take the test," that would be very sarcastic, meaning that it won't happen and I’m not taking the test, instead of just saying no. The author included that just to let you know that the chances of her taking the test is very low, effectively conveying her unwillingness through indirect and humorous means.

The author includes this paragraph in order to show an end to the story and to show that Saeng has not given up. Ho wanted to show how the plant and the geese represented the continuation of Saeng's life in the United States. The geese will come back and the Hibiscus will bud and flower, and Saeng will retake and hopefully pass her diving test. This paragraph is not just a closing but a new beginning of life for geese, a Winter Hibiscus, and Saeng, illustrating resilience and the cyclical nature of hope and perseverance.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to show Saeng's strength and encouragement. When she’s willing and able she will take the test again with more confidence. Saeng says this to herself to help her get through until she can drive. She’s saying by next spring she’ll take her test. By next spring she’ll be able to drive. By next spring she’ll be used to her new home. This paragraph tells that it takes time to do things; you don’t always get it right away, so keep trying, and her resilience is what will ultimately help her succeed.

In my opinion the author concludes the story with this paragraph because Saeng was feeling down about not passing her driving test, a disappointment weighing heavily on her. But when she saw those flowers, a vibrant splash of color in the urban landscape, she realized when she came to @CAPS1 she forget all about her home town, the fields and natural beauty she left behind. So she decided to get back in touch with a nature side, reconnecting with a part of herself she had neglected, and hold off taking her test intill the spring instead of rushing things, allowing herself time to appreciate the world around her and approach the test with renewed calm.

I believe that the author concludes the story with that particular paragraph to show that she still has hope of finding home and being happy. The hibiscus plant in her mind is a symbol of home and happy memories with her grandmother. So when the plant buds, she will feel like she is at home again and is happy; that is when she will take the driving test, representing a step towards independence and control in her new environment. Also, that paragraph shows that she is slowly getting accustomed to the new home and lifestyle, “A flock of Canada geese flew by, their faint honks dear and—yes—familiar to Saeng now. Almost reluctantly she realized that many of the things that she had thought of as strange before had become, through the quiet repetition of season upon season, almost familiar to her now, like these geese.” This growing familiarity suggests a softening of her initial resistance and a gradual acceptance. Through these examples, I believe that the narrator put that last paragraph there to show Saeng's assimilation into her new lifestyle and her acceptance of her situation, highlighting her resilience and the possibility of finding happiness even in unfamiliar surroundings.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to show that Saeng did not give up on the test, despite facing challenges. For example, she says "I will take the test again." It shows that she wants to take the test and pass it, demonstrating her determination. Saeng is going to wait until spring comes and when the snow melts to take the test, indicating her patience and willingness to prepare. In the beginning, the story introduces her taking the test, and it ends with her resolved to take the test again, highlighting her perseverance and concluding her journey with a sense of hope.

At the end of "Winter Hibiscus," the author, Minfong Ho, concludes the story through stating, ìwhen they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again." The author ends the story in such a way in order to reveal the hope that lies in Saeng's future. After failing her driver's test, Saeng returns home with disappointment and sadness. This last paragraph, however, shows that soon enough Saeng's luck will change. The reader is left with a hint that Saeng will retake her test and pass. Also, this ending paragraph reflects upon Saeng's determined personality to overcome many obstacles she is facing. This paragraph proves she will not give up even after she was forced to live in the United states instead of her home. Her success in fitting in with her new life is shown when through the quote, "Almost reluctantly she realized that many of the things that she thought of as strange before had become... almost familiar". Truly Saeng is a determined character, and the ending suggests that she will continue to adapt and persevere in her new environment, ultimately achieving her goals.

The reason the author concludes this story with the paragraph is to offer a sense of hope. The story is all about the girl missing her home country, and the concluding paragraph implies that the girl will adapt to her new country by the next year. The story and the paragraph show the girl's strength to overcome challenges, suggesting a positive outlook for her future. This is why the author ended the story with this paragraph, leaving the reader with a feeling of optimism about the girl's ability to adjust and thrive.

The author is letting us/reader know that they plan to do the same thing again next year when the snow is all gone, when the geese come back, and when it’s warm enough for the hibiscus flower to bud/bloom again! The author @MONTH1 will also be concluding the sentence to show that this is the life the little gardener chose, and she will keep up with new gardening till the next spring arrives once more.

Saeng concluded the story with that paragraph because it shows what she has just been through and feels she could go through it again. If she fails the driving test again, then she can use the plants to overcome her problems. She might actually pass the test this time. The unique plants show that she is stronger than she thinks and believes now that she feels comfortable with the plants that bring back memories of her childhood, giving her the resilience to face future challenges.

She shows that she loves her grandmother and she loves what they do like gardening and stuff like that. Her mother cares about her but she is really strict with her, always pushing her to excel in school and adhere to a rigid schedule. This creates a contrast between the nurturing environment of her grandmother's garden and the demanding atmosphere at home, highlighting the different kinds of love and expectations in her life.

The author concluded the story in such a way that the readerís eyes are opened. It shows the reader that dispite what happened in @MONTH1, how bad things seem, and how hopeless you feel, thereís always a way to make it better. Saeng failed her test, was in a new land, and had lost her grandmother, but still planned to try again. Like the waves on the shore, they will always try to wash away the sand by coming back again. Just like these waves, Saeng is willing to try again, as should we all, learning from setbacks and persevering towards our goals with renewed hope.

The author concluded the story with that paragraph because that season is over and a new season is starting, bringing with it the promise of change and different experiences. The narrative arc has reached its natural conclusion, resolving the conflicts and tensions built up throughout the story, signifying a transition to uncharted territory.

The author concludes the story with "when they comes back, saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt & the geese reture and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” This quote meaning that once the flower buds she will take the test over again because Saeng will have the courage & the will to do it, knowing she will pass it. The hibiscus, a symbol of resilience and beauty emerging from harsh conditions, represents something to her that gives her motivation and determination. Everyone has something that motivates them in life to keep them going & Saeng has her plant. The author kind of gives you direction & idea where the story going to go also when the flower buds, suggesting a future filled with renewed hope and the promise of success.

Saeng is not only just dissappointed from failing her drivers test, she is also upset and missing her home of Vietnam. Walking home she spots a little piece of Vietnam right there in the United States. She buy the beautiful winter hibiscus, or saebba, to remind her of her past. The end of this story combines the two different countries, cultures and almost worlds her life is from. When she says, "when they come back," she is referring to the geese. To her the geese symbolize her life in life in America and how she has became accustom to it. The hibiscus is also a symbol of her life. It is a symbol of her life and past in Vietnam, bringing back memories, and buying that plant was like getting a little piece of home. When the "hibiscus is budding" then she will attempt the test again. When this little piece of home gets bigger then she will try again. When she is more stable in the American culture, yet still has a firm grasp of her own, then she will be ready, finding a balance between her past and present.

I believe that the Author ended the story with this paragraph, because I think it is showing that Saeng isn’t a quitter. Despite the initial setback and her mother's expectations, Saeng's anticipation for the Hibiscus to bloom again reveals her resilience. Saeng can’t wait until the Hibiscus comes back. When the Hibiscus comes back she’ll retake the test and show her mother that she can do it, proving her determination and growth.

The reason why the author concluded the story with this paragraph is because when Saeng saw the geese, she knew that with the return of spring, she would be ready to seek out different flowers. She thinks back to her homeland and how she could witness the flowers growing directly from the earth. Although now in the city, she hopes the flowers will blossom like those she remembers from home, a place she dearly misses. Lastly, she describes the flowers as her friends, recalling specifically the Madagascar periwinkle growing wild from the cracks in brick walls or tiled roofs, a common sight there. Ultimately, the author conveys that Saeng is ready to embrace the coming season and search for plants reminiscent of her homeland, bringing a piece of it to her new urban life.

The author of ìWinter Hibiscusî concludes the story with this paragraph to depict a development in the character of Saeng. At the beginning of the story, Saeng is dejected about failing her driverís test. However, this ending paragraph portrays the change that Saeng undergoes. In the text, Saeng proves to not adapt well to the change from Vietnam to Canada. She finds solace in a native flower of Vietnam, a winter hibiscus. By ending the winter hibiscus in the concluding paragraph (ìÖand this hibiscus is buddingÖî), the author depicts Saengís change of attitude and her acceptance toward Canada. Saeng now feels that, like the hibiscus returning after winter is over, she will be able to return and pass the driverís test. Also, the concluding paragraph depicts Saengís new adaptation towards the creatures of Canada. Prior to her imagination to the garden, Saeng had no exposure to Canada geese. In the concluding statement, Saengís mentioning of the creatures displays her adaptation to Canada (ìÖwhen the snow melts and the geese returnÖî). This shows Saengís development and adaptation to her new surroundings. At first, Saeng proved to have a hard time leaving her native Vietnam behind and embracing Canadian culture. However, this concluding paragraph summarizes the noticeable change that Saeng goes through. In this way, the author includes this paragraph to note the development in character that Saeng undergoes, highlighting her growing sense of belonging and resilience in her new environment.

They conclude the story with that because the winter is over and spring is here, bringing with it a sense of renewal and hope, and it will be beautiful again, promising a fresh start and the cyclical return of life after a period of dormancy.

The author concludes the story with, "when they com back, saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding. Then I will take that test again." Then she will become more familiar. For example, the author says, "Almost reluctantly, she realized that many things that she had thought of as strange before had become , through the quiet repetition of season upon season almost familiar to her now." That tells me that she feels that over time, with continued practice, she will become more familiar with driving and then she will take the test again. Then she hopefully will pass it, demonstrating her growth and adaptation to her new environment.

The author of ìWinter Hibiscusî decided to conclude the story in that way because she wanted to tie in the theme of new beginnings. Saeng is new to America and has had a rough time fitting in. She misses everything about her old home, from her grandmother to the old plants there. Saeng fails her driving test, so she feels that all is lost. But the hibiscus plant helped her realize she has another chance. The hibiscus can survive the winter and bloom in the spring and that is what Saeng realizes she must do. The last paragraph said ìIn the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and the hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.î Spring is the time for new beginnings: the geese return from the south, the flowers start to bloom, and Saeng can retake the driving test. In the last paragraph, Saeng realizes she wants a new beginning as well to be brought I the spring. In conclusion, the last paragraph ties the theme of new beginnings into the story. It shows Saeng's new realization and how the hibiscus inspired it.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to show that Saeng really wants to pass the test. You know this when it says “And in the warm moist shelter of the greenhouse, Saeng broke down and wept.” This passage shows that she didn’t want to fail. When Saeng got home, she had the white bud in the pot, and her mother saw that she was crying. Then her mother was going to put the plant in the ground, but Saeng took the shovel and did it herself, finally realizing she could take the test again. This final act highlights Saeng's determination and reinforces her strong desire to succeed.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph for several reasons. First, when the hibiscus buds in the spring, after a long winter of dormancy, that means that the plant, like Saeng, is about to bloom and come into its own. That also means that Saeng will be ready in the spring to take the test again, having used the winter to practice and prepare. Also the last paragraph is at the end because if the struggling hibiscus plant can persevere and thrive, then the girl, drawing strength and hope from the plant's resilience, can pass her driver's test and be happy both ways, finding success and inner peace.

I think the author concludes the story with this paragraph because the author is saying it's going to be a better year or some change is going to happen, and he feels he could have done better than what they did and is going to take that test again, aiming for a more satisfactory result next time.

The author concludes with this paragraph to emphasize the new beginning that Saeng is looking for. She was so disappointed when she failed her driver’s test, and the hibiscus was the thing to make her happy. She needed a new beginning to start over in a new country, and the flower, the snow, the geese, and the test all symbolize new beginnings and challenges to overcome; the geese and snow represent a change in season, the budding hibiscus represents new life, and the passing of the test represents a milestone in Saeng’s life. Ending the story with this paragraph makes the reader expect something new and exciting to happen to Saeng, suggesting a hopeful path forward despite her initial setbacks and the difficulties of adapting to a new place.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to explain to the reader that she isn’t done gardening, that she’ll go back when it blooms once again, signaling a return to her passion. Also, she isn’t done growing, learning, or finding solace in the earth. She’d rather garden than go to school, highlighting her preference for the tangible rewards and quiet contemplation found amidst the plants, suggesting a deeper connection to nature than to formal education, and leaving the reader with a sense of anticipation for her next season in the garden.

The author concludes this story with the few words “then I will take that test again” because she wanted us to know that she is not going to give up on something she failed once. She is going to keep going until she succeeds with passing “the test,” showing resilience and determination in the face of setback. This ending emphasizes her commitment to achieving her goal, conveying a message of perseverance and hope that resonates beyond the immediate context of the story.

The author concludes the last paragraph of the story because she already knew that she should not be afraid of trying a new life or new environment. For example, in the story, the mother says, ìItís flowers arenít pretty, but itís strong enough to make it through the cold months. here, this winter hibiscus. ìIt shows that the mother want Saeng to learn that Saeng should be strong even in times of difficult. Another example is, when the narrator says, ìshe realized that many of the things that she had thought of as strange before become, through the quiet repition of season upon seasonÖî It shows that Saeng realized that the new place that sheís leaving right now is almost the same as their old home- the same cycles of life and growth. In conclusion, the last paragraph tells that Saeng should face the new reality of the world, understanding its cyclical nature. She should be strong and follow the flow of life.

The author concluded this story for an internal adjust. Saeng's memories are expressed through the one at the hibiscus. The spring is a season where everything is fresh and new. As by spring, Saeng's hope would be restored and thriving, when the budding hibiscus blooms, and they will have the ability to try at the test again with more strength and inspiration, suggesting a cycle of renewal and perseverance.

The author of ìWinter Hibiscusî concludes the story with Saeng, the main character, vowing to attempt the driving test in the spring when the hibiscus is blooming. This is a way of showing the reader that even after this story ends, Saeng will not give up. The author adds the thought of the hibiscus in bloom because the hibiscus is a symbol of strength for Saeng. The hibiscus flower is common in her home country, Vietnam, and the hibiscus she bought reminds her of everything she left behind when she came to America from Vietnam. Saeng is trying to accept her new life style and uses the hibiscus as a tool to help her through the tougher times. After Saeng buys the flower she vows to retake the failed drivers test after spring comes. Spring is a symbol of fresh start and renewal, mirroring Saeng's own desire for a new beginning. Saeng also feels that if the hibiscus can make it through the winter in America so can Saeng. The conclusion for this story uses a lot of imagery that suggest that Saeng will be strong and continue to live in America, facing future challenges with resilience and hope.

The reason the author concludes the story with this paragraph is because she failed the test and, made to appreciate nature a little better, now understands the true value of what she overlooked while striving for academic success, revealing a bittersweet irony.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because Saeng will return to the flowers again in the spring, drawn back by their beauty and the memories they hold of simpler times and the connection to nature that soothes her soul, promising a renewal of the spirit alongside the blooming season.

The author states that idea because if you can not do it once do it again. First, if you take a test and can't pass it the first time, do it again and you will be more likely to pass. For example, in the story Saeng could not pass a test, so they could have let her take it again to see if she could pass it, perhaps with adjusted support. Second, she could ask for help from a teacher or use a book and study the material more thoroughly. For example, it will help you pass a lot easier if you study hard enough and understand the concepts. That is what I think the statement means; persistence and utilizing available resources can lead to eventual success.

The author concludes this story with this paragraph because its how each year will begin and end, marked by the familiar ritual of the town's annual Founder's Day celebration. This event, steeped in tradition, serves as both a remembrance of the past and a hopeful look toward the future, effectively framing the community's shared experience within the cyclical nature of time.

I believe the author concludes the story with this paragraph because the author wants to express to the reader that Saeng has been comforted by the hibiscus and is willing to give the test another try. She is now more open-minded about the situation. In the beginning of the story, Saeng was upset and annoyed about failing her driver’s test. For example, “the tearstains on her daughter’s cheeks and her puffy eyes. I-I failed the test,” Saeng said to her mother, showing she was clearly upset and disappointed in herself. The author didn’t want to end the story with a sad, unsatisfying ending, so Saeng changes her attitude about the test by the end of the story. For example, “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again.” I believe that this attitude shift was because of the memories of her mother country that soothe her and also her mother's support. In conclusion, the author ended the story with that hopeful image to teach the reader a lesson: to allow for change to occur, understanding that time does indeed heal, and that new beginnings are always possible.

The author of the story “Winter Hibiscus” concludes the story with the motivational paragraph because he/she wants to show the reader that Saeng is determined to adapt to her new life and home and overcome common obstacles like a driver's test. Saeng had a hard time coping with her problem, so she bought a hibiscus because it reminded her of home and her grandmother's garden. I think that the line “and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again” from the last paragraph is a symbol for growing up and overcoming obstacles, suggesting that when things feel more like home, she'll be ready to face her challenges. The conclusion for the story is a nice ending, showing Saeng's resilience and hope for the future.

I think the author concludes the story with this paragraph because when the snow melts and the geese return, she's going to have higher confidence in taking and passing the test. After she failed the test later on in the story, the geese had flown away, signifying a loss of hope. So, when the geese return, their familiar honking will remind her of what had just now happened, and her renewed determination. When the snow melts and spring comes, symbolizing a fresh start, the hibiscus flower, a symbol of resilience, will bloom once again, further solidifying her belief in her ability to succeed.

In the story ìWinter Hibiscus,î the spring represents the return of new hopes, comfort, and belief. As she says in the story, ìin the spring when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.î She perceives the hibiscus's return as a sign of renewed hope, giving her the courage to face the test again. Here, the hibiscus symbolizes hope. Secondly, when she says ìthe geese return and this hibiscus is budding, ì it represents comfort, especially with her mom's support bolstering her confidence, because believing in oneself is challenging without that maternal comfort. Lastly, she says, ìCanada geese flew by, their faint honks dear and yes familiar to Saeng now. Almost reluctantly she realized that many of the things that she had thought of as strange before had become, through the quiet repetitions of season upon season, almost familiar to her now.î As the season progresses and the hibiscus begins to grow, she anticipates regaining the belief and strength necessary to retake the test; the hibiscus embodies new hopes, comfort, and belief for her, representing a cycle of renewal and adaptation.

Coming back from failing her driving test, Saeng is comforted by finding the hibiscus flower. It brings back cherished memories about Saeng's homeland, because it is very similar to flowers that grew by her old home. The author concluded the story by saying "When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again," to compare Saeng to the hibiscus. Like Saeng, the hibiscus must try to adapt to new surroundings. The author shows that Saeng recognizes this connection and is inspired by it. In Saeng's mind, if the hibiscus can survive being moved, then so can she. Just as the hibiscus waits for the right season to bloom again, Saeng will wait for the right time to try again.

The story of ìWinter Hibiscusî is a prolonged metaphor for both connections to a comforting past as well as expectance and the future. Saeng misses her homeland but she must learn to adapt to her circumstances, and pass her drivers test. The story is nicely concluded with Saeng's promise to herself that come spring, she will take the test again. The hibiscus flower itself generates this promise as it gives her some closure and alleviates some home-sickness. Saengís promise indicates that she is coming to terms with her situation. When she sees the Canada geese flying, she has somewhat of an epiphany about the seasons; this moment underscores her developing understanding of her new environment. ìAlmost reluctantly, she realized that many of the things she had thought of as strange before had become.. - Almost familiar to her now.î This feeling, coupled with her resolve to retake the test, illustrates how she is accepting her new reality. I feel that was a landmark for Saeng and the conclusion illustrates that by allowing us to see her adapt and change.

In ìWinter Hibiscusî by Minfong Ho, Saeng has a deep emotional connection to the memories and flashbacks that the hibiscus brings back to her. At one point in the story, she cries out of mourning for her grandmother because the hibiscus plants bring back a wave of memories of her grandmother's care. Later on in the story, she takes the plant to her mother. At first her mother is upset but then she becomes understanding of her daughterís actions and feelings. Saeng is upset that she didnít pass her test and her mother understands that the hibiscus represents more than just a plant to Saeng, and that is why she brought it home. I think the author ends the story this way because wants the reader to see that because the hibiscuses is so important to Saeng and reminds her of her past, she will have a reason and motivation to continue and reach her goal of passing, connecting her present struggles to the strength and resilience of her heritage.

Since it is getting close to winter, the geese are going south. The plants are losing their leaves. Saeng says that she will take the test again. It seems that when the geese return and the hibiscus buds, it will give her hope and confidence. Especially the hibiscus, because it reminds her of her homeland and her grandmother; when she first saw it and held the leaf, it brought a tear to her eye, remembering her grandmother's gentle smile. And when it comes back next year, it will rejuvenate her spirit.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because she thinks that it will explain what happened to Saeng very well. Perhaps the silence that followed her disappearance, the lack of definitive answers, stemmed from the very nature of the secrets she carried. The whispers and hushed tones surrounding her name after she vanished suggest a community grappling with something they couldn't quite understand or articulate. This ambiguity, this lingering sense of the unexplained, serves as a final, poignant reflection on Saeng's life, suggesting that some mysteries, like the echoes of forgotten songs, are destined to remain unresolved, leaving us to ponder the unseen forces that shaped her destiny and ultimately led to her enigmatic departure.

The author concludes her story with that last paragraph because it shows the relationship between Saeng and the hibiscus, and how much just seeing it feels. It also shows that the hibiscus motivates her because it reminds her of her homeland that she loves so much, and that it's like having a physical memory of her homeland, a tangible connection to the place she longs for, solidifying her determination and providing comfort.

The author is relating that when the geese are ready, they will come back, when the flower is ready it will begin bud and grow. When she is ready she will take the test, is what is being said. She is explaining that she needs time just as the geese and flowers do as well. So you can compare Saeng to both the geese and hibiscus, because they too need time in a way for when they are ready to do what they do. Just like the geese follow their natural rhythm to return and the hibiscus waits for the right moment to bloom, Saeng understands her own internal timing for taking the test. In a way Saeng has molded as one with both objects, embodying the patience and natural progression inherent in both nature's cycles and her own personal growth.

I think the Author ends this as the concluding sentence because it symbolizes how the girl perceives things. The girl means when the geese return and the hibiscus is budding it means that it is going to be warm again, which means when it is warm again it brings her spirit up because it reminds her of her homeland. I think by her being reminded of her homeland would help her take the test easier because she will be more happy. This I think will help her do better on the test. For example, the author said in the story that the flower bring her comfort and I think being comfortable is the best way to succeed and pass the test. the author concludes the story with that paragraph because it sounds like an interesting ending paragraph that has something to do with the story, hinting at the protagonist's uncertain future and leaving the reader to ponder the lasting impact of the events they have just witnessed, thus completing the narrative arc.

I think the author concludes the story with that saying because it shows that she is adapting to the new place. It shows that she isn't going to give up, even though it's difficult. Just like the geese don't give up flying back and forth every winter and spring, she too will persevere and make this new place her home.

In the short story ìWinter Hibiscusî Saeng decides to retake her failed driverís test in the spring. She does so because she is comforted by the moderate weather of the spring. It reminds her of home, and Saeng is very closely attached to home, missing its familiar warmth. It reminds me of all the places Iíve been and how I still remember my favorite one. Like Saeng, I buy objects that remind me of my old home; for instance, I have a small snow globe that mirrors the winters I experienced there. Saengís commitment to her old home makes me feel less different when I miss my old home, suggesting that this longing for a past place is a common human experience.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph because Saeng is going to start over and do better the second time because she doesn’t want to disappoint herself. She realizes her previous mistakes and is determined to learn from them. That is why the author concludes the story with this paragraph, emphasizing Saeng's resolve for self-improvement and a more fulfilling future.

I think that the author concludes the story like this because it shows a new beginning. When the spring comes, everything comes back to life, signifying renewal. Plants grow back, animals are seen again, and the sun shines bright, ending the long winter. This is a new beginning for them, so it can be seen the same for her, offering a fresh start after a difficult time. She could try again because it gives her another chance to learn and grow, leaving past failures behind. Another reason he ended the story like this is because Saeng loves nature and finds solace in it. Maybe when nature is back around her in full bloom, it will give her hope and confidence to pass her test, drawing strength from the revitalized world around her. The return of spring serves as a powerful metaphor for her own potential for renewal and success.

The last paragraph of the story was: ìWhen they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.î I think the author concluded the story with that paragraph to show that she is adapting and that she is starting to accept the change. I think that because throughout the story she is upset and not really liking the change. ìAnd in the warm moist shelter of the greenhouse, Saeng broke down and wept.î The text says. This last paragraph seems optimistic talking about the flower blooming and the geese returning which seems like she is starting to accept the change and is looking forward to the future. The imagery of spring and rebirth further reinforces this sense of hope. In my opinion, the author added that paragraph to finish the story to show that Saeng is starting to accept the change and be optimistic, suggesting a path towards embracing her new environment.
Saeng told her mother that she failed the test. She asked what to make up for it, perhaps by helping out in the garden. Her mother nodded in agreement, then went inside and started to make dinner.

The Author concludes that when the geese come back she will take the test because she believes she will be more ready for the test then and it will be easier in the spring. This extra time will give her more time to learn and study, and hopefully her head will be more focused instead of thinking about her home. It will be easier to complete the drivers test in spring with focused intention. She feels bad like she let her mother down for failing it, “I just stared at the hibiscus,” this tells that she felt too ashamed to even look at her mother after disappointing her. So next spring she wants to make her mom happy and pass, because she will be ready and more confident in her ability to succeed.
The reason the author chose this paragraph is because the paragraph means that when the snow melt and all the geese returned, the flowers **bloomed**. That one flower she had to **run** tests on.

The author concludes the story with the paragraph she did to tell people never to give up. She tells people never to give up through this method because she realizes at the end, she will be prepared for what's to come. One more reason she might have used this is that even though you're down, you have friends and family to pick you up from it and offer support. The line “...Through the quiet repetition of season upon season” basically says that she just needed to get into a routine, and she will be able to accomplish what she wants, suggesting perseverance through challenges ultimately leads to readiness and support.

The author concludes the story with this sentence because she wanted to make a comparison between flowers and the test. To finish with this shows she will try season after season just like geese come back every year. Since she tries to make a connection, it shows she hasn’t given up; she will keep trying year after year. Also, it says that this girl is determined and she won’t stop trying till she gets it right. The author concludes the story with that paragraph so the reader has something to think about. When the author concludes with something like that, he/she wants the reader to make their own ending or prediction. And sometimes it means a sequel may be in the works, leaving the possibilities open and sparking the reader's imagination.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it makes the story a happy ending, showing how she doesn’t give up and is taking the test again. Also, she doesn’t want to disappoint her mom; she wants to make her happy and give the test a second chance, demonstrating resilience and a desire to fulfill her mother’s expectations, ultimately leading to a more positive resolution.

She ends it with that statement to show that she is ready to relive spring in the new country now that she is comforted by the hibiscus. The test is adapting to the new country and she failed it she believes because she had to be comforted by her native plants, but she believes that she will pass the test next year because every repetition of the season allow her to become more adapted to the new culture. When she says "when the snow melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding then I will take that test again," all those things tell her it’s a new year and make it easier to accept what’s happening, giving her hope for a better, more integrated future.

She realized that things come and go but also change. That content times of the year the world around her changed. She had no control over it. She also had to deal with living in a new country. Living in a new country was hard for Saeng. She had to eat new foods, hear new sounds, and see things that she never had seen before. Failing her driver's test was hard for her; it made her feel even more isolated. Not knowing the language and what was going on around her was tough on her. The world around her wasn't something she was used to; it was a constant adjustment. She knew she had to change herself and work harder to get what she wanted, adapting to her new environment and pushing past the obstacles in her path.

The author ended the story with that paragraph to let the readers know that she did not give up. In the story, it seemed like she had thoughts of giving up, especially considering the challenges she faced adjusting to a new culture. But her thoughts of her homeland, the memories and values associated with it, comforted her when she thought she was going to give up. But the last paragraph of the story, through her explicit declaration, she confirmed that she wasn’t giving up on her dreams and aspirations, despite the hardships encountered.

The author concludes the story with this because it shows that she is still uncomfortable. For example when she broke down in the flower shop, overwhelmed by a scent that triggered memories of her old life. This shows that even though familiar things can remind her of home, it isn’t the same; the context is different. You have to get used to and become accustomed to a new place, embracing its unfamiliarity. This also shows that she thinks with more time to get used to her new home, and to integrate these reminders into her new reality, that she will be able to pass the test and truly feel at peace.

The author uses this conclusion for a reason. The reason the author uses this cliff-hanger of a conclusion is to keep the reader interested and wanting more. By saying, "I will take that test again," the author makes the reader question if Saeng will pass the test next time and the reader will wonder what "the test" is, leaving them eager to discover the outcome of Saeng's future attempts and the true nature of the challenge. This open-endedness serves as a hook, encouraging continued engagement with the narrative.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because she probably doesn’t want the snow to melt so that the geese wouldn't return. Also, it informs the reader about what Saeng was thinking as she observed the changing seasons and anticipated the familiar sight of the geese gracing the sky once more, her thoughts reflecting a deep connection to the cyclical nature of life and the comforting predictability of the geese's return, ensuring a sense of continuity and hope.

There was a specific reason as to why the author concluded the story with that quote. The author wanted to show how the plant gave Saeng a new sense of determination. Saeng previously was upset and tearing the plant apart in frustration over her failed test. But It seemed that she realized, observing the plant’s resilience, how it was able to bud against the odds and survive despite her neglect. So she now was determined to battle the odds as well, face her academic challenges head-on, and retake the test she failed with renewed effort.
